HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Rally in Treasury Market Ends As Price of 30-Year Bond Slips

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
A three-day rally in the Treasury market ran out of steam yesterday as traders took profits.
The price of the 30-year bond fell 2/32, to 103 17/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, closed at 5.87 percent, unchanged from Thursday. A week ago, the yield was at 5.88 percent. 
 With yields already at low levels, market participants are showing reluctance to buy Treasury securities without strong evidence that the economy is indeed slowing and inflation is not a threat. The lowest point the yield of the long bond has reached this year was 5.66 percent in January, when expectations were running high that the Asian slowdown would reduce the demand for exports from the United States, thus placing a drag on growth here and snuffing out inflation pressures.
Indeed, bond prices received some support from a report that showed the United States trade deficit widened to $12.1 billion in February.
Bonds got a further lift after the Federal Reserve reported that industrial production in March rose two-tenths of 1 percent. Analysts had expected production to be unchanged in March. But the Fed revised its data for January and February to show output had declined two-tenths of 1 percent in each month.
"Further confirmation of a declining path of economic growth was seen in the industrial production report that indicated some head winds could soon emanate from the manufacturing sector," said Anthony Chan, managing director and chief economist at Banc One Investment Advisors.
The moderating effects of yesterday's trade deficit report will likely have to hold investors for quite a while, since next week's economic calendar is sparse. Sherry Cooper, chief economist for Nesbitt Burns Securities, said: "The steady deterioration in the trade deficit will take some of the heat off the Federal Reserve, and at its current pace, the widening trade deficit could reduce 1998 G.D.P. growth by as much as 1.5 percentage points.
"This would provide an offset to continued strong domestic demand growth and tight labor markets."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Bank Merger Fever Spreads To Canada

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

DATELINE: TORONTO, April 17

 BODY:
Two more of Canada's largest banks announced plans today to merge, compressing the country's already highly concentrated financial services industry to just four large national banks and raising concerns about competition.
The proposed $15.9 billion (United States) merger between the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce and the Toronto-Dominion Bank would create an institution with more than $320 billion (United States) in assets and 2,300 branches across Canada. The deal would also reach into the United States, where Toronto-Dominion owns Waterhouse Securities, a discount brokerage firm, and Waterhouse Bank, while Canadian Imperial owns CIBC Oppenheimer, a full-service securities firm. 
 The deal comes after two weeks of huge bank deals in the United States and less than three months after the Royal Bank of Canada and the Bank of Montreal announced plans to join and create Canada's largest bank, with assets of about $333 billion (United States).
Indeed, the leaders of CIBC and Toronto-Dominion said this morning that their decision to merge was strongly influenced by the rapid consolidation of banks in the United States and Canada.
"We made this decision in the midst of some of the most profound and turbulent changes in the history of our industry," said A. L. Flood, the chairman and chief executive of CIBC.
The new bank -- which will be named CIBC -- will have a market capitalization of $30.2 billion (United States), making it Canada's second-largest bank and one of the 10 largest in North America.
Government regulators, however, have said they will not allow the banks' aggressive actions to bully them into approving the mergers. Consumers and small-business owners worry competition will be stifled if there are only four big banks.
Shares of CIBC and Toronto-Dominion fell today on the Toronto Stock Exchange. Shares of Toronto-Dominion fell $4 (Canadian), to $69 (Canadian), and CIBC fell $3.10 (Canadian), to $55 (Canadian).
Both banks are considered well run and innovative, and they have recently expanded into new fields. CIBC was the first Canadian bank to sell its own auto, property and life insurance policies through a subsidiary. Toronto-Dominion is an important player in the discount brokerage business.
Mr. Flood said he first discussed a possible merger with A. Charles Baille, the chairman of Toronto-Dominion Bank, during a telephone call on Jan. 23, hours after the proposed merger between the Bank of Montreal and Royal Bank of Canada was announced.
The two remaining large Canadian banks, the Bank of Nova Scotia and the National Bank of Canada, have not announced any plans to merge, but analysts are not ruling out further consolidation.
These rapid changes in Canadian banking come after decades of stability.
Last year, Mr. Baille openly opposed bank mergers, saying that "size is not a strategy, but a statistic." But the recent wave of mergers, including the mammoth deal between Citicorp and Travelers Group, have changed his mind.
"In a world of increasing consolidation," Mr. Baille said today, "size can arguably be an important defense."
But in Canada, laws would have to be changed before the bank mergers could proceed. And the message from Canadian regulators today was that nothing should be taken for granted.
"The No. 1 concern of the Government remains what is good for Canadians and the Canadian economy," Canada's Finance Minister, Paul Martin, said in a statement today.
Canadian regulators have long opposed big banks and have imposed regulations prohibiting any individual person or entity from owning more than 10 percent of a bank. A Task Force on the Future of the Canadian Financial Services Sector is now considering changes to those laws.
But the Government will not allow any merger to proceed until the task force issues its report, sometime in September, Mr. Martin said.
"International scope and size cannot be the only criteria for our decisions on the evolution of Canada's financial sector," he said. "Strong domestic competition is also a fundamental principle we support."
Under the terms of the announced merger, CIBC shareholders will receive a one-for-one exchange for the new merged bank stock. Because speculation has forced up the value of Toronto-Dominion stock more than 50 percent since January, its shareholders will receive 1.3 shares in the new bank for each Toronto-Dominion share held.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
G.M. Earnings Hint at Trouble Later This Year

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

DATELINE: DETROIT, April 17

 BODY:
The General Motors Corporation worried Wall Street today by reporting first-quarter earnings that suggested underlying weaknesses in the company's prospects later this year.
While General Motors' bottom line benefited from cost-cutting worth $1.2 billion in the first quarter, and from selling a greater percentage of high-profit sport utility vehicles, mini-vans and pickup trucks, earnings suffered from a sharp increase in rebates and other incentives offered to improve the company's sluggish sales. Those marketing costs rose 51.7 percent, to an average of $1,305 a vehicle sold in the first quarter, up from $860 in the first quarter of last year. 
 "Essentially, they are treading water," said Maryann N. Keller, an auto analyst with Furman Selz L.L.C., a New York investment banking and brokerage firm. "What they save in one place, they spend in another."
Other analysts said they had lost confidence that General Motors' future earnings would live up to Wall Street's expectations -- the consensus among analysts is that G.M. will earn $8.11 a share for the year, up from the $7.90 it earned last year.
"There is a question of whether G.M. will make its earnings estimates this year," said Jack V. Kirnan, an auto analyst with Salomon Smith Barney, who estimates the company will earn just $7.75 a share for the year.
J. Michael Losh, G.M.'s chief financial officer, did little to assuage Wall Street's concerns. He refused today to tell analysts whether he was comfortable with their earnings estimates for the year. "We're confident as we look forward to 1998 that we're going to have another good year," was all Mr. Losh would say.
For the first quarter, General Motors earned $1.6 billion, or $2.27 a fully diluted share, down 10.7 percent from $1.796 billion, or $2.28 a share, in the quarter a year earlier. When the results are adjusted to reflect the company's spinoff in December of its giant Hughes military business and the resulting addition of Delco Electronics to the Delphi business unit, the company earned $1.7 billion, or $2.21 a share, in the 1997 quarter.
Revenue, when adjusted for the spinoff, rose 2.6 percent, to $41.6 billion.
The consensus among analysts was that G.M. would earn $2.25 a share, according to the First Call Corporation, the Boston-based investment research network.
While the earnings exceeded expectations, shares of General Motors fell $1.1875, to $68.9375. Some analysts said the company's earnings generated worries that the auto industry would begin a bitter price war, dragging down stock prices for the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation today as a result. Ford stock fell 87.5 cents, to $48.8125, while Chrysler stock fell 50 cents, to $43.6875.
"People are concerned that there is going to be a bloodbath in marketing costs," Mr. Kirnan of Salmon Smith Barney said. Many are worried that "the marketing costs are going to continue to eat up the vast amount of the cost cuts," he said. Even if G.M. earns as much as analysts expect, he said, the company will be likely to do so because it has bought back more of its stock, not because it has improved its core business dramatically.
In the first quarter, G.M. spent $1.6 billion buying about 24 million shares of its common stock, and it has announced plans to buy an additional $3.68 billion. Since January of last year, the company has bought back a total of $5.3 billion, amounting to about 12 percent of G.M.'s stock.
"That's why people are buying the stock now -- not because they have great expectations for growth in the automotive business, but because they expect the company to return excess cash through buybacks," said John A. Casesa, an auto analyst with Schroder & Company. "Operationally, they're running in place."
The company's largest unit posted an earnings increase of 8.1 percent. G.M.'s North American operations earned $826 million, up from $764 million in the first quarter of last year -- its best-ever quarter. Its net profit margin edged up to 3.2 percent in the first quarter from 3.1 percent the year before, still short of the company's 5 percent goal.
"Our continued aggressive cost-cutting initiatives and increased sales of higher-profit trucks drove improvements" in the North American business, said John F. Smith Jr., G.M.'s chairman and chief executive. The company is on track to meet its goal of cutting $4 billion in costs this year companywide, he said.
Profits from G.M.'s international operations were hurt by the economic slump in Asia and the difficult economic environment in South America. Profits fell 38.9 percent, to $160 million in the first quarter from $262 million in the period a year earlier. Profit margins fell to 2.0 percent from 3.2 percent a year earlier.
The company's newly formed Hughes Electronics Corporation saw its income more than double from the first quarter of last year. Hughes contributed $54 million to G.M.'s profits, up from $24 million the year before.
 
Cut for Chrysler's Chief
DETROIT, April 17 (Bloomberg News) -- The Chrysler Corporation awarded its chairman, Robert J. Eaton, a 1997 compensation package valued at $11.17 million, down about 14.2 percent from what he made a year earlier.
Mr. Eaton's cash bonus slid to $3 million in 1997 from $4.5 million the previous year, according to a proxy statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. His salary rose to $1.61 million from $1.44 million in 1996. Altogether, Mr. Eaton's 1996 pay package had totaled just over $13 million.
The pay cut for 1997 came amid lower earnings at Chrysler, the only major vehicle manufacturer based in the United States to report a drop in net income for 1997.

SECTION: Section B; Page 7; Column 1; Arts & Ideas/Cultural Desk 

LENGTH: 1827 words

HEADLINE: Leftist Scholars Look Right At Last, And Find A History

BYLINE: By PATRICIA COHEN 

 BODY:
Since postwar leftist radicalism peaked in 1968, conservatives have affixed Ronald Reagan's name to a revolution, the South has deserted the Democrats for the Republicans, the Christian right has pushed its way onto the national stage, and liberal confidence in government action has become about as commonplace as the rotary phone.
Yet historians have all but ignored modern American conservatism. Its founding thinkers like Richard Weaver and Russell Kirk have rarely been read on college campuses; its adherents, from prowar students in the 60's to anti-union women, have been overlooked or dismissed as kooks; its religious underpinnings have been belittled. 
 "Twentieth century American conservatism has been something of an orphan in historical scholarship," Alan Brinkley, a liberal historian, has declared.
The orphan has finally been adopted. The parentage, however, may come as a surprise: many of the researchers are not conservatives but liberals. And they are using the techniques of social history, an approach that has most frequently been applied to the left and viewed with suspicion by the right.
By marrying social and political history, this new wave of scholarship is revising the history of Americans on the right -- their resolute devotion to particular issues and their success in compelling the political machinery to respond. And it is spelling out how a set of ideas that was soundly repudiated 35 years ago is today front and center in American life.
The most glaring absence from the conservative story has been "pots and pans" history, which looks at the everyday lives of ordinary people, from young organizers to activist housewives, from religious-minded business entrepreneurs to isolationists. Compared with books on union organizers, slaves or Populist farmers, works on conservatives have lacked empathy and rich detail, says Michael Kazin, a self-described leftist historian at American University.
Now "what we're discovering is that there's not just an intellectual conservative history, but a popular conservative tradition," Mr. Kazin says. "That's what new about the scholarship."
Liberal historians are discovering that characterizations of conservatives as either narrowly self-interested or extremists were crudely drawn. Many add that they have developed a deeper understanding of conservative concerns or sensitivity to them, even though they still reject them. One result is a more rounded picture of a variety of people who often don't share more than their hostility to liberalism: cold war anti-Communists, economic libertarians, neoconservatives and traditionalists (the Catholic intellectuals and grass-roots fundamentalists who believe God and moral values should be pre-eminent in society).
The common enemy that brought these divergent groups together was Communism, says Lisa McGirr, a liberal and an assistant professor at Harvard who is writing the first social history of the right in Orange County, California, in the 1960's. After initially organizing in Orange County school districts against the "red menace," mothers, dentists, businessmen and arms industry engineers exchanged newsletters and books like "The Naked Communist" that warned of the Communist danger. They met to watch anti-Communist films in lodge halls and churches, which were becoming important community centers for these new residents. Some thousands joined the state's John Birch Society, seen as one of the few vehicles for opposing the "liberal Leviathan," Ms. McGirr says. "There is a real anti-statism on the right," she adds. "I don't think it's correct to argue that 'local control' is simply a code word for bigots." The conspiracy-minded racist rantings of its leaders eventually led to the John Birch Society's decline in the second half of the decade, but onetime members refocused their attention on issues like sex education, abortion and pornography. "Let the dishwashing wait," said one housewife, to safeguard "freedom for our children." These former John Birchers and a broad range of other conservatives found a champion for their concerns about morality, race and law and order in the 1966 nominee for California Governor, Ronald Reagan.
John A. Andrew, a liberal historian who published "The Other Side of the 60's" (Rutgers) last year, a book about the Young Americans for Freedom, declares "the right was just as radical" as the left in the 60's.
There was a difference between the two, however: The Young Americans, founded in 1960 after conservatives became disillusioned with Richard M. Nixon and the liberal bent of the Republican Party, learned how to recruit their own candidates and run campaigns; the left-wing Students for a Democratic Society never did. Mr. Andrew adds that the Kennedy Administration was so worried about the right's popular appeal that it started the Ideological Organizations Project in 1961, which included White House monitoring of right-wing organizations and illegal tax audits.
Contrary to the accepted story line, Mr. Andrew says, Barry Goldwater's smashing 1964 defeat was not dispiriting to these young conservatives. In fact, it inspired the political organizing that eventually put Mr. Reagan in the Oval Office.
Mary Brennan, a liberal historian who wrote about the Goldwater coalition in "Turning Right in the 60's" (1995), is now examining the role of conservative women in the anti-Communist movement in the 1950's. "It's very easy to overlook women on the right because they they will often say, 'I'm just an housewife,' " says Ms. Brennan, who's writing a biography of Joseph McCarthy's wife. "By all accounts, Jean McCarthy wrote many of her husband's speeches, but she denied any responsibility."
 
Giving Weight To Women's Teas
 Women shied from the spotlight but organized postcard-writing campaigns, stuffed envelopes, held teas to raise money and educate each other about the dangers of Communism. Large caches of historical material on the popular conservative movement remain unexamined, Ms. Brennan says. As an example, she cites the University of Iowa's large collection of rightist publications, which function as an index to eight decades of community causes, from taxes to fluoridated water, from lax morals to integration.
For the last few years, historians have been grappling with the question of why conservatives, particularly the rank and file, have been ignored. In 1994, for example, the American Historical Review published a forum on the topic, with an article titled "Why Is There So Much Conservatism in the United States and Why Do So Few Historians Know Anything about It?" There isn't even a biography of Russell Kirk, whose 1953 book, "The Conservative Mind," gave American conservatives an identity and a genealogy and catalyzed the postwar movement.
That more conservative scholars themselves haven't mined this history is especially puzzling. Certainly one reason is that many had a more ambitious goal over the last couple of decades: to build a powerful political movement. The hundreds of conservative think tanks, organizations and publications that have sprung up in the last 20 years have grown into an "alternative academy," says George Nash, a conservative historian and author of "The Conservative Intellectual Movement in America." It has focused on current issues like taxes and foreign policy. Conservatives "ignored history," says Lee Edwards, a senior fellow at the conservative Heritage Foundation who is writing a political history of the movement.
There may be another reason that social history in particular has been sidestepped. "There is a conservative bias" against it, says the conservative historian Gertrude Himmelfarb, explaining that its practitioners often seem motivated by ideology. They distort history by elevating the marginalized over the powerful, she says, and disparage diplomatic, constitutional and intellectual studies as elitist.
Conservatism, with its reverence for authority and established hierarchies, may also not be hospitable ground for bottom-up history. Perhaps it's not surprising then that conservative historians have tended to emphasize institutions and elites, not grass-root activists; established leaders, not radicals.
Minority and feminist scholars -- the 60's multiculturalists -- were, in fact, the ones who seized on social history's bottom-up approach to recover their own neglected pasts. And just as women and blacks were once on the edges of a postwar Establishment dominated by white Democratic and liberal Republican men, so was the Right.
 
Why So Late? A Confession
 It was also on the fringe of the academic Establishment. Leo P. Ribuffo, a historian at George Washington University and an "unreconstructed McGovernite," compares the profession's neglect of the right to its initial cool reaction to early books about African-Americans, women and industrial workers.
The rise of the right in recent years -- and the appetite for fresh dissertation topics -- finally pushed liberal historians and graduate students to turn their attention to conservatives.
But why so belatedly?
In what may be the 90's version of liberal guilt, liberal historians are confessing to what conservatives have always accused them of: bias. "Most historians are looking for people in the past who can be positive examples for the present," says Benjamin Alpers, a liberal historian and co-organizer of a 1996 conference on conservatism at Princeton University. "They're driven to study people they are attracted to, and most historians are not on the right."
Many historians, accepting a hand-me-down liberalism, also didn't think they needed to study the right. "In the United States, liberalism is not only the dominant but even the sole intellectual tradition," Lionel Trilling famously declared in 1950. In the postwar blush, Trilling and other members of what is known as the consensus school believed the story of America was the story of the triumph of progressive reform, secular liberal values and science.
"Many historians are sympathetic to that development," George Nash says, "so that movements which opposed those trends are seen as reactionary or losers in history."
Conservatives had no ideas, Trilling argued, only "irritable mental gestures." Other consensus scholars like Richard Hofstadter, Daniel Bell and Seymour Martin Lipset argued the right was an economically and culturally backward fringe; people who were deviant, paranoid and resentful about their status in society.
Yet rather than wandering on the periphery, much of the right has stood solidly in the middle class, a garage door opener in one hand and a computer mouse in the other. "Finally, finally," says Gertrude Himmelfarb, "there is a rediscovery of a kind of populist conservatism." These are the people whom liberal historians are now studying.
In the end, the legacy of liberal bias may turn out to be the rescue of conservatives' history.

HEADLINE: Industrial Output Rises Unexpectedly

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 17

 BODY:
Industrial production rose unexpectedly in March, increasing two-tenths of 1 percent, the Federal Reserve said today.
Production increased as utility output surged with the return of colder weather after a mild January and February. "A cool March pushed industrial production up, but the Asian influence on the U.S. economy will pick up as we move into the second quarter," said Arthur Quach, an economist with Daiwa Securities America in New York. "We are looking for slower growth in the second quarter." 
 A sharp economic slowdown has curtailed Asian demand for American products.
The Fed also revised its data for January and February to show that output at factories, utilities and mines declined two-tenths of 1 percent in each month. The Fed had previously said that February output was unchanged and that January production was up one-tenth of 1 percent. Before today's report, analysts had expected March's production to be unchanged.
Industrial output during the first quarter rose nine-tenths of 1 percent, the slowest pace in seven years.
Production at utilities rose 4.8 percent last month. Manufacturing output fell two-tenths of 1 percent as production of autos and trucks, fabricated metals, lumber and primary metals declined. Mining production rose two-tenths of 1 percent.
Capacity utilization, the rate at which producers are operating, fell to a 17-month low of 82.2 percent last month from a revised 82.3 percent during February.

HEADLINE: About New York;
Bronx Actors Play the Roles Of Their Lives

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ 

 BODY:
THE words to "God Bless the Child" echoed in the cavernous space, although the tune hardly calmed a baby squealing in the audience. Undeterred, a dozen people filed onto the stage and stood in a semicircle against a burlap backdrop. The house lights dimmed and their voices rose.
"Smoke, ashes, broken glass, confusion, grief," they called out, invoking the memory of modern plagues that battered their Bronx neighborhoods in the 1970's. 
 "In the morning I'd wake up to go to my job," Astin Jacobo declared. "And when I come home, everything was on fire."
Life inspired art by the very setting: a Bronx community center built on what had been a vacant lot at East 178th Street and Mapes Avenue. The tale unfolding on stage was real, cobbled together over the last 24 years the same way the actors had pieced together their neighborhoods with new homes, rebuilt apartments and gardens.
They all belonged to the Northwest Bronx Community and Clergy Coalition, a group of tenant associations and churches from a dozen communities that united in 1974 to stop the arson and abandonment that had already ravaged the borough's southern half. They survived and thrived, becoming players in a story of community renewal that is still being written.
"The history books say that there was a Civil War, Lincoln freed the slaves and that's it," said Lois Haar, who joined the coalition when she was a student at Fordham University. "There's more to that story. Just like our story. What could happen in 50 years is the books might say the Bronx was burning and then the banks reinvested. That happened. But who made it happen?"
The coalition's members originally wanted to make a video documentary about their history when they called upon Lyn Pyle, an artistic co-director of Mass Transit Street Theater and Video. As they traded ideas over breakfast at a Norwood diner, it dawned on them that an evening of storytelling would have more impact by using the very people who lived the stories. So what if they weren't trained actors.
"These were people who were used to improvising, and that's what gave me faith," Ms. Pyle said. "People who do this kind of community organizing respond to the moment to accomplish whatever they need to do with the politicians. If someone doesn't show up for a meeting, others are ready to show up in your corner."
FOR five weekends, coalition members traded stories to help Ms. Pyle come up with a broad outline of themes that would capture the group's struggles and spirit. They recalled days when "smoke was the perfume of the Bronx" and how one woman lived in an "ice castle" whose hallways were sheathed in layers of frozen water that had cascaded down the stairs. They recounted how they forced landlords, banks and bureaucrats to deal with crumbling buildings and dirty streets. They also spoke about a person or event that prodded them into action.
"I don't know if being an Irish Catholic is an event, but I believed what they told me in church," Ms. Haar said. "When I was a kid they told me we were all equal in God's eyes and would have justice. That wasn't true in practice. The coalition offered a way to practice that."
It also gave a way to meet people from different neighborhoods and cultures who shared a common frustration with the "experts" who tried to hoodwink them into complacency and powerlessness. Their stories made clear that things could change when they united for the neighborhood's future. In turn, they found drama in the daily, and history on their street corners. It all offers inspiration to those who moved into new homes and encouragement to those who never left.
"So many things conspired against staying put," Ms. Haar admitted. "Mortgages for Levittown, the G.I. Bill, highways. Moving was the American solution. It was how you showed progress that you were doing better because you could leave where you came from. Maybe I should have lived in the Middle Ages, since I'm happy to stay with the same four walls."
Thursday night, she and her friends faced the theater's fourth wall, the audience. Among them were people who had once looked at piles of junk and declared that their home would one day be built right there. When someone flubbed a line, others stepped in. They improvised. These people know how to make something from nothing. "We take from here," Mr. Jacobo said at the show's end. "We take from there. And here we are."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Rape and Murder Stalk Women in Northern Mexico

BYLINE: By SAM DILLON 

DATELINE: CIUDAD JUAREZ, Mexico

 BODY:
Juarez is a city of factories set in the Chihuahua desert, with most of the assembly lines worked by women. And one or perhaps several sexual predators are prowling its vast industrial parks and honky-tonk saloons where workers go to kick back.
At least 70 women, many of them manufacturing workers, have been raped and murdered and their bodies dumped in the Chihuahua desert over the last five years. 
 Twice, authorities have charged suspects with multiple homicide and declared the problem solved. But Juarez women keep dying; a dozen bodies have turned up amid the cactus already this year, and five more have been reported missing. On April 16, the body of an unidentified teen-age girl, raped and strangled, was discovered under a railroad trestle, the Juarez police said.
The murders have shone a spotlight not only on the victimization of women in a city that runs on their $3-a-day labor, but also on the growing influence of a fledgling women's movement galvanized into action by the sexual attacks.
Many young women drawn here by Juarez's 400 tax-free maquiladora assembly plants break with the conservative customs of their rural villages, often pooling resources to live with other women and pursuing an independent social life. Feminist groups and congresswomen say they believe the violence is fed by a male backlash, and they criticize the stumbling official investigation of the killings as an example of mismanagement, mediocrity and machismo.
"Juarez is the ideal place to kill a woman, because you're certain to get away with it," said Astrid Gonzalez Davila, a founder of the Citizens Committee Against Violence, a group that works with the relatives of murder victims.
"The failure to solve these killings is turning the city into a mecca for homicidal maniacs."
Juarez has always been violent, but previously there was no reason to suspect that the murders of women were part of a chain of related events. The government says that 95 women have been murdered in this city of 1 million residents in five years; feminist groups have counted 118.
The killings have become a national scandal and have put pressure on the Governor of Chihuahua, Francisco Barrio Terrazas, for a stepped-up investigation. In an interview, Mr. Barrio said the murder rate for women is no higher than for most other Mexican cities (although Juarez women are twice as likely to be murdered as New York City women) and defended his government's inquiry.
"It's been very well handled," he said.
But several Mexican federal congresswomen who traveled to Juarez in February on a fact-finding mission disagreed. "This investigation has left a bad taste in our mouth," said Representative Laura Itzel Castillo. "There's been no professionalism."
The murders first attracted attention in 1993, when a criminology professor at the Chihuahua State police academy, Oscar Maynez Grijalva, noticed that virtually all the victims were poor, young, slender women with cinnamon skin and long dark hair. He tried to persuade Chihuahua officials that a serial killer was loose but he was ignored. He later resigned in protest.
"The authorities were just indifferent," said Irma Perez Franco, the mother of a 20-year-old shoe store clerk who was murdered in 1985. The police treated her with disdain from the moment she reported her daughter's disappearance, she said. "This didn't matter to them at all."
Mrs. Perez finally persuaded detectives to question her daughter's co-workers to determine who had seen her last. "But all they wanted to do was look at the cowboy boots and flirt with the clerks," she said. "They had no investigative plan."
During the same weeks in which Mrs. Perez's daughter was killed, eight other bodies were discovered in one stretch of desert, and the public began to clamor for police action.
In October 1995, authorities arrested Sharif Sharif, an Egyptian chemist, after a Juarez prostitute accused him of raping her at his home. The authorities discovered that in the 1980's, before moving to Juarez in 1994, Mr. Sharif had been convicted twice of sexual assault in Florida. He had served six years of a 12-year sentence for the second crime, the beating and rape of his live-in housekeeper in Gainesville.
The authorities announced that they had found the Juarez predator. They charged Mr. Sharif with the murder of six women, but a judge dismissed those charges in 1986. The day of Mr. Sharif's release, prosecutors filed new charges, accusing him of the murder of another woman.
In an interview at his prison quarters here, Mr. Sharif acknowledged that he frequented bars where some murder victims have been kidnapped, but said, "Raping and killing people is not my business."
Irene Blanco, a Juarez woman whom Mr. Sharif has appointed as his advocate said: "The authorities needed a scapegoat and chose Sharif."
The police in Florida, however, have urged Mexican authorities not to release Mr. Sharif. "He's demonstrated himself to be a vicious predator of women," said Capt. Sadie Darnell of the Gainesville police.
Mr. Sharif's guilt is debated hotly in Juarez. But what is indisputable is that since his arrest the killings have continued.
In April 1996, the authorities raided several bars and detained nearly 200 Juarez youths, including Sergio Armendariz, a 28-year-old nightclub security guard, along with several members of a gang he was said to lead. Mr. Armendariz and half a dozen others were later charged with murdering 17 women.
But the integrity of the investigation came under attack when Chihuahua human rights officials accused the police of torturing several Juarez teen-agers to coerce their testimony against the gang members. In a prison interview, Mr. Armendariz said that after his arrest the police battered him for days, demanding that he sign a confession. "They beat me until they got tired of beating me," he said.
Jorge Lopez Molinar, the state's attorney in charge of the investigations, charged that the police had matched bite marks on several victims' bodies to Mr. Armendariz's teeth.
But since Mr. Armendariz's detention, the bodies of at least nine raped women have been found in the desert. Mr. Lopez acknowledged that about half a dozen recent murders fit a pattern of serial murder.
Robert K. Ressler, a former Federal Bureau of Investigation agent who specialized in serial murder, said investigators should remain alert to the possibility that a psycopath is traveling to Juarez from the United States. "You could have a guy in the U.S. who goes down there periodically to do these things," he said.
In recent months, women's groups have staged protests accusing Chihuahua authorities of ignoring signs that a sexual predator remains on the loose. A leader has been Esther Chavez Cano, an accountant who pieced together a detailed list of victims that has helped their families monitor the investigation.
Mrs. Chavez said that machismo, rooted in a popular culture across northern Mexico that glorifies ruthless desert horsemen who force women into submission, may be stronger here than elsewhere in the country. Yet in recent decades, thousands of women have taken factory jobs in Juarez and the numbers of single mothers have surged.
"Women have not become liberated, they just have a double workload," but some men resent what they perceive as women's newly independent lifestyles, she said. "A patriarchal backlash has accompanied these murders," Ms. Chavez said. Authorities often suggest that murdered women have invited attack by wearing mini-skirts or going out dancing, she said.
"They minimize the crimes and blame the victims," Mrs. Chavez said.

HEADLINE: Awash in U.S. Aid. Could Float Fine Without It.

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 17

 BODY:
Israel's newfound economic success through its embrace of high-profit, high-technology industries has led many Israelis and Americans to question why the nation still needs so much American foreign aid.
Israel is the largest beneficiary of American foreign aid -- by far. It received $3 billion in American economic and military assistance last year, a figure that has held steady for several years even as the overall foreign aid budget has been slashed at the demand of Congress. 
 Egypt is in second place in the ranking of beneficiaries, receiving about $2 billion last year. The two countries were rewarded with huge packages as a result of the 1979 Camp David accords, and together they account for about 40 percent of the American foreign aid budget.
But today the Israeli Government is being forced to admit the obvious: while American aid money is welcome, it is no longer a necessity.
There was widespread applause -- and relief -- among American lawmakers in 1996 when Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu vowed "economic independence" before a joint session of Congress, offering "to begin the long-term process of gradually reducing the level of your generous economic assistance to Israel."
What that means is still in debate.
The Israeli Government has proposed a phaseout of the $1.2 billion in economic aid now promised to Israel in exchange for a one-third increase in military assistance over the next 10 to 12 years. Military aid would grow to $2.4 billion a year from $1.8 billion under the plan. This would mean an overall reduction in the aid package of $600 million a year, or 20 percent.
Representative Sonny Callahan, Republican of Alabama and chairman of the House Appropriations subcommittee that oversees aid to Israel, said last month that the Israeli proposal to reduce aid was "a tremendous recognition of accomplishment -- accomplishment on the part of both countries."
But others in Congress think the Israelis should be willing to accept far larger cuts, although few are willing to say so publicly for fear of offending the American Jewish community or Israel's powerful lobby on Capitol Hill.
As one Congressional aide put it: "Many people here consider it a taboo subject, but the fact is that the Israelis have got to understand that other, far more needy countries are being cut off completely from American aid. Yes, they are talking about ending the economic aid, but they're also talking about a big increase in military aid."
The initial Israeli proposal also drew criticism because of Israel's request that it be permitted to spend more of its military aid in Israel. Under the current package, Israel is limited to spending no more than 25 percent of the American military aid in Israel. Israeli officials' request to spend more of the aid at home has alarmed American defense contractors.
The United States has not always been so generous with Israel. In the first years after its creation in 1948, the United States provided almost no direct support. The first significant aid, totaling $86.4 million, was made available in 1952.
"I think the United States was unclear whether this new experiment was going to survive," said Arthur S. Berger, a former State Department spokesman on Middle East issues who is now with the American Jewish Committee. "Also at that time, the American lobby for the Arab world was exceedingly strong, both within the State Department and from the oil companies."
Israel's overwhelming victory in the 1967 war led to a rethinking of American strategy in the Middle East -- and the spigot of aid for Israel finally opened wide.
The annual aid package for Israel grew from $13.1 million in 1967, to $76.8 million in 1968, to $600 million in 1971. By the late 1970's, Israel had become the largest single recipient of American aid.
The Camp David agreement in 1979 between Israel and Egypt led the United States to promise large aid packages to both nations. By 1985, the annual package for Israel totaled about $3 billion. The figure has changed little since then.
During much of the 1980's and early 1990's, American assistance was all that stood between Israel and economic collapse. But with the turnaround of the Israeli economy, that has changed.
The American Israel Public Affairs Committee, the powerful lobbying group in Washington, insists that Israel will continue to need military assistance for years. But it acknowledges that the need for economic help is fading.
"I think there's a recognition on the part of both the Administration and Congress that Israel still faces military dangers," said Howard Kohr, the committee's executive director. "But I think clearly there will be a time when there won't be a need for economic assistance. This is a sign of Israel's growing economic independence."

HEADLINE: Israel Redefines Its Dream, Finding Wealth in High Tech

SERIES: ISRAEL AT 50: Oranges to Software

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN 

DATELINE: KIBBUTZ GIVAT BRENNER, Israel, April 17

 BODY:
The exit for Kibbutz Givat Brenner, the largest of Israel's proud old collective farms, is marked by a bright sign for "House of Dreams."
House of Dreams is actually an amusement park that the 70-year-old kibbutz now runs to pad the waning income from its orchards, plant nurseries and aging factories. But the name also carries a poignant echo of the dreams of the early Zionists from Russia, who landed on the shores of the Promised Land envisioning a Jewish nation forged in the selflessness of collective field labor. 
 A few miles north in Tel Aviv, in a concrete block of offices on what were barren sand dunes when the state of Israel was born, several dozen men and women, all in jeans, shorts and T-shirts and well short of 30, worked intently at their computers while sipping cappuccino from paper cups. On a sheet of typing paper taped to the door, these rooms are identified as the offices of Mirabilis, from the Latin for miracle.
Seventeen months ago, Mirabilis did not exist. Today, the innovative chat software invented by its four founders, ICQ (read "I seek you"), is one of the hottest new instruments on the Internet, with 10 million registrations and as many as 57,000 new users daily.
Though only a few miles lie between the "dreams" and the "miracle," they trace the extraordinary road Israel has traveled from the socialist experiment of defiant European Jews to the high-tech revolution that has created a Silicon Valley in the Middle East, second only to the United States in start-ups.
High tech now accounts for nearly a third of all Israeli exports, and with close to 3,000 start-ups and research-and-development projects, the share is likely to continue growing.
By any yardstick, Israel is prosperous -- more than it has ever been -- and learning to love it. Exports have catapulted to about $32 billion last year, most of them industrial and scientific, from $30 million in 1948, most of them agricultural. The per-capita gross domestic product has reached $17,000, more than Portugal or Spain, and many times that of Israel's Arab neighbors. Some 120 Israeli companies are traded on New York exchanges, which places it second among foreign countries only to Canada.
The wealth is tangible. Visitors are regularly struck by the proliferation of cell phones, on which Israelis spend more time talking than any other people. With 1.6 million in use, Israel has one for every three people. The number of cars has almost doubled in nine years, to 1.65 million last year from 882,000 in 1988, and big luxury sedans are no longer exotic. People for whom traveling abroad used to be an impossible dream now pour out of the country in droves for vacations in Europe, South America and Asia. Cafes, gourmet restaurants, shopping malls and outlets of every American chain sprout routinely in Tel Aviv and Jerusalem.
A report recently prepared by the United States-Israel Joint Economic Development Group, a panel of government and private experts in both countries led by Under Secretary of State Stuart Eizenstat, praised the Israeli Government for making "tremendous strides" in reforming its economy and declared that the country now "stands at the cusp of developed-country status."
 
'Tremendous Strides,' And Growing Pains Too
It is also true that Israel has not done it alone. For decades, West Germany and now Germany have paid reparations for the Holocaust, and since the 1979 Camp David peace accord, the United States has been doling out a hefty $3 billion in annual aid, $1.8 billion of it military, making Israel by far the biggest single recipient of American foreign aid.
The success has not come without serious glitches. Current indicators point to an incipient recession. Unemployment in a country that once prided itself on finding jobs for every citizen has reached 8.2 percent, most of it concentrated in angry blue-collar "development towns."
In December rioting broke out in the Negev town of Ofakim after unemployment there reached 14.3 percent.
Tensions with the Palestinians because of the stagnation in peace negotiations under Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu have battered tourism, and some economists fear that the problems could also start scaring investors away.
Mr. Eizenstat, for one, warned in his report that the impasse "is a major element in the current difficulties Israel is having," especially in tourism. Eventually, he said, foreign investment could also suffer.
Another, less tangible problem is that the high-tech revolution and the global reach it has given Israel could further distance Israel economically from its Arab neighbors, delaying even longer the dream of a "new Middle East" that accompanied the 1993 Oslo peace agreements.
Today, 96 percent of Israel's exports and 93 percent of its imports have destinations outside the region.
But whatever the difficulties, and the Middle East is never without them, the trendy upper-middle-class youths hanging out at the sushi bars on Tel Aviv's Ha'Arbaa Street represent a remarkable evolution from the ascetic soldier-farmers of the pioneering kibbutzim.
"I remember when Tel Aviv streets were sand," said Dan Propper, president of the Manufacturers Association and managing director of OSEM, a group of food manufacturing companies. "I remember convoys of camels taking orange crates to Jaffa ports, one tied to the tail of the other. Bedouins pastured their goats in the streets. jackals roamed the center of Tel Aviv."
Even five years after the founding of Israel, Avner Zaks, the secretary of the Givat Brenner kibbutz, remembered how the veterans -- those who had pitched the first tents and broken the first land in 1928 -- wept when they heard of Stalin's death. That was before the terrible human cost of his utopia was revealed, and when collective labor was still the dominant ethic of the Jewish state.
That ethic still survives here at Givat Brenner in the communal dining room, in the free housing, education and medical care, and in the pooling of all outside income.
"For many years we thought that working hard was enough," said Ruth Klidar, a longtime kibbutz member. "If we got up at 6 and worked through the afternoon, that was good.
"Then we found out that much of the work made no money. Take the dining room as an example -- it's basically a restaurant, which should have no more than 10 employees. We have 30, so we're losing money."
The real problem is not money -- Mr. Zaks said the kibbutz takes in about $27 million a year. But the major source of income now is the salaries of members who work outside, and fewer and fewer young people stay on. Mr. Zaks said that 85 percent of young people left after completing their education, and that fewer than 100 of the 12,000 people on the kibbutz were 25 to 35. Meanwhile, about 300 of the 850 full members are over 65.
"The young don't want everything in common," said Mr. Zaks, who at 53 is the classic icon of a kibbutznik with his trim figure, healthy tan and dusty sandals. "They want more control over their lives. You have to adapt to a new system of living. We built this on the ethic of sacrifice. But now our mission is finished."
 
Collective Evolution, Industry Revolution
That mission was initially to settle the biblical homeland, to defend it and make it bloom. But the goals began to evolve even before the founding of the Jewish state.
During World War II, Givat Brenner began supplying products for the British Army, laying the foundation for exports. The need for irrigation equipment led to creation of a foundry. This has evolved into a specialized aluminum die-casting company, which now produces, among other things, the housing for emergency phones along the New Jersey Turnpike.
With time the kibbutz added a juice factory, a furniture factory, a large nursery, and turf production for lawns and parks, in addition to its agricultural products.
A similar evolution was taking place in the state as a whole. "When you're looking at the development of Israeli industry," Mr. Propper said, "you're really looking at the development of the country."
"Industry was established at the beginning of the century for agriculture," he added. "In the second stage, we supplied the British and other armies. Then came the war of independence of 1948, and the beginning of the arms industry. Then in the early 1950's came the immigration from North Africa. The land couldn't supply enough jobs, so factories had to be built, and the 'development towns' grew around textile plants."
After the 1967 war, France declared an embargo on weapons exports to Israel, forcing the sophisticated arms development that eventually gave rise to the high-tech revolution.
The major change, said Amotz Asa-El, associate editor of the Jerusalem Post and its former business editor, came with an abortive attempt in 1977 to scuttle socialism. The economy was not prepared, and it sank into hyperinflation.
"In 1985," Mr. Asa-El said, "to deal with hyperinflation, the unity Government led by Shimon Peres launched a stabilization plan that laid the foundations for the kind of economy Israel now has. He ordered a freeze in the humongous public sector, he emancipated the central bank, he ordered a deep cut in the defense budget, from a sixth of the entire budget to about 10 to 13 percent, where it now stands."
The measures had two major effects. Generally, they launched the process of liberalization and privatization that Mr. Netanyahu has campaigned to accelerate. Specifically, the cut in the military budget fed the civilian high-tech industry.
This time Israel was ready. Since the mid-1970's, many thousands of Israelis had lived or trained abroad.
"Look at us today," said Finance Minister Yaacov Neeman, who has led a campaign to liberalize the economy. "We have a situation where the Prime Minister graduated in business from M.I.T. The governor of the Bank of Israel, Jacob Frankel, has a Ph.D. from Chicago University and was a long time with the World Bank in Washington. I taught at N.Y.U., at Cardozo Law School and at U.C.L.A., and as a tax lawyer for the past 25 years have been exposed to many American multinationals."
The Netanyahu administration has been credited with considerable progress in liberalization, privatization and opening markets, though Mr. Eizenstat said in his report that Israel should further reduce the budget deficit, government spending and taxes.
For Israel's 50th anniversary, which by the Hebrew calendar falls this year on April 30, Mr. Netanyahu has pledged to further ease restrictions on the shekel, making it effectively a convertible currency for the Israelis. For the first time Israeli citizens will be allowed to get and use foreign currencies freely, to hold bank accounts abroad and to buy foreign real estate.
 
Inroads Toward Peace And Exits From Russia
Two more major shifts occurred in the early 1990's: the arrival of hundreds of thousands of immigrants from the collapsing Soviet Union, and the breakthroughs in Israeli-Arab relations at the 1991 Madrid Conference and the 1993 Oslo agreements.
The immigrants brought a rich array of skills, especially in the sciences. Though negative stereotypes of Russians persist, rare is the high-tech company without its share of talented Russians.
While the peace initiatives failed to generate the hoped-for trade or partnership with the Arabs, they gave Israel a new respectability abroad, opening new markets in Southeast Asia, the former Soviet Union and Africa. Real exports grew by 15 percent every year, and investments began to flood in, reaching a record $3.7 billion last year.
Some economists warn that things may slide if the momentum in peacemaking does not resume. Mr. Asa-El disagrees.
"The Oslo process is not undone yet," he said. "Stagnation, yes; procrastination, yes; tension, yes; but not a reversal. Investors don't give a damn whether there's a 'comprehensive peace.' They only want to know that people will show up tomorrow and continue producing lucrative products."
Besides, high tech is by nature less sensitive to politics than other industries. As Mr. Neeman noted, "If there's trouble, you pop your diskette into your pocket and continue somewhere else."
Even more than that, the Internet liberated computer-savvy Israeli youths from the country's biggest handicap: its isolation from markets.
"This is the modern gold rush," said Yossi Vardi, an Israeli businessman who found the financial backing for the four young founders of Mirabilis, one of whom is his son. "There were railroads, radio, television. But in cyberspace, no government has to grant a concession; you don't need a lobby. The concession is granted by people to whom you give the best product."
ICQ has attracted enormous attention among followers of the Internet -- Mirabilis recently held an on-line party for its 10 millionth registration. But because attracting followers has so far been the company's main goal, it has yet to charge -- or make -- a shekel. The founders have no doubt that the money will come when the time is right.
And the money can be big. Another pair of Israelis, Gil Schwed and Shlomo Kramer, had an idea for a network fire-wall system -- programs that protect computer systems from incursions. They parlayed it into CheckPoint Software Technologies Ltd., whose sales last year totaled $83 million -- up 160 percent from the year before.
At Mirabilis, the idea was software that allows users to communicate with others even while they are linked to other sites. Spread only by "word of mouse," without paid publicity, Mirabilis was an instant success in the rapidly spreading world of the Internet. Not surprisingly, more than half of ICQ's users are under 25, while only 2 percent are over 55.
In one of the cramped cubicles in the offices of Mirabilis, two of the founders -- Yair Goldfinger, 26, the chief technical officer, and Asaf Vigiser, 25, the president -- still seemed to treat their success as something of a lark. Mr. Vigiser never finished high school. Yet in about a year and a half, the four friends looking for a way to harness their computer addiction have gained 65 employees and a potential fortune.
The offices have no identifiable decor: boxes compete with workstations for floor space, and the walls are bare aside from a miniature basketball hoop, and posters from American media.
"Look at us," said Mr. Goldfinger, a John Lennon look-alike in shorts and pigtail. "We were just four Amiga and Internet freaks, and the only way for us to make it was the Net. Here people come and go whenever they want. Everyone loves it. It's a cult. For me it's like a cigarette -- it's an addiction."
"Why in Israel?" he added. "I guess it's in the nature of the culture. Israelis have always been good commandos. They don't go by the book. They look for the cutting edge, for a way to do it."
 
Israel at 50
 
These articles focus on facets of Israel as it nears the anniversary of its independence, on April 30. The series began on April 6 with profiles of eight Israelis typifying the country's social diversity. The second article, on April 10, reported on the controversy surrounding a television series reviewing Israel's history.

 BODY:

U.S. Exports to Japan Fall, And Trade Gap Widens
American exports to Japan plummeted in February and helped send the United States trade deficit to its widest gap in a decade. 
 The data released by the Commerce Department demonstrated how the effects of Japan's stalled economy were spreading beyond its shores. The figures also seemed bound to increase the growing tension between Washington and Tokyo over Japan's slow reaction to the severity of its economic problems. Page A1.
 
Drug and Technology Stocks Rally
A number of drug and technology stocks that dropped on Thursday recovered sharply yesterday, helping send the Dow Jones industrial average and the Nasdaq composite index to new highs. The Dow surged 90.93 points, or 1 percent, to 9,167.50, a gain of 2 percent for the week. The Nasdaq index rose 8.36, or half of 1 percent, to 1,866.60. D4.
 
Shares of Broadcom more than doubled on their first day of trading. D4.

Treasury prices slipped despite the trade report, which suggested that Asia's economic problems would act as a drag on growth in the United States. The yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond ended at 5.87 percent. A week ago the yield was 5.88 percent. D4.
 
Cendant Confident on Deals
Cendant's chief executive, Henry R. Silverman, pledged that all of his company's pending takeover deals would be completed despite an accounting problem whose disclosure caused shares of Cendant to plunge on Thursday. The stock recovered a bit yesterday. Cendant also said that it had $5 billion in outstanding credit lines. D2.
 
Industrial Production Rises
The nation's industrial production rose two-tenths of 1 percent in March. The unexpected increase came as utility output surged with the return of colder weather after a mild January and February. D3.
 
Nissan Warns of Profit Plunge
Nissan Motor of Japan said it expected that its group profit tumbled for the year, hurt by slumping sales in both Japan and the United States. And for the first time in 26 years, Nissan expects to sell fewer than a million cars in a fiscal year. D2.
 
Laura Ashley Sells 40% Stake
Laura Ashley, the troubled British clothing and home furnishing company, plans to sell a 40 percent stake to a Malaysian property and retailing company for $72 million. The company, best known for its chintz fabrics and frilly dresses in the 1970's and 80's, announced the cash infusion at the same time it reported a loss of $83.4 million for its fiscal year. D2.
 
EMI Music Chief Resigns
The head of the EMI Group's music unit, James G. Fifield, resigned following weeks of speculation after he failed in an effort to become chief executive of EMI. The British company said Mr. Fifield, a 55-year-old American, would be paid $21 million in compensation. D2.
 
Overseas Gains for McDonald's
McDonald's said earnings rose 5 percent in the first quarter, matching Wall Street analysts' estimates, as the giant fast-food chain benefited from gains in Latin America and Europe. Revenue rose 7 percent. D3.
 
Coca-Cola Enterprises Names Chief
Coca-Cola Enterprises, the world's biggest Coca-Cola bottler, named its president and operating chief, Henry A. Schimberg, to the additional post of chief executive. D2.
 
SGS-Thomson Posts Strong Profits
Shares of SGS-Thomson Microelectronics, the large European chip maker, rose in the United States on better-than-expected profits for the first quarter. D2.

HEADLINE: U.S. TRADE DEFICIT SOARS AS EXPORTS TO JAPAN DECLINE

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 17

 BODY:
American exports to Japan plummeted in February, helping send the United States trade deficit to its widest gap in a decade and demonstrating how the effects of Japan's stalled economy are spreading beyond its shores.
The trade figures, released by the Commerce Department today, substantiated other evidence of a severe economic downturn in Japan, where consumer spending on both Japanese and foreign goods, ranging from clothes to computers to cars, has slowed dramatically. 
 The figures also seemed bound to increase the tension between Washington and Tokyo over Japan's slow reaction to the severity of its economic problems and the pain they can cause elsewhere. The deterioration in the world's second-largest economy and broader weakness in Asia are already hurting the profits of American high-technology companies and other exporters. Japan's weakness is also creating harmful ripple effects in Asian countries struggling to recover from a financial crisis that began last summer.
The United States deficit in trade of goods and services rose to $12.1 billion in February from a revised figure of $11.5 billion the previous month. This was the largest gap since the Commerce Department began measuring trade figures on a monthly basis in 1992, and it was last exceeded in 1987, under a system that measured trade quarterly.
Years ago today's news would have been regarded as dire for the American economy. Today it seemed to say more about Japan's troubles.
With the American economy short of skilled workers, the old concern about trade deficits -- that imports are taking jobs from American workers -- is rarely discussed in Washington. Moreover, the influx of more low-priced imported goods is one reason inflation has been low.
American exports of goods to Japan in February totaled $4.64 billion, down nearly 15 percent from the same month a year ago, when they were at $5.45 billion. That was a dramatic deterioration from January, when the level of exports to Japan barely changed from a year earlier.
Although monthly trade data can fluctuate and do not necessarily indicate a trend, the February figures are an embarrassment to both the Japanese authorities and to the Clinton Administration, which promised that its drive in the first term to negotiate market-opening agreements in Japan would result in a slow but steady increase in American goods to Japanese consumers.
Imports from Japan rose only modestly, to $9.93 billion from $9.70 billion a year ago. Exports and imports of services, which are inherently more difficult to measure, are not recorded each month on a country-by-country basis.
While the American economy remains strong, the risk of declining exports to Japan is minimal, and in fact they help keep the United States economy from overheating. But should the American economy slow considerably, declining exports to Japan could take their toll.
Today's figures suggest that pressure may grow within Japan for a further devaluation of the yen, which would make the country's cars, electronics and other goods more competitive abroad and is one way Japan could strengthen its economy.
But over the last week, Japanese authorities have been desperately trying to lift the yen, largely to contain a growing political problem for Tokyo here and in Asia.
Both the United States and Japan's neighbors have criticized Japan for doing too little to lift the rest of Asia out of its troubles. They argue that a stronger yen is needed to help stimulate more exports to Japan. So far the effort to talk up the yen has been unsuccessful: After a meeting of the largest industrialized countries here on Wednesday, the yen continued to fall against the dollar.
Today the chief of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority, Joseph Yam, warned that a major devaluation of the yen could easily touch off another devastating round of trouble for countries throughout Asia.
"Further volatility in the yen may produce another round of competitive devaluations in other countries," Mr. Yam told reporters here this morning, at the conclusion of three days of meetings that sought to diagnose the causes of the Asian crisis.
Today's report showed that Asia now accounts for roughly two-thirds of America's trade deficits.
"It is the Asian financial crisis and the effects of that and Japan," Robert Shapiro, a top Commerce Department official, said today, explaining the record-high deficit. "The fact is, our exports are growing in every other region of the world."
American exports to Mexico are up 23 percent so far this year, for example, and the trade deficit with Mexico has dropped by 43 percent, compared with last year. The trade surplus with South and Central America is up nearly tenfold in the first two months of this year, compared with the corresponding period in 1997, a statistic President Clinton seems likely to be touting this weekend at the second economic summit meeting of Latin American leaders. The trade gap with Western Europe is also headed down. But the big export problems are in countries hardest hit by the Asian crisis. American exports to South Korea were down 43 percent. They were down 52 percent to Indonesia and 18 percent to Thailand.
"There is a huge decrease in what we can import, and that may last a while," South Korea's Deputy Minister of Finance and Economy, Chung Duck Koo, said today. "We have gone through the first tunnel," he said of his country's brush with bankruptcy, "but we have two tunnels ahead" as banks revamp and companies lay off workers in coming months.
How quickly South Korea and its neighbors get through those tunnels, however, depends more and more on what happens in Japan. Events over the last week, when Japanese finance officials visited Washington but gave few specifics about their plans to stimulate the economy, created little confidence.
"We certainly don't feel any better, and maybe a little worse," one senior Administration official said after the meetings.
David Hale, the chief economist for Zurich Research, concluded earlier this week that Japan's problems posed a double threat.
"Unless the yen falls in value, Japanese firms will have little way out of the country's worsening recession," he said. "But if it is allowed to fall, there could be many unpleasant side effects."

HEADLINE: Case Before Supreme Court May Be Key to Jones Appeal

BYLINE: By NEIL A. LEWIS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 17

 BODY:
Whether Paula Corbin Jones succeeds in her efforts to reinstate her lawsuit against President Clinton may depend on a different case that will be argued in less than a week before the United States Supreme Court, lawyers who deal with sexual harassment issues said today.
On Wednesday, the Justices will be asked to decide whether a Chicago businesswoman may claim sexual harassment after she was subjected to sexual advances by a supervisor, but suffered no adverse job consequences after she refused to comply. One issue is whether a legal case of sexual harassment is possible when no tangible detriments occur at the workplace. 
 In dismissing the Jones lawsuit earlier this month, a Federal judge said one reason for the ruling was that Ms. Jones failed to show any tangible detriment at her job even if the allegations she made about President Clinton were true. Ms. Jones had argued that after she rebuffed a crude sexual advance in 1991 at a Little Rock, Ark., hotel from Mr. Clinton, who was then Governor of Arkansas, she suffered in various ways at her state clerical job.
In her ruling, Judge Susan Webber Wright of Federal District Court took note of the upcoming Supreme Court argument and said it would have no relevance to the Jones case because the circumstances were different.
But Yolanda Wu, a staff lawyer at the NOW Legal Defense and Education Fund, said that if the Supreme Court rules in favor of the Chicago woman, Kimberley B. Ellerth, Ms. Jones's chances of winning her appeal would be greatly enhanced. "It's very much the same legal issue in the Paula Jones case," Ms. Wu said, "whether you have suffered some tangible or economic harm to make out a case of sexual harassment."
Lawyers for Ms. Jones, who announced this week that they would ask the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit, in St. Louis, to hear their appeal, did not detail their legal arguments. But Ms. Jones's main lawyer, Donovan Campbell Jr., referred to next week's Supreme Court argument in Burlington Industries v. Ellerth. The United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit, in Chicago, ruled that Ms. Ellerth's case should go forward even though she had suffered no obvious harm at the workplace. Ms. Ellerth had sued Burlington Industries, charging that a vice president for whom she worked made frequent comments about her legs, said he could make life at the office difficult for her, asked her to engage in sex with him and said that he was reluctant to promote her because she was unwilling to comply. But she was promoted nevertheless.
Michael C. Lynch, a Washington lawyer who specializes in sexual discrimination suits, said that if the court ruled in favor of Ms. Ellerth, "it may even compel the Eighth Circuit to reverse Judge Wright."
Judge Wright had written that the cases were different because Ms. Ellerth had been threatened but there was no similar threat in Ms. Jones's case.
Ms. Yu also noted that the courts have been split on a separate issue central to the Jones case, whether a single sexual advance may be so egregious as to create a hostile work environment.
The Supreme Court said in a 1986 case that a sexual advance had to be "severe" to create a sexually hostile environment. Judge Wright's ruling suggested that a one-time encounter could only meet this requirement if it was something akin to a sexual assault. She said Mr. Clinton's behavior, if true, would be boorish but would fall short of that standard.
A third avenue for appeal could be the interpretation of an Arkansas statute making "outrage" ground for a civil lawsuit. Judge Wright was obliged to consider Arkansas law in evaluating whether Mr. Clinton's alleged behavior could be said to be outrageous conduct.
But lawyers noted that her opinion did not mention a Feb. 12 ruling by the Arkansas Supreme Court, which offered a fresh interpretation of the outrage law. The state Supreme Court, in a split opinion, ruled that a case should be allowed to go to trial in which five women had charged that a doctor improperly and needlessly touched their breasts during medical examinations.
While that behavior might seem less offensive than the complaint against Mr. Clinton -- that he lowered his trousers and asked Ms. Jones to perform oral sex -- Debra S. Katz, a lawyer specializing in sexual harassment suits, said the Arkansas court ruling does not help Ms. Jones.
"That opinion rested on the notion that there was a special relationship between a doctor and his patient," she said. "That could even help Clinton's case since I don't think there's an argument to be made that such a relationship exists between an employer and an employee."
John W. Whitehead, the president of the Rutherford Institute, which is paying Ms. Jones's legal expenses, but not lawyers' fees, said he was considering providing a grant to her lawyers who have been working without pay.
Mr. Campbell said today that he believed his unreimbursed fees totaled $500,000 to $1 million.
Mr. Whitehead said that he believed the lawyers' costs were close to $1 million but that any grant his organization would make would fall far short of that.

HEADLINE: Fare Promotions Snarl Bus Service, Critics Say

BYLINE: By LYNETTE HOLLOWAY 

 BODY:
The Metrocard has done such a good job of luring commuters to city buses that rider advocates and union officials say an old demon has returned in force: "bus bunching."
The so-called bunching occurs when buses on the same route get caught in traffic and arrive at certain stops at the same time, creating long gaps in service. And sometimes, the critics said, there is no room for passengers when the buses get there. 
 The advocates and union officials blamed the bunching on what they said was the transit authority's failure to increase the number of buses on busy routes.
Ridership on the city's 220 bus routes increased to almost 1.6 million in February from 1.3 million in February 1997, or about 20 percent, according to the latest statistics available from New York City Transit. The average weekday ridership increased by 114,000 passengers a day on 42 high-volume routes in the fall of 1997, compared with the fall of 1996, the transit authority said.
Reasons for the increased ridership, said Jared Lebow, a transit spokesman, are the free transfers between subways and buses that were introduced last July; the Metrocard bonus program, which gives riders a free trip with each $15 purchase, and the city's robust economy, which is generating more workers -- and thus more commuters.
In response to the increased demand, the transit authority added service on 32 bus routes in March, Mr. Lebow said, and increased the number of bus operators by 500 -- to 8,000 -- over the last year. In June, the transit authority will increase service on 46 more routes, he said.
But the critics called the effort too little too late, saying they had warned officials almost a year ago that ridership on buses would increase with the free Metrocard transfers. "They were never prepared for this," said Gil Rodriguez, a vice president of Local 100 of the Transport Workers Union, which represents 7,000 operators. "On some routes, people are being turned away, while others are being packed in like sardines."
Larry Hanley, president of Local 726 of the Amalgamated Transit Union, which represents about 1,100 operators and mechanics on Staten Island, said that of the 160 daily trips that originate from the borough, 1,300 people must stand during the 40-minute ride to Manhattan.
"Historically, the transit authority was careless about responding to ridership growth," Mr. Hanley said. "But they need more help and more growth."
Gene Russianoff, a lawyer for the Straphangers Campaign, an advocacy group for riders, said commuters in boroughs outside Manhattan are hardest hit by bunching.
One passenger, Mike Renner, 42, a car-service driver who lives in Dyker Heights, Brooklyn, was waiting yesterday for the B-63 bus near Ninth Street and Fifth Avenue in Park Slope. "My biggest complaint is the wait between buses," he said. "Sometimes it takes 15 to 20 minutes, and other times you'll get three buses coming in a row."
The transit agency does not keep statistics on bunching, but it tracks "service regularity," the percentage of buses that arrive within 50 percent of the scheduled interval after the previous bus. For example, if a bus is due every 8 minutes, the route's regularity rating is the percentage of buses that arrive between 4 and 12 minutes after the last bus.
From the fall of 1996 -- before the explosion in bus ridership -- to fall 1997, regularity declined on 33 of the 48 major routes the authority tracks.
In Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx, the boroughs most affected by the free transfers, the percentage of buses arriving at regular intervals declined on 22 routes and improved on 3.
"Buses are swimming in riders," Mr. Russianoff said. "What these numbers show is that they need to add more service."
Tony Neo, a 30-year-old banker who lives in Bayside, Queens, commutes daily to Forest Hills on the Q-46, where regularity dropped to 56 percent during the last quarter of 1997 from 74 percent during the last quarter of 1996. He believes that any delays he has experienced are the result of human error on the part of neophyte riders.
"If there's any delay in getting on the bus, it's because people don't know how to put the card in the slot," Mr. Neo said. "I have to take the bus all the way up Union Turnpike to Bayside every day, so for me the card saves me two fares; it's good economics. There may be more people riding the bus, but I can't really tell the difference."
