HEADLINE: To Hell in a Handbasket

BYLINE: By Fareed Zakaria; Fareed Zakaria is the managing editor of Foreign Affairs and the author of the recently published "From Wealth to Power: The Unusual Origins of America's World Role."

 BODY:

A Thread of Years
 By John Lukacs.
 481 pp. New Haven:
 Yale University Press. $30. 
 Of the many differences between the movie "Titanic" and history, one in particular is telling. In the movie, as the ship is sinking the first-class passengers (all third-class human beings) scramble to climb into the small number of life-boats. Only the determination of the hardy seamen -- who use guns to keep the grasping men at bay -- gets the women and children into the boats.
In fact, according to survivors' accounts, the "women and children first" convention was observed with almost no dissension, particularly among the upper classes. The statistics make this plain. In first class, every child was saved, as were all but five (of 144) women, three of whom chose to die with their husbands. By contrast, 70 percent of the men perished. In second class, 80 percent of the women were saved but 90 percent of the men drowned.
The men on the first-class list of the Titanic virtually made up the Forbes 400 of the time. John Jacob Astor, reputedly the richest man of his day, is said to have fought his way to a boat, put his wife in it and then stepped back and waved her goodbye. Benjamin Guggenheim similarly refused to take a seat, saying: "Tell my wife . . . I played the game out straight and to the end. No woman shall be left aboard this ship because Ben Guggenheim was a coward." In other words, some of the most powerful men in the world adhered to an unwritten code of honor -- even though it meant certain death for them. The movie makers altered the story for good reason: no one would believe it today.
It is the decline of codes of behavior like "the ideal of the gentleman" that John Lukacs mourns in "A Thread of Years," an impressionistic social history of the 20th century. An erudite and wide-ranging scholar who has written books on Hitler, Budapest, the cold war and Philadelphia aristocrats, Lukacs sees this ideal as inseparably tied up with Anglo-American civilization. Hence its decline is a symptom of the fall of that civilization. Britain and the United States may flourish as nations, economically, politically, even culturally. But culture and civilization are not the same. The Anglo-American self-conception as a distinct, superior civilization, with codes of behavior and honor, manners and morals, has faded. "That this belongs within the history of this century," Lukacs explains, "may be the theme of this book." It is a bold venture, since even to speak of the ideal of the gentleman today is to be considered slightly balmy, as if you wanted to reinstate the divine right of kings, outlaw electricity and put women in corsets.
Writing about something so intangible is difficult, and Lukacs has constructed an unusual form of history to do it, mixing fiction with analysis. The book is made up of 69 chapters, one for every year from 1901 to 1969. Each chapter begins with a brief fictional vignette depicting, for example, two men at a Philadelphia club in 1901, an American woman in Paris in 1920, a Roman Catholic college in America in 1961. Each vignette is followed by a few pages of dialogue between Lukacs and an imagined interlocutor, who together debate the choice and the meaning of the sketch. Why Philadelphia in 1901? Why American Catholics in 1961?
Now if this sounds odd, it is, but Lukacs disarmingly admits as much: "This book may be an attempt at a new genre. Do not take this too seriously." Alas, it doesn't really work. "A Thread of Years" has moments of beauty, insight and whimsy. But they do not add up to a coherent portrait or a sustained theme. In experimenting with fiction and history, the book falls between the two genres, having neither the texture of fiction nor the logic of history.
Lukacs handles many of the fictional vignettes skillfully, particularly those about Europe before World War II. He conjures up the smells inside a Swiss mountain lodge ("the faint trace of steam heat . . . the thin scent of varnished wood"), the sounds of arrival at a grand lake hotel ("the soft crunch of the gravel as the automobile rolls up the great curved driveway") and the look of a summer resort in 1915 ("People are sitting in white wicker armchairs on their porches or the front lawn, like a spread of black and white cauliflowers"). Few historians ever do this, leaving it to novelists like Dos Passos and Doctorow. Lukacs does it well, achieving what the great Dutch historian Johan Huizinga called "historical sensation. . . . A sense of streets, houses, fields, as well as sounds, colors."
But these achievements are fragmentary because Lukacs seems to want to tell two stories, maybe more, simultaneously. The first is quite simply that of the entire 20th century, or rather whichever of its highlights, moods and memories strike Lukacs's fancy. (There is a good bit about Hungary in this book.) The second, about the decline of the gentleman, pops up here and there but gets lost in the broader story. Lukacs has one character, a Philadelphia gent named K, who reappears now and then but never becomes the protagonist. Though there are three explanatory chapters, called "ribbons," placed at 20-year intervals, to let the reader feel the spine of the book, they don't really help, being mostly a potted history of the American century.
The dialogues often wander as freely as the vignettes, and we are treated to the author's pet enthusiasms and peeves on a variety of utterly unrelated subjects. (He hates the movie "Casablanca," Henry James and rock music, among other things, and likes Gershwin, Huizinga and Spain -- but dislikes Hemingway's use of Spanish.) Some of these diversions are individually a delight, but after a while you begin to resent the lack of discipline.
In his own impressionistic way, however, Lukacs does outline the fall of Anglo-American civilization and its ideals. He alludes to its causes -- the decline of Britain, the rise of immigrant and Catholic influences in American culture, the erosion of religion, the triumph of relativism, but perhaps most of all the loss of confidence. At its peak, the Anglo-American elite had a striking air of high-minded paternalism, born of a cultural sense of superiority and a Protestant sense of mission. The ideal of the gentleman was not simply a matter of manners but of morals. It was a way of embodying the values of that civilization -- fair play, decency, chivalry. These codes have been increasingly criticized over the course of this century as being artificial, ethnocentric and hypocritical -- all of which they were. But "hypocrisy," Lukacs explains, "is the cement that held civilization together." Standards should surely represent a society's highest aspirations, not its tawdry realities. And the artifice of good manners, vital to civil discourse, has now been replaced by "a moral and intellectual sleaziness pretending to be 'sincere.' " From the saccharine confessions of daytime television to the verbal abuse of talk shows, we have created our own brand of fakery.
Most important, we have freed our upper classes of any sense of responsibility. The rich will always be with us. Every society has an elite, those more wealthy or powerful or famous than the rest. We can only ask that it recognize that with this privilege come responsibilities. Social conventions, moral strictures, the gentleman's code, were all attempts to civilize the strong. (The first citation of "civilize" in the Oxford English Dictionary, Lukacs tells us, dates from 1601, when the word meant "to bring out of a state of barbarism, to instruct in the arts of life.")
Society expected the rich to behave themselves and conform to certain ways of living, spending and participating in the public life of the land. When they did, they were honored. Near East Potomac Park in Washington there stands a haunting monument, a statue of a man with arms outstretched, Christlike, with an inscription on its pedestal: "To the brave men of the Titanic, who gave their lives that women and children might be saved." It was erected by voluntary donations from 25,000 women. When the elite did not behave appropriately -- and they often broke their norms -- it was a matter of dishonor and disappointment. Today, by contrast, we expect very little of those in positions of power -- whether they are Presidents or tycoons or movie stars -- and they rarely disappoint us.

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;
Drop in Asian Travelers Affects Tourism in U.S.

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
THE economic malaise that broke out in Asia last fall has helped make much of that continent a bargain basement for American travelers. But the conditions that have made Asia such a good value for visitors portend bad news for the tourist industries of Hawaii, California, Australia and New Zealand. And the ripple effects, mainly the tighter grip that Asian visitors will keep on purse strings, are expected to be felt from the casinos of Las Vegas to the Mall of America in Bloomington, Minn.
"Clearly tourism from Asia is going to be off this year," said John Marks, president of the San Francisco Convention and Visitors Bureau. "We're already experiencing a dramatic decline from Korea. And tourism from Japan is also going to be off, but we just don't know how much. If I had to speculate, maybe 10 percent." 
 While Chinese tourists are turning up in greater numbers throughout Asia, the United States doesn't expect a significant number, at least in the short term. The main impediments are distance, cost and United States law requiring potential visitors to demonstrate to the United States consular officer in their country, and the immigration officer here, their intention to return home.
Northwest Airlines, which has had extensive routes to Asia for more than 50 years, says that tourism from Japan to the United States is already down about 10 percent through March 20 of this year, compared with the same period last year.
In 1996, the last year for which statistics are available, San Francisco had 384,000 visitors from Japan, 136,000 from Korea and 145,000 from Taiwan. Because the Taiwanese economy is comparatively healthy, Mr. Marks said, any drop in visitors from Taiwan this year should be minimal.
Los Angeles is also bracing for a drastic decrease in Korean visitors, who numbered about 200,000 in 1997, according to Bob Moore, of the city's Convention and Visitors Bureau. But while Mr. Moore said fewer Japanese tourists will go abroad this year, his talks with tour operators suggest that Los Angeles may attract the same number of Japanese visitors as last year, about 750,000 -- mainly because of bargain tour packages. "They're very attractive to the single female workers who make up a large part of the visitors from Japan," he said.
These observations were seconded by Frank Murakami, general manager of the Los Angeles office of the Japan Travel Bureau International, Japan's biggest travel company. "The trend this year is to Southern California," he said, because it is less expensive than San Francisco, and it is the jumping off point for Las Vegas.
The so-called Golden Triangle for Japanese tourists, Mr. Murakami added, used to be Los Angeles, San Francisco and Las Vegas. "Now it's Las Vegas, Disneyland and Universal Studios," he said.
Japanese are attracted to Las Vegas more for its entertainment than for gambling, according to Mr. Moore and others. But many Asian travelers visit Las Vegas primarily to gamble. Jason Ader, an analyst for Bear, Stearns, said the expected falloff in Asian tourism to the United States, which he forecast at about 10 percent, could cause a 10 to 15 percent reduction in baccarat revenues in Las Vegas through 1999 -- or as much as $60 million annually. Moreover, any decline in Asian tourism to Las Vegas will also be felt at the Grand Canyon, a popular day trip from the gambling mecca. The Mall of America is not making forecasts about numbers of Asian visitors, but a spokeswoman said that those who come are expected to be more frugal.
California still expects healthy tourism overall in 1998, spurred by domestic travel and more visitors from Canada and Mexico. But Hawaii is especially vulnerable to a drop in visitors from Asia -- or anywhere else. Tourism is far and away Hawaii's biggest industry, accounting for about $11 billion in revenues a year, a third of its jobs and a quarter of its tax revenues.
Tony Vericella, the president of the Hawaii Visitors and Convention Bureau, predicted that arrivals from Korea, which numbered 122,000 last year, could drop as much as 80 percent in 1998. While arrivals from Japan are expected to be within 1 percent above or below last year's 2.1 million total, Mr. Vericella said, the weak yen means that the Japanese who do visit Hawaii will have fewer dollars to spend. Spending by Japanese tourists has already fallen from an average $354 a day a few years ago, the visitors bureau said, to $298 last year.
The Asian economic crisis also slammed Australia and New Zealand, both of which had been expecting a strong 1998. Australia had especially high hopes, after a 7 percent gain in fiscal 1997 that resulted in a record 4.3 million foreign visitors and $6.1 billion in tourist revenues. Instead, international arrivals are expected to plummet between 6 and 9 percent, according to Australia's Tourism Forecasting Council, and tourism earnings could fall 20 percent -- despite a projected doubling of visitors from China, who still represent only a trickle. On the other hand low air fares and package tours enticed enough North Americans in the past two months that Australian tourist officials are projecting a 6 percent increase in their numbers this year. But with The World Tourism Organization predicting that the financial crisis within the Asia Pacific region will keep about 12 million Asian tourists from traveling throughout Asia by the year 2000, the outlook is not bright.

LENGTH: 1774 words

HEADLINE: Checking Medicine's Vital Signs

BYLINE: By Michael M. Weinstein; Michael M. Weinstein, an economist, is a member of the editorial board of The Times.

 BODY:
Three jumbo jets crashing every two days. If the airlines killed that many people annually, public outrage would close them overnight. Hospitals kill that many patients every year because of missed diagnoses, medication mishaps and other preventable errors. Yet there's hardly a whimper of protest.
Shocking? Choke on these findings by some of the nation's leading researchers: 
 Medical errors account for up to a quarter of the deaths from heart attack, stroke and pneumonia. Perhaps half the nation's diabetics are treated improperly. Up to 85 percent of prescribed medical treatments lack scientific validation. An intensive-care unit at one medical center committed nearly two errors per patient each day, a third of which were potentially serious. Surgeons in some parts of the country perform mastectomies rather than lumpectomies on Medicare patients 35 times more often than those in other regions, and for no apparent medical reason. Rates of heart surgery vary by a factor of three. One study found that nearly 20 percent of coronary angiographies lacked medical justification. A quarter of the surgeries to implant tubes in children's ears are inappropriate and a third are questionable.
Missed diagnoses. Unjustified surgery. Unwarranted tests. Drug mishaps. How can this medical mayhem be avoided?
For starters, we need choice -- the leeway to pick the physicians, hospitals and health plans and clinics that do the best job treating patients in our communities. Most people, including Federal employees, Medicare enrollees and employees of large businesses, have at least some choice of health plans and doctors. (Employees at smaller firms often have none, a problem that should be addressed by Congress.) But choice alone does little good if we can't distinguish excellent from mediocre, let alone atrocious. Most of us know more about the effectiveness of our deodorants than we do about the competence of our surgeons.
So how can we choose the best quality?
Such choice is not provided by various versions of a patient "bill of rights," now before Congress. A package of consumer protections is a useful though limited idea that would give people in managed-care plans some peace of mind, but it barely touches the scandal of mediocre medicine. After all, the statistics just cited are drawn largely from studies of patients in traditional fee-for-service plans. And even for patients in managed care, the bill's most potent element is merely a right of appeal if a health plan refuses to pay for a doctor-prescribed treatment.
The right of appeal would improve medical practice in isolated cases. But it would do nothing to protect patients from doctors who prescribe the wrong drugs or surgeons who perform needless and potentially risky operations. What patients really need is a right to information. Providing it would transform health care by putting patients in control, rather than doctors and insurance companies. In fact, outside Washington there are important projects under way that are on the verge of handing Americans a report card on health plans -- the tool that enables patients to guard the quality of their health care.
In Boston, Dr. Lucian L. Leape of the Harvard School of Public Health is studying how physicians and health plans can cut down on mistakes. Drug mishaps injure more than 220,000 hospital patients a year. Leape's powerful point is that these mistakes can be significantly reduced if hospitals adopt simple procedures. One of these is "unit dosing," in which hospital pharmacists would prepare injections in advance, before a patient suffers cardiac arrest and a nurse scrambles to draw the precise amount of a potent drug. Some hospitals and clinics have adopted this precaution. The scandal is that others have not.
In Los Angeles, Dr. Robert H. Brook of the Rand Corporation and the University of California at Los Angeles has developed criteria for determining when medical procedures -- like coronary bypass surgery, mastectomies and hysterectomies -- are appropriate and when they are ineffective or needlessly risky. Brook's work is the source of many of the statistics given at the beginning of this article, and it could tell physicians and health plans how best to practice medicine if they would listen. But few do. The doctors who perform unwarranted treatments are rarely incompetent, let alone villainous. Their decisions are more often based on habit and presumption. In a sensible system, decisions would be solidly rooted in Brook's clinical evidence.
In New York, a state agency rates the performance of cardiac surgeons with an increasingly sophisticated method that adjusts for the severity of the patients' condition. And in Boston, Dr. Troyen Brennan of Harvard Medical School organizes an evening seminar for a small group of colleagues on the latest advances in treating asthmatics. The seminar is part of his two-year program to evaluate overall health care at 11 outpatient clinics associated with Harvard. Brennan sends nurses into the clinics to examine a random sample of patient records and determine, according to a detailed questionnaire, whether patient care conforms to the highest standards set by Leape, Brook and others. Do the clinics, as one seminar guest recommended, teach asthmatics to use "peak flow" meters that gauge their lung performance? Do the clinics administer the proper vaccines, perform diagnostic blood tests, offer nutritional advice and teach how to examine breasts and prostate glands for early signs of cancer? Do doctors spend enough time with patients, and are patients satisfied?
The key to Brennan's evaluation is a detailed examination of patient records -- a strategy developed 10 years earlier by another Harvard team that uncovered startling amounts of malpractice in New York State hospitals. Brennan's task is harder because he is documenting not only when doctors err but also when they excel.
Grading clinics is a first step to the more important task of grading health plans and the medical groups -- the networks of doctors and hospitals that treat patients as a team -- that health plans increasingly make available to members. Behind a veil of ignorance, most family decisions to join Kaiser or the Blues, Aetna or Prudential is based on rumor. Rumor perpetuates mediocrity or worse.
Enter David Lansky and the Foundation for Accountability in Portland, Ore. He is taking Brennan's strategy to the next level -- by creating America's first reliable report card for health plans. The foundation will not assign grades to any specific plan. Instead, it will provide its method for grading plans to others -- the Federal Government, groups of employers, nonprofit groups like the American Association of Retired Persons or accreditation groups like the National Committee for Quality Assurance, which pioneered the development of criteria by which to rate H.M.O.'s.
The foundation's report card will assign five grades, each between 0 and 100. Grades for the "basics," "living with illness" and "changing needs" will measure the plan's success in helping patients connect with the right doctors, cope with chronic medical problems and adapt to old age and other health care transitions. The heart of the report card will be grades for the prevention and curing of illness.
The grade for prevention, building upon work of Leape and others, will indicate if the plan provides, for example, routine Pap smears, mammograms, screens for prostate and colon cancers, annual eye and foot exams for diabetics and inhalers for asthmatics. The grade for curing illness will reflect findings on appropriate care: has the plan routinely administered beta blockers after heart attacks and radiation therapy after breast-cancer lumpectomies?
The foundation also plans to grade results as well as treatment practices. Beyond doing all the right tests and procedures, has the plan kept the blood-sugar levels of its diabetics low? Has it kept its asthmatics out of hospital emergency rooms? Do patients suffering from depression remain at work? Do heart attack patients relapse? Do asthma patients actually use the peak-flow meters they are trained to use?
The foundation's initial report card will be crude. It will be based on a slim list of criteria and rely heavily on interviews with patients because such surveys are the easiest data to collect. But a complete report card also requires data on clinical practice that can come only from patient records. As yet, health plans neither routinely collect nor report clinical data for public scrutiny.
This problem cannot be solved in Los Angeles, New York or Boston. For the solution, look squarely to Washington. Congress needs to compel health plans to report data on their performance. For report cards to compare one plan with another, every plan must track the same categories. Congress can compel that too by adopting the framework provided by the foundation.
On this front, Washington finally appears headed in the right direction. Last month, President Clinton's commission on health care proposed a private agency to oversee the development of standards that could complement the work of Lansky's Foundation for Accountability. And key members of Congress have proposed legislation that would create Federal agencies for the same purpose. The Administration could give the process a dramatic boost by requiring that the health plans serving Medicare patients and Federal employees provide enrollees with a standardized account of their clinical data.
Medical disclosures along these lines dwarf in importance Congress's pending preoccupation with a patient bill of rights. The best way to raise the quality of health care is to set people like Leape and Brook loose to teach doctors what treatments work best and then set people like Lansky loose to tell patients which health plans are listening. If patients follow the grades, then only those health plans that invest in a reputation for quality will prosper -- much as the Hewlett-Packards, M.I.T.'s and Intels thrive on their reputation for excellence.
What people need to know about health care -- where to find high quality -- is knowable. Following the progression from Leape to Brook to Lansky, and with a forceful nudge from Congress, the health care report card could be published and be in consumers' hands within months, radically shifting the balance of power toward patients. Finally, medical consumers can take charge of the market, elevating high-quality plans, dooming mediocre or worse plans and, in the process, insuring that no more medical jumbo jets crash.

SECTION: Section 5; Page 14; Column 1; Travel Desk

HEADLINE: WHAT'S DOING IN;
Shanghai

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON; SETH FAISON is chief of the Shanghai bureau of The Times.

 BODY:
Shanghai is in the middle of a huge make-over. As the largest and most cosmopolitan city in China, it often seems determined to be at the forefront of the nation's fast-changing ways. Today that means that Shanghai is undergoing a boom in construction so vast that officials like to boast that nearly one-fifth of the world's cranes are at work in their city.
Even if that is overstated, visible changes seem to appear almost every day. In the past year alone, Shanghai has opened a new Stock Exchange, completed hundreds of office buildings, and finished a complex of elevated highways that has sharply improved traffic congestion.
The financial crisis has halted work on new buildings in many Asian cities, but Shanghai seems heedless of the bust, at least so far. There is barely a corner of the city that is not plagued by round-the-clock construction, and with all-night work crews going at it, virtually no place is guaranteed silence even late at night.
For the visitor, the construction sites are making life a bit messy, but they also give the city a palpable vibrancy. Shanghai is a city on the move, as its residents are proud to tell you. Like New Yorkers, Shang hainese are undeniably the most urbane, flamboyant, sassy and arrogant residents of the country.
With a compact downtown area and a tendency toward narrow and winding streets, Shanghai is a wanderer's city. Leave the bicycles for Beijing and other places. Shanghai, like Manhattan, is best seen on foot.
Yet without conspicuous markers for north, south, east or west, it is easy for visitors to lose their orientation. One solution is to not even bother trying to keep your sense of direction: simply wander down any street that looks inviting. When too tired or lost to continue, you can hop in a cab. They are available virtually all over the city at any hour, and the address of a hotel or a next destination, written in Chinese, is all you need.
The city's main shopping streets, Nanjing Road and Huaihai Road, are good places to start any exploration. But the mazelike side streets are worth venturing into as well, with their close-up views of ordinary houses and back-street life.
 
Events
 From tomorrow until Saturday, Shanghai will play host to its First International Flower Festival. After years of treating flowers as a bourgeois waste of time, Shanghai is now welcoming more than 100 Chinese and foreign flower companies to participate in the exhibition, the largest flower show ever held in China. The Dutch tulip has been chosen as the theme flower of the festival, which will also feature several themes for floral arrangements: spring in the countryside, urban scenery and exotic flowers. Held at Changfeng, 25 Daduhe Road; (86-21) 6245-3270.
In mid-June an exhibition of recent works by the artist Tang Guo will be on display at Shanghart, one of the city's few modern art galleries. Tang, who lives in Nanjing, uses ink, earth and other materials on paper. Shangart is in the Portman Ritz-Carlton Hotel, 2/F, 1376 Nanjing West Road; (86-21) 6279-7135. Open seven days, 9 A.M. to 9 P.M.
From May 2 to June 1, the Shanghai International Arts Festival will feature a series of dance, music and theater performances. For a schedule and ticket information, contact the Shanghai Performance Advertising Company at (86-21) 6466-5938.
Among the highlights of the arts festival are a performance of Swan Lake by the National Ballet of Nancy and Lorraine, from France, May 2, 3 and 4 at the Majestic Theater, 66 Jiangning Lu; (86-21) 6466-0419.
A musical highlight on May 3 will be a performance by the Portal Jazz Quartet, a French group consisting of Michel Portal, saxophonist, Louis Sclavis, clarinetist, Francois Moutin, double bass player, and Daniel Humair, percussionist. At the Lyceum Theater, Maoming Road at Changle Road; (86-21) 6247-5572.
 
Sightseeing
 The greatest addition to Shanghai's cultural life in recent years is the Shanghai Museum, opened in October 1996, by far the most magnificent, and most magnificently displayed, collection of art in China. A striking-looking structure that took some inspiration from an ancient Chinese urn, the new museum seems to embody Shanghai's cosmopolitan nature, and it also sets a new standard for showing art in this country. The overall design, the layout of galleries and the specially built display stands all combine to enhance a visitor's appreciation of the museum's first-rate bronze, porcelain and jade collections.
From April through September the museum is exhibiting historical relics from Xinjiang Province. Chronicling China's Silk Road, the ancient trade route that exported silk and imported Buddhism, among other things, the exhibition includes ceramics, jewelry and mummies. The museum is at 201 Remin Avenue, in People's Square, (86-21) 6372-3500, and is open daily from 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. Admission: $5.
No visitor to Shanghai should miss a walk on its majestic waterfront, known as the Bund, where the buildings once run by old British banks and trading houses still dominate the view. The old tree-lined esplanade that hung over the river was replaced a few years ago with a more modern one, losing some character but gaining a better view of the bustling river traffic.
Across the Huangpu River, which feeds into the Yangtse River just 25 miles to the north, stands the Oriental Pearl Tower, a modernistic creation that at 1,400 feet is the tallest in Asia. The tower, on Lujiazui Road in the Pudong district, (86-21) 5882-8888, is well worth ascending, not only for its unparalleled view of the city but also for its flavor of the new Shanghai, both modern and tacky. It can be reached by a cross-river ferry that leaves from the Bund at Jingling Road every 10 minutes and costs 5 cents. Admission to the tower is $6.
An even better way to see the waterfront, not just the old financial houses but also the vast industrial shipyards in the area, is to take a 90-minute cruise on a riverboat that departs from the Bund twice a day (10:45 A.M. and 3:15 P.M.) and costs $3. Tickets are best bought a day in advance from the Shanghai Huangpu River Guide Company, at 239 Zhongshan Dongyi Road, (86-21) 6374-4461.
A dozen blocks south of the Bund is the Old City, which remained under Chinese control in the days when the English and French and Japanese carved out their own concessions. The narrow and crowded streets preserve an air of old Shanghai, and give way to a central area known as Yu Yuan, a classical Chinese garden. At its core is the Huxinting Tea House, standing in the middle of a rectangular pool, and a lovely spot for afternoon tea. For $3 you get a choice of Chinese teas, a selection of several traditional snacks and a view of the crowded garden.
 
Where to Stay
 A flavor of old Shanghai can be found in the Ruijin Guest House, 118 Ruijin Second Road, (86-21) 6472-5222, fax (86-21) 6473-2277. The grounds of what was once an elegant mansion have been kept up well, in a quiet and secluded part of town, and one can easily spend a sunny afternoon lounging on the well-manicured lawns, sipping lemonade. Its 100 rooms cost $75 to $125.
The Metropole, at 180 Jiangxi Road, (86-21) 6321-3030, fax (86-21) 6321-7365, downtown near the Bund, has an ornate lobby that seems to capture the mood of cosmopolitan Shanghai left over from the colonial era. It has a charming, dark wood-paneled bar, but its 120 rooms are plain. They cost $50 to $75.
Budget: The 120-room Qingnian Hui Hotel, at 123 Xizang Road, (86-21) 6326-1040, fax (86-21) 6320-1957, is centrally, if noisily, located on a crowded shopping street in the downtown area. Housed in the building that was once home to Shanghai's Y.M.C.A., it is also known as the Y.M.C.A. Hotel. A second-floor ballroom is home to daily ballroom dances populated mostly by a charming clientele of retirees. Its rooms cost $40 to $60.
The Pujiang Hotel at, 15 Huangpu Road, (86-21) 6324-6388, fax (86-21) 6324-3179, is nicely situated just off the Bund and across the street from the Russian Consulate. Until last year its ballroom was home to the Shanghai Stock Exchange. Called the Astor Hotel before 1949, the Pujiang retains a flavor of old Shanghai with wooden floors and high ceilings. Its 80 rooms cost $40 to $60.
Luxury. The newest addition to Shanghai's growing collection of first-class hotels is the Regal Hotel, 516 Hengshan Road, (86-21) 6415-5888, fax (86-21) 6445-8899, in the part of the city ruled by French authorities -- with their own police force, bureaucrats and tax collectors -- before World War II. The Regal is a gleaming glass-and-marble concoction with all the modern comforts, including the city's best health club. There are 200 rooms, from $140 to $350 a night.
Down by the waterfront, the most magnificent of Shanghai's pre-revolution hotels is the Peace Hotel, 20 Nanjing East Road, (86-21) 6321-6888, fax (86-21) 6320-0300. Recently renovated, it has a stately Art Deco lobby and bone-and-walnut decor. A jazz band of elderly gentlemen still plays in the ground-floor bar each evening. Its 280 rooms cost $120 to $350, and the ornate Chinese restaurant on the eighth floor has a grand view of the harbor.
 
Where to Eat
 Green Willow Village, in the heart of Shanghai's shopping district at 763 Nanjing West Road, (86-21) 6258-4422, is one of the city's oldest and most distinctive restaurants, known as Luyang Cun in Chinese. Decorated in a simple, old-fashioned style, it offers a Yangzhou cuisine famous for its Mandarin fish in pine nuts, prawns in hot chili sauce, and soft-shelled turtle with dried orange peel. A four-course meal for two will cost about $40 (including beer; wine is not available).
For more traditional Shanghai fare, try Lao Ban Zhai, 596 Hankou Road, (86-21) 6322-3668, with such specialties as steamed long-tail fish in anchovy sauce, and pork meatballs cooked with crabmeat. The shredded Hainan chicken with sliced bean curd is also worth a try. A four-course dinner for two is $25 to $30, including beer.
For a cozy, fashionable seafood restaurant frequented by Shanghai's younger set, go to Lulu's, at 69 Shimen First Road, (86-21) 6258-5645, where the waiters ask you to pick your seafood while it is still swimming in one of the freshwater tanks that line the entranceway. Big yellow fish is particularly good, as are the fresh crab and eel. Sweet lotus root is an excellent appetizer. Dinner for two, with beer, is $40.
A more typically popular Shanghai dining experience awaits customers at Tin Tin Seafood Restaurant, 807 Julu Road, (86-21) 6247-2362. At one end of a large, noisy dining room, a stage show includes heavily sequined singers of Chinese pop songs. While you listen and watch, try the stir-fried river shrimp or bullhead fish in brown sauce. Twisted beancurd with pork is also quite good. Dinner for two, with beer, is $30.
A small street lined with restaurants, called Huang He Road, just around the corner from the Park Hotel, offers an array of choices for the adventurous. One of the city's best vegetarian restaurants, Gong De Lin, is there at No. 43; (86-21) 6327-0218. The pea greens with garlic are excellent, as is the resembling-chicken tofu, which is indeed tofu prepared to look like chicken. Dinner for two, with beer, is $50.

SECTION: Section 5; Page 31; Column 1; Travel Desk 

LENGTH: 1260 words

HEADLINE: Facing West on China's Silk Road

BYLINE: By PETE HESSLER; PETE HESSLER is a teacher and writer living in Fuling, China.

 BODY:
THE train left Xian late on a warm evening last August, rocking gently past the Ming Dynasty city wall. The ancient wall was the last thing I saw before going to bed, and then in the morning, we were in the dry loess hills of southern Gansu Province, where steep terraced slopes crumbled away into dusty gorges. There were walls here, too -- simple walls of packed earth that formed neat rectangles around tile-roofed houses. But something in the rugged landscape made the walls seem desperate in comparison with the grandeur of the Xian city wall.
Xian means Western Peace, and from there, the train was following the Silk Road west -- west of western peace, to the deserts of Xinjiang Province and its capital, Urumqi, in the far reaches of China. It was a well-worn route. For more than 2,000 years, it has seen travelers of all sorts: Chinese silk traders, Uighurs, Huns, Mongols, Kazakhs, Buddhist pilgrims, Islamic priests, Nestorian Christians. Some of the travelers, like Marco Polo, had been welcomed; others had met with walls of one sort or another. There is no other part of China where history speaks so vividly of the country's fitful contacts with the outside world. 
 I could sense this history even in the comfortably crowded Car 13 of the hard-sleeper class, because I was the only foreigner -- and an American to boot. Americans came late to the Silk Road, but a year in China had taught me that no other foreigners weighed so heavily on the consciousness of today's Chinese.
"All Chinese like Americans," a young man said. He was 25, from Hebei Province, working in safety management for a Xinjiang oil company, and we had been talking for half an hour when he shifted to politics.
"Many Americans think there are problems with human rights here," he said. "In fact, Old Hundred Names doesn't care about that." It was a traditional term for the common man, a reference to the fact that Chinese surnames are few.
"Old Hundred Names worries about eating, about clothes," he went on. "Look out there." I did -- a dusty village, garbage beside the tracks, a skinny donkey followed by peasants in blue. Old Hundred Names. "Do you think those people worry about democracy?" he said. "They need to improve their living standard and then they can start thinking about other things."
I saved my responses for simpler questions -- the money questions -- which came in a steady stream from passengers who stopped by to chat as the scenery slipped past: What's your salary? How much are those boots? That watch? What are the unemployment benefits in America?
We passed Lanzhou, the muddy Yellow River sluggish under a sheet of haze, and then in the afternoon a fertilizer salesman sat next to me. How much is a new car in America? he wondered. A used car? What about the license fee? Taxes? Insurance? He scrawled my responses -- guesses, all of them -- in a notebook, and then he paused to look out the window.
"My parents came to Xinjiang in the 1950's, after Liberation," he said. "They came to help build the country. It was like America."
Both of us stared outside: a shepherd with his flock in a green field, a man in blue riding a bicycle along a dusty road, a row of mud houses surrounded by walls, a range of craggy white peaks to the south, and westward, a broad empty horizon of the sort one rarely sees in China. There were no trees for miles. "Go west, young man," the fertilizer salesman said.
 SOMETIME during the second night, the train passed Jiayuguan, the westernmost fort of the Great Wall. I couldn't see that barrier, but still in the morning it was clear that a line had been crossed. There were no villages or walls, only rocks and dust and low rugged hills that were sharply shadowed by the bright desert sun.
"Forty percent of the shoes in America are made in China," a 27-year-old soldier on the way to his post in Kashgar, 60 miles from the Kyrgyzstan border, told me. I had no idea where he had acquired this fact, but he spoke with authority.
"That's why Clinton wanted the most-favored-nation status for China," he opined. "But Congress was against it. Every year they have the debate, but the Americans want to buy Chinese products."
I remembered what people had told me before I came to China: the Chinese are afraid to talk about politics with foreigners. Had this really been true in the past? It was hard for me to imagine, because it seemed they liked to talk about nothing else, except prices. And did soldiers in other countries worry about international trade?
Meanwhile, the train grew hotter as we moved into Xinjiang and the Taklimakan Desert. The hills dropped steadily, and with them the clear sky fell lower and lower, until at last, the land was perfectly flat and the horizon sat like a great dome of blue stretched taut above the black earth.
We stopped for an hour in the oasis city of Hami, where the station signs were in Arabic script as well as Chinese. Xinjiang is also called the Uighur Autonomous Region, but in recent years, the Uighurs, an indigenous Islamic minority group who constitute nearly half of the province's population, have complained that their autonomy is being diluted by waves of Han Chinese immigrants sent west by the Government. The Uighurs say that Chinese settlers receive the best jobs in Xinjiang as well as the bulk of its political power, and this dissatisfaction has led to outbreaks of violence.
There weren't any Uighurs in our car, and even at the Hami station, there were only a few, selling grapes and Hami melons beside the tracks. During the stop I asked the oil worker if any Uighurs worked in his department, and he shook his head. He admitted that Chinese-Uighur relations in Urumqi were strained, and then he shrugged.
I asked him if he could speak Uighur, and he laughed. "You don't need it," he said. "At work, when you go shopping -- always you use Chinese. But I know a few words. Salaam aleikum is 'hello.' And 'thank you' is ----." He paused, thinking hard. He had lived in the region for two years. "I forget," he said at last. "But I know 'good bye.' "
And he said it, but he spoke softly and the word was lost in the hot desert wind.
THE oasis towns appeared every hour or two, rising suddenly along the tracks, then disappearing just as quickly into the rock and dirt and sand. They weren't oases in the classic sense: no palms or shining pools of water; just concrete and glass and dust. It was as if they had been reversed, the oases and the desert; we would roll out of town and I would breathe a sigh of relief, unable to imagine that these places had once been inviting to travelers. The land was barren but it was also mesmerizing, and the towns had no charm.
I would have been happy to continue for days, passing from oasis to oasis, watching the great nothingness beside the tracks. The train was comfortable and the people friendly; all day long they brought me food and drink -- tomatoes, cucumbers, flavored ices, dried fish, beer. Occasionally, somebody stopped by to talk about prices or Chinese-American relations, but at last, it was as if the wasteland had swallowed all conversation. Nearly everybody sat silent, staring out at the scenery.
The Flaming Mountains rose to the north, red and scarred by countless ridges, and then the Tian Shan range came into view. Snow was streaked bright in the high peaks. It grew dark; a full moon hung in the eastern sky.
The train rocked westward. It seemed we'd never get to Urumqi, but I didn't care. There weren't any walls for miles and miles.

HEADLINE: ASIA-PACIFIC ISSUE;
Asia Lures Travelers With Bargains

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL; EDWIN McDOWELL, a business reporter for The Times, covers the travel industry.

 BODY:
ASIA'S recent economic woes have made much of that region a bargain again, with air fares, hotel rates and package tours lower than they have been in years.
Tourism in Asia is down, and hoteliers in Hong Kong, Thailand, South Korea, Indonesia (including Bali), Singapore, Malaysia, Vietnam and the Philippines are desperate to raise their occupancy rates. The only way they can do so is by offering bargains. The Korean National Tourist Office, which acknowledges that the country is relying heavily on foreign tourists -- especially Americans -- to fill their rooms, noted that rates now average $166.78, down from $261.48 on Oct. 31. 
 Hotels affiliated with international chains have been the most reluctant to cut room rates, because, as a Hyatt International official said, "it's always hard to get them back up again." While holding the line on rates, Hyatt is discounting food prices in its hotels -- and suggests visiting its Web page, www.hyatt.com, for up-to-the-minute specials. Other chain hotels are offering upgrades, as well as free breakfast, free tours, free local phone calls and transportation to or from the airport. Many such bargains are bundled within package deals.
By contrast, Hong Kong-based Century International Hotels, with some two dozen hotels in seven Asian nations, is offering rates through May that average more than 50 percent off. A room at the Century Park Hotel in Bangkok is now as low as $39, compared with a published rate of $126.
Many bargains are noted below, and more are quite likely to follow, since the crisis may last anywhere from 18 months (according to the chairman of Cathay Pacific Airways) to three years (World Tourism Organization). But caveats are in order:
Seats for many inexpensive flights are limited, nonrefundable, do not include frequent-flier miles and must be paid by check or cash. Hotel rates do not include taxes or service charges and, because of fluctuating exchange rates, may be higher or lower at checkout.
Moreover, getting the lowest hotel rate usually requires bypassing a country's Web site as well as a hotel chain's worldwide reservations service and booking instead directly with the hotel (by phone in advance, or in person after arrival), with local travel agencies or with tour operators.
Finally, be aware that the posted rate (or rack rate) is, like an automobile sticker price, usually just an approximation. According to the Pacific Asia Travel Association, for example, Shangri-La Hotels and Resorts said that only 3 percent of its customers paid the rack rate, and there is no reason to think it is much different at other upscale hotels, in Asia or elsewhere.
So keep in mind that "50 percent off" may be 50 percent off a rate almost no one is paying.
 
Air Fares
In the Asia-Pacific region, air fares fell 12 to 14 percent in dollar terms in the year ended last month, according to American Express, although those same fares actually rose almost 3 percent when bought in local currencies.
-- United Airlines, Continental, Korean Air and Asiana have all reduced round-trip air fares to South Korea from Los Angeles to as low as $550, from more than $700 last year.
-- Singapore Airlines, inaugurating service from Newark Airport last month, is offering a $699 Newark-Singapore round trip via Amsterdam. Travel must start by April 30 and be completed by June 30. (800) 742-3333.
-- Cathay Pacific's "All Asia Pass" flies round trip to Hong Kong from Los Angeles or New York for $999, including air travel for up to 17 other Asian destinations within 30 days after arriving in Hong Kong. Seniors, students and those who book on the airline's Web site receive a $100 discount. Good for travel through May 31 or between Aug. 20 and Dec. 15. For travel between June 1 and Aug. 19, add $400. The travel period can be extended to 45 days for an additional $100; 60 days ($200), or 90 days ($300). (800) 233-2742.
-- Malaysia Airlines has a variety of promotions. The most notable is a $739 round trip, plus four nights at any of 100 hotels in 19 locations throughout Malaysia. The offer is valid for any two or more passengers traveling together, booked together before May 15. Travel must commence by June 30.
Passengers who buy a full-fare economy ticket on Malaysia Airlines from North America to Asia will be upgraded to business class, business-class passengers to first class, and business and first-class passengers will receive free car service to and from the airport. Flights must be booked by Nov. 31, 1998, and travel must be completed by Jan. 31, 1999. (800) 552-9264.
-- A Thai Airways package to Bangkok, available through May, includes round-trip fare from Los Angeles ($739) or the East Coast ($999), four nights' free hotel, transfers, breakfasts and a variety of tours. (212) 265-6021, extension 1007 or 1009.

SECTION: Section 14CN; Page 3; Column 1; Connecticut Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1429 words

HEADLINE: Q&A/Joel Gordes;
Insurers, Risk and the Global Climate

BYLINE: By ROBERT DUBROW 

 BODY:
JOEL GORDES, an energy consultant, believes that Connecticut's multibillion-dollar insurance industry has a choice: face possible financial ruin from losses due to more frequent and severe storms, droughts and wildfires or commit some of the industry's considerable resources to efforts to stem global warming.
Mr. Gordes is a consultant to Dr. Jeremy Leggett, formerly of Greenpeace International, and now of Solar Century in Britain. Dr. Leggett began the discussions about climate change between insurers and environmentalists in Europe. 
 Mr. Gordes now engages in similar discussions with Connecticut and other United States insurers, proposing products he feels would both increase insurers' bottom lines and reduce emission of climate-changing gases.
Mr. Gordes has been involved in energy-related work since 1975, when he was hired by a solar energy company in Waterbury. He was vice chairman of the Connecticut General Assembly's energy committee when he served as a State Representative from 1987 to 1991.
A lifelong Connecticut resident, Mr. Gordes, 51, lives in Colebrook. In a recent interview, he discussed global warming and the insurance industry. Following are excerpts from that conversation.
Q. Why should the insurance industry be concerned about global warming?
A. The insurance industry is based upon stability of weather within certain types of boundaries.
There has to be an actuarial experience to be able to say, "This is what the premium should be for this property in this place." If climate is changing, the probability of risk changes, and that's not good. There could be more flooding, hail storms, intense wind storms, intense precipitation events.
Some recent research from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration says that climate change may make hurricanes worse. Brushfires could become urban firestorms if they come off the ridges and go into Los Angeles.
It's going to be erratic and volatile, and that's not a great situation to base insurance premiums on.
Q. What is the magnitude of losses from these kinds of events?
A. If Hurricane Andrew had hit a more populated and wealthy area, like Miami, it would have been a $50 billion loss rather than the $16.5 billion loss it was. If a similar event hit metropolitan New York, New Jersey and then went into Connecticut, it could be as much as $110 billion.
Q. Have insurance losses been increasing in the 1990's?
A. Of the 25 largest weather-related insurance losses in the United States, 21 have occurred in the past decade. There has been a remarkable increase in billion-dollar catastrophic losses. Two primary reasons are greater wealth and people building more in harm's way. However, even when you normalize for that, it appears there are other factors at work.
Q. With all the uncertainty involved in projecting the future of global climate, why should the insurance companies take this seriously?
A. Absence of certainty does not mean absence of risk. If you wake up at the end of the day and say, "What if I'm wrong, what if there really is climate change?" it may be too late by then to do anything about it. The insurance industry is the first in line to be bankrupt if climate change is real.
Q. What should the insurance industry do about climate change?
A. European insurers usually have staff climatologists on board. The United States industry, with the exception of Employers Reinsurance of Kansas, generally does not.
They need to start looking at the probabilities of what could happen. Then they can ask what they can do to help mitigate climate change that at the same time will increase their bottom line -- for instance, making their own facilities more energy efficient. They own tremendous amounts of property. It will make it lower cost to maintain, at the same time they are reducing emissions.
The other thing is reducing property-casualty losses through energy types of upgrades.
A few winters ago we had all the huge icicles, called ice dams, forming along the edges of roofs. They are caused by heat escaping from poorly insulated ceilings, melting the snow on the roof from below, the water running down over the unheated eaves, refreezing, working its way back under the shingles and causing water damage inside the home. Insulating the ceiling correctly and ventilating the air above it stops ice dams.
So here's a case where saving energy, which is saving emissions, saves future claims for the insurance industry. The insurance industry could say, "We're going to give you 10 percent off your insurance for three years, if you will insulate your ceiling."
Q. Did the insurance industry have a presence at the December global warming conference in Kyoto?
A. The European and Asian insurers certainly did, and they came out with some very, very strong statements calling for emission reductions. Even as far back as 1995, Lloyd's of London, Munich Reinsurance and Swiss Reinsurance were calling for reductions. The American industry has not been there.
Seventy-one insurers have signed a United Nations accord, pledging to consider the issues of climate change and other environmental problems in all business practices. Employers Reinsurance is the only United States company to sign.
Q. Have the European and Asian insurers been involved in encouraging energy efficiency?
A. They've gone even further. They've started to invest in renewable energy. Swiss Reinsurance has put money into a fund to help people in the third world with photovoltaics. There are a number of English insurers joining the campaign called Solar Century.
Q. Why can't insurance companies simply not insure vulnerable areas instead of trying to mitigate global warming?
A. Then you don't have much of a business. And you are going to have to have the insurer of last resort take over, which is usually the government. In the long run that usually doesn't work too well. Somebody has to pay somewhere. If you're an insurer, you calculate the risks and do your business. There are a lot of other tools they are developing to manage those risks, financial tools mostly, but that ignores what may be the biggest threat.
Q. Why can't insurance companies simply raise their rates as their response to global warming?
A. They have been doing that -- in Florida, in certain other prone areas. But remember, it's a regulated business, and the minute you start raising rates, people start squawking to their state senators and representatives and insurance commissioners. It's a politically driven process.
Q. Are there precedents for the insurance industry advocating social policy changes that would reduce risks?
A. Absolutely. What about the support they've given to Mothers Against Drunk Driving? What about seat belt safety and air bag safety? In one case they took some pension funds and invested them in businesses that created jobs for union members from whose pension funds the money came.
Why should insurance companies, if there is a solid link to climate change from fossil fuel emissions, be investing in fossil fuel projects? It's like a health insurance company investing in tobacco.
Q. What has been the response of United States insurance executives to your arguments?
A. They are, as insurers usually are, very cautious. They want to see more ironclad links before they begin to take action. However, a few are starting to make some statements, one that will be putting something in their annual report.
We've come up with certain reasons why the United States insurers have not followed in the footsteps of the European Community. The Europeans have more global exposure to losses. The Europeans do not have a massive disinformation campaign going on by their fossil fuel industry, as we do.
United States companies don't want to scare their stockholders and customers by saying climate change is imminent. Many also sell auto insurance. And one of the things we're going to have to do, if we want to stop emissions, is get a lot of people out of their autos.
Q. How important is this issue for Connecticut?
A. Connecticut's economy is still heavily invested in the insurance industry. Some statements were made by Republican State Chairman Chris DePino about how Democratic Senator Joseph I. Lieberman's support for climate change legislation and the Kyoto treaty holds a risk for him. I don't think the Republican chairman has reckoned with the threat that climate change could present to the insurance industry in his home state. So I think he's barking up the wrong tree.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Joel Gordes, at home in Colebrook, is trying to convince insurance companies that it will indeed pay to pursue alternate energy sources. (Don Heiny for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 2; Page 35; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 2147 words

HEADLINE: TELEVISION;
They Let the Talking Heads Talk, but They Set the Tone

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN 

 BODY:
IN the mists of television past, the on-screen interviewer was likely to be an anonymous scholar or an uncomfortable newspaper reporter, but by the time the rabbit ears had vanished and long before you could say "Hi, Larry!" a transformation had occurred. Tilling the fields of journalism, entertainment and hospitality, interviewers sowed a new profession: the reporter as video artist.
With the incessant and unnerving expansion of cable, the interviewers have continued to multiply. On duty at all hours, they are made-for-television inimitables, many of them more famous than most of their guests. Some carry on the journalistic mission; some wander afield into show business, celebrities tangling with celebrities. In reviewing the performances of a few of the best known of those who bring the nation some semblance of all the news all the time, we find ourselves reviewing a high-powered segment of their medium. 

THE SOPHISTICATE
Ted Koppel, "Nightline"
Mr. Koppel is distinguished by his know-it-all air. He winks at his audience as he dares his eminent guests to outwit him: "Mr. Berger, take a crack at the question that I put to Secretary Albright and which she evaded so skillfully." It's the smartest kid on the block against all comers.
Not long ago he twitted a Los Angeles police officer on the subject of symptoms of biological terrorism: "Everyone with a stuffy nose and a headache is now going to think, 'Oh, my God, that could be a biological weapon.' "
Yet he is not frivolous. He is a close listener with a knack for interpreting officials' words in a way they did not intend. After listening to a somewhat muddled explication about the prospects for Iraq by the national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger, Mr. Koppel clarified: "So Unscom" -- the United Nations inspection team -- "can't do its job now, won't be able to do its job after a bombing, I think we're agreed, right?" Mr. Berger did not improve his position by falling back on the Administration mantra: "It's up to Saddam Hussein. It's up to Saddam Hussein."
After listening to William S. Cohen, Secretary of Defense, go on about the need to bomb Iraq in order to send a signal to Iran, North Korea, Sudan and Libya, Mr. Koppel passed the ball to the Secretary of State, Madeleine K. Albright.
"And now," he said, "if I'm hearing Secretary Cohen directly, we are holding out the possibility of perhaps bombing Iran, North Korea----"
"No!" broke in Ms. Albright.
"No! No! You are wrong!" broke in Mr. Cohen.
It's the sort of question, a touch unfair perhaps, that compels his guests to sort out approximately what their talking points mean.
 
THE MAITRE D'
Charlie Rose, "The Charlie Rose Show"
Having established himself in the late-night spot on the PBS schedule, Mr. Rose provides a Vanity Fair of television, a mix of business and show business, art and politics, and personalities around town. His range is upscale by television standards. In a recent stretch, he supplied viewers with Anna Quindlen, the writer; Gary Oldman, the actor; Tom Peters, the business guru; Dr. Angela Christiano, the hair researcher; Joan Sutherland, the singer; Thomas Hoving, the former director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and Nathan Myhrvold of Microsoft. The rumpled air that goes with Mr. Rose's North Carolina accent somehow connects his guests with his audience.
Over the years, it seems to me, our nighttime Charlie has learned to listen more and fawn less. He still slips into flattery (proclaiming Joan Sutherland "the unparalleled operatic voice of the century" and introducing the actor Rupert Everett as "known for stealing audiences' hearts"), but he usually stops before he melts away.
One can quarrel with some of his subjects. Some viewers might have done without his unproductive dippings into the Monica Lewinsky stew, as if there were a shortage of that stuff on less fastidious channels. But he makes up for such lapses with reasonably adult conversations on heavy matters like the Asian economic crisis (led by Henry A. Kissinger and Richard C. Holbrooke) and gay rights.
Both those panels might have benefited from more difference of opinion among the panelists, especially the Kissinger team, lockstep boosters of the International Monetary Fund. But Mr. Rose, a born courtier, deserves some credit amid the talk-show brouhaha for avoiding contentiousness for its own sake. And this particular program produced a startling sentence from Mr. Kissinger: "I have no independent opinion." Now that's something you don't often hear on the tube.
 
THE GREETER
Larry King, "Larry King Live"
If at heart Charlie Rose wants to run a salon, Larry King wants to tend bar. He'll bend an elbow with any headliner who'll join him, serving up every brand of journalism lite. If fortune had taken Mr. King in a slightly different direction, he might have wound up as a political-machine glad-hander, with a big greeting to the world and an arm around the audience, which he admonishes, "Don't go away!" before each commercial break. For ambitious politicians, new-book authors, movie stars, publicity seekers of every breed, he provides a compliment, a blurb.
Depth is not Mr. King's strong suit. Popping restlessly from guest to guest, from call-in to call-in, he plays to limited attention spans. He's streetwise, operating down there somewhere between Barbara Walters and Geraldo Rivera. When Jeff Greenfield sits in for him, the tone of the show rises notably, perhaps at the expense of its ratings.
A lot more comfortable with personalities than with issues, Mr. King isn't put off by bottom feeding. Count on your host to squeeze every bit of juice out of the misadventures of Princess Diana, Paula Jones and Marv Albert (in between appearances of Ross Perot, in whom he seems to hold stock). If you're looking for the latest on Ms. Lewinsky, trust Mr. King to come through, even if it requires resorting to characters you wouldn't depend on for the right time. He is not much for wit, but when he asks a guest, "Why should we be interested in Monica?," he is his own parody.
Mr. King is television's regular guy. He asked the upright Senator Orrin G. Hatch about goings-on in the Oval Office: "If Hillary doesn't care, why's it your business?" He is given to male-bonding cracks, for example asking Representative John Conyers Jr., a Clinton defender, whether his female interns have access to him at all hours. You'll find no superior-than-thou affectations on "Larry King Live." His inelegant frankness -- never heard, be assured, on the "Lehrer News Hour" -- is his most winning quality.
 
THE RESPECTABLES
Jim Lehrer, Elizabeth Farnsworth, Phil Ponce and Margaret Warner, "The News Hour With Jim Lehrer"
The "News Hour" stalwarts are not always the most exhilarating company, but there is no doubting the seriousness of their mission. Their collective eye is on the issues.
Although David Gergen, everybody's former adviser, adds a smattering of bookishness to the "News Hour" and some essayist can be counted on to do some sports slumming at World Series time, the nightly focus is heavily on public affairs.
The reception for Washington regulars -- Cabinet members, Congressional bigwigs and such who travel the channels -- is notable for its workmanlike journalism and good breeding. Even at times, say the recent gives and takes between partisans of the White House and the special prosecutor, when a touch of rudeness prevailed elsewhere, the Lehrer team minded its manners. No guest need fear Koppel-style wise cracks, much less Sam Donaldson-style bluster. As for the audience, Mr. Lehrer's easy-going down-home approach to weighty matters invites trust.
All interviewers are at the mercy of their interviewees, which accounts for the bouts of ennui that particularly afflict PBS, but when Mr. Lehrer comes up with with a well-chosen guest or three he makes the most of the occasion. In his questioning of several visitors from Congress during the military buildup in the Persian Gulf, he pressed cordially but pointedly on the reluctance of America's putative allies to join in an attack and what such an attack might realistically accomplish. Mr. Lehrer is a master at playing off one opinion against another without setting anybody's teeth on edge, or giving a guest an inferiority complex.
The "News Hour" band is also notable for its attention to the thinking behind such matters as lawyers' maneuverings and judges' decisions. Interviewing a guest reporter about the appointment of a special prosecutor in the Bruce Babbit case, Mr. Lehrer typically led him in a sober direction: "Take us through the process." That's not a question to stir the juices, but in the television world, illuminating the workings of the system is rarer and more daring than delivering a dose of gossip or scoring an easy point.
 
THE SUNDAY MORNING SET
Sam Donaldson, Cokie Roberts and George Will, "This Week With Sam Donaldson and Cokie Roberts"
Bob Schieffer, "Face the Nation"
Tim Russert, "Meet the Press"
If "This Week" seems a touch schizophrenic, attribute it to the format, which halfway through the hour transforms its stars from reporters to opinionators. See Mr. Will turn in the blink of a commercial from the cultured interviewer into the committed (or commitable) right winger, who can always find occasion to stick it to the politically correct.
Mr. Will has the excuse of a well-stocked mind, an acquaintance with American history -- he can recite the provenance, with dates, of the special prosecutor law -- and a talent for a tidily turned phrase.
His colleagues perform without such assets. No sooner does Mr. Will make a provocative comment than Mr. Donaldson is likely to ground the discussion back to the obvious or the merely noisy. In a typical outing a few weeks ago, Congress's failure to pass a Federal drunk-driving standard brought interesting perspective from Mr. Will, Bill Kristol and George Stephanopoulos. Mr. Donaldson's contribution was to wax indignant about drunks killing children. He confesses, "Usually I try to dominate."
On his Sunday show, as at White House press conferences, Mr. Donaldson lives up to his reputation for a confrontational manner and persistence in reminding a guest that he has failed to address the question. The Donaldson theme is "I'm Forever Playing Gotcha." Knowing how to put a politician or a diplomat on the spot is a useful talent, but it can also reduce a complicated issue to a yes or no.
Carried away by his ratings and self-regard, Mr. Donaldson sometimes seems to be trying out for "The Sam Donaldson Hour," where he could exclusively interview himself.
Ms. Roberts trades on her Washington connections. Insidership is not synonymous with insight, but she has plainly read the morning papers before turning up for work, and often asks the sort of questions that will have occurred to her viewers, which is flattering enough to make her an audience favorite. It was Ms. Roberts who noted last Sunday that she had never seen politicians run away from contributions as fast as the Republicans are running from the tobacco industry. Anyway, her common-sense style complements that of the erudite Mr. Will and provides relief from the bumptious Mr. Donaldson.
Their Sunday-morning competitors, Mr. Russert and Mr. Schieffer, also find themselves up against politicians given to evasion and obfuscation. Both make worthy adversaries.
Mr. Schieffer, the CBS veteran who presides on "Face the Nation," is not the most exciting television personality around, but he compensates with solid experience and a professional mien. He knows the right questions and does not show off about it. Perhaps his want of pretension saves him from professional egomania. Unlike so many television journalists, he does not operate under the assumption that he is more interesting or important than his guests.
Over on "Meet the Press," Mr. Russert brings plenty of energy and research to his interviews. Although given to sappy little jokes about his hometown or favorite sports team, he is vigorous in pursuit of a tricky prey. He can be as tough as Mr. Donaldson but is more engaging.
Like all the other Sunday morning revelers, in recent months Mr. Russert has been in thrall to the Clinton-Lewinsky-Jones triangle, but he gets more fun out of the game. The other week, in a technique he previously used to memorable effect in exposing Louis Farrakhan, he asked William H. Ginsburg, Monica Lewinsky's lawyer, to explain a series of somewhat perplexing comments he had made since becoming a television mouthpiece. What, for example, did he mean by calling the relationship between the President and his client "collegial"? The fuzzy answer only dug him deeper into confusion, which after all, is one of the pleasures of the interview shows.

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
Fuji the Latest Addition to Bustling Raritan Center

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
BY next January a patch of land in the 2,300-acre Raritan Center business park in Edison will be transformed into the Northeast regional office and distribution center for Fuji Photo Film U.S.A., ushering in a new stage of growth for the giant park, and by extension, the city and that area of Middlesex County.
The new 465,000-square-feet building will rise on 20 acres at King George's Post Road and Clearview Avenue within the park, which straddles Edison and neighboring Woodbridge Township. 
 Fuji, based in Tokyo with corporate offices in Elmsford, N.Y., will shut down its present smaller regional office in Carlstadt, said Robert A. Fisher, the company's director of distribution.
The company, a manufacturer and marketer of imaging and information products, will lease the new building for 10 years from the developer, Federal Business Centers, of Edison. The estimated cost of the project is more than $30 million.
At the same time, construction of an overpass at Woodbridge Avenue (Route 514) is under way, along with elimination of one traffic light and the installation of three others.
The overpass will improve access to Raritan Center, among the largest taxpayers and employment centers in central New Jersey, and relieve traffic congestion along Woodbridge Avenue.
The $20 million cost of the improvements, expected to be completed by this fall, is being borne by the county and state as part of a public-private partnership, which includes the developer, property owners and local government.
Development at Raritan Center has been at a sluggish pace for most of this decade. But since the announcement of the overpass last year a 111,973-square-foot building has been completed for Federal Express and an 89,000-square-foot, multitenant speculative building, along with Fuji's, is under way.
Once occupied by the Raritan Arsenal, the center is now half developed with 13 million square feet of occupied space and some 300 companies employing over 13,000 workers.
The traffic improvements, contemplated for over 20 years, are integral not only in attracting new businesses to the area but in retaining existing ones, said David B. Crabiel, director of the Middlesex County Board of Freeholders, citing Fuji's move to illustrate his point.
"Without them Raritan Center and that whole area would not thrive as well as we anticipate it now will," Mr. Crabiel said.
Agreeing with that assessment is Peter Viceglia, president of Federal Business Centers, which owns 1,000 acres at Raritan Center and is one of two major developers developing the park; the other is the local Summit Associates. In real estate today the key is, "transportation, transportation, transportation," Mr. Viceglia said, adding a twist to the old developer mantra.
FORMING public-private partnerships to nudge along road-improvement projects and spur development is picking up momentum throughout the state as public aid for such projects dwindles. Another example is the widening of River Road, the main artery through the Bergen County community of Edgewater and its stretch of the Hudson River waterfront.
The first two-mile leg is finished and the second, just over two miles, is under way and expected to be completed next fall, fully opening up the riverfront corridor to development, county officials said. The cost of the $19 million project is being shared by developers and the county, state and local government.
In Edison the public-private partnership works like this:
The independent Middlesex County Improvement Authority sold low-interest bonds to finance 80 percent of the $20 million cost of the overpass; the remaining 20 percent is coming from the state's Department of Transportation.
Six property owners -- including Federal Business Centers and The New York Times, which has a printing plant not far from Raritan Center along Route 514 -- donated a total of five acres of land necessary to accommodate the overpass. Federal Business Centers also contributed $750,000 to the project.
The improvement authority will receive annual payments of $4 million from the state and $1 million from the county for four years to repay the bonds, said Sarah Clarke, the authority's director of economic development. This allows us "to move forward on the project now instead of later," she said.
The authority was anxious to move quickly to take advantage of the state's strong economy, which is encouraging companies to expand, and a low vacancy for industrial space in Middlesex County, which is encouraging developers to start new projects.
In the first quarter the county's available industrial space, with uses ranging from manufacturing, to high-technology and warehousing, dropped to 16 million from 17.9 million the same time in 1997. As a result, the county's vacancy rate fell to 10.87 percent from 12.4 percent, according to CB Commercial, the national commercial brokerage firm.
The company puts the vacancy rate in the submarket in and around Edison, including Raritan Center, at 7.92 percent, down from 9.1 percent the year before. In turn, the area's average asking rents rose 25 cents per square foot per year to $5.04. "It is a vibrant market," said Robert M. Singer, first vice president at the Teaneck office of CB Commercial, which represented Fuji in the Raritan Center transaction.
EDISON, with 96,000 people in 26 square miles, is the state's sixth largest city and one of its main assets is location, said Mayor George A. Spadoro. It is accessible to a web of major highways, including the New Jersey Turnpike, the Garden State Parkway and Interstate 287.
The new overpass "will open up the flood gate to new development," Mayor Spadoro said, saying that the tax revenue generated would enable the township to maintain high employment and low taxes. "Everyone benefits," he added.
In addition to the Fuji project, construction has started or will soon start on two others in Edison outside Raritan Center. One is a three-building, 1.3 million speculative project consisting of office, warehouse and distribution space. Rising on 55 acres at the 410-acre Industrial Park at the foot of Mill Road, it is being developed by the park's owner, Heller Industrial Parks.
Jeffrey J. Milanaik the company's president said he was moving forward with the project because "space in Edison is tight, especially for blocks of 300,000 square feet or more."
The other project is a warehouse distribution center with 830,000 square feet, including office space, on 50 acres along Nixon Avenue. The developer is Reckson Morris Industrial, a partnership of the Morris Companies of Secaucus and Reckson Associates Realty Corporation of Melville, L.I., a real estate investment trust.
"Companies are growing and as they grow they are consolidating into one site from scattered locations," said Ron Schram, senior vice president for marketing and leasing at Reckson Morris. "We are catching that trend."
He said the partners would seek final approval for the project next month and expect to start construction by July.
Mr. Singer of CB Commercial said Fuji had looked for three months before deciding on the Raritan Center site, which was selected from among 20 within as well as outside of the state. "Knowing that the road improvement was to be completed with a year was an important part of that decision," he added.
"It made the location more attractive," said Mr. Fisher of Fuji, adding that the city's granting the project a five-year tax abatement also helped.
Fuji will consolidate its operations, now in two buildings in Carlstadt, together totaling 325,000 square feet, into the 465,000 square foot building in Raritan Center.
"Being under one roof," Mr. Fisher said, "will enable us to operate more efficiently." He said the new building, which Fuji has the option of expanding by 50,000 square feet, would house some 200 employees.

SECTION: Section 11; Page 7; Column 1; Real Estate Desk
