HEADLINE: In the Region/Long Island;
A Surging Economy Revives the Hotel Industry

BYLINE: By DIANA SHAMAN 

 BODY:
WHEN Paul F. Amoruso, president of Island Hospitality in Jericho, and his partner, H. B. Gianos, bought the 136-room Best Western in Holtsville in 1995, the $5 million they paid represented one-third of its replacement cost.
The price was low because the hotel, like several others on Long Island, had failed in the early 90's because of plummeting demand for rooms in a struggling economy. 
 Now, with a revived hotel market bringing strengthening demand and rising room rates, Island Hospitality will begin a 57-room addition on May 1 -- the first new hotel construction in Suffolk County in almost a decade. Many other developers are also re-entering the Long Island market, or are eager to do so.
"Now that we have worked our way out of losses in the defense industry, and now that the computer, telecommunications and biotechnology industries have grown," said Michael Hollander, president of the Long Island Convention and Visitors Bureau in Hauppauge, "the need for hotel rooms has been rising, and I expect to see about 1,000 new rooms coming on line over the next three years."
New hotels will include two Extended Stay America hotels, one in Bethpage with 104 rooms on which construction is to begin in mid-May and one in Melville with 134 rooms due to start in December.
In addition, a 129-room Wingate Inn in Garden City is to start in 90 days, and a 163-room Red Roof Inn in Westbury starts in the fall. And construction is to start this summer on a 122-room Marriott Residence Inn in Islip near MacArthur Airport.
The Parkoff Organization of Great Neck plans to build a 218-room hotel and conference center in Long Beach once it has the financing. Manhattan East Suite Hotels of Manhattan is looking for a site. Urgo Butts & Company of Chevy Chase, Md., developer of the Residence Inn in Islip, is considering additional Residence Inns in Uniondale -- where it owns the 615-room Long Island Marriott -- and in Stony Brook. And Breslin Realty Development of Garden City hopes to attract a hotel to its upcoming Brookhaven Town Center mall in Yaphank.
Other hotels have undergone major renovations, or are now being upgraded. Apple Core Hotels of Manhattan, for example, is spending $2 million on improvements to the 182-room Best Western Hotel and Conference Center in Hempstead. The 360-room Wyndham Wind Watch Hotel in Hauppauge got a $1.5 million overhaul last year.
Rising room rates and occupancies are the obvious lure. At the Best Western in Holtsville, for example, income this year is 30 percent above projections, with the occupancy rate now 85 percent, up from 67 percent a year ago, said Mr. Amoruso of Island Hospitality.
"Usually when a market achieves occupancies above 70 percent it means there is unaccommodated demand, and that definitely exists in the Nassau County market," said Marie K. Laib, a senior analyst with Hospitality Valuation Services in Mineola, a hotel industry consultant.
With several developers like Breslin planning large retail and commercial projects in Suffolk, " I think we'll see moderate growth in hotel construction there as well," she added.
In 1997, the average occupancy rate on Long Island increased to 73.1 percent from 72 percent in 1996, and the average daily room rate increased to $96.79 from $89.66, according to Smith Travel Research of Hendersonville, Tenn., an independent research firm that tracks hotel-industry performance and surveys hotels with 20 or more rooms.
There actually has been a shrinkage over the last six years in the number of rooms available on Long Island, said Chuck Ross, the company's vice president. In 1992 there were 120 properties with 10,900 rooms; in 1997 there were 118 with 10,500 rooms, he noted.
Analysts say that new growth is being stifled by the difficulty of developing on Long Island. "Zoning and environmental laws make it tougher to build on Long Island and in Manhattan than in 98 percent of the rest of the country," said Michael J. Rietbrock, a senior lodging analyst at Salomon Smith Barney.
Manhattan East Suite Hotels has been looking for a site on Long Island for well over a year, said Daniel J. Denihan, one of the partners in the company, which owns and operates 10 hotels in Manhattan.
SHOULD its search be successful, the hotel chain will join others in bringing a relatively new concept to Long Island -- accommodations that have kitchenettes so that they can cater to the traveler who stays a week or more.
Marriott Residence Inns was one of the early pioneers of the concept, but its room rates are equivalent to, or even exceed, those in full-service hotels. The 160-room Residence Inn in Plainview, which is owned and operated by Urgo Butts, has until now had the extended-stay market on Long Island to itself.
Now with Extended Stay America of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., planning to complete both of its hotels over the next 13 months, the budget-conscious traveler will have a less costly option. Room rates at its Long Island hotels are expected to be in the range of $199 to $299 a week, compared with about $1,113 to $2,275 a week charged by the Residence Inn in Plainview.
Extended Stay America, whose shares are traded on the New York Stock Exchange, is a three-year-old company that already owns and operates 218 properties nationwide and has 75 under construction. To maintain its room rates in a range of $159 to $399 a week -- with the variation depending on geographic area and services offered -- amenities are kept to a minimum. There are no restaurants and usually no pools. Front desks close at 11 P.M. Housekeeping is an extra charge.
The 104-room Bethpage facility, which is to be built on a 2.6-acre site on South Oyster Bay Road that was formerly part of the Northrop Grumman complex, is expected to open in December. The 136-room hotel in Melville, expected to open in May 1999, will be built on a 4.9-acre site on Spagnoli Road, off Route 110.
Extended-stay hotels "are a tremendous growth area though they currently represent only 2 percent of all the rooms in the United States," said Mr. Ross of Smith Travel Research.
He said that Long Island, with its switch from the military industry to high technology, would probably be a good market for these types of accommodations, because high technology draws trainees and consultants who want to stay for a longer period.
Still, more traditional hotels are also coming to Long Island, including the 129-room Wingate Inn, to be built on a two-acre site on Stewart Avenue and South Street in Garden City. It will cater to the business traveler by offering a business center with facsimile machines, printers, copiers and other equipment along with meeting rooms. Individual rooms will have computer hookups and voice mail. Wingate Inns of Parsippany, N.J. is a three-year-old chain that has 28 hotels in operation throughout the country.
The Garden City project, where room rates will be about $90 a day, is being developed by a joint venture of the Albanese Development Corporation and Albert L. Salvatico, a private investor, both of Garden City. The five-story hotel was designed by Ronald Schmidt & Associates of Englewood, N.J.
The hotel will be entering an underserved market, said Russell G. Matthews, the executive vice president of Albanese, noting that central Nassau contains millions of square feet of office and retail space. Hofstra University and Nassau Community College add to the demand for hotel space and spillover demand is also coming from Manhattan, he said. Yet only two major hotels, the Marriott in Uniondale and the 280-room Garden City Hotel, serve the area.
However, a 163-room Red Roof Inn will also start construction this year on a three-acre site not far from the Wingate, which is on the former Roosevelt Raceway property in Westbury. Red Roof Inns is leasing the parcel from MCS Realty Partners of Manhattan, which has built 600,000 square feet of retail space on another portion of the former Raceway site.
Red Roof, based in Hilliard, Ohio, has 260 properties in 35 states and the District of Columbia, and is in the economy category, with daily room rates of $45 to around $100. It offers business amenities but no pools or health clubs. The company is looking for several other sites on Long Island in addition to the one in Westbury, said Gail B. Whitcomb, a senior vice president.
Although developers are optimistic that Long Island's hotel market will not become oversaturated despite all the new projects and proposals, others recommend some caution.
"I agree that the outlook is good, but in any market you have to be careful of overbuilding and Long Island is no exception," said Ms. Laib of Hospitality Valuation Services.

SECTION: Section 14LI; Page 1; Column 2; Long Island Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 2000 words

HEADLINE: Indian Nations Wary of Restrictions on Tobacco

BYLINE: By MARY REINHOLZ 

 BODY:
TO get to Chief Harry B. Wallace's Smoke Shop and Trading Post, you have to drive over the railroad tracks in Mastic and wind through a maze of suburban streets until you reach a dirt road on the Poospatuck Reservation.
Signs leading to the rustic store advertise prices for tax-free cigarette brands, the only industry in this quiet low-income enclave of 250 Native Americans. 
 Even in the pouring rain on a recent weekday, there was a steady trickle of customers entering Indian land in Suffolk County to buy cigarettes at the shop, one of three owned by tribal entrepreneurs selling tobacco and other products on the wooded 55-acre property that is part of the Unkechaug nation.
"I'm addicted and know I'm going to die from smoking, but I'm on a fixed income and these save me money," said Bob Rozycki, 52, of Ridge, who said he buys about five cartons of Marlboros there a month.
Mr. Rozycki figures he saves at least $5 on each carton. Marlboros were on sale that day at $15.75 each, reduced from about $18.25. If state sales taxes were included, they would go for about $23 to $24 each. A carton bearing the name Omaha, the first brand made at a reservation in Nebraska and distributed by Mr. Wallace in New York, was selling for $9.75.
Mr. Wallace, a Dartmouth graduate, is a New York City lawyer who relocated to the Poospatuck reservation in 1991 and started his successful business from a trailer on his mother's property. He has done so well with his business that he has built, besides his current store, a two-story house.
Mr. Wallace smoked during an interview at his nearby law office, puffing on an Omaha that he contends is less addictive than non-Indian cigarettes.
"No one denies that cigarettes are bad for your health," he said. But the major tobacco companies have made it exceedingly worse by the addition of preservatives and additives. You have to understand that Native people have always had tobacco. We're trying to bring tobacco back to a more non-abusive use. That's what the Omaha people are doing. We are abeing punished for the bad acts of other people."
Mr. Wallace said the anti-tobacco legislation, if enacted, would put a dent in the fragile economy of the Poospatuck reservation "because all but four people" are employed in some fashion as a result ofthe three smoke shops.
Of course, the price of all cigarettes across America will be sharply increased, forced up to $1.10 extra a pack by the year 2003, should the recent landmark anti-tobacco legislation get voted into law by both houses of Congress.
The legislation was introduced by Senator John D. McCain, Republican of Arizona, and passed 19-1 by the Commerce Committee that he chairs. It has strong bipartisan support despite the fact that the major cigarette manfacturers have said they will not cooperate with the new legislation, saying it would put them out of business.
Mr. McCain's bill contains provisions about the sale of cigarettes on tribal land and considers tribes as states for the purposes of eligibility for public health funding to treat tobacco-related illnesses.
According to Senator Ben Nighthorse Campbell, Republican of Colorado and chairman of the Senate Committee on Indian Affairs, "The Senate tobacco legislation protects traditional and ceremonial uses of tobacco and respects tribal authority to make and enforce laws on Indian lands."
Nonetheless, Mr. Wallace, who is also president of the Long Island Native American Business Association, is concerned that the Federal Government will require states to impose taxes on reservations that sell tobacco to non-Indians despite tribal sovereignty -- an issue that New York's reservations won last year after a bitter showdown with Gov. George E. Pataki.
There are nine Indian nations in New York. Two Long Island reservations have smoke shops selling tobacco without state sales taxes: the Poospatuck, one of two New York tribes that had refused to sign any tax compact with the state, and the Shinnecock reservation in Southampton, which also has three smoke shops operated by Native Americans. Mr. Wallace does not quibble with efforts by Federal legislators to curtail teen-age smoking, which Senator Campbell has described as at an 80 percent level on Indian reservations and tobacco use there in general at "crisis levels."
But the chief said he was prepared to go to Washington -- "en masse, if necessary" -- to lobby against an amendment to the McCain bill, introduced by Senator Slate Gorton, a Republican from Washington.
The amendment, passed by a 10-9 vote, specifies that tribes "or tribal corporations" shall collect any excise or sales tax imposed by a state within the exterior borders where the sale occurs on "non-members of the Indian tribe" who buy tobacco products. In turn, the amendment provides, the taxes would be remitted to the Treasurer of the United States who would remit them to the state where the transaction took place.
"This is a continuation of Senator Gorton's agenda, which is to abrogate totally our treaty rights and destroy the sovereignty of Indians," Mr. Wallace said. "What does he want -- to have people marked with some kind of designation? If this bill is passed in its current form it could halt Native American economic development dead in its tracks."
Because of treaty rights, states are generally barred from enforcing state laws and taxes on tribes. Indeed, a spokeswoman for Senator McCain said he opposed the Gorton amendment "because he opposes any state taxation on tribal lands because of the longstanding Federal law that tribal lands are tax exempt."
Mr. Wallace, noting that New York has no law prohibiting Indian sales to non-Indians, noted, "That's the precise issue of sovereignty Governor Pataki has said will be respected for Indian nations."
Last year Mr. Pataki abandoned his attempt to collect taxes on cigarettes and gasoline sold on Indian reservations to non-Indians, estimated by state officials at about $100 million a year. At one point the New York Department of Taxation and Finance had seized trucks with shipments bound to reservations to insure they were in compliance with a department tax regulation, said a department spoksman, Kevin Quinn.
Protests erupted as 1,000 Native Americans and their supporters blocked traffic along a 30-mile stretch of the New York State Thruway near Buffalo, burning tires and clashing with state troopers.
Mr. Quinn said that because of smoke caused by the tire burning, a car passenger was killed in a collision with a tractor trailer.
Last May 22, in a drastic policy shift, Mr. Pataki asked the Department of Taxation and Finance to repeal the tax regulation. Today, said Michael McKeon, a spokesman for Mr. Pataki, "The Governor's position is that nations should have the right to control over their own economy. This has been a tradition in New York for centuries."
But the issue, which also plagued Mr. Pataki's Democratic predecessor, Mario Cuomo, remains a complex one. Last year the New York Association of Convenience Stores sued the State Department of Taxation and Finance in an effort to compel it to enforce the very regulation the agency is now trying to repeal. The case is before the New York Court of Appeals in Albany, the highest court in the state.
Meanwhile, said Mr. Quinn, the Governor is looking into legislation that would exempt Indians from collecting taxes from the sales of tobacco or motor fuel purchased by non-Indians.
James B. Crane 2d, a lawyer whose Albany firm is pressing the lawsuit on behalf of the New York Association of Convenience Stores, contends "that Native Americans have historically used sovereignty as a shield in a prophylactic fashion," adding, "It's a nice buzz word, but sovereignty is a limited doctrine."
Mr. Crane said that the National Association of Convenience Stores "is looking to New York to develop a methodology that respects Native American sovereignty but also results in having taxes collected and thereby leveling the economic playing field." He added: "It's not just a problem in New York, it's a problem in about 18 other states."
The problem for non-Indian tobacco merchants translates to unfair competition, said Michael Cuomo, owner of Mike's One Stop Shop, a convenience store in Mastic Beach. Mr. Cuomo (no relation to the former Governor) said that he once owned a successful smoke shop across the street from his convenience store but it lost "80 percent" of its sales after Mr. Wallace began selling tax-free tobacco on the nearby Poospatuck Reservation in 1992.
"One of the problems for retailers is the unfair competition and the fact that the government permits tax evasion on a mass level," Mr. Cuomosaid. "I respect Indian sovereignty but the tribes don't benefit from the money being made at retail locations -- only the entrepreneurs. Mr. Pataki and his predecessors have chosen to make public policy based on anarchy and threats of violence at the reservations as opposed to the rule of law."
Last month, Assemblyman Jeffrey Klein, Democrat of the Bronx, charged that Indian reservations in New York were becoming spawning grounds for cigarette bootlegging.
"Someone can pull up with a van and buy 250 cartons a day," he said, "and sell them in a day all over the city on the black market."
"That's absurd," Mr. Wallace responded when informed of the allegation. "I don't known what evidence he has, but it's already been established that the overwhelming bulk of transactions are legitimate and for personal use."
John Dossett, general counsel for the National Congress of American Indians in Washington, said there were 1.5 million people living on Indian reservations in America and "hundreds" of compacts and agreements that Indian tribal governments across the country have worked out for collection of state taxes.
"Some of the compacts are written so the tribe collects the taxes and remits to the state based on a formula of how many people live in an area compared to the non-Indians," he said.
"In other states," Mr. Dossett noted, "the tribe collects and keeps the taxes to run the schools and bridges. Indian tribes have a 31 percent poverty rate on Indian reservations and a 56 unemployment rate, according to 1990 census figures. So the amount of economic deprivation is incredible. Indian tribes have been trying their hands at all kinds of economic development."
Mr. Wallace will not disclose annual volume sales on tobacco products bought at his store, but he says that the three tribal smoke shops together employ "directly or indirectly" most of the adults on the reservation, many of whom, he said, had previously been on welfare and other forms of public assistance. He added that the smoke shop "makes direct surcharge payments to the nation for the licensing privilege to operate."
Elected chief for five successive one-year terms, Mr. Wallace went to Dartmouth as an undergraduate on a full scholarship. His wife, Margo ThunderBird, a Shinnecock, has joined him in converting his former smoke shop into a community cultural center where, he said, children are taught the language of the Unkechaug nation.
Mr. Wallace, who also manages reservation programs such as a food bank and summer youth projects, said that he knew he would encounter resistance when he first started his smoke shop after receiving approval from the seven-member tribal council.
But he added: "I didn't realize the extent of the resistance back then. My background as an attorney enabled me to withstand some of the negative onslaught we got from some folks. I got death threats from people who would say, 'If you continue to run this, I'm going to blow your place up.' "
Asked why a Native American merchant would be the target of such hatred, Mr. Wallace didn't hesitate in his reply. "Because we're supposed to be impoverished," he said, "to subsist within a welfare economy and not succeed in any way shape or form. That makes it complacent and keeps the status quo."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Chief Harry B. Wallace at his Poospatuck Reservation smoke shop and trading post. (Lois Raimondo for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Change Is Part of Temporary Worker's Job

BYLINE: By ROBIN F. DeMATTIA 

 BODY:
NIKE OTUYELU of New Rochelle, who is studying for a master's degree in management at Baruch College in Manhattan, needs money for expenses like almost any student. She found the solution as an office temporary, taking a job where she sets her own hours -- days, nights or weekends -- and can apply the theories she learns in class.
"I've been learning a lot more about an industry I really had no interest in initially," Ms. Otuyelu said of her job at Oxford Health in White Plains. "And temping allows you to build skills you wouldn't normally aim to develop, such as learning to be very flexible, time management and how to prioritize." 
 Unlike the older practice of filling in for an ill secretary, temporary workers today range from administrative support personnel to graphic designers, accountants, lawyers, marketing specialists and top executives. The industry has grown from $20.5 billion in annual receipts in 1991 to a record $43.6 billion in 1996, with an average daily employment level of 2.3 million people.
"The industry is continuing to grow because it makes a lot of economic and life-style sense," said Catherine Candland, chief executive officer and founder of Advantage Staffing Services, which has headquarters in Stamford.
"When I first got into the staffing field 13 years ago, we were placing people in positions because someone was out sick or on maternity leave," Ms. Candland said. "The business world was not really as adept at the idea of bringing in talent that was temporary. But the caliber of person doing temporary work is much more diverse now than it was then. Many people who are between 22 and 50 are starting to recognize that your career is something that you manage. And I think businesses certainly see the advantages of bringing talent in for certain projects and having a leaner core staff."
Ms. Candland's understanding of the industry has made her company highly successful and brought her kudos from the group of temporaries, called associates, who work for her as well as the companies that are her clients. Advantage, which provides temporary, interim and alternative staffing for small companies to those on the Fortune 100 list, has offices throughout the state and in Connecticut, Pennsylvania, Maryland, Virginia, Washington and Texas. The company has experienced 35 percent growth a year since its founding and had close to $100 million in revenues last year, making it the largest company owned by a woman in Connecticut as well as the largest independent staffing concern in Connecticut. Ms. Candland has been named to Fortune's list of "America's 40 Smartest Entrepreneurs," has been called Southern New England Entrepreneur of the Year by Ernst & Young and Entrepreneur Magazine, listed in Entrepreneur Magazine's list "40 under 40" and on Mirabella's list of "1,000 Most Influential Women in the United States." She also received an American Express "Vendor of the Year Award" last year.
Advantage was one of the first companies to offer benefits -- health, dental, life insurance, a 401 (k) plan, paid holidays, vacations and free training -- to temporaries as well as its own full-time employees. Ninety-five percent of Advantage temporaries are rated above average to excellent, according to company statistics, and the company has a retention rate for temporaries of 600 percent more than the industry average (nine months compared with two to six weeks).
"Advantage doesn't waste my time with candidates who don't fit the bill," said Len Johnson, human resources manager at Fuji Color Processing in Elmsford. "If they don't have someone that's right for the position, they'll tell me that. So when I use an Advantage temp, it's the right person as opposed to someone who's forced to fit."
Mr. Johnson said Fuji uses temporary workers primarily for clerical and customer service positions, though when he was with a previous employer, Mr. Johnson hired a human resources manager who was an Advantage associate at the time.
"Managers are sometimes skeptical about bringing in a temp when they have a permanent position they need to fill," he said. "But they have in many cases found they like the temp enough to make a hire, and there's far less risk of hiring someone who has already been temping because they've done the job and you know their skills and background."
The National Association of Temporary and Staffing Services reports that more than 6 million former temporary employees moved into permanent jobs in 1996 (5.3 million were full-time positions), with almost 40 percent of the jobs being filled by clients of a temp company.
May Bloomer Bartels falls into that category. She worked as an associate with Advantage during 1996 and 1997 and last summer was hired as art director at Knowledge Industries in White Plains, one of the companies where she had been a temp.
"I was very conscious of the kind of work I wanted," said Ms. Bartels, who operated her own sculpture studio while working as a temporary. "Advantage was very considerate of whether the work was challenging enough for me, and they had a good body of clients. I stayed with clients for several months at a time, which is good because you are given more responsibility on your project. You're not simply a fill-in."
Ms. Bartels said she knew Advantage was right for her from the first meeting. "One of the things that impressed me about Advantage was their careful screening process. I was there for four hours. They tested me on the computer, looked at my portfolio and gave me an extensive interview." Now that Ms. Bartels contracts for temporary workers for her company, she said she knows "the person Advantage is sending is truly capable."
For those who are not quite ready for a job, Advantage offers free computer training. "We are getting very highly qualified professionals who want to work with Advantage; we just need more of them," said Jacqui Gray, director of sales in the Advantage office in White Plains. "And if you can't find them, you have to create them. We'll help train people in computer skills, because you have to keep up with the changes almost every week. You can't beat it, so you've got to join it."
Ms. Gray's job involves meeting with company representatives to discuss their needs. "Companies are turning to staffing firms for more ideas," she said. "We're all going through a problem with recruiting, because the unemployment rate is so low. We've teamed up with our clients to do job fairs together. We screen resumes for our clients and work as a contract recruiter, and we're working closer with schools and colleges, doing more presentations to tell students what the expectations are in the marketplace."
She observed that "10 years ago, companies may have had bigger budgets and would typically staff positions, but now, especially because technology is changing so much, they bring in more specialized people for special projects."
Cheryl Considine, director of art and catalogue production at Amscan Inc. in Elmsford, uses Advantage associates for presentations and art compositions. "We often need temporary help for special projects that we get short notice on. And because I have really good communication with Advantage, 95 percent of the time the caliber of the worker is exactly what we're looking for." The only disadvantage of using temporaries, she said, is that "once in a while you get someone you're happy with and they take a position somewhere else because there's no long-term commitment. But we expect that."
Short-term assignments suit Nicole Powell of White Plains just fine. "If I need time off, it's very easy for me to go ahead and take it," she said. Ms. Gray said that some of the older temporaries take the winter off, while they live in Florida for the season, and others like the opportunity to have more than two weeks' vacation.
Ms. Otuyelu said, "The only thing I really don't like is the uncertainty, but that also happens with a full-time job."
The assignment length is often economical to the companies. "It usually works out well for a temp to be here a certain time, because it avoids a placement fee," Mr. Johnson said, referring to a person hired full time. "When compared to recruiting, it's equivalent to or cheaper to hire someone temp to perm."
While some assignments turn into permanent jobs, the main focus is on short-term positions. "There's a great interest by people who want to be independent contractors and control their own job growth and destiny," Ms. Gray said. "I think part of it is Generation X, where people don't want to get tied down to one company or such a routine. My generation, the Baby Boomers, worked 80 hours a week, and it was ridiculous. We sacrificed our home life. The new group coming up is not going to turn out like that. They've learned from us that you can burn out quickly."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Rachael Ramsey, right, of Advantage Staffing Services with Moice Dixon and Drana Gjuraj, temporary workers. (Susan Farley for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Going Once, Gone! Action's Fast In Real Estate

BYLINE: By FRED MUSANTE 

 BODY:
KEVIN AND LINDA SMITH were looking for a new home with more room for themselves, their two sons and Mr. Smith's dog training business.
A four-bedroom farmhouse built in 1810 with nine acres of land in Canton beckoned. Mr. Smith said he and his wife first saw it at 1 P.M. on March 1, and five hours later they signed a contract with the owner. 
 The dizzying speed of the agreement left them a little queasy because they hadn't even put their own house on the market yet. But their anxiety evaporated when their house also sold quickly.
"We had our house on the market for 20 to 25 days," he said. "We didn't have a lot of showings, but the third or fourth person who came here to look at it was the one who bought it."
The buyers, another young family, also moved quickly. Mr. Smith said they began negotiating over the price less than an hour after walking in the door, and signed a contract the next day. Apparently concerned that the Smiths might be lured away by a better offer, the buyers gave them a significant nonrefundable down payment in return for a contract stipulation taking the house off the market.
Connecticut is enjoying its best residential real estate market in a decade. Houses are selling in days, instead of languishing for months, and it isn't unusual for sellers to receive multiple offers, some of them topping the listing price.
Real estate brokers compare the current market to the heady 80's, but with an important difference: prices so far have remained stable, rather than soaring upward driven by high demand and low supply. And real estate agents can only complain that good properties aren't coming on the market fast enough to keep up with the buying spree.
"It's about time," said John Alubicki, manager of DeWolf New England Real Estate in Avon, which represented the Smiths.
"I can't tell you if it's up 19 percent, 25 percent, or 75 percent, and I don't care," said Barbara Schmerzler, a broker in Westport and president of the Connecticut Association of Realtors. (A spokesperson at the association's office in Hartford said home sales in January and February were 19 percent higher than the same two months in 1997.)
Ms. Schmerzler attributed the rise in market activity to improvement in the economy, the burgeoning stock market and generally high consumer confidence across the nation. People are no longer afraid of losing their jobs, she said.
Further fueling the market are the lowest mortgage interest rates in 20 years, she added. Many renters have found it cheaper to buy a house than continue to rent, especially since a shortage of attractive apartments has driven up rents across the state. And new Federal tax regulations allowing sellers to keep more of their capital gains have also generated a lot of selling and buying.
Ms. Schmerzler also said that different regions of the state have different forces at work in their markets.
Fairfield County has seen New Yorkers, flush with money from bonuses and stock portfolios, competing with corporate executives relocating from other states, and with residents who want to buy a bigger house or move into a better neighborhood.
Litchfield County, especially around Sharon and Kent, is attracting New Yorkers looking for a second home, as well as retirees from around the state. Many of these retirees are in their 50's and 60's, rather than the septuagenarians who characterized this group in the past, Ms. Schmerzler said.
Throughout the center of the state, the improving economic climate for small businesses has generated a lot of buying and selling among young families and first-time buyers, as well as early retirees who often use their nest eggs to open small businesses. Along the shoreline, retirees and prosperous families are competing for views of Long Island Sound.
Prices in the suburbs, Ms. Schmerzler said, range from around $90,000 for small Cape Cods and condominiums in communities like East Hartford and Manchester to $300,000 to $500,000 for an average house in Westport, to estates priced in millions of dollars in New Canaan and Darien. In every region, it has become very difficult to find an attractive, well-kept house with a good location at the lower end of the price range.
The large cities -- Bridgeport, New Haven and Hartford -- haven't seen their real estate markets improve as much as in the rest of the state, but Ms. Schmerzler said single-family homes and condominiums in those communities have just begun selling faster.
Brokers first noticed the improving home market last summer, and it has accelerated steadily since then. The spring season used to be the busiest, but that tradition ended about 10 years ago, said Marilyn Maurer, a broker in Madison. Usually, the market slows down around Christmas and New Year's, but not this time, which gave it a lot of momentum with which to start 1998, she said. The snowless, mild winter kept builders at work and buyers on the hunt.
Harry and Lois Fischer, of Avon, wanted to buy a condominium for their daughter, Sharon, who was renting. They found a unit they liked, also in Avon, last September, and found themselves in a bidding battle.
"There were three other people who wanted that condo all on the same night," Mrs. Fischer said. The asking price for the unit was $132,000, and their bid of $130,000 prevailed.
Similarly, Thomas and Charlene Bayley bought a condominium in Avon. Mr. Bayley, who is employed in Buenos Aires, said they wanted a home base in Connecticut and that they had had a difficult time finding a suitable house to rent last April, finally convincing a home seller to take his property off the market and lease it to them for a year.
In December, the Bayleys went into the market as buyers, looking for a condominium in a gated and guarded complex. They found it in a little over two hours on New Year's Eve, quickly agreed with the owner on a price, signed a contract on Jan. 2 and closed on Jan. 30.
The house they had rented, which the owner was unable to sell a year ago, was recently sold without even being listed, Mr. Bayley said.
That the ease and speed with which houses sell, and the bidding battles that sometimes occur, haven't driven up prices is a curious phenomenon. Ms. Schmerzler said that "buyers are picky," and don't want to get into the situation that some people who bought in the late 80's found themselves. Many bought houses at prices that by the 90's exceeded the value of their properties.
Some brokers are concerned, nonetheless. "I get a little worried about it, because if a nice house comes on the market at a reasonable price, there are two or three offers on it at the asking price," said Anne M. Smith, a broker in Fairfield. "That's what happened in the 80's."
For the moment the housing market demands buyers with steady nerves and a checkbook at hand. "The number of situations in which there are multiple offers is something we're seeing quite frequently," said Mr. Alubicki. "It's a daily occurrence."
One of the real estate agents in his office recently had a buyer who was interested enough in a property to make an offer that was higher than the listing price, but lost it to a still higher bidder.
"If people don't move quickly, step up to the plate and make an offer, they can lose it," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: In Ridgefield, the sign in a broker's window shows the slashes indicating houses sold. Throughout the state, sales are moving quickly as the economy improves and the job market seems less threatening. (Chris Maynard for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: What's Ahead for Ocean Beach?

BYLINE: By JULIE MILLER 

 BODY:
OCEAN BEACH PARK in New London was glamorous in the 1940's. Vacationers from Hartford and from Springfield, Mass., rented cottages and rooms near the beach, known for its fine-grained sand and spectacular views of Long Island Sound. Visitors strolled on the boardwalk and in the evening danced to the music of the big bands in the recreation hall.
On a hot summer night, Letitia Smith could hear the music of Tommy Dorsey's orchestra and the laughter of the dancers from her home across the street. "I was a young teen-ager. My mother let me go over and stand in the ballroom at the foot of the stage. I got autographs from all the big bands," said Ms. Smith, who lived in New London for 55 years and is now a resident of Uncasville. 
 Ronnie Hodge, who lives a block and a half from the beach, recalled that the boardwalk was lined with food stands. Boys, perched on the railing, eyed the cliques of girls walking by. The miniature golf course was in its prime, and traveling carnivals set up rides and other attractions in the parking lot.
Over the past 20 years, however, the beach has fallen victim to the same forces that have drained New London -- hard times and the flight of businesses and residents from the city. The small amusement park, which attracted busloads of schoolchildren on day trips, is gone. The picnic pavilion and some of the food stands need repair. The terrace of the main building, which overlooks the Sound, is crumbling. Sections of the building are boarded up. Places where flowers once flourished are empty patches of soil. Attendance during the summer has fallen from more than a million to fewer than 300,000.
Ms. Smith and Ms. Hodge are members of Save Ocean Beach, a group formed a year and a half ago to stop the deterioration of the beach, owned by the city, and restore it as a public recreation park. Members of the group are particularly upset with the condition of the buildings. And they are dissatisfied with the way the city has managed the beach. They urged the City Council last December not to let another summer season begin without renovating the buildings. But the council decided to delay major changes until completion of a study of the beach by Wallace Roberts & Todd, an urban planning firm.
Save Ocean Beach members welcomed the news that the beach was included in the properties to be analyzed by the Wallace firm, which was hired by the New London Development Corporation, a group focused on economic development in the city. The firm will consider how to increase the economic potential of Ocean Beach as a public park. The firm is expected to make its recommendations by summer.
A heartening sign, like the Wallace firm's study, is something New Londoners haven't seen in a long time. "Everybody has been so down on New London," said Ms. Hodge. "It was as though somebody gave the city a vote of confidence."
The firm has also been assigned to design a plan for the peninsula area made up of the former New London Mills property, the Naval Undersea Warfare Center, the city wastewater treatment plant and other privately held land. The sites are a five-minute drive from Ocean Beach. The New London Development Corporation hopes to attract biotechnology research operations and other commercial and recreational projects to the peninsula. Pfizer Inc. is to be the anchor company of the development with a $150 million building at the New London Mills site on Pequot Avenue.
Members of Save Ocean Beach offered their ideas for improving the beach at a meeting with Richard Collier, a senior associate with the Wallace firm. They said they envisioned the beach as a family recreation area and discussed turning the bathhouse, which is seldom used, into a community center. They also suggested rebuilding the picnic area and adding a pier for fishing, a nature trail, a seafood restaurant and activities for teen-agers.
Members of the group said they want the beach to remain city-owned and compatible with the surrounding residential neighborhood. "We've been paying taxes for this beach," one member added. "It belongs to the people of New London."
A hotel and conference center is another of the many ideas mentioned for Ocean Beach. Stephen Percy, a real estate agent and board member of the New London Development Corporation, said such a center would help the park become self-supporting. But Claire Gaudiani, who is president of Connecticut College and of the New London Development Corporation, said she didn't think the corporation had any definite interests yet, since plans for the beach are in the early stages.
New London's City Manager, Richard Brown, asked that Ocean Beach be added to the list of properties to be studied by the Wallace firm. "There are a number of ideas that would be attractive, but they have to be supported by market studies," he said. "I certainly applaud what Save Ocean Beach has done. But they're not the only consumers who use the beach. I want the beach to be what the City Council determines it should be. And we'll look at how that is to be funded. We'll determine whether or not the project can be done by New London Development Corporation, the city or outside investment."
Mr. Collier said people must remember that the future of the beach must be grounded in reality, not based on what it was 20 years ago. "Hopefully, we can come up with a plan most people can support. We'll try to build consensus," he said.
The 80 members of Save Ocean Beach organized out of fear the city would place the beach under control of a private operator without hearing residents' opinions first. The group was also concerned that use of the beach would be restricted.
Since then, Save Ocean Beach has kept pressure on the city, and there are some indications the city is responding. The main building at the beach, which is now condemned, will be partially renovated by July. Several fees for the season, which begins on Memorial Day, were reduced to draw more visitors. And the city put a marketing plan into effect. Save Ocean Beach is an example of the surge of citizen activism New London is experiencing, said another member, Eleanor Butler. "It's turning us around. People are tired of waiting for the city to do things. They're looking for ways to make things better."

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/North Bergen, N.J.;
Work Begins on a 350,000-Sq.-Ft. Retail Center

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
THE site should have been a retailer's dream: Seventeen acres atop a rocky slope in the Hudson County community of North Bergen, N.J., visible to drivers along the Route 3-Route 495 corridor on the way to or from the Lincoln Tunnel, just over a mile away.
Because of a 1980's developer's financial problems, however, the property at Kennedy Boulevard has long been anything but dreamlike. But things are beginning to change. In the next month, demolition will begin at the billiards parlor and Shop Rite supermarket that had occupied the site for decades, and workers began removing the remnants of a failed housing development destroyed by fire four years ago. 
 The structures will be replaced by a retail center comprising 350,000 square feet of stores -- 80 percent of which have been leased, most to national retailers -- a 20-screen Regal movie theater, a new and bigger Shop Rite and parking for 1,300 cars.
Construction is to start this month on the project, called Columbia Park, with completion expected in 16 months. It is being developed by The Real Estate Equity Company, or TREECO, a concern based in Englewood, N.J., and by Forest City Ratner Companies, a prominent developer in New York City. The Ives Group of Fair Lawn, N.J., is the project architect.
Financing for the $100 million development, which includes the cost of the land, is coming from the partners' own equity and bank loans. The partners are to close the deal on the site next month.
For the developers the project represents an opportunity to capitalize on what they say is the site's locational advantages and the area's density. Some 472,000 people with an average household income of $64,900 a year live within a three-mile radius of the site, according to a market study done for the partners.
"Demographically the site is perfect," said Sandeep Mathrani, senior vice president and director for retail development at Forest City. He said his company, which is making its first foray into New Jersey, viewed the area "as the sixth borough" of New York City.
Frederick S. Fish, a principal with Nathan J. Shamlo at TREECO, added, "It is one of the few places in the New York metropolitan region that is under-retailed with national-brand merchants."
The project is good news for North Bergen, which because of an inadequate infrastructure watched from the sidelines during much of the mid-80's construction boom as developers bypassed it for other Hudson County communities, such as Jersey City. "Columbia Park is the beginning of a new chapter of growth for North Bergen," said Joseph R. Auriemma, the township's administrator.
THE project, he said, is part of a broader plan in the works for several years to improve the township's image as a place to do business and to upgrade its road and transportation systems, which have been hindrances to growth.
Those efforts are now bearing fruit, he said, adding that some $100 million in public funds have been secured for road improvements, primarily for three overpasses. Several other projects are also being advanced, including a 500-unit residential complex on the township's quarter-mile stretch of the Hudson River waterfront.
"North Bergen is pro-business and will support projects that will increase its tax base and benefit its residents," said Mayor Nicholas J. Sacco, who is also a State Senator.
Once complete, Columbia Park will produce $50 million to $60 million in new tax revenue to the township and generate up to 800 full- and part-time jobs, the developers and township officials said.
The project reflects the trend in New Jersey and the region toward what are called "power centers." Columbia Park meets the definition of such centers used by the International Shopping Center Council of Manhattan: open-air retail strips with 250,000 to 750,000 square feet of space and three or more large "big-box users" or speciality stores.
"The major growth is of big-box users, and it shows no signs of abating," said Ted Kraus, who heads a retail consulting firm in Mercerville, N.J.
Columbia Park is proceeding at a time when the economy is strong, national retailers continue to return to urban locations and the amount of available retail space is tightening. New Jersey's retail vacancy rate is 3.5 percent, down from 5 percent the same time last year, Mr. Kraus said.
"This is as good as I've seen it in the 26 years I've been in the business," he said, noting that "under today's conditions the North Bergen project should be a home run."
It took more than timing, however, to get everything in alignment at the Columbia Park site, where redevelopment efforts have languished for more than a decade. In the mid-80's an earlier developer -- Peter Mocco, a former Mayor of North Bergen -- began building condominiums on part of the site.
But after the exterior shells of the buildings were completed Mr. Mocco ran into financial problems and the dormant project became a magnet for the homeless until the buildings were swallowed by fire in 1994, Mr. Auriemma said, adding that the site itself became "a black hole."
Ultimately, Mr. Mocco lost the property to his lender, and when that bank failed the property wound up in the hands of the Federal Deposit Insurance Company. Early last year the F.D.I.C. sold it at auction to TREECO, which was later joined by Forest City.
"We knew the site's potential," Mr. Fish said. In 1987, his company redeveloped a 100,000-square-foot former Sears department store across Kennedy Boulevard in Union City into multiple uses.
The company also knew that the site is part of an urban enterprise zone, designated by the state 18 months ago. Such zones provide tax incentives to businesses and lower sales taxes -- 3 percent instead of 6 -- to retail customers. Much of the tax revenue generated by the zones can be reinvested back into communities for approved projects, making North Bergen's strong desire to redevelop the site even stronger.
After 15 months of negotiations and the resolution of two lawsuits involving the owner of the supermarket -- who wanted to develop the site himself -- the partners, in cooperation with township officials, put together the current plan, which includes the larger supermarket.
Along with granting the project a five-year tax abatement, the township is using $1 million raised from the urban enterprise zone to prepare the site for development, including razing the existing buildings and making improvements such as adding a turning lane for cars to enter the site.
The idea behind the plan is to maximize the site, generate tax revenue and attract more businesses, said Herb Klitzner, the township's lawyer. He said the township rejected proposals by other developers who wanted to build housing there.
TREECO's initial proposal for a 150,000-square-foot center was expanded when Forest City, which has developed the Metrotech Center in downtown Brooklyn and other urban sites, entered the scene. The property is unusual because its rear portion drops 30 feet down the side of the cliff, essentially putting the site at two different levels, said Mr. Mathrani of Forest City.
As now envisioned, the upper level, facing Kennedy Boulevard, will house the shopping center, with its back section extending onto a concrete platform built into the side of the cliff. The movie theater will occupy the lower level, which faces Route 495, an access road to Route 3, Mr. Mathrani said. He added that a ramp would connect the two levels.
In all, the center will house 12 tenants. The larger retailers will include, in addition to the 70,000-square-foot movie complex, a 33,000-square-foot Circuit City electronics store and a 25,000-square-foot Staples office supply store.
The supermarket will expand to 65,000 square feet from 40,000, Mr. Fish said, and there will also be seven smaller tenants; rents will range from $25 to $30 a square foot.
One side of the building will contain a sign with the names of the tenants, giving them and the project "a billboard along Route 3," Mr. Fish said.

HEADLINE: OFF THE RACK;
The Richer Rich, and Where They Live

BYLINE: By FRED BROCK 

 BODY:
CONSIDER: The income of the top 1 percent of Americans, or about 2.6 million people, now equals that of the bottom one-third of the population -- or 88 million people.
That is just one of the disquieting statistics in a column in the May issue of Smart Money that takes a sobering look at the income gap between rich and poor. The column, "Rich Man, Poor Man," by Albert R. Hunt and Alan Murray, describes inequities in income distribution that many people believe are tearing at the very fabric of American life. Moreover, the authors say that the gap is growing and that the figures used to describe it -- from the Census Bureau, Congressional Budget Office and Federal Reserve Board -- probably understate the situation. 
 The gap wasn't always growing, Mr. Hunt and Mr. Murray note. From the end of World War II until the late 1960's, it actually narrowed a bit. But then it stabilized. By the early 1980's, when the gap started to widen, the poorest 20 percent of Americans had 4.3 percent of all income; by 1996, that share dropped to 3.7 percent. During the same period, the income share of the richest 5 percent of Americans grew to 21.4 percent, from a little less than 16 percent.
There is also a gap -- a canyon, actually -- between liberal and conservative perceptions of the situation and what to do about it.
Liberals, the authors write, see the growing economic pie as failing to feed the neediest and contend that some of the biggest winners are not all that deserving. They argue for Government investments to help the poor and a $1-an-hour increase in the minimum wage, to $6.15. They also believe that moving to a flat tax or national sales tax would make the situation worse by raising taxes on the middle class to generate the same revenue or by forcing cuts in programs for the poor.
Many ardent conservatives, Mr. Hunt and Mr. Murray say, dismiss the income gap as irrelevant, arguing that the only real issue is increasing wealth. In a classic defense of "trickle-down economics," this viewpoint holds that as the income gap widens, the poor eventually benefit. Lower income taxes and lower capital-gains taxes, its advocates say, not Government programs or regulations, will spur investment and raise wages.
Nowhere is this income gap more obvious than in the May issue of Worth magazine, which contains its annual listing of the richest towns in America, based solely on median home prices. This year's list contains 250 towns with median values of at least $315,000; the 1997 list included 238 towns with median values of at least $300,000. To make the list, a town also has to have a population of at least 600.
The 10 richest towns include 8 from last year's list, though the order has changed. The two new additions to the top 10 are Belvedere and Los Altos Hills, both in California. Falling off the list this year were Centre Island, N.Y., on Long Island, and Kapalua, on Maui in Hawaii, because their populations slipped to less than 600.
This year's richest town is Aspen, Colo., population 5,049, with a median home price of $1.51 million. The others are Jupiter Island, Fla., 601, $1.22 million; Rolling Hills, Calif., 1,748, $1.17 million; Atherton, Calif., 7,500, $1.15 million; Matinecock, N.Y., on Long Island, 880, $1.07 million; Hillsborough, Calif., 10,589, $1.02 million; Belvedere, 2,071, $986,000; Rancho Santa Fe, Calif., 12,300, $963,000; Los Altos Hills, 7,900, $960,000, and Snowmass Village, Colo., 1,449, $960,000.
Seven states account for more than 85 percent of the list: 78 of the towns are in California, 54 in New York, 24 in New Jersey, 20 in Illinois, 15 in Massachusetts, 12 in Connecticut and 11 in Florida. The New York-New Jersey-Connecticut region accounts for 90, or more than a third.
The article, by Jane Berentson and Loch Adamson, also contains profiles of residents of these enclaves. For the photographs, the magazine posed many of these people happily surrounded by trappings of their wealth.
 
MOVING ALONG The May issue of Money reflects more changes under its new managing editor, Robert Safian. The magazine continues to have a more modular and cleaner look and features two new columns: Virtual Consumer, about on-line shopping, and Object Lesson, a buying guide.
Money's annual feature on the best places to live in America, usually published in the July issue, will appear in a condensed form this year, in conjunction with the magazine's site on the World Wide Web (www.money.com/bestplaces). And its annual college survey, scheduled for September, may be scrapped; a spokeswoman said no final decision had been made.
 
CREDIT WHERE DUE Worth and Money examine premium credit cards for big spenders. Both like the American Express Platinum card, despite its $300 yearly fee, because it offers many travel perks, including a free companion ticket if the card holder buys a first-class or business-class ticket.
And, Worth sniffs, "it's the only card left with a modicum of snob appeal."
 
A DRIVING ISSUE The May issue of Individual Investor likes auto stocks, especially shares of Ford and Chrysler and the American depository receipts of Honda. But the magazine thinks the A.D.R.'s of Volkswagen are overpriced, despite what is expected to be huge success for its new Beetle.

HEADLINE: Buyers Finding Smaller Inventory of Homes for Sale

BYLINE: By LISA PREVOST 

 BODY:
TWO years of unrelenting buyer demand has reduced the inventory of homes for sale throughout the New York metropolitan area.
Residential listings in many suburban communities are significantly below those of the last year or two. And in New York City, the ongoing demand for housing has so depleted the listings that multiple-bidding wars for newly available properties break out frequently, brokers and real-estate executives say. 
"The biggest factor is, this city is booming, in some sense, psychologically," said Steven James, director of sales for Douglas Elliman's East Side office. "It looks good, it feels good. It's an exciting time in this city, and that translates into sales. People are thronging to live here."
But while New York's appeal is driving up prices in Manhattan and Brooklyn, brokers say buyers in the suburbs are still resistant to overpaying, thereby discouraging rapid appreciation.
"I would not be putting adjectives on this market as a buyer's market or a seller's market," said Gilbert Mercurio, executive vice president of the Westchester County Board of Realtors. "It's somewhere in the middle."
Spring generally brings an increase in residential listings. But because of the real-estate market's unbroken pace over the winter months, brokers don't expect to see much of an upward blip this year. Along with the robust economy and low interest rates, mild weather conditions enabled buyers to keep looking throughout the winter months, traditionally a time when demand lags.
With a backlog of buyers waiting for new properties to come on the market, brokers say, new listings aren't languishing long enough to rebuild an inventory.
The smaller inventory in the suburbs has meant that buyers generally have to look longer before they find a suitable property. And brokers say they don't have enough houses to meet the demand.
"Everyone is saying the same thing, office to office: 'We wish we had more inventory,' " said Mary Ann Evick, executive vice president of William Raveis Real Estate in Connecticut.
When a house comes on the market in the suburbs, brokers say, buyers must be prepared to act quickly, with multiple offers common now for desirable properties.
 Brokers in New York City report similar patterns. According to the Corcoran Group, its listings showed 16 percent fewer apartments for sale in Manhattan at the close of 1997 than at the end of 1996. Listings for apartments priced below $500,000 were down 24 percent, the agency said.
The Halstead Property Company reported a drop of 27 percent in apartment listings below 96th Street in Manhattan for the first quarter of the year, compared with the first quarter of 1997.
New listings continue to come in, said Tresa Hall, sales director of the Corcoran Group's East Side office, but they are slowing. "There was a time about a year, year-and-a-half ago when we would have 15 or 20 new exclusives to talk about at the beginning of our meetings," she said. "Now, we have three."
Particularly acute is the shortage of large family apartments, and buyers must pay dearly for a classic six-room on the West Side, or eight rooms on the East Side. According to Kay Brover, an executive vice president with Douglas Elliman in their West Side office, as of last week her agency listed only 34 six-room co-ops on the West Side. And most of those are priced between $425,000 and $1 million.
While smaller apartments for growing families tend to be more available, Ms. Brover said, "they're getting outpriced -- you can't find a decent two-bedroom for under $300,000."
CHANGES in the Federal tax law that exempt a couple's first $500,000 of gain on a real estate sale from capital gains tax has not helped replenish listings the way many brokers expected. "We thought we'd see some of your middle to larger apartments coming on the market, but we're just not seeing a lot of that happening," said Diane Ramirez, executive director of sales for the Halstead Property Company.
Because listings are so limited in every size and price range, Ms. Ramirez said, customers are settling for less-than-prime street and building locations "just to get a good apartment." The most desirable listings, of course, bring buyers out in droves.
"We recently had, in one case, 14 people with written bids above asking price wanting the same million-dollar property," Ms. Ramirez said.
Ms. Hall of the Corcoran Group said she had seen high-end properties overbid by as much as $300,000. "If a buyer really wants to get an apartment, we tell them they must come in at asking price and even go a little higher," she said.
There are more available apartments for rent now than in the past two years, according to Nancy Packes, president of Feathered Nest, a Manhattan real-estate brokerage. But given that her figures show that average rental prices for apartments on the Upper East and West Sides rose 6.05 percent in 1997 and are continuing to rise, she noted, buyer demand is obviously exceeding supply.
In Brooklyn, the growing cachet of neighborhoods such as Park Slope and Prospect Heights has depleted inventory and driven up prices there to the point where very little is currently available for sale below $500,000, according to Mary Ann Albano, vice president and sales manager at the Park Slope office of William B. May.
"Two years ago I could show somebody 10 houses in each price range, and now today, I can't even show them five," Ms. Albano said. "People who were once moving out to the suburbs are no longer doing so. When they sell their co-op, they want to buy a house here. Since they can't do that because there's nothing on the market, co-ops are getting tight."
Listings are also down sharply on Long Island. As of the end of February, total inventory in Nassau, Suffolk and Queens was down 12 percent from the same time last year, and 16 percent compared with February 1996, according to the Long Island Board of Realtors. The average sale price has risen 11 percent in the last two years. While the dearth of inventory can be tough on buyers, said the board's chief executive, Joseph Mottola, "it behooves the seller to be cautious about committing, leaving the way open for the highest offer."
AS for Northern New Jersey, Denise Smith, spokeswoman for Weichert Realtors, reported the following figures for first quarter 1998 listings, compared with last year's first quarter for Essex, Morris, Somerset, Union and Sussex Counties:
In Essex, there were 2,080 listings, compared with 2,364 in 1997; in Morris, 2,402 against 3,012; in Somerset, 1,960 against 2,206; in Union, 2,365 against 2,894, and in Sussex, 2,159 against 2,264.
In Westchester County, residential listings numbered about 6,600 at the close of the first quarter, about 2,000 fewer than a year earlier, according to Mr. Mercurio, of the Westchester Board of Realtors. The reason, he said, is two years of record-high sales. "This sharply accelerating sales volume in our residential categories has simply outpaced the normal build-up of inventory that occurs," Mr. Mercurio explained.
In Fairfield County, Conn., data compiled by William Pitt Real Estate showed 887 listings in Greenwich at the end of the first quarter this year, compared with 949 for the same period a year earlier; in New Canaan, there were 246 listings for detached homes this year, against 294 in 1997, and in Westport, 261 detached-home listings, against 273 in 1997. Half of the listings in Greenwich were for $1 million or more.
The average price of homes sold as of April 13 in Fairfield County was up only about 8.6 percent over last year. Buyers are checking the sale prices of other homes on the street they are interested in and refusing to pay too much, said Jerry Whitson, a broker with William Raveis. At the same time, however, Mr. Whitson said he had to convince buyers that if they did not act quickly when they find a house they like, they would likely lose it to someone else.
"I have three people waiting for houses now -- if something new comes on, they must come out and see it that day," he said. "We're seeing an old phenomenon that happened in 1986 -- multiple offers."

Gilbert Mercurio of Westchester Board of Realtors says two years of record sales has cut inventory. (John Sotomayor/The New York Times, left; Susan Farley for The New York Times)
