HEADLINE: If I Had a Hammer

BYLINE: By GEORGE JAMES 

 BODY:
EDWARD A. SMITH, a commercial contractor, was there in 1984 when Paterson Habitat for Humanity undertook its first affordable-housing project in the old industrial city.
"I framed the first house," he said. 
 And last Saturday -- 70 houses later -- he was there again. Only this time he was the group's project director, overseeing about 50 volunteers, as diverse as a roofer and an orthodontist, as they banged away with hammers during the rough framing of a duplex on East Third Street that would become the first homes to be owned by another two poor families.
"I'm strictly a volunteer," Mr. Smith said. Then he laughed and said, with some pride: "A full-time volunteer. Fourteen years. Right from the beginning."
The house going up in Paterson is one of thousands built throughout New Jersey over the last decade by non-profit organizations. Whether as volunteers or modestly paid employees, dedicated people like Ed Smith are essential to the efforts of the community development groups that are trying to fill housing gaps in economically depressed areas as Federal government programs have dwindled.
New Jersey is among the top 10 states in the number of non-profit community development groups, housing experts say. In a little more than 10 years, some 170 non-profit community-based development corporations have built about 12,000 units of low- and moderate-income housing in New Jersey, said Diane Sterner, executive director of the Affordable Housing Network of New Jersey, a statewide association of about 120 such groups. In many cases, their efforts have provided job training and spurred economic development in the neighborhoods as well.
"This is a success story," said David Schwartz, director of the American Affordable Housing Institute at Rutgers University, which does research on local and national housing issues. "But it's not a story that suggests the non-profits have been able to meet the need."
Even though the groups cannot do it all, Professor Schwartz said: "They've done some very good work, some outstanding work. They're mostly dedicated people, people working very hard."
Here is a glimpse of some of those people in three such groups: Friends of the Carpenter in North Plainfield, Isles in Trenton, and Paterson Habitat for Humanity, as well the Affordable Housing Network itself.
 
From Theory to Practice On Urban Development
Martin Johnson still has the build of the running back that he was at Princeton University, but it is his scholarly side that helped to create Isles 17 years ago and still guides the nonprofit agency that designs and implements community development programs in Trenton.
His commitment is sustained by a visceral understanding of the bleak daily existence of the people that Isles serves, knowledge that is rooted in memories of his childhood in Akron, Ohio, growing up in a working poor family with a father who disappeared and a mother who took ill.
A football scholarship to Princeton saved him. And his studies there in cultural anthropology led to the creation, with several Princeton professors and students, of Isles as a means of building leadership and a strong economy in Trenton's poor neighborhoods.
Since 1990, Isles -- short for islands of redevelopment -- has completed construction or rehabilitation of 85 units of affordable housing using minority contractors or its own construction crew. It has another 90 under construction and another 109 on the drawing boards.
The staff has grown over the years to 30 people with an annual operating budget of $1.4 million from government grants and private donations. Mr. Johnson, the group's 39-year-old president, said that one of the agency's first major projects was to help to develop a community garden in a rubble-strewn lot. There are now gardens at 65 sites, providing 150,000 pounds of produce to neighborhoods where supermarkets are scarce.
Isles also has provided training in the construction trades to some 50 high-school dropouts, an environmental education program and a community-based effort to clean up contaminated industrial sites.
"Oh, I love this," said Takisha Griffin, a 20-year-old construction trainee, after she lugged sheets of plasterboard into a house under rehabilitation. A single mother, she dropped out of high school to care for her child but will soon have a job with Isles.
"I'm proud to say I'm no longer on welfare and I'm also proud to say I passed my G.E.D.," she said. "The training program helps so much. People you normally see on the street, possibly doing, if not selling, drugs or causing some type of mischief -- now they have jobs. They're going to school. They're getting an education. People are getting their G.E.D. They're moving up in life."
Mr. Johnson, who recently spent a year at Princeton's Woodrow Wilson School teaching courses in urban economic development and poverty and policy, says of Isles, "It's important for me, obviously, to know that we're doing good work here in the city and that there are thousands of people that are benefiting from this work."
"However, that's not what keeps me here," he adds. "What keeps me here after all these years is a really deep conviction that what we're doing is in effect a laboratory that's looking at ways you can engage people in a a much more systematic way and a much more cost-effective way in building local economies that then can be replicated in other places around the country."
 
From Porch Repair To Whole Houses
The Rev. John Giordano, pastor of St. Luke's Roman Catholic Church, and the Rev. Brooks Smith, pastor of the Watchung Avenue Presbyterian Church, became friends about 20 years ago when they first arrived to work in Plainfield.
One day Mr. Smith told Father Giordano of a young hard-working couple who had grown up in North Plainfield who could no longer afford to live in town.
In 1980 they talked of forming a group to help such families and about 10 people from their churches and town responded to create a volunteer board.
"We thought 'Friends of the Carpenter' was sort of a cool name," said Mr. Smith.
"The connotation with Jesus being a carpenter," interjected Father Giordano. "It had a religious connotation."
"Without," added Mr. Smith, "being too religious."
Since then, the group has arranged to build 13 townhouse units and has rehabilitated 65 houses, using federal money and donations.
Leonard Lang, one of the longest-serving volunteers and the board's vice president, recalls that when he joined the group in 1983 it was mostly involved in touch-up work, like repairing porches.
"I suggested we get more ambitious and build new houses," said Mr. Lang, a lighting consultant who owns a number of rental properties in town.
The group bought a piece of property and built eight townhouse units called Chatham Rowe I in 1984; a year later it purchased land across the street for an additional five units called Chatham Rowe II.
As the group's activities increased, the board members who used to divide the tasks decided to hire a part-time executive director, Paul Babik, two years ago. He spends 15 hours a week processing the complicated paperwork involved with getting funding and approvals. (Mr. Babik can be reached at (908) 317-6884. Inquiries about the group can also be made at the Watchung Presbyterian Church, (908) 755-2781.)
Friends has also organized an annual spin-off called Paint the Town; last year 150 volunteers from five churches and a synagogue painted houses for people who are unable to upgrade their properties themselves, such as the ill and the elderly.
Friends of the Carpenter does more than put roofs over people's heads, Father Giordano said.
"If we can take houses that are decrepit and knock them down for new townhouses and rehabilitate houses in bad shape," he said "it also improves the look of the town as well."
 
A Variety of Volunteers, A Variety of Motivations
He was banging nails into the frame of a house under construction on North Third Street in Paterson. His name is Rick Cooper but the other volunteers working for Habitat for Humanity called him Doc because he is an orthodontist.
"It's a break from tightening braces every day," said Dr. Cooper, who has an office in Caldwell. Pressed further about his motives, he added: "You're doing some good, volunteering, helping other people. Teaching other people how to do it."
The volunteers come from every walk of life and range in age from 14 to 80. Many are members of church groups or corporations. Some are proficient; many have to be taught the basics. Many on this day were women who are part of a group called Women Raise The Roof that is trying to raise $120,000 and build a house themselves.
One of them was Marcia Stribling, executive director of the Girl Scout Council of Bergen County.
"As a girl I always wanted to do this kind of stuff," Ms. Stribling said. "But when I was in high school, girls took home ec and boys took shop and that was it."
Learning such skills is practical for anyone, she said, and added: " And I know I'm doing something for somebody. That's what's really wonderful about it."
Habitat, a nonprofit ecumenical organization whose best-known volunteer is former President Jimmy Carter, has 1,426 affiliates in the United States, 22 of them in New Jersey. The group, based in Americus, Ga., has built nearly 60,000 houses around the world.
Pete Brovarone, a roofer from Dumont, was the Paterson Habitat affiliate's volunteer of the year for putting in 720 hours. Like many volunteers, he really doesn't care to discuss his motives.
"They don't have to say anything," said Lou Quiroz, the salaried, part-time site coordinator. "It's enough said they just keep coming back."
Barbara Dunn, the executive director of Paterson Habitat, said there are many who volunteer their efforts for religious reasons. Ed Smith, 58, a commercial contractor who volunteers as project director, is one.
"I have been extremely blessed by God in my lifetime and I think that one of the things as Christians we're called to do is to give back, to help the poor and help those who are needy and less fortunate," he said.
It hasn't always been easy, he admitted.
"I have to be perfectly honest with you, sometimes you wonder why you do it," he said. "Because in the course of 10 years, I've had my vehicles broken into and my tools stolen at least 10 or 12 times. But you just have to say that's experience and that's part of it."
These are some of the people who built 11 houses in 1997, making the Paterson group the No. 1 affiliate of Habitat for Humanity in the 10-state Northeast region.
A few blocks away on Arch Street, Jeffrey Ellerbee was trying to fulfill the requirement that prospective homeowners give at least 500 hours of "sweat equity" helping build houses before they take over their own, which they buy for below cost. He was rehabilitating the house he and his wife and five children hope to move into next month.
"When she found out that we got approved, it was like the Fourth of July to my wife," said Mr. Ellerbee, a 42-year-old repairman for the Paterson Housing Authority. "Every day we ride through here she can almost assume herself sitting on the porch."
 
Finding Strength In Numbers
In 1987 the National Housing Institute and a now-defunct Jersey City neighborhood group suggested an inventory of what nonprofit community development groups were doing. Diane Sterner, who was working for a Newark community group called La Casa de Don Pedro, was hired as a consultant.
At the time she found about 60 groups throughout the state who were doing some sort of community development and met with them to determine what kind of services would help them do their jobs better.
In 1989, a dozen representatives of the groups, including Martin Johnson of Isles, formed a steering committee to create the Affordable Housing Network of New Jersey. Today it has 120 member organizations out of a total of 170 statewide.
Diane Sterner, who became the network's executive director, said its mission was to promote the work of community-based development organizations and create and preserve affordable housing and rebuild lower income communities in New Jersey.
Besides providing a forum for exchange of information, the network, with a staff of 10, also provides training and technical assistance to members on the specifics of such things as applying for funding and hiring an architect and contractor.
It also lobbies for affordable housing and is pressing for a $290 million State Jobs From Housing and Economic Development Bond Act.
Carol Wayman, director of policy for the National Congress for Community Economic Development, a trade association for community nonprofit development corporations, praised the New Jersey Affordable Housing Network as a model for similar organizations in the country.
"They were one of the first to come up with a community economic development public policy agenda," she said, referring in part to their efforts for the housing and jobs bond issue. "They really looked at the landscape of state government programs and how the state could structure itself to support low-income communities."
Ms. Wayman said that 2,200 community-based nonprofit redevelopment groups across the country have created 400,000 units of affordable housing and that New Jersey is among the leaders, both in number of groups and in houses built.
Jane M. Kenny, commissioner of the state Department of Community Affairs, says such groups in New Jersey have been instrumental in strengthening neighborhoods.
"They're serving a very important need because they are getting into areas of communities where we might not have seen construction occur for 25 years and they're anchoring the neighborhoods with affordable housing," Commissioner Kenny said.
From her vantage point, Ms. Sterner says she sometimes feels remote from the work in the field. But then she is buoyed when she sees what the nonprofits have accomplished.
"To see the excitement of the kids when they're living in places, when they have have their own bedroom and a yard to play in and all those things they never had in their lives before," Ms. Sterner said. "That's the kind of thing that keeps me going."

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT: FOCUS ON PRECIOUS METALS -- COINS;
The Eagle Hasn't Lost Its Wings

BYLINE: By RICK GLADSTONE 

 BODY:
GOLD'S prolonged depression has thrown miners out of work and ravaged the financial health of many precious-metals companies. But it has created a boom in gold coins.
Worried about how much higher the stock market can go, some investors have been moving money into these coins in the last few years, particularly toward the end of 1997. Rather than viewing gold as an anachronistic hedge against uncertainty and inflation, many see it as a bargain staring them in the face. 
 "Stocks have been a much better investment than gold, but every dog has its day," said Christopher Holton, vice president of marketing for Blanchard & Company in New Orleans, the largest retailer of the American Eagle gold coin -- the most popular in the world. "If you want to buy low and sell high, the first thing you have to do is buy low."
Gold dealers are not predicting a return to the $850-an-ounce days of 1980 and are reluctant to even speculate when gold will break out of its current $300-an-ounce trading range. But the metal's 10 percent recovery from 18-year lows of $280 an ounce, reached in January, has offered some optimism that gold is increasingly viewed as an underpriced asset.
Mr. Holton said sales in March were nearly twice the February level. He described Blanchard's average customer as "55 years old, college educated and either a professional, an entrepreneur or someone in management; that individual also has investments in stocks and bonds."
George Milling-Stanley, manager of gold market analysis at the World Gold Council, a trade group based in Geneva, said sales of gold bullion coins in the United States tripled in 1997, partly because of the depressed price and the stock market's protracted rally. "Some people think it would be a good idea to preserve their gains by going into an investment like gold," he said.
Part of the appeal of gold bullion coins is their size and relative affordability. Unlike gold bricks or bars, they are easily stored, can be mailed to one's home and have a commonly recognized value.
"The nice thing about gold coins is they're the same, like a dollar bill; you can exchange one for another," said Jonathan E. Potts, president of Fidelitrade, a commodity brokerage based in Wilmington, Del. "They're portable. You can carry them with you, hand them on to your children."
Brokers generally sell coins at 3.5 percent above the market price of gold and buy them at 3 percent above the market price, pocketing the difference. (The Eagle sold for $327.47 on Thursday.) But some gold investment strategists say coins' advantages compensate for the disadvantage of the markup.
"Coins will give you a direct, close link to the movements in the price of a metal," said Edward Kempf, a senior research analyst at CPM Group, a precious-metals and commodity research firm based in New York. "If you buy shares in a major gold producer, you have to look at management, political risk, their balance sheet," Mr. Kempf said. "You don't have to do that buying the gold itself."

HEADLINE: NOTICED;
Sheets, the New Status Symbol

BYLINE: By MONIQUE P. YAZIGI 

 BODY:
DIANA BUCHANAN, who plans to marry in August, spent much of last week in and out of linen shops on the Upper East Side that sell what might be called the Rolls-Royces of sheets.
On Tuesday afternoon, she agonized for 40 minutes over the purchase of a $95 boudoir pillow, an item the size of a baby's-crib pillow, at D. Porthault, where a set of queen-size sheets and two shams starts at $1,000 for solid colors and $1,800 for prints. 
 For help in understanding the protocol of ultra-luxury bedding, Ms. Buchanan had enlisted her mother, who had come in from Connecticut to point out the hearts-on-white at D. Porthault, the signature chain pattern at Pratesi, the monograms at Leron and the white Jacquard at Frette.
Caressing a crisp cotton pillowcase, Ms. Buchanan, 27, said that the tiny pillow was all that she could afford at this point but that someday she hoped to have a whole sheet set. "I understand the importance of having the right sheets," she said. "It's a very subtle way of saying you have excellent taste without, say, driving a Porsche."
The famous linen shops in the area of Madison Avenue and the high 60's, which have supplied generations of town-house and country-home bedding for the old guard, are being discovered by a new set: people in their 20's and early 30's who want the status of high-end sheets even if they don't yet have the life style to match.
Store owners and managers say that an increasing number of their younger customers are dropping $1,000 to $5,000 on linens for starter-type studio or one-bedrooom apartments. In an economy that keeps minting 29-year-old overnight successes -- and has spawned a culture to match that values traditional totems of the luxe life -- 350-thread-count, Egyptian-cotton sheets are now having their day in the sun.
"It's easier to spend money on sheets than on new furniture," said Stephanie Hamada, 35, who is a publicity director for the accessories company Diego Della Valle and who has Frette sheets on the bed in her one-bedroom Upper East Side apartment. "We're all going toward high-end luxury-quality goods. It's like the Hermes of linen. There's this whole thing about linens and candles."
In the back of the Frette store, clerks make up a queen-size bed to show novice buyers what a duvet cover is and how many pillows are needed (don't even mention blanket covers).
But many are still unprepared for the shock of learning, after purchase, that luxury sheets need ironing and a delicate washing, for which the heavy-duty machines in their building basements are unsuited, unless, of course, sheet fanatics whisk their linens from the dryer when they are still damp. For those who don't want to bother, Frette salesclerks hand customers the card of Rosa Duran, who will hand-wash a sheet set for $32. It's a bargain, considering that Jeeves of Belgravia charges $25 a sheet and $10 a sham.
Elycia Rubin, 27, a talent executive at E! Entertainment Television in Los Angeles, says the sheets, which are all made by European companies, are also popular on the West Coast. "All of the Hollywood celebrities and yuppie types are obsessed about making a really classy bed," she said. "It's not about flannel sheets anymore. It's about showing class. God forbid anyone has sheets on their bed that have less than a 200-thread count."
Ms. Rubin, who found her own Frette sheets at an outlet in Milan, Italy, added, "Cars, clothes, jewelry, sheets -- it's all in the same line."
NOR is it only women who have developed an allegiance to old-line European linen houses that, like Frette, have separate divisions devoted to bedding for private planes and yachts.
Store managers said that more and more men, many of them single, are asking for three or four sets of "whatever is classic," in the words of Laura Sullivan, an assistant manager of Frette. "They are the Wall Street and music-industry types," she added.
Scot Lerner, an owner of Halpern Construction, a building company in Manhattan, said, "I train all my girlfriends and my housekeepers how to wash those sheets."
Chatting by cellular phone from his Land Rover, Mr. Lerner, 33, said that in selecting sheets, "you have to look for a high thread count." He continued: "I'm not buying a sheet and leaving the tag out. I do a lot of things in my bed, and if I don't have good sheets, my skin wears out."
He passed the phone to a friend, Randall Kane, 32, another connoisseur of fine bedding, who said: "Well, I like Pratesi, but I have more of Ralph Lauren. You know, the woven ones. They're good, too."
Mr. Lerner disagreed. "Oh, no, they pill," he said. "But I hear Ralph is coming out with a better line."

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT: FOCUS ON PRECIOUS METALS;
Gold Industry Tries to Dig Itself Out

BYLINE: By WILLIAM R. LONG 

DATELINE: DENVER

 BODY:
THE gilded dome of the Colorado state capitol makes a fitting crown for this city as the capital of the nation's gold mining industry. But the dome has a lot more luster than the industry these days: Gold prices are bumping along at levels too low for many of Denver's mining and exploration companies to make money, and there is no relief in sight.
Companies are closing mines, putting new projects on hold, laying off employees and cutting costs to try to ride out the hard times. Big losses are eroding cash reserves and share prices are in the doldrums. 
 And Denver's companies are not alone: The industry depression is worldwide, and companies in gold-mining countries like Australia and South Africa are in even worse shape because their costs are higher.
Many in Denver's gold industry were unprepared for a prolonged slump in gold prices. "What I think we all expected is that if gold prices went below $300, it would be for the short term," said Michele Stell, managing director of the Denver Gold Group, a trade association for the 60-odd mining companies that call Denver home.
But the spot price of gold in London, which spent most of the 1990's in the $375-to-$400 range, started declining steadily about two years ago; it has been near or less than $300 an ounce since November, and sank to an 18-year low, less than $280, in January. A modest recent rally left the spot price at $308.50 on Friday, enough for the most efficient companies, like Newmont Gold, to eke out a profit, but still dangerously low for many others.
The troubles of Echo Bay Mines Ltd., one of the largest gold companies based in the Denver area, are typical of the hard times in the United States industry.
So far this year, Echo Bay has suspended operations at one mine and scaled down at another, cut its exploration budget in half and slashed spending on new projects by 85 percent. It has laid off 800 of its 2,100 workers, cut home-office jobs to 35 from 112 and let go three-fourths of its exploration staff. It expects to produce only 500,000 ounces this year, down from 721,000 in 1997.
Those and other cost-cutting measures, combined with the company's policy of hedging gold prices by buying and selling gold futures, "have positioned us to weather a continued period of low gold prices," said Peter Cheesbrough, senior vice president and chief financial officer of Echo Bay. He said the company had already sold its entire 1998 production in the futures market for at least $340 an ounce, considerably more than recent spot prices.
"Right now we're conserving cash," said Robbin Lee, manager of investor relations. Including one-time charges for layoffs and other cost-cutting measures and a $362.7 million write-down of assets, Echo Bay lost $420.7 million in 1997.
Echo Bay's situation is grim, but better than that of some other American producers. Pegasus Gold Inc. of Spokane, Wash., had just expanded its Mount Todd mine in Australia when prices slipped too low for its output to be sold profitably, said John Pearson, vice president for investor relations at Pegasus. The company put the mine in mothballs last September and took a $353 million charge; the closing put Pegasus in default on a line of credit needed to finance a new mill.
Pegasus cut its payroll nearly in half, to 600 from 1,020, sold its jet and otherwise trimmed costs, but its stock sank anyway, from $8.50 in February 1997 to $1.60 at the end of the year. The company filed for Chapter 11 protection in January and the American Stock Exchange delisted Pegasus soon after.
Pegasus was soon joined by more casualties. The Dakota Mining Corporation was delisted from the American Stock Exchange in February, because its earnings sank below the exchange's criteria. Royal Oak Mines Inc. technically defaulted on $44 million in notes on March 17 and said it might have to suspend its nearly completed $470 million Kemess gold and copper project in British Columbia. Royal Oak got a reprieve later in March when it lined up $120 million in new financing.
"The market is in just a very ugly mood," said Dr. John Dobra, an economist and director of the Natural Resource Industry Institute at the University of Nevada in Reno. With prices so low, he said, about 60 percent of the world's production would be occurring at a loss, assuming 1996 production costs.
"The industry is in trouble if the gold price stays at $300, even $325," said Daniel McConvey, a gold-mining analyst at Goldman, Sachs. Mr. McConvey is predicting an average price this year of $310 an ounce; Ronald Londe of A. G. Edwards & Sons is more pessimistic, projecting $275 to $285 an ounce for the next 12 months and perhaps longer.
Gold's heyday seems long past. In December 1980, after years of monetary instability and high inflation, prices rose briefly to $850 an ounce, and gold was seen as a haven.
But today, with inflation fast asleep, major investors and the central banks of many countries no longer want to stockpile gold. In 1997, Australia and Argentina sold most of their gold reserves. Other causes of low prices, analysts say, are depressed demand in East Asian nations and uncertainty over European gold policy."As long as inflation stays under control," Mr. Londe said, "gold really has nowhere to go."
Many producers are responding as Pegasus and Echo Bay did, by cutting production. Mines that would have produced about 150 tons of gold in 1998 have been closed in recent months, according to David Christensen, a gold analyst with Merrill Lynch in San Francisco. "We're going to need about 400 tons of permanent mine closures before the price is stabilized," Mr. Christensen said.
Such contraction would be painful for the shakiest companies but would leave the lowest-cost producers, like Newmont, relatively unscathed. Newmont spent an average of just $250 to extract each ounce last year; nonproduction costs like exploration, interest payments and overhead add $50 or so an ounce, leaving Newmont a slender profit even at today's depressed prices.
Newmont Mining, which owns 94 percent of Newmont Gold, has tightened its belt, too, laying off 500 people.But "we're not in danger of closing any mines," said Doug Hock, a company spokesman.
Companies large and small, said Ms. Stell of the gold trade association, "are in a survival mode."

SECTION: Section 14; Page 3; Column 1; The City Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1252 words

HEADLINE: MAKING IT WORK;
30 Years After Battle, Uneasy Truce on Heights

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
IF Harlem were flat, the yawning distance between Morningside Avenue and Morningside Drive would seem small -- a few dozen yards. But from 116th Street and Morningside Avenue, where West Harlem ends, you ascend 161 steep steps past green gum wrappers, purple Bic lighters and white plastic syringes to Morningside Drive, the beginning of the Columbia University campus, known to local people outside the university as "up the hill," or "the folks with the money," or, simply, "those people."
Thirty years ago this coming Thursday, Columbia exploded in the student demonstrations of 1968. While student anger centered on the Vietnam War and campus-related military research, Columbia's relations with the surrounding, largely black community quickly became part of the maelstrom. And while the rebellion is perhaps best remembered for the occupation of campus buildings, the nightstick-wielding police and the hundreds of students arrested, Harlem remembers something different: Columbia as overbearing landlord. 
 For years before 1968 and years afterward, Columbia bought dozens of buildings and evicted thousands of tenants, many of them black and Hispanic. The 1968 rebellion came to focus on a gymnasium that Columbia planned to build in Morningside Park, and resentment in the surrounding community also focused on the university's growth on Morningside Heights, the area north, west and south of the main campus. In 1969 the Cox Commission, a fact-finding board appointed by the faculty after the 1968 disturbance, criticized the administration of Columbia's president, Grayson Kirk, for "unhealthy relations" with the community and the way the university had expanded.
Today, Columbia is by far the largest landlord in the area. It owns nearly half the commercial space between 109th and 116th Streets on Broadway, about 150 buildings in all, and officials say it plans to continue expanding and renovating its holdings. At the same time, community leaders say, the memory of 1968 continues to scar relations between Columbia and its neighbors.
"If Columbia does not do more to scale down that perception of arrogance, it is going to get worse," said the Rev. Glen C. Missick, 47, pastor of the Church of the Master at Morningside Avenue and 121st Street, which faces the campus. "It's a class thing and, yes, it's a race thing."
Lloyd A. Williams, 48, president of the Greater Harlem Chamber of Commerce, said: "The feeling was and is that Columbia is an isolated community that doesn't want people of color living near them. Anyone who wanted to strike a match in 1968 would have gotten a flame."
But those same community leaders and others also say that Columbia's president since 1993, George Rupp, and his administration have tried to be more open, consulting widely with neighborhood groups on the campus's real estate strategy on Morningside Heights.
In 1968, John T. Herbert was one of the 40 or more black students who occupied Hamilton Hall, the administrative center of Columbia College. "George Rupp and his administration have set a tone, a positive tone," said Dr. Herbert, 50, the director of anesthesiology at Harlem Hospital Center, which is affiliated with Columbia. "But there is still more to be done."
That is a contention with which Columbia's executive vice president for administration, Emily Lloyd, 53, agrees. "Cataclysmic events are always etched in memory," she said. "But perception of change always lags the change."
Columbia had been buying buildings near its core campus since 1919, but according to Andrew S. Dolkart, author of "Morningside Heights: A History of Its Architecture and Development," to be published by Columbia University Press, it accelerated its purchases in the 1950's and 60's because university administrators were becoming alarmed about the transformation of parts of West Harlem and Morningside Heights from a middle-class community to a poor community, where unemployment, crime and deteriorating housing were becoming significant problems. "Administrators were worried that people would not want to come to their school anymore," said Mr. Dolkart, a part-time historical consultant to Columbia.
The university started buying buildings, in part to stem their deterioration and in part to accommodate its own growth, Mr. Dolkart said, but it appeared to do little to explain its larger purposes to those affected by its purchases. Marie Runyon, a political activist and mother of a 7-year-old daughter, remembers the eviction notice placed on her 24-unit, six-story apartment building at 130 Morningside Drive in 1961.
"The sign said: 'This building is coming down to make way for the Columbia College of Pharmacy. Prepare to move immediately. 130 Holding Corp.,' " Ms. Runyon recalled. "Only later did we find out it was Columbia. They were evicting us under an assumed name!"
What followed for Ms. Runyon and 23 other families was five years of demonstrations and successful court actions: She and others continue to live in the building. But tenants elsewhere were less lucky. "There must have been thousands of evictions," said Ms. Runyon, now 83, "most of them successful and none of them publicized."
Indeed, Ms. Runyon said that Ronald E. Golden, a senior official in Columbia's office of real estate from 1965 to 1987 and the person who oversaw much of the university's expansion and evictions, came to be known as "the most hated man in all of Morningside Heights." Mr. Golden did not return calls seeking comment.
By February 1968, when Columbia began building the gymnasium, the university had become a divisive symbol. "We saw Columbia expanding into Morningside Park as imperialism and colonialism writ small," said James S. Kunen, 49, a student activist who wrote "The Strawbery Statement," a widely read 1969 account of the rebellion. Like the United States in Vietnam, Mr. Kunen said, "Columbia was taking advantage of a weaker, darker people."
Columbia's gymnasium was to be built on public park land, although the public would have limited access to it. In 1961, Columbia had signed a 50-year lease with the city to rent the land in Morningside Park at $3,000 a year. The gym was to have two tiers, the larger top tier for the university and the smaller lower tier for the public, meaning, in effect, Harlem. "From Morningside Drive, it was to look like a Greek temple," said Bob Roistacher, 54, a demonstrator at Columbia and now chairman of the Morningside Heights Residents' Association. "From Morningside Avenue, it was to look like a bunker."
The university never built the gymnasium, and Dr. Kirk, who died this year, took early retirement as university president four months after the demonstrations.
"We stopped Columbia cold," said William W. Sales Jr., 55, a leader of the Hamilton Hall occupation and now chairman of the department of African-American studies at Seton Hall University in South Orange, N.J.
Today, Morningside Park is a seemingly pleasant patch of green between Morningside Avenue and Morningside Drive, but drug use and crimes of assault are common there. Periodically, Mr. Missick and volunteers sweep through the park to gather used needles, so families can sit on the grass. "But there's always more needles," he said. "Always."
Mr. Missick noted that Mr. Rupp, Columbia's president, is, like himself, an ordained Presbyterian minister. "I cannot but hold him to a higher standard than any other president of Columbia," he said. "By helping us, he is helping the school."

SECTION: Section 4; Page 4; Column 1; Week in Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1154 words

HEADLINE: The Nation;
Meet the Fish That Might Save Seattle

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN 

DATELINE: SEATTLE

 BODY:
NEAR the end of a recent lovefest for endangered salmon, with corporate titans joining environmental leaders and politicians to announce their goal of rescuing a West Coast icon before it becomes extinct, came one jarring note.
"And what do you most like about salmon?" Gov. Gary Locke of Washington asked schoolchildren who had been brought before the cameras to make the case about one generation's responsibility to the next. 
 "I like to catch them," said an 8-year-old boy, "and I like to eat them."
There's nothing like an honest, old-fashioned assertion of humanity's place atop the food chain to put an environmental challenge in perspective. But in the days leading up to Earth Day, which falls on Wednesday, a new sense of environmental self-interest seems to be taking hold.
While the Endangered Species Act, the most powerful environmental law in the land, may have been created to save salmon, owls and butterflies, many policy makers are now arguing that it may really be about saving us, the dominant species.
As Seattle Mayor Paul Schell put it, in a bit of political haiku, "Ironically, as we work together to save the salmon, it may turn out that the salmon saves us."
 
Keeping Things in Check
The salmon may do for Seattle what the striped bass did for New York City: check unbridled urban development. Concern over a landfill in the Hudson River that threatened the fish's habitat eventually scuttled a riverfront highway project. In the same vein, Seattle's quality of life is now threatened by a bulging metropolitan area, and the Endangered Species Act may be just the thing to keep the city's growth in check.
Think globally, act locally, has worked fine as a refrain, spawning recycling, chemical-free backyards and earth-friendly corporate labels. But in trying to persuade Americans to sacrifice in the name of a cleaner globe, some environmentalists say appeals to altruism can only go so far.
The debate over saving ancient forests took a marked turn when it was discovered that in the process of leveling national forests, loggers were not only destroying the habitat of the endangered spotted owls but also the Pacific yew tree, which contains a substance used in one of the most promising drugs for the treatment of breast cancer. The argument suddenly became one about a medical hope for despairing women.
Similarly, this month it was reported that one out of every three plant species in America, and one out of every eight in the world, is threatened with extinction by human activities. The report is a biodiversity four-alarm fire, though that term is still largely an abstraction to most people.
The coalition of scientists and environmentalists at the World Conservation Union who conducted the survey were quick to explain: most medicine comes from wild plants. Lose them, and lose potential cures for cancer.
"I still think we're better off appealing to principles rather than, say, economics," said Dennis Hayes, founder of the original Earth Day in 1970, and now president of the Bullitt Foundation, a well-endowed environmental group here. "But it does seem like the people who are most fanatical about saving something like salmon are those who really like to eat them."
There was a great furor from developers around Austin, Texas, and in Southern California a few years ago when Federal officials said they would restrict urban sprawl to protect vanishing bird species. But homeowners discovered that the bonus of open space led to an increase in their property values. What was good for the dying birds turned out to be good for home equity.
The critics of environmental restoration insist that the Endangered Species Act and other laws have elevated plant and animal concerns to a high altar of eco worship. "Laws of the beetle, by the beetle and for the beetle" is how Representative Helen Chenoweth, Republican of Idaho, described the species act.
But recent polls in the Pacific Northwest suggest that a large majority of people see something in it for them in the effort to save the region's signature fish. They are willing to pay more in utility or water bills to bring salmon back to rivers.
The attempt to save wild salmon on the West Coast is the most ambitious effort yet to try to restore a natural system to large urban areas. In the Puget Sound region, nearly three million people live in an area where many strains of chinook salmon are close to extinction. The effort to bring those fish back may force restrictions on everything from lawn care to future expansion of companies like Boeing and Microsoft.
"Ultimately, we're talking about real changes in people's lives," said Tryg Sletteland, director of Pacific Rivers Council, a Oregon-based environmental group. "We're talking about limiting growth, increasing housing density and limiting traffic."
 
Wretched Urban Excess
Cities elsewhere are attempting to do the same thing. Denver, now nearly 500 square miles, is trying to reign in some of its runaway growth. But without a federally sanctified icon like salmon, the city has had to make a general appeal to protect the Rocky Mountain good life. Only as traffic has worsened in the metropolitan area have some of those appeals hit home, Colorado's city planners say.
Even Las Vegas, the fastest-growing city in the country and the epitome of wretched urban excess, has tried to save wild plants and animals by appealing to the self-interest of its citizens. In signing a conservation plan last week to protect the Palmers chipmunk and Clokey's eggvetch, a plant, in the Spring Mountains just outside Las Vegas City limits, elected officials talked about the great thrill and tourist draw it would be to go out for an afternoon of nature out of range of a slot machine or blackjack table.
Underlying the nation's latest conservation efforts is the basic assumption -- let's save the salmon, kids! -- as old as any American virtue. In outlining his plans to green groups for a millennial campaign for Earth Day, Mr. Hayes managed to refer indirectly to someone not usually mentioned in environmental circles.
"Earth Day 2000 will be almost Reaganesque in optimism," he said. "Humans made these problems. We can decide to do something different."
But the more daunting question is whether land that has been been sealed by pavement, crammed with skyscrapers and had its genetic bank plundered can ever again respond to the laws of nature. The answer, from people like Governor Locke, is -- yes. And then Americans can go back to doing the things they take for granted in the natural world.
At the salmon meeting, for example, the Governor spoke of the need to restore biodiversity, to protect quality of life, to keep the economy humming. Then he mentioned his own stake in the issue. "Just as my dad took me salmon fishing on Puget Sound," he said, "I want to be able to do the same with my daughter Emily."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 2433 words

HEADLINE: SPENDING IT;
How Big Banks See the World

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY L. O'BRIEN and SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
ATTENTION, shoppers: Some of America's biggest banks think it is time you stopped foraging around for necessities like credit cards, mortgages, insurance and checking accounts and just got all those financial goodies in one place: Theirs.
Big bank mergers are afoot -- linking titans like BankAmerica with Nationsbank, Banc One with First Chicago and Citicorp with Travelers Group -- and one of the Big Ideas behind them is that consumers will embrace the concept of one-stop shopping for financial services. Other companies, like Fidelity Investments, the mutual fund giant, and Merrill Lynch, the nation's leading brokerage firm, are pursuing similar strategies. 
 "It's a business proposition whose time has come," Citicorp's chief executive, John S. Reed, said on April 6, when his company's merger with Travelers was announced. Mr. Reed said that customers in the future would not "want to go from place to place" to manage their personal finances.
Should a savvy consumer buy into this argument? Some already do.
"It's kind of nice to have one statement and to have access to all of your money with one phone call," said David Dillon, a 34-year-old Chicagoan who trades stocks and keeps his savings and checking accounts with Fidelity. "And from what I can tell, the prices and interest rates are competitive. Everybody's within a fraction of one another."
Well, not exactly. A little searching -- and, in some cases, a willingness to use the latest technology -- can unearth much better deals than those offered by the expanding giants.
Fidelity charges a $14.95 commission per stock trade for active traders and $19.95 a trade for those who buy and sell less often. In comparison, Ameritrade, an on-line brokerage, charges $8 a trade. And while Travelers charges an average auto insurance premium of about $925 a year for a 35-year-old male in Manhattan, Electric Insurance charges $456 for the same policy. Not even all big banks are equal. Citicorp charges an interest rate of 16.25 percent on a two-year, unsecured personal loan, while the Chase Manhattan Corporation charges about 11 percent for an equivalent loan.
Of course, the potential savings may look small to consumers willing to pay extra for the convenience of getting one financial statement a month that neatly ties their far-flung money management needs into one package. And some banks, such as Citicorp, negotiate many of their fees downward if you pledge allegiance and concentrate your personal finances with them; for example, that personal loan from Citibank can fall to 12.25 percent for one-stop shoppers.
Large banks are not exploring one-stop shopping on a lark. They are all in need of finding new ways to do business. Hemmed in for years by arcane regulations that did not apply to many of their competitors, and often too conservative in their own managerial styles, banks have seen many of their most profitable businesses picked off by specialists like brokerage firms, credit-card companies and mutual fund families. Banks also labor under the longstanding perception that they are more akin to public trusts than businesses. This sometimes saddles them with customers who willingly fork over $30 a month for cable television or $20 a month for on-line computer services, but squirm at a few extra dollars a month for banking.
So being all things to all people, and charging for that service, is one way that banks feel they can restoke their competitive juices. But predicting what appeals to consumers when it comes to managing their personal finances is as much an art as it is a science.
"When we look at consumer behavior and how people bank, there is no such thing as an average consumer," said James McCormick, president of First Manhattan Consulting Group. "It's a world of widely disparate behaviors."
CONSUMERS like Mr. Dillon -- those willing to bundle most of their financial needs with one supplier -- account for perhaps 20 percent of all customers of financial services concerns, Mr. McCormick said. The vast bulk of customers are more like Rita Buland, a secretary in Manhattan. Ms. Buland follows the advice of the old Motown hit by the Miracles: She shops around.
"I would not do anything but banking at a bank," Ms. Buland said. "I worked for many years in a medical center. I learned not to take my body or my money to a general practitioner."
In fact, banking experts say, it is discriminating, finnicky shoppers like Ms. Buland who are forcing the financial services world to change. The model, these gurus say, may be the retailing industry. In the future there will be a few very powerful national vendors with broad product lines, like Wal-Mart. (The new Citigroup, for example.) There will be very big, specialized companies, like Home Depot. (Charles Schwab, perhaps.) And there will be room for small, very local providers of highly personalized service, like the dry cleaner on the corner. (Think of community banks and credit unions, for instance.)
Over the last decade, the winners in financial services have been the category killers. These include specialized companies like MBNA in credit cards, Countrywide Credit in mortgages and Geico in auto insurance. These organizations used technology to lower their costs and they improved their marketing, thereby taking customers from their more traditional counterparts in the staid banking world.
"Customers are learning to expect more for less," said Scott M. Birnbaum, a consumer banking expert with Mercer Management Consulting. "Intense competition and new technology are making better products and better service."
The financial services companies that are pairing up in the latest round of mergers want to trump the category killers by offering financial consumers the convenience of the shopping mall. The trouble is that there is little evidence that big companies can sell myriad financial products to all their customers.
"Every decade in banking, people talk about cross-marketing," said Shailesh J. Mehta, chairman of the Providian Financial Corporation. "We just haven't seen anyone with a successful formula."
It's not that Providian hasn't tried itself. Originally an insurance company, it expanded into credit cards, then spent years pushing its various divisions to sell one another's products -- without much success. In retrospect, Mr. Mehta said, the company's experience in insurance should have offered a cautionary tale.
"Eighty percent of the life insurance agents never sold an auto policy," he said. "And 70 percent never sold a health policy. What says making the insurance policy part of a bank is going to change that?"
His conclusion? "You can't push the consumer around." And so Providian sold its insurance operations last year to concentrate on consumer lending. "We found we could create greater shareholder wealth picking one market and focusing on it rather than trying to be everything to everybody," he said.
Providian's experience is common across nearly every financial category.
"Typically, families in the top half of the income structure deal with between 5 and 10 financial firms," said Scott Cook, chairman of Intuit Inc., the maker of Quicken software. "Commonly, they choose to get their credit card, mortgage, checking account and mutual funds from different firms, even when their bank offers all four product lines."
Demographics play a significant role in all of this, and time appears to be on the side of companies arguing for financial supermarkets. One-stop shoppers tend to be people younger than 40. Analysts and corporate executives say that it is those older than 40 who have a more jaundiced view of banks.
"The World War II generation has a healthy disrespect for the financial system, based on their experience as kids in the Depression, and they have passed a bit of that on to their children, the baby boomers," said Stephen A. Cone, president of Fidelity's consumer marketing division. "As that memory trails off, people are much more receptive to the idea of one-stop shopping."
YET before megabankers rejoice at this generational shift, they should pause to consider a technological development whose potential is still unfolding: the Internet. While younger people may have an affinity for bundling, they are also the most adept at using the technology that can make one-stop shopping much less necessary. The Internet allows customers to retrieve lots of detailed financial information quickly and makes moving their business among vendors that much easier.
"It doesn't matter any more how big you are," Mr. Cone said. "It matters whether people are going to your Web site."
Using a software package like Quicken, for example, a person can build electronic links to bank accounts at Citibank, credit cards from American Express and investments from Schwab. Intuit is taking this approach much further, creating electronic search engines that will take information from a given user to shop the World Wide Web for the best financial deals. For example, it will use a person's car model and driving record to find the lowest price on an auto insurance policy.
"Shopping financial alternatives is usually hard today," Mr. Cook said. "The Internet makes financial shopping a cinch -- fast and free to do. Why would you pay more money to switch to your bank's captive insurance arm?"
THE evolution of on-line stock brokerage services may provide devotees of financial supermarkets with a sobering indicator of what can happen when consumers begin to surf the Internet with gusto in their quest for cheaper financial products.
Today, according to Piper Jaffrey, nearly 20 percent of all stock trades by individuals are entered over the Internet, from a standing start four years ago. The going commission for such trades is about $16, far below the prices charged by full-service brokers and less than the cost at many discount brokers.
Indeed, Charles Schwab, long the bane of full-service brokers, is now fighting off competition from Internet brokers, like Ameritrade and the E-Trade Group, that are undercutting its price. Last Wednesday, Schwab posted first-quarter earnings that were below expectations because of price cuts that it took to be more competitive.
On Internet time, the competitive cycle spins ever faster, a boon to consumers willing to shop around. E-Trade's $15 commissions are being undercut by firms charging as little as $5 a trade. And that is prompting E-Trade to adopt the same strategy as some of the financial giants with which it competes.
Christos M. Cotsakos, chief executive of E-Trade, based in Palo Alto, Calif., argues that his upstart company has established enough of a brand reputation that it no longer has to compete by offering the lowest price.
"There are some people where price is all that matters, and they have no loyalty," Mr. Cotsakos said. "But there is a middle kingdom where brand is important, as long as you aren't charging them $300 for something they can get for $14.95."
E-Trade has climbed firmly aboard the one-stop-shopping bandwagon, with plans to introduce credit and debit cards. And already, it looks a lot like a bank, with $1.3 billion in cash balances from customers. Some 30 percent of E-Trade's customers have their paychecks electronically deposited into the money-market portion of their brokerage accounts.
Banks, of course, can exploit the Internet themselves, but so far they haven't found it easy. Citibank already offers on-line stock trades for $19.95, although critics say that its slow and unwieldy Web site is no match for either E-Trade's or Schwab's. There have been a handful of all-electronic banks, but they have attracted few customers.
The new financial Goliaths won't have any trouble deploying their ample resources to build fancy Web sites and invest in any other technology that might make it easier to reel in new customers. Yet banks historically have tripped over their own size, finding it hard to remain agile and respond to market changes quickly as the financial ground shifted beneath their feet.
If quaint notions like personal service remain in demand, bankers still have all those branches on street corners that they can convert into mini-malls. But experts say that older consumers who prefer banking in branches, rather than on the Internet, the telephone or with automated teller machines, tend not to be interested in one-stop shopping. And they may not understand that the new products do not come with guarantees from the Federal Government.
"Banks have held a special place in consumers' minds as companies they can trust because of things like deposit insurance," said Mary Griffin, legal counsel for Consumers Union, the nonprofit organization that publishes Consumer Reports magazine. "Because of that trust, it can be easy for banks to deceive and mislead people."
Last year, Nationsbank, without admitting or denying guilt, paid $30 million to settle a lawsuit that accused the bank of duping hundreds of thousands of customers in eight states into buying mutual funds and stocks by falsely portraying those products as being federally insured.
"We vigorously denied the allegations, and we're confident our investment consultants fully disclosed all risks associated with those products," said Ann Anderson, a Nationsbank spokeswoman. "But rather than engage in protracted litigation, we chose to settle and put the matter behind us."
CUSTOMERS, though, may not be so quick to put their frustrations behind them when mergers go awry. Bollixed-up statements and tangled phone-mail trees can quickly repel once-loyal customers.
Nor does brand loyalty survive every merger. New Sub Services, a company that sells magazine subscriptions through inserts in credit card bills, says offers from big national banks with well-known names get 20 to 50 percent more responses than similar offerings from regional banks. But that advantage turns to a disadvantage if the big bank buys the small bank and slaps its name on customers' credit cards. Customers tend to bolt when that happens, New Sub says.
So if consumers of financial services are proving to behave more like wolves than sheep, they should be heartened to realize that for all the hand-wringing about megamergers, there will still be abundant choices for customers on the prowl. The combination of Nationsbank and BankAmerica will create an enormous bank, but one that still will control only a little more than 8 percent of the nation's bank deposits.
But if Nationsbank and BankAmerica were to link up with Citicorp and Travelers . . .

HEADLINE: The Nation: Free Lunch;
Feeding the New Work Ethic

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT 

 BODY:
MOST lotteries offer such low odds of winning that they invite comparisons to rare lightning strikes. But there's a new lottery with terrific odds and lots of winners: It's called Corporate America.
As much as this month's huge mergers were about restructuring the financial-services industry, the deals also had the happy-go-lucky feel of a windfall celebration. When the Citicorp-Travelers Group merger was announced two weeks ago, John S. Reed, the Citicorp chairman, was asked how he reacted when his counterpart at Travelers first proposed the merger just five weeks earlier. "My instinct," Mr. Reed said, "was to say, 'Why not?' " 
 Why not, indeed. Details of the merger, including concerns from industry regulators, could be handled later: It was time for the C.E.O.'s to enjoy the sight of jaws dropping on their surprising news, and to watch stock-price jumps add $67 million in paper profits in a single day to Mr. Reed's holdings of Citicorp stock, and $248 million to the Travelers stock held by Sanford I. Weill, its chairman.
"This is a bigger opportunity for everybody who is part of it," Mr. Weill said the day of his merger announcement.
He could just as easily have been talking about all the people who are taking part in the broader stock market. The Dow Jones Industrial Average has climbed from 2,000 to over 9,000 over the last decade, generating pronouncements from market watchers that a fundamental shift has occurred in the way people invest. With so much at stake -- the proportion of Americans' wealth tied up in stocks, about 28 percent, is at a 50-year high -- bad market news is always lined with at least some silver, if not gold. Stock drops are viewed by many as just opportunities to buy, as are giant mergers.
The obvious route to playing this big lottery is buying stock. But there is an even better lottery ticket, one that appears to cost nothing and is spreading deeply through the ranks of many companies: stock options.
These options, which are typically issued in addition to salary and bonus, grant the right to buy a company's shares at a set price for a set period of time -- meaning the chance to buy stock at a discount if the share price rises. Options used to be given only to top executives, but they are now handed out to roughly 50 percent of midlevel professionals at major companies, and many surveys show that at least 1 in 10 of the companies offer them to most of their employees.
In fact, options have become a kind of currency beyond a company's walls: as part of Jerry Seinfeld's last contract, he got stock options in NBC's parent company, General Electric. One reason options are doled out so freely is that, because of favorable accounting rules, they don't show up as a charge against a company's earnings. And because they only pay off if the stock rises, companies like to think of them as risk-free investments.
When combined with the surging stock market, these options have created unexpected wealth, on paper and in real dollars, for legions of employees. Many see the granting of options to all ranks of workers as a laudably egalitarian approach to allowing employees to share in their company's prosperity. But there have also been some striking side effects.
With so many rich option profits, the gap is widening in American society between those who hold stocks and stock options and those who are left out of the market lottery. Options can also create a disconnect between the effort people put into their jobs and the pay they receive for it. In Silicon Valley, many workers job-hop as they search for the one company where the options will pay off as well as they have for those who are now among the many "Microsoft millionaires."
The gap between pay and effort can be especially wide for chief executives, who get huge grants of stock options for reasons that appear to have very little to do with the size or performance of their companies. For those at the top, even a relatively small uptick in the stock price can translate into millions of dollars in paper profits.
Many chief executives have blunted resentment of their rich option packages by sprinkling options through their company's ranks. But when the stock drops sharply -- yes, it does happen at a lot of companies -- the C.E.O. may suddenly be blamed for wiping out part of employees' anticipated savings from cashing in the options.
Further widening the gap between pay and effort, many companies lower the price of options when their share price falls steadily, effectively lowering the bar over which employees must jump for the options to pay off. The practice, known as "repricing," infuriates many outside investors, who say that repricing can have the perverse effect of rewarding poor performance.
 
License to Churn
Given that there is no real downside to stock options, it is perhaps not surprising that big option packages provide an incentive for chief executives to experiment more freely with ways to lift their companies' stock price. William Gerard Sanders, a professor of strategic management at Brigham Young University, studied 250 large American companies from 1991 to 1995, and found that large stock-option holdings for top executives tended to increase the frequency of acquisitions and divestitures -- "symbolic churning," as Mr. Sanders called it -- to get stock prices up.
"Option pay," Mr. Sanders said, "essentially grants the executive a potential winning ticket in a compensation lottery."
It is a lottery that many people are rushing to join, particularly in high-technology companies where stock options are standard equipment in most pay packages. The vigorous economy in Silicon Valley, for example, has given options something of a public-relations halo -- employees with options ideally feel more like owners, and have an incentive to work through the night. At big companies, however, many lower level workers don't quite know what they can do differently to help lift the stock price -- except, at consumer-goods companies, maybe buying more of their company's own products.
"People become enfranchised with stock options, and I think the work ethic in high-technology companies can be tremendously accelerated," said Jim Trattner, who runs the Trattner Network and Talentwave, two companies based near San Francisco that place executives and provide contract help to technology companies (Mr. Trattner's companies also take stock options from clients as part of their fees.)
But Mr. Trattner, a former clinical and industrial psychologist, said the proliferation of stock options among technology companies had caused another change that he does not necessarily applaud.
"I'm old enough to say that there used to be a sort of intrinsic motivation to do something for the love of it," said Mr. Trattner, who is 59.
"Now," he added, "it's like, 'Let's make a buck,' and I think there is something lost in that."

SECTION: Section 4; Page 3; Column 1; Week in Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1525 words

HEADLINE: The World;
50 Years Ago in Israel: Trying to Imagine the Future

BYLINE: By MARC D. CHARNEY 

 BODY:
BY declaring itself independent 50 years ago, Israel announced its intention to give Jews a new future. The past, especially the still gaping wound of genocide, had been too terrible. So there was a great temptation to peer into the future and imagine what it held.
Israel was a child whose birth had been long anticipated by many: visionary thinkers, socialists, nationalists, religious leaders, guerrilla fighters, foreign diplomats, desperate refugees. Everyone had a different idea of what form the future would take; any one vision might capture a sliver of the picture, but none seemed to see it whole. 
 One prediction was easy: There would be war. The outcome, and the shape of Israeli society, was another matter.
It was easy to see the besieged nation absorbing huge numbers of immigrants. But few saw how long the siege would last, or how divided Israel would become over the search for peace, and over social and religious issues.
Professor Michael Stanislawski of Columbia University, a specialist in Israeli history, says that Israel's founding fathers shared a faith that they were witnessing the "normalization" of the Jewish people in a new melting pot after the centuries in exile. The country's population today, and the depth of its internal disputes, would surely surprise them, he says.
Here then is a look at some early visions offered up for Israel. They share two things: Each begins with a shrewd observation, but none is completely right.
In 1902, the founder of modern Zionism, Theodor Herzl, wrote a utopian novel, "Altneuland" ("Old-New Land"), in which a Jewish Palestine was a hub of global commerce:
Europe is nearer to Palestine than to America. . . . You can now go by rail from any place in Europe to Damascus, Jerusalem and Baghdad . . . The Cape-to-Cairo line . . . has now been built, and so has the Trans-Siberian line to China, thus completing a network of which we are nearly the center.
In the late 1930's Zionists fruitlessly tried to persuade Britain to permit large-scale immigration to Palestine despite violent Arab opposition. A royal commission led by Earl Peel heard Chaim Weizmann, the leader of mainstream Zionism, in Jerusalem on Nov. 25, 1936:
There should be one place in the world, in God's wide world, where we could live and express ourselves in accordance with our character, and make our contribution . . . We would not have to be always on the defensive, or, on the contrary, become too aggressive, as always happens with a minority which is constantly on the defensive. . . .
If we do not employ Arab labor, it is thrown in our faces: "You come into the country and you do not employ the labor for the country which is already there." And if we do employ Arab labor, we are likely to lay ourselves open to the reproach: "Here they are, they come and live here, and the real work is being done by others, while they are simply overlords" . . . I hope we may be able to find a way by which Arabs may employ Jews in larger numbers, and Jews may employ Arabs in large numbers.
 
An Arab Minority
 Vladimir Jabotinsky, the militant right-wing rival of the mainstream Zionists, also spoke about relations with the Arabs, appearing before the Peel Commission on Feb. 11, 1937:
The idea is that Palestine on both sides of the Jordan should hold the Arabs, their progeny and many millions of Jews. What I do not deny is that in that process the Arabs of Palestine will necessarily become a minority in the country of Palestine. What I do deny is that that is a hardship.
 In 1948, as Jews prepared for the end of Britain's Palestine mandate at midnight on May 14, the United States State Department sought to have President Truman keep the land under United Nations trusteeship rather than immediately recognize a new Jewish state -- which Truman did anyway. A memorandum of Jan. 20, 1948, from the State Department's policy planning staff, led by George F. Kennan, forecast:
Ultimately the U.S. might have to support the Jewish authorities by the use of naval units and military forces . . . It is improbable that the Jewish state could survive over any considerable period of time in the face of the combined assistance which would be forthcoming for the Arabs in Palestine from the Arab States, and in lesser measure from their Moslem neighbors.
On the day of independence, Dr. Weizmann spoke to Israel's Jews in a radiogram from New York, where he had been involved in the frantic diplomacy:
OUR FOREFATHERS BUILT WITH ONE HAND WHILE DEFENDING THEMSELVES WITH OTHER STOP WE CALLED UPON TODAY ACT IN THIS TRADITION STOP IT IS PROFOUND DESIRE OUR PEOPLE ESTABLISH RELATIONS HARMONY AND MUTUAL RESPECT WITH THEIR ARAB FELLOW CITIZENS WITH NEIGHBORING ARAB STATES AND WITH ALL OTHER NATIONS IN HUMAN FAMILY STOP
The next night, Menachem Begin, who came to lead the militant right after the death of Jabotinsky in 1940, spoke over the radio of the Irgun guerrilla group.
It is Hebrew arms which decide the boundaries of the Hebrew State. So it is now in this battle; so it will be in the future.
When a cease-fire was declared after Israelis won initial victories in the 1948 war, Abba Eban, Israel's representative at the United Nations, made an appeal for good relations with the Arabs in an article in the September 1948 issue of Commentary:
Arabs and Jews need each other for any progress or any escape from deadlock . . . the salient new fact created since May 14 is that the Arab world must either seek an adjustment with Israel or sink ever deeper into a mire of international discredit, social disturbance and political upheaval . . . If self-interest is even a subsidiary motive of political action, then Arabs must come to the conference table soon.
And what would happen now inside Israel? David Ben-Gurion, a principal exponent of the secular socialist ethics that many Zionists had brought from eastern Europe, addressed Kibbutz Hameukhad, invoking the spirit of the halutz, or Zionist pioneer, who was central to his vision:
Human freedom is the primary attribute of a halutz . . . A second attribute is equality . . . A third attribute -- perhaps the most important one -- is human cooperation, which means faith in the community, a bond with it and the will to pioneering unity.
The ultra-Orthodox leaders had something else in mind as a source of ethics; Rabbi J.Z. Dushinsky, representing the anti-Zionist group Agudath Israel -- which would later join Ben-Gurion's coalition -- described it to the Peel Commission, sitting in London, on Dec. 21, 1936:
The holy Torah has promised the Holy Land to the people of Israel, but it is by that very Torah that we are commanded not to occupy the country by force . . . but we are confident that to the extent that the returning exiles to Zion will fulfill the will of God, as revealed in the Torah, and will make the national home the abode of the Torah in all branches of economic and cultural endeavor . . .
 Sir Horace Rumbold questioned him:
Q. There should be a proportion of members of Agudath Israel employed in the posts and in the railways, but you also object to their working on Saturdays?
A: Yes.
Q: Do you not see what that leads to? . . . The railways certainly are an important element in the economic life of the country . . . do you not think that is going to make it rather difficult?
A: They will be run by Arabs on Saturdays, by non-Jews. On Saturdays the work can be done by non-Jews.
A week later, Yitzhak Ben-Zvi, president of the Jewish community's executive council, described how Palestine's various immigrant populations got along:
The Jewish population is united in religion, language and a common purpose and identifies itself with the aspirations and purpose of the Jewish national home. There is no difference on this score between the immigrants from European countries, such as Germany, Poland and Czechoslovakia, and those who came from Asiatic countries, such as the Yemen, Iran or Kurdistan.
On April 22, 1949, just 13 years later, a controversial article appeared in the newspaper Haaretz. The writer, Arye Gelblum, described immigrants from North Africa as dirty, disease ridden and prone to drunkenness and prostitution:
And then, other Oriental Jews will eventually join them, too! What will happen to the State of Israel and its standards with this type of population? Obviously all these Jews are entitled to come here no less than others, and they should be brought over and absorbed, but if it is carried out without consideration for our limited capacities and if it is not done gradually, they will "absorb" us rather than we them.
If such social tensions were not on people's minds while Israel was fighting to survive, one widespread hope was that warfare would end soon. The popular singer Shoshana Damari entertained troops with a song of the risk and promise of battle:
. . . From the roads leading south
A platoon returns from battle.
As stars fade it shall return from night,
The desert stretching primordial and vast,
Smile, sister, we have returned from our plight --
This battle was the last.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 18; Column 1; Week in Review Desk 

LENGTH: 892 words

HEADLINE: The World;
In Ireland, Courage and Good Timing

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE Northern Ireland peace agreement, framed with such difficulty out of so many years of hatred and mistrust, was itself an accident of timing. Its implementation will require a similar mixture of bravery and luck.
Some sort of settlement was going to happen sometime, as it will also happen, sometime, in the Middle East. But this triumph benefited as much from the confluence of unpredictable events as from the courage of the participants. 
 Thirty years of vicious and personalized killings, one by one, since the Troubles began again in earnest in 1969, built a solid sense of disgust among most in Northern Ireland, Protestant and Catholic. That disgust, combined with a comparative economic boom in both Britain and the Irish Republic, made the violence seem that much more self-defeating and antique, particularly among younger people with an increasingly European sense of themselves and their future.
But disgust has never been enough to stop the killing in Northern Ireland. It still required acts of imagination and courage from political leaders -- including President Clinton. He had already reached out to the Catholic side to grant a visa to the Sinn Fein leader Gerry Adams in early 1994, ignoring the protests of Britain and his own Cabinet.
Mr. Clinton was also willing to fold the easy domestic card of Irish republicanism and reach out to the Ulster Unionists and their young leader, David Trimble, giving them similar access to the American Government. The result was a lessening of suspicion of Mr. Clinton's motives -- and those of his special envoy, the former Senate majority leader, George Mitchell, who chaired these talks.
Even the aging revolutionaries of Sinn Fein, the political wing of the Irish Republican Army, had grown weary and fearful for their own children. So when Mr. Adams got his visa, he was ready to use the credibility Mr. Clinton provided to persuade the I.R.A. to forswear violence for a seat at the negotiating table.
Much important work had been done by the former Conservative Prime Minister of Britain, John Major. Still, the pact probably would not have happened without the election of a new Labor Prime Minister, Tony Blair. He had a huge majority, a willingness to spend political capital early and new ideas about sovereignty and the decentralization of power.
 
When Success Is Failure
For Mr. Mitchell, the satisfaction of orchestrating an agreement under the pressure of a deadline is muted only by his continuing astonishment at the ability of the participants to think the worst of one another.
"One of their worst practices is that each party judges success by the failure of the others," Mr. Mitchell said in an interview here. "If Trimble feels success, Adams feels failure. So every decision became a zero-sum game." Matters got so bad in the all-day, all-night marathon that Mr. Mitchell and the two Prime Ministers, Mr. Blair and Ireland's Bertie Ahern, drafted language they called "the mutual assured destruction paragraph.
Mr. Adams was convinced that Mr. Trimble would insure that the North-South consultative bodies, which give Dublin a small say in the running of the north, would be delayed or killed by the Northern Ireland Assembly, where Mr. Trimble's party would be a majority. Mr. Trimble was convinced that Mr. Adams wanted to delay the establishment and functioning of the Assembly.
In the end, with Mr. Clinton's help of advice and jaw-boning with all the parties, a compromise was reached out to insure that the North-South bodies would hold a round of meetings before the Assembly was constituted, expected to be by February 1999. And the "mutual assured destruction paragraph" was drafted to say that if one body does not function, neither does the other.
Mr. Mitchell sees dangers to the agreement in the likelihood of violence from fringe militants on both sides who want to derail the deal, and the unavoidable risk that the agreement might be rejected in simultaneous referendums in both parts of Ireland on May 22 -- although opinion polls show sizeable majorities in favor.
 
Delicate Issues
But more important, the implementation of a complicated set of arrangements will be difficult. They include the delicate issues of police reform, turning in of arms by militants, the freeing of prisoners and the establishment of the Assembly and North-South bodies, both of which must deliver increased prosperity and justice to the citizens of the North, especially the Catholic minority.
That will require that the new Unionist willingness to transcend the parochialism of the past be matched by a new generosity toward the Catholics, who have given up the idea of a united Ireland through any means but the consent of the majority population of the North.
There are hopeful signs. "Gerry Adams and Sinn Fein have been brought in from the cold," notes Padraig O'Malley of the University of Massachusetts in Boston. "This is not peace in our time," he said. "But even if the Sinn Fein governing body were to vote against the pact, it would not produce a big split. So to that extent, the I.R.A. as we have known it in our time, is over."
And in 1973, the last time a multiparty peace deal was reached in Northern Ireland, Unionist dissenters caused the arrangement to fall apart within months. Their leader then was David Trimble.
