HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends;
A Wakeup Call for Workfare's Advocates

BYLINE: By RACHEL L. SWARNS 

 BODY:
IN polishing his achievements in town hall meetings in Brooklyn and fund raisers as far away as Arizona, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani always mentions one that sets him apart from other politicians: His creation of the country's largest workfare program, a welfare work force of 34,000 people who sweep streets, clean parks and answer phones for their welfare checks.
But workfare, which Mr. Giuliani once hoped would become a model for the nation, is a program officials elsewhere are largely avoiding. Most of them view it as a last resort, a program that is costly and typically fails to moves people into real jobs. And while they admire the sheer size of Mr. Giuliani's work force, most officials are focusing on programs that will push people into the job market faster and for a longer time than municipal programs like New York City's Work Experience Program, as workfare is called. 
 "They want to get people working," said Jack Tweedie, who tracks welfare policy across the country for the National Conference of State Legislatures. "And the research suggests that workfare is not that successful in getting people off welfare and into jobs."
In the past Mr. Giuliani has said that as many as 110,000 workfare workers had found real jobs. But he and city officials rarely measure workfare's success by the number of participants who find employment.
Those officials say their program has helped reduce the welfare caseload by a third, getting rid of some people who worked off the books while receiving welfare checks. The officials say that participants have a new sense of responsibility, that the public, too, benefits from a cleaner city. These successes, they say, make the program invaluable.
City officials seem to place hopes for job placement elsewhere, requiring some welfare applicants to search for jobs first and offering welfare mothers school and vocational training to supplement their workfare jobs. And the same officials who called workfare the "heart and soul" of a program designed to move people off welfare are describing it as "a last resort" that best serves those with few jobs skills.
 
A Last Resort
"Workfare must be work of last resort," said Jason A. Turner, the city's new welfare chief, at a City Council meeting last month. "We're not saying everybody can go to work in the private economy. But we're saying that's our preference."
New York City is adopting strategies used elsewhere in the country. In Florida, South Carolina, Ohio and Wisconsin, only the least-skilled, least-educated welfare recipients end up in workfare programs.
Los Angeles, which has the nation's largest welfare caseload and the second-largest workfare program, plans to spend the next two years helping welfare mothers look for jobs, improve their education and hone vocational skills, in an attempt to keep them off workfare. Los Angeles County has also begun to offer job search services to single adults.
But policy makers who have shunned workfare are watching New York City's experiment keenly and with some foreboding. The experiences in the city, where the unemployment rate is 9.2 percent -- or nearly double the national average -- may well reflect their own futures, they say.
"Our first choice is to see if people can be placed in jobs," said Don Taylor, executive director of the Mississippi Department of Human Services, who has worked aggressively to keep workfare a tiny part of his state's welfare program. "But if we end up with high unemployment and the jobs simply aren't there, we may have no other recourse."
Critics of the Giuliani administration acknowledge that the city would find it hard to comply with new Federal and state rules without workfare. Under Federal law, 30 percent of all mothers on welfare must participate in work activities by Sept. 30. That required percentage goes up 5 percent each year and stops at 50 percent. States get credit for a decline in their caseloads.
In 2001, the Federal Government will stop paying benefits to all families who were on welfare in December 1996. The New York constitution requires the state to provide for its poor, which means the state and its counties will have to absorb the cost entirely. If they want to avoid paying for people in the long run, city officials will have to move them into jobs.
Mr. Turner, the architect of Wisconsin's welfare program, said that moving New York City's welfare recipients into jobs will only get harder. Most of the people with job skills are already employed. Drug addicts, the illiterate, the unskilled and the victims of domestic violence will be much harder to place.
"They can't go further" without a major new effort, said Mr. Turner before he took the job as New York's City welfare chief in January. That task now falls to him.

GRAPHIC: Photo: To earn his welfare check, a workfare participant in San Francisco, Anthony Brown, hoses the interior of a city bus. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By JAN M. ROSEN 

 BODY:

'IRREGULARITIES'
Cendant's Nose Dive
Investors like company books the way Japanese like fish: uncooked. So, fairly or not, an announcement by Cendant late on Wednesday that it had discovered "potential accounting irregularities" that would force it to lower 1997 earnings of $872 million by as much as $115 million greased the skids under its stock price; on Thursday the shares plunged $16.56, or 46.5 percent, to $19.06. Even though the stock edged up $2.125 on Friday, the event was a huge embarrassment for the company's president, Henry Silverman, who won a wide following on Wall Street as he built up the HFS Corporation, which merged with CUC International in December to form Cendant. And it was costly for several big mutual funds that had sizable Cendant stakes. On Thursday, Fidelity Magellan lost 1.5 percent of its value; Morgan Stanley's institutional aggressive equity portfolio lost 5.2 percent, and the Kaufmann Fund dropped 2.8 percent. 

PEOPLE
Grounding an Ace
Robert L. Crandall, 62, the combative chairman and chief executive of American Airlines who led many industry innovations, including frequent-flier programs and sophisticated computer reservation systems, will retire next month. He will be succeeded by Donald J. Carty, the airline's president. . . . Cantor Fitzgerald, a government bond broker, is suing Iris Cantor, the widow of the firm's founder, accusing her of violating a partnership agreement. . . . If the face of the Columbia Lion is crimson, blame Robert J. Barro, left. The economist backed out of a lucrative deal offered by the university, deciding to remain at Harvard. . . . Franklin D. Raines, an architect of the Clinton Administration's balanced-budget plan, quit as the White House budget director to become chief executive of Fannie Mae.
 
MARKETS
Rebounding to a Record
Stock prices trekked through hills and valleys. The Dow Jones industrial average, after setting a new high on Wednesday, tumbled 85.70 points on Thursday before gaining 90.93 on Friday to end the week at a record 9,167.50. One negative factor was a plunge in Asian markets after the finance ministers of the Group of Seven major industrialized nations, meeting in Washington, indicated that they would not move to support the weak Japanese yen. Another was slightly disappointing earnings from Merck and a warning from Intel, whose earnings just met expectations. Both the drug and technology sectors were weak, but recovered on Friday, and the financial services sector was strong, propelled by big merger plans.
 
The I.M.F.
A Worldwide Warning
The International Monetary Fund, in an assessment of world economies, lowered its projection for world economic growth to 3.1 percent from 4.1 percent a year earlier, largely because of Japan's malaise. The group also said that the United States was likely to ride out the rest of the Asian financial crisis largely unscathed but that American stock and bond markets were increasingly vulnerable to a major fall. . . . Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin called for tough international financial disclosure rules to avert crises of the sort now roiling Asia.
 
EARNINGS
Those Smiling Brokers
Healthy earnings gains, exceeding analysts' expectations, were reported by Merrill Lynch, up 11 percent; Paine Webber, up 20 percent, and Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, 55 percent. The gains, reflecting the booming stock market and speculation that brokers are prime targets in the current wave of financial industry mergers buoyed the share prices of all three firms. At J. P. Morgan, however, earnings fell 44 percent as costs for investment banking outpaced revenue. Still, the earnings surpassed Wall Street expectations. BankAmerica reported a 7 percent gain.
 
THE ECONOMY
A Cooler Spring
Is inflation vanquished or merely hibernating? In any case, consumer prices were unchanged last month, while retail sales unexpectedly fell 0.1 percent. Consumer price growth was held in check by a fourth consecutive monthly drop in energy prices, the Labor Department said, and prices for personal computers and supplies fell 2.8 percent. In another sign of a slightly cooler economy, the Commerce Department said housing starts declined 2.8 percent last month, to 1.59 million units at a seasonally adjusted annual rate. That was the first decline since November but still left starts at their second-highest level since January 1989. The nation's trade deficit widened to $12.11 billion in February, the largest since the nation started compiling monthly figures for both goods and services in January 1992.
 
THAILAND
Cauldron of Crisis
Faced with an ultimatum by Thailand's central bank to raise fresh capital, the Wanglee family dynasty is reluctantly preparing for a distress sale of a controlling stake in Nakornthon Bank, the family's crown jewel. Vorawee Wanglee, above, is chief executive. The collapse of Asian financial markets has struck a blow -- a fatal one, some economists say -- at perhaps the most outstanding feature of Thai business: the domination by a few wealthy Chinese families. "Our ancestors could never have imagined that it would come to this," said Thamnu Wanglee, the bank's president. "But they also could never have imagined such a crisis."
 
CYBERCAFES
No Place Like Home
In the mid-1990's, cybercafes were a now idea, serving light food, coffee and computer access for customers willing to pay $7 to $14 an hour to surf the net or check their E-mail. But in city after city, cybercafes have quietly closed or turned into something else -- a victim of their own strength. People who sampled the World Wide Web con leche began buying their own computers and speedy home connections. Now, many, like the Internet Cafe, below, in New York's East Village, have idle terminals.

HEADLINE: How to Stay a Titan

BYLINE: By Ron Chernow; Ron Chernow is the author of a forthcoming biography, "Titan: The Life of John D. Rockefeller Sr."

 BODY:
On May 15, 1911, in a soft voice that belied the supreme drama of the moment, Chief Justice Edward White read aloud a 20,000-word opinion, ordering the breakup of Standard Oil for violating the antitrust laws. Thus ended a morality play that had riveted America for five years, ever since Teddy Roosevelt's trustbusters decided to teach the trust and its founder, John D. Rockefeller, a lesson in corporate citizenship.
Amid the current wave of corporate mergers, the specter of Standard Oil now hovers over a swelling antitrust debate. On Tuesday, the appeals hearing in the Justice Department's antitrust probe of Microsoft is scheduled to begin. Many critics have noted the often eerie parallels between Rockefeller and Bill Gates. 
 Standard Oil was the most feared and admired monopoly of its day, refining, distributing and marketing nearly 90 percent of America's oil. Microsoft produces 90 percent of the operating systems in new personal computers, prompting similar public ambivalence, for computers are now as indispensable to the economy as oil.
The saga of John D. Rockefeller abounds in cautionary tales for Bill Gates. Like Mr. Gates, Rockefeller earned his fortune in a new industry where the rules of the game had to be improvised. He invested in his first Cleveland refinery in 1863, just four years after oil was discovered in Pennsylvania. In 1870, he established Standard Oil to bring this chaotic industry under his control. While skeptics wondered whether the oil would last, Rockefeller exhibited a fierce, messianic faith in its future. As he coped with a chronic surplus of refining capacity, he lost all trust in competition and began to champion a new economic dispensation: cooperation, his euphemism for monopoly.
In building his empire, Rockefeller patented many tactics that would be outlawed by the Sherman Antitrust Act in 1890. He colluded with railroads to win lucrative freight rates, secretly bought out rivals, throttled oil producers by controlling the pipelines, and monopolized oil sales by slashing prices when interlopers appeared. Like Mr. Gates, he adhered to the gospel of high-volume, low-cost production, believing that he had vouchsafed something precious to humanity: cheap illumination by kerosene.
Mr. Gates, of course, is no less evangelical about computers. He stoutly denies that Microsoft is a monopoly because it has lowered prices and improved products. Yet falling prices for personal computers and constant upgrades of Windows technology don't really acquit him of being a monopolist; they simply affirm that he is a very smart monopolist. Many people assume that the trust kings of the Gilded Age simply gouged consumers and sold shoddy products. But Rockefeller was an enterprising businessman who boasted that, in its first 20 years, Standard Oil lowered retail kerosene prices to 7.5 cents per gallon from 23.5 cents -- a drop only partly explained by sinking crude oil prices. The trust blanketed oil fields with efficient pipelines and pioneered marketing by tank wagons. It was dreaded more for its low, predatory pricing than for fleecing consumers. Incessant innovation and relatively cheap prices may be necessary conditions for maintaining a monopoly.
Rockefeller never construed his monopoly as an unlimited license to mint money. If he got too greedy, consumers could switch to substitutes -- say, coal instead of fuel oil. Indeed, Edison's light bulb finally doomed the kerosene business that first formed Rockefeller's fortune, though he and Standard Oil were then rescued by the automobile. Rockefeller set prices high enough to guarantee substantial profits but never so high as to lure competitors back into the field. And he refrained from achieving a 100 percent monopoly, later confessing that he allowed a few dozen refiners to eke out a meager existence so he could cite competition in the industry.
The same qualities that make people like Rockefeller and Bill Gates matchless businessmen -- a single-minded intensity, an implacable attitude toward competitors -- prepare them poorly for the delicate art of public relations. Almost from Standard Oil's inception, Rockefeller was hounded by courts and legislators, yet he never conceded any legitimacy to public inquiry. He seldom granted interviews or allowed himself to be photographed. When Ida Tarbell exposed his methods in McClure's Magazine from 1902 to 1905, making him America's most hated mogul, he didn't dignify her serial with a response. By the time Standard Oil hired its first publicist, in 1906, it had already lost the battle for public opinion.
Under fire from the Justice Department, Mr. Gates has awakened belatedly to the need to burnish his image, fielding a small army of aggressive public relations people. He now pops up in golf advertisements and on talk shows. The change in persona, if often cosmetic and unconvincing, at least acknowledges the need for greater accountability and the decisive role of public opinion in antitrust cases.
 A s Rockefeller's story illustrates, antitrust prosecutions tend to be highly political. Major cases are long, expensive and hard to win; trustbusters resort to them as weapons of last resort. Because Standard Oil adopted a strident, antagonistic tone toward investigators, it bore the brunt of Teddy Roosevelt's wrath. Some Standard Oil executives thought that U. S. Steel, International Harvester and other trusts forged by J. P. Morgan escaped prosecution by taking a more conciliatory approach.
In defying the Government's 1995 consent decree that prevented it from "bundling" its Windows operating system with its Internet Explorer browser -- the fear being that Microsoft would unfairly parlay dominance in desktop computers into Internet control -- Microsoft gambled on a hard-line approach. Yet, in refusing to make concessions, it has only invited wider scrutiny -- as the Standard Oil precedent would have predicted.
If Microsoft seems an all-powerful colossus, it is actually far more vulnerable than Standard Oil. The oil trust was 20 times the size of its nearest competitor, the puny Pure Oil. Except for production, where its market share never exceeded 35 percent, Standard Oil owned the entire industry. The antitrust crusade against it was spearheaded by a ragtag band of maverick refiners, muckraking journalists and reform-minded attorneys general, supported by small oil producers from new fields in Texas, California and Kansas.
By contrast, Microsoft faces a phalanx of formidable competitors, including Netscape, Oracle, I.B.M. and Sun Microsystems. These powerful companies deploy hordes of lawyers, publicists and politicians to keep Microsoft on the defensive.
Even so, Mr. Gates remains popular, even heroic, among many Americans. The move to block him will succeed only if his competitors can convince the public that they aren't trying to win in the political arena what they have failed to achieve in the marketplace. So far, there are only glimmers of a mass popular revolt against Mr. Gates of the sort that Ida Tarbell and Teddy Roosevelt managed to engineer against Rockefeller.
If Standard Oil's fate argues for Microsoft to take a more cooperative approach, it also suggests that the Justice Department should avoid broad antitrust action against the company. Standard Oil presided over a comparatively static industry, with big technological shifts -- like the advent of long-distance pipelines or oil tankers -- occurring only two or three times a decade. The core products remained remarkably unchanged.
By contrast, the computer industry thrives on perpetual revolutions in the design, power and even purposes of its products. New technologies, like network computers or the Java programming language, have the potential to reshape the industry and subvert Microsoft's domination. The panicky, almost paranoid reaction of Bill Gates to his competitors is perhaps the strongest testimony to his underlying anxiety about his monopoly -- an anxiety that seldom ruffled the sleep of John D. Rockefeller.
The Justice Department should insure that Mr. Gates doesn't abuse his operating system monopoly as he expands into new areas. At the same time, it should recognize that he can never rule his industry as absolutely as Rockefeller did the oil business. There's no need to re-enact the agony of the Standard Oil breakup.

HEADLINE: Talks Indicate Japan's Links With Russians Are Improving

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 18

 BODY:
Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto began a two-day meeting with President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia today in an effort to improve economic cooperation and work toward a peace treaty that would finally mark an end to territorial disputes dating from World War II.
Both men appeared vigorous and cheerful as they greeted each other with an embrace in the resort town of Kawana, 80 miles southwest of Tokyo. 
 The meeting is not expected to achieve a breakthrough, but it still marks a steady improvement in Russian-Japanese relations.
Antagonism between the two countries has been a central feature of the Asian political landscape for decades; they never signed a peace treaty after World War II. Japan resisted economic cooperation with Russia in large part because it insisted on first recovering a group of islands that Russia seized in the closing days of the war.
Over the last few years, however, Japan has switched tactics. It still wants the return of the islands -- which Japan calls its Northern Territories and Russia says are part of the Kurile Island chain. But Tokyo now seems prepared to discuss other issues and improve ties in the hope that this will eventually lead to return of the islands.
"I'm looking forward to having frank talks with Ryu," Mr. Yeltsin said, using a nickname for the Japanese Prime Minister. The two leaders disclosed little about their conversation today, but they are to hold a news conference on Sunday after their meetings.
Mr. Hashimoto's strategy has been to try to build trust and a personal relationship with Mr. Yeltsin. To that end he organized what he called a "no necktie" summit meeting in a resort villa. In Japan, it is often said that officials find it easier to speak directly and get to the bottom of a problem when they are meeting informally and have shed their neckties -- or easiest of all when they have shed everything and are drinking sake while bathing together nude.
This meeting will not go that far, however, and in any case it is unclear whether the informality will make much difference for Mr. Yeltsin, who is impetuous and brash and thus everything that Mr. Hashimoto is not.
The main point of the meeting will be to further develop the plan outlined at a similar meeting in Russia last November to achieve a peace treaty by 2000.
As part of the economic cooperation measures envisioned in that plan, Mr. Hashimoto is expected to announce that he will make it easier to provide Japanese trade insurance for transactions with Russia. That step might in turn lead to more Japanese investment in Russia.
The two countries will also discuss cooperation in combating global warming, and in organizing disaster drills in the Sea of Japan between their naval forces. They may also call for a regular security dialogue in Asia involving Japan, Russia, China and the United States.
If the two nations can sign a peace treaty and improve relations, then there is potential for a mutually beneficial economic partnership. Russia has vast quantities of untapped natural resources in its far East, areas closer to Tokyo than to Moscow. And Japan has the technology and capital to exploit those resources, as well as the need for them to power its industry.
Trade and investment between the two are already increasing, though slowly. And a fishing agreement signed in February may resolve disputes that in the past have frequently led Russian patrol vessels to seize Japanese fishing boats. In a sign of improved relations last year, a Russian destroyer made a courtesy call on a Japanese port for the first time in 103 years.
After meeting today in Kawana and walking together with arms around each other, Mr. Yeltsin and Mr. Hashimoto burst into a wedding being held at the resort and offered their congratulations. Mr. Yeltsin kissed the stunned bride on both cheeks.
"I hope you have many children," Mr. Yeltsin told her. "I would like to convey the best wishes of the entire Russian people to you."
Mr. Hashimoto is planning to visit Russia for further talks this fall, and Mr. Yeltsin is expected to return to Japan again next year.

HEADLINE: Where Opium Reigned, Burmese Claim Inroads

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN 

DATELINE: LASHIO, Myanmar

 BODY:
In the remote valleys and rugged mountains here in northeastern Myanmar, opium offers more than a narcotic high. For years, it has provided a livelihood for hill tribes who inhabit the northern expanse of the Golden Triangle, the lush, lawless area of Southeast Asia that is the source of much of the world's heroin.
Opium finances daily needs, from rice and cooking oil to assault rifles. The rifles are used to wage rebellion and to defend the mule caravans transporting the sticky, pungent opium to be refined into heroin for American and European drug habits. 
 Myanmar, formerly Burma, produced an estimated 2,600 tons of opium last year, enough to make more than 200 tons of heroin -- at least 60 percent of the world total. But the drug trade is changing along Myanmar's porous frontiers with Thailand, China and Laos, and one of the most startling shifts may be in the attitude of the military junta that seized power in this country in 1988.
For years the junta tolerated opium trafficking as the price of its cease-fires with insurgent ethnic groups. Now it says that it wants to eradicate all opium within five years. To show what it has accomplished, it recently allowed three American reporters into an opium-growing region usually closed to visitors.
Some diplomats in Yangon, the capital, view the eradication claim skeptically because land devoted to opium cultivation has doubled under the junta's rule and the country's mismanaged economy has grown to rely on laundered drug profits.
The Government says it has eradicated 41,000 acres of poppies, one-tenth of the land under opium cultivation in Myanmar. "The crop eradication areas are only small parts of the areas they do control," a Western diplomat said. 'They are window dressing."
Col. Gyaw Thien, the chief of Myanmar's counternarcotics program, disagreed, declaring that the Government was being asked to solve a century-old problem in two weeks without any help. "It's quite unfair," he said. "We are making much more effective interdictions and seizures than we have in the past."
Last year, police and army units reported seizing 1.5 tons of heroin, compared with about half a ton in 1996, though their record seizures amount to less than 1 percent of Myanmar's output. "This drug problem is not only the problem of the United States," Colonel Gyaw Thien said. "It's our problem too. We know that we cannot fight this alone."
The junta's new policy puts Washington in a quandary because the United States cut off counternarcotics aid to Burma after the coup in 1988. Restoring such aid could undercut other American economic sanctions and lend legitimacy to a dictatorship that stands accused of widespread abuse of human rights.
"We think we can get rid of 60 percent of the heroin going into the U.S. in 12 months' time if the U.S. cooperates with us," said Lieut. Col. Hla Min, the deputy director of the Office of Strategic Studies, a planning branch of military intelligence.
A Western diplomat who watched the shift concluded: "What this Government wants to do is perpetuate itself in power. They know it's got a bad image. They looked at drugs and found this is the one asset they have. They'd like to use whatever they've done to improve their image and try to get sanctions lifted."
The State Department acknowledges in its latest drug control report that it has no evidence that Myanmar's Government is trafficking in drugs on an institutional level.
"However," the report said, "there are persistent and reliable reports that officials, particularly army personnel posted in outlying areas, are involved in the drug business."
The Government denies this, citing the arrest of 11 army officers last April for colluding with a heroin refining operation in northern Shan state. The senior officer, a lieutenant colonel, was sent to prison for 25 years. It also deported Li Yunchun, a fugitive trafficker indicted in New York, to Thailand, which handed him over to the United States.
But new traffickers, notably the Wa, a fierce hill people whose ancestors hunted heads, have wrested control of the lucrative heroin business from remnants of renegade Chinese Nationalist soldiers and rebel militias.
Nearly a million Wa straddle the border between China and Myanmar. Their insurgent army has diversified from heroin into methamphetamines, powerful synthetic stimulants that have saturated Thailand and since turned up in Japan, Taiwan and Malaysia, Burmese and Western officials say. A Burmese counter-narcotics official said the Wa now make more money from methamphetamines than from heroin and refine both drugs themselves using chemicals smuggled in primarily from China.
Because of aggressive action by the Thai police, the old trafficking routes through the Golden Triangle are shifting from Thailand into China, or less often Laos and even northeastern India. Some heroin still moves by truck down from the Shan highlands market town of Lashio, through lowland Mandalay to the port of Yangon, as Rangoon is now called.
Eradicating opium could help the military Government's strategy of subduing ethnic insurgents who traffic in opium to finance their wars of independence. Government troops cannot enter most Wa-controlled territory without a battle.
With an army estimated at 15,000 to 20,000 men, the Wa have grown so strong, acquiring surface-to-air missiles and modern communications equipment, that Government troops complain about feeling outgunned. Last summer, a 30-man Government patrol was wiped out when it ran into a Wa mule caravan smuggling methamphetamine to Thailand.
"The Burmese would like nothing better than to do away with the drug trade," another diplomat in Yangon said, "because it would take guns out of the hands of these armies."
The Government's creation of a handful of opium-free zones has upset local farmers. "What we're talking about is really changing their life style," said Jorgen Kristensen, an official with the United Nations Drug Control Program, which has introduced alternative development projects. "Poppy cultivation is ingrained in their culture."
At Nam Tit, a Wa town about a half-hour's walk from the Chinese border, Zi Zi Fa, a farmer in patched shirt and shorts, said his grandfather and father grew opium poppies. He earned about $650 for his own annual crop of 12 1/2 pounds of opium, which he did not need to take to market. "When I was growing poppies," he said, "the buyer came to me."
Since the Government told him to grow soybeans instead, Mr. Zi said, he earns one-tenth of what opium paid, not enough to feed 10 family members.
"The family is barely surviving," he said, echoing a complaint expressed by opium farmers in Afghanistan and coca farmers in Colombia and Peru.
"If we did not grow poppies, our income would not last more than one or two months," he said. 'In the high mountains, rice doesn't grow, and it's too cold. The corn is fit only for the pigs."
In the nearby border town of Chin Shwe Haw, Kyan Ti Jy, a farmer from the ethnic Chinese Kokang minority, said, "We earned more money growing poppies, but our leader said to stop growing opium." Mr. Kyan obediently planted lichee trees and sugar cane. Now, he complained, "nobody's buying sugar because there's no mill." Construction on a sugar refinery is not expected before September.
With their incomes slashed by more than half, "the farmers are not very happy," said a local official, Kyan Tin Wan.
"But the Government is giving out rubber plants and lichee trees almost free of charge, and free fertilizer," he said.
It will take at least three years for the lichee trees to bear fruit. In the meantime, Kyan Tin Wan said, "large families who cannot stand it are going out of designated opium-free areas to where the Government cannot touch them."
The official conceded that even farmers who gave up opium as a crop "still might be growing a little bit here and there for medicinal purposes."
At his base in Lauk Kai, the Kokang political leader, Peng Jiasheng, said it was hard for his people to stop growing opium.
"We admit there is poppy growing in this area to a certain extent, but not the way we've been portrayed," he said. "It's not that the leaders are buying opium and taking it down to the Golden Triangle. We're not involved in that."
Before the Kokang concluded a cease-fire with the Burmese Government in 1989, Mr. Peng trafficked in opium himself.
"When we were insurgents, we needed to expand our army and we needed weapons and food," he said. "For that we needed to grow more poppies."
His troops did not cultivate opium, Mr. Peng said, but levied a 40 percent tax on what local farmers produced. "Seventy percent of the people in this area were supporting us financially for the insurgency," he explained. "But now there's no more fighting and our troops are drastically reduced." At the height of the rebellion, he said, the Kokang and Wa could field 60,000 soldiers between them. Now, he insisted, his troops have dwindled to 500.
"Today it's peaceful, so we don't need to grow poppies," the Kokang leader said, waving a hand adorned with a heavy gold bracelet and gold rings. "If my people can have their stomachs full and something appropriate to wear, they are happy enough. They don't need anything more."
Taking the profit out of opium may be the toughest challenge because when the leader of a drug operation quits, contenders jockey to replace him. For years, Khun Sa and his narco-army dominated the heroin trade under the guise of fighting for Shan self-determination. After some of his troops mutinied, Khun Sa negotiated his surrender in January 1996 and lives comfortably, but in poor health, under Government observation in Yangon.
"We were fighting him for years," Colonel Hla Min of the Office of Strategic Studies said, justifying the Government's accommodation with Khun Sa. "We were not gaining much ground because he was well equipped, well dug-in, and the terrain was terrible. We were sacrificing too many casualties."
"Khun Sa is a walking encyclopedia regarding the drug issue," Colonel Hla Min said. "Everything he knows, we know. But this is a multibillion-dollar business."
The vacuum left by Khun Sa was soon filled by Wei Hsueh-kang, a Wa commander who is said to have 7,000 troops protecting his heroin and methamphetamine operation. "All information is that he's getting larger by the day," said a Western official who follows narcotics matters.
For all the heroin they export to the United States and Europe, such leaders do not tolerate its use in their own ranks. Khun Sa detoxified errant soldiers in cages exposed to the blistering sun or in soggy holes in the ground. While older Kokang people may use opium as medicine, Mr. Peng said, heroin "is not medicine, so there's no excuse."
"Trading in heroin is a serious offense," he said. "We shoot the person."

HEADLINE: Huge Bank Mergers Worry Consumer Groups

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 18

 BODY:
With the latest wave of bank mergers announced in recent days, most of the public attention was focused on what the mergers would mean to profits, stock prices, executive salaries and corporate synergy. Increasingly, though, citizens' advocates and some lawmakers are questioning what this consolidation in the banking industry will mean to a very basic group: consumers.
Concerned consumer advocates predict that the behemoth mergers of Travelers Group Inc. with Citicorp and of Nationsbank with the BankAmerica Corporation will eventually mean higher costs and fewer services for many customers, especially those with low and moderate incomes. 
 These advocates, who tend to represent consumer groups with a markedly liberal ideology, cite studies indicating that large multistate banks tend to charge higher fees for checking accounts and for the use of automated teller machines. Similarly, these advocates point to studies by the Federal Reserve indicating that when newly merged banks consolidate operations, the branch offices they close tend to be concentrated more heavily in poorer neighborhoods.
"Our general view is straightforward," said Ed Mierzwinski, director of consumer programs for the United States Public Interest Research Group, an advocacy organization. "The bigger banks use monopoly power to charge higher fees. Basically, these mergers create fewer choices for consumers. Fewer choices mean less competition and more monopoly consolidation of power."
But some economists describe these consumer advocates as victims of an outmoded ideology that glorifies a past banking environment in which financial institutions routinely red-lined poor neighborhoods, and consumers had an extremely difficult time getting cash during hours when their neighborhood bank was closed.
"I think they're missing the boat," said Randall Kroszner, an associate professor of economics at the University of Chicago's Graduate School of Business, who specializes in banking issues. "I think they're focusing on the wrong issues. They're concerned about change. But you have to look at where we're starting from. We are starting from an environment that has been extremely anti-consumer."
The number of banks and savings and loan institutions has declined as a result of deregulation, acquisitions and failures, to 10,922 in 1997 from 18,193 in 1981. But at the same time, the number of bank branches has remained relatively stable, around 83,000, meaning consolidation has not had an adverse effect on convenience.
Moreover, some economists argue that the merger frenzy has been taking place at the top of the banking food chain, not at the level of neighborhood banks. A study published last year by John Boyd, professor of finance at the University of Minnesota, indicated that 85 percent of those banks that were taken over had assets of more than $100 million. In Mr. Carlson's view, competition in the banking field still remains because the merger mania so far has not threatened small local banks.
"To a very substantial extent, the consolidation is big banks buying big banks or buying medium-size banks," Mr. Boyd said. "And the small local banks are just sitting there doing what they always do -- making money."
The fear of the consolidation and abuse of banking power, however, is not limited to a few liberal organizations. Senator Arlen Specter, Republican of Pennsylvania, and Representative Jim Leach, Republican of Iowa, said this week that their committees would conduct hearings this month on the mergers.
"I'm very concerned about the impact on consumers of all these mergers," said Mr. Specter, a member of the Anti-Trust, Business Rights and Competition subcommittee of the Senate Judiciary Committee. "Consumers are going to have fewer banks to go to that are competing for their business."
"Every time you turn around, something is happening," he continued. "We live in a free enterprise economy, laissez-faire. But it's time we stop, look and listen to see if the public interest is being served. We know that the Wall Street interests are being served."
Mr. Leach, who is chairman of House Banking Committee, also promised to look into the issue.
Whether concentration of banking in fewer and fewer hands is good for consumers might depend on which consumers are being considered.
Some liberal consumer advocates note that several studies show that large multistate banks tend to charge higher fees for banking services. In a June 1997 study, the governors of the Federal Reserve Board found that large multistate banks charge, on average, $4 more to stop payment on a check than do small banks that operate in one state. These larger financial institutions also were more likely to charge higher fees for automated teller transactions at other banks.
The Federal Reserve study also showed that on average, the larger banks required a higher minimum balance in checking accounts to avoid a monthly fee, were more likely to provide simple passbook savings accounts and to require a smaller minimum deposit to open one.
But some economists, including Mr. Kroszner, assert that the big financial institutions, with their one-stop shopping appeal, could be more beneficial to affluent consumers, who might buy stocks or mutual funds at their local branch or use one of their teller machines at some far-flung site without having to pay a fee.
"We will probably end up with a two-tiered banking system, the larger banks serving jet-setters and business people," Mr. Kroszner said. "That doesn't mean that the small community bank is going to go away. They provide a different type of service, more personal, more relationship oriented."
The question is whether these full-service banks will still be around in every neighborhood. Another Federal Reserve study, this one published in September, showed that despite little change in the overall number of bank branches, the number of branches in inner-city neighborhoods declined 21 percent from 1975 to 1995.
"This is the most obvious area of impact," said John E. Taylor, president of National Community Reinvestment Coalition, a trade association of groups seeking more investment in inner-city areas. "Where there are overlapping branches as a result of a merger, somebody is going to close branches. Disproportionately, these branch closings occur in minority and poor neighborhoods."
The Federal Reserve study indicated that it was difficult to determine whether the branch closings in poor inner-city areas were the result of acquisitions or of population loss in these neighborhoods.
"In 1975, low-income neighborhoods had the largest number of offices per capita," the study said. "By 1995, there was relatively little change."

HEADLINE: Deaths of Sea Turtles Create Split on Causes

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: SOUTH PADRE ISLAND, Tex.

 BODY:
Straight up the coast from here, a 100-pound loggerhead turtle named Bill -- with no front flippers -- lives in a water tank at a marine science institute, the apparent victim of someone with a big knife.
At Padre Island National Seashore, Donna Shaver, who has fought for the last 18 years to save sea turtles, points out a steel table where a sea turtle awaits a necropsy to determine a cause of death. Then she heads to a pit that holds 10 dead turtles -- 4 of them Kemp's ridleys, which are believed to be the world's most endangered turtles and one of the most endangered species. 
 "It's very frustrating and it's very depressing," said Ms. Shaver, who is a research biologist for the United States Geological Survey on Padre Island and the Texas coordinator for the Sea Turtle Stranding and Salvage Network.
Conservationists say the turtles die when they get trapped in the nets of shrimp boats and drown. The large number of deaths, along with with mutilations that conservationists suspect are intentional, have led three groups to demand that the waters off this national seashore be permanently closed to shrimpers.
The groups, Earth Island Institute's Sea Turtle Restoration Project, the Humane Society of the United States and Help Endangered Animals-Ridley Turtles want 65 miles of coastline designated as a marine sanctuary.
But the shrimping industry says that any number of causes, including pollution, are causing the deaths and that more turtles are dying because there are simply more of them out there. Putting the area off limits to shrimpers would cause more than $150 million in economic loss to an industry that employs 15,000 people in the state, said Wilma Anderson, the executive director of the Texas Shrimp Association. It would also endanger the existence of the fishing ports of Brownsville and Port Isabel, among the nation's most lucrative, she said.
David Wellesley, a 47-year-old shrimper, said he doubted that shrimpers were responsible for all the dead turtles.
"There ain't no shrimper on this coast that will tell you he wants to catch a turtle," said Mr. Wellesley, who works on the 75-foot Uncle Buddy, docked in Aransas Pass. "I watch a lot of PBS and Discovery Channel. I've got nothing against the turtle."
But Ms. Shaver said the turtle deaths were clearly related to shrimping. They drop 90 percent in the two months each summer when Texas bans offshore shrimpers to let shrimps grow, she said.
In March, 54 sea turtles were found dead, 18 of them ridleys. In March 1997, 11 were found, 3 of them ridleys. Last year, 459 turtles, including loggerheads, greens, leatherbacks, hawksbills and Kemp's ridleys, were stranded on the same coastline, Ms. Shaver said, and 173 were ridleys.
The worldwide population of adult ridleys is estimated at 3,000, up from fewer than 2,000 in the 1980's.
The deaths of ridley turtles come in the midst of a 20-year effort to coax the olive-colored turtles to nest at Padre. The ridleys, which can grow to 100 pounds and more than two-feet in length, are the smallest of the sea turtles. They had nested almost exclusively in Mexico, but from 1978 to 1988 more than 22,000 eggs were shipped here in a project between the two countries. The project was intended to create a backup nesting site in the United States.
Since the early 1990's, Federal law has required American shrimpers to sew metal or plastic grates into their nets to shunt the sea turtles out through a nearby flap. Known as turtle-excluder devices, or T.E.D.'s, such shields are supposed to free 97 percent of captured turtles.
"The Coast Guard says we're 95 to 98 percent in compliance," said W. K. Zimmerman, who owns Nautical Marine, a Port Isabel company with 10 shrimp boats. "But the first time they find one dead turtle on the beach, we're all bad boys and we're not using our T.E.D.'s."
Closing the coastline may be an option. But studies by the National Marine Fisheries Service, an agency of the Commerce Department that is responsible for protecting the turtles, show that such action would not be effective, said Colleen Coogan, a biologist for the agency's southeastern region.
Stricter enforcement by the United States Coast Guard to catch those few who do not use the excluder devices should protect the turtles as well as closing the coastline would, Ms. Coogan said.
Meanwhile, Tony Amos, the University of Texas researcher who saved Bill, the mutilated turtle, is trying to find him a home at an aquarium, so far without luck.
"They like to have a complete animal to put on display," Mr. Amos said.

HEADLINE: THE BOATING REPORT;
EF Language Tames the Seas, and Rivals

BYLINE: By BARBARA LLOYD 

DATELINE: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., April 18

 BODY:
Mark Rudiger's voice resonated from the deck intercom on EF Language, the leading 64-foot sailboat here on its stopover in the Whitbread Round the World Race.
"Now hear this, now hear this," the voice said. "Drinks will be served on the Lido deck." 
 Wry laughter filled the cockpit. They were no tourists, and their yacht was no Love Boat, and liquor is not allowed on board. But the lighthearted moment Wednesday captured the essence of what the crew had accomplished the last eight months. It had turned a grueling trip across unknown waters into an unexpected coup.
Team EF Language had begun the race as a crew with a reputation for being expert round-the-buoy sailors but relative neophytes in the rigors of a 31,600-nautical-mile marathon around the world. And the 1997-98 competition has been as tough as it gets in yachting. America's Cup sailors flooded to the event, and old Whitbread stalwarts such as Grant Dalton and Lawrie Smith were back.
But EF Language has not only stood up, but also claimed significant victories. It has won three of six Whitbread stages so far and finished second, fourth and fifth in the other three. With 608 points over all, the EF boat, with Paul Cayard of San Francisco as its skipper and team mentor, has 115 points more than its second-place opponent, Swedish Match. With three legs left, it is in an enviable position in the nine-boat international competition.
In fact, so strong is EF Language's potential grip on the Whitbread trophy that some aficionados actually fell for an April Fool's Day news story announcing that the boat would skip the seventh leg from here to Baltimore so as to hone itself for the final two legs.
EF Language is in a comfortable niche, and here in sunny Florida, it has been tough to keep the smiles under control. Autograph seekers are at every corner, and the circus atmosphere of the Whitbread base here, complete with tents, eateries and souvenirs, makes the hardships at sea seem remote.
But as always, Cayard takes nothing for granted.
"It seems like a great spot to be in," Cayard said Thursday. "But it's not without pressure. I still have high expectations for my team. I am still looking at the big picture, and I don't want to break anything on the boat in the next few legs. Even if it's my own sense of pride, I don't want to be dribbling into the finish line."
The crew has not let up under his tutelage. With the seventh stage scheduled to start Sunday and Baltimore a mere 870 nautical miles north, the team went sailing Wednesday to calibrate its electronic instruments and check the boat's newly installed mast. On Friday, they set out to sea again, this time to re-create the start itself.
This focus has characterized EF's crew throughout the journey. In February, when the boat rounded Cape Horn, the legendary tip of South America, the team did not break open the sailor's traditional bottle of Champagne. "We had freeze-dried apple pudding to celebrate," said Rudiger, who is the boat's navigator. "It looked like purple mush."
If any member of the crew has the right to complain about small matters -- albeit in jest -- it is Rudiger. Rudi, as his teammates call him, spends about 80 percent of his time below deck in a cramped space about the size of a home freezer.
It has a double seat, not unlike the front of the little bumper cars people ride in amusement parks. Cayard, like Rudiger more than 6 feet 2 inches tall, often crams in beside him. With the 40-foot seas and boat-bashing that goes on in a Whitbread race, even a machine shop sounds quieter than their racing cubbyhole. There they pore over the steady flow of weather faxes and computer data that streams in day and night.
Smith credits EF's navigational decisions for its commanding lead. "They haven't had any bad luck," he said, "and their navigation has been excellent. They've done well by being in the right place more than anyone else."
It is well-earned, if grudging, praise from the 42-year-old Smith. He had been skipper of EF before the race started, but traded that spot to skipper Silk Cut, a British entry. "Obviously, I gave away a very good campaign," he said. It did not help that Silk Cut was dismasted on its way to Cape Horn, a breakdown that cost Smith any chance of winning.
There is no love lost between the two teams, and a standoff subsequently developed over their masts. Both EF Language and Silk Cut had identical spars, and Team EF asked Smith in Sao Sebastiao, Brazil, the last stopover, to share information about what had failed on Silk Cut's mast. Smith refused; if EF was worried about its mast falling down, he said, the team could choose not to sail. Ultimately, he suggested that EF pay him for the information.
"I wanted to make sure that if someone dies because EF's mast falls down, I could say that I offered them the technology but they refused to pay for it," Smith said succinctly.
Johan Salen, EF's president, insisted that the information was a matter of concern for the good of the competition. "This sport cannot survive if you cannot help each other in safety-related issues," Salen said.
The EF team installed a new mast here after convincing race officials that the mast it already had needed to be replaced because it showed structural fatigue. EF team members are treating Smith's lack of cooperation as fallout from EF's being in the lead; Silk Cut is sixth.
The EF Language team has its own views of its success. "I think preparation is a big factor for us," Rudiger said. "This team got an early start, our sail development is top notch, and it's turned out to be real important that we have boat speed."
Salen added, "Winners are those who manage their problems in the best way."
EF has spared no detail or expense to do that. The syndicate fields two boats with an unprecedented $20 million budget. The budgets of most of its eight rivals are half of Team EF's. EF Education, the race sponsor, is a multinational Swedish educational services company. It has 54 people on its Whitbread payroll; 38 other sponsors and suppliers assist in the effort.
EF Language is winning, earning the approval of the sponsors. But the group's second yacht, EF Education, has not done nearly so well. The all-female crew is in last place with 148 points. It has been the victim of gear failures and generally a poor showing that can be attributed in large part to the women's relative lack of ocean experience.
Having two teams, each with a similar new boat built in Sweden, has allowed Team EF the luxury of economies of scale. With twice as many shore crew members than other Whitbread crews, EF can focus on whichever yacht needs more help.
Richard Brisius, a Swede who is shore manager, oversees a slick and efficient Whitbread campaign. At any time, he has two 40-foot containers filled with gear and supplies traveling by ship to the next Whitbread port. Here in Fort Lauderdale, two other containers are in constant use. One serves as a storage container, the other as a maintenance shop.
"Our idea has been to create a setup ashore where people find everything they're used to having," Brisius said. "Once ashore, they can quickly get into a work mode, get everything fixed on the boat, and then have quality time off."
Brisius ships three skateboards from place to place. And he understands the need for in-line skates, bicycles and even a kayak. But he drew the line the day crew members looked admiringly at four-foot wood-carved giraffes in South Africa. "I told everyone, 'No giraffes,' " he said. " 'No giraffes.' But I think someone hid a wood rhino."

HEADLINE: Mayor Prices New Name

BYLINE: By MIKE ALLEN 

 BODY:
Eager to play down the possible $1 billion cost for a new Yankee Stadium, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is reiterating the idea of naming a new stadium for a corporation that would help pick up the tab.
While such a deal might upset many fans, it holds great appeal for a Mayor trying to minimize the political and economic cost of moving the Yankees out of the Bronx, probably to the West Side of Manhattan. 
 "Naming rights of baseball parks have gone as high as $100 million, and it's estimated that naming rights for a Shea or Yankee stadium would exceed that amount by a considerable amount," the Mayor said Friday on his radio call-in program on WABC-AM. After citing other possible sources of private funds, including permanent advertising rights, he added, "All of those things are things that need to be negotiated."
The possibility of such a sale surfaced two years ago, when a report commissioned by the city and state estimated that the naming rights for a new stadium for the Yankees could be worth $1.5 million a year. At the time, the Mayor joked that the name of the new stadium "depends on the amount of money" that is offered.
Since then, he has raised the idea several times. But he is pushing it afresh after the collapse on Monday of a 500-pound steel joint at Yankee Stadium, which forced the postponement of two games and emboldened proponents of a new field.
The city's inspectors found no structural problems with the stadium. For the Mayor, though, it was a chance to promote a new stadium, which would include the lucrative skyboxes that the 75-year-old Yankee Stadium lacks. Donning a Yankees cap and jacket when cameras were around, he spent much of the week promoting replacements for Yankee Stadium and Shea Stadium.
Although the estimated cost of $1 billion for a new home for the Yankees came from a report commissioned in part by the city, the Mayor dismissed it throughout the week as the unsubstantiated exaggeration of opponents.
On his radio program, he said he would use the coming days to educate New Yorkers about the costs and benefits of retaining both baseball teams by "explaining how it can be done, without nearly the difficulties that many who just oppose any kind of development, or any change, really, will suggest."

HEADLINE: In Easy Year for Incumbents, Republican Breaks the Norm

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: JENKINTOWN, Pa., April 17

 BODY:
In an election year when voter contentment and a humming economy seem likely to keep most members of Congress in office, Representative Jon D. Fox diverges from the norm.
Mr. Fox, a Republican who was first elected to Congress in 1994 from the affluent suburbs west of Philadelphia, is perceived as one of the most vulnerable incumbents in what is widely described as a low-stress year for those already in office. 
 Mr. Fox, who has never won more than 49 percent of the vote, is being challenged by three members of his own party in next month's primary. If he wins, his opponent in November is the same Democrat who lost to him by just 84 votes two years ago. And Mr. Fox is on a select list of sitting Republicans whom Democrats hope to oust in their long-shot quest to retake control of the House.
"His fellow Republicans smell blood in the water and are going after him," said Olivia Morgan, a spokeswoman for the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee.
Two of his Republican challengers have more cash than Mr. Fox has, according to the Federal Election Commission. And three have started broadcasting television ads.
"Unless you are up on TV, you won't be able to take out an incumbent," said Jonathan Newman, a lawyer who has so far emerged as Mr. Fox's most aggressive challenger.
Mr. Newman has lent himself $575,000, and has half a million dollars left. Melissa Brown, an opthalmologist who has appealed to doctors across the country for contributions, has $367,000 on hand. Mr. Fox has $193,000 in his campaign treasury. Michael McMonagle, a longtime abortion opponent, has about $37,000.
The big spending promises to make this the most expensive Congressional race ever in this district, which lies largely in Montgomery County and encompasses some of the wealthy Main Line suburbs.
In 1992, voters elected a Democrat, Marjorie Margolies-Mezvinsky, for the first time since World War I -- only to throw her out in 1994 because she cast the deciding vote for President Clinton's tax-raising budget.
While the district remains heavily Republican, its relatively liberal leanings -- in favor of abortion rights and gun control -- have opened it increasingly to Democratic candidates who can appeal to its many homemakers. President Clinton won here in both of his elections.
But with both parties finding success in the ideological middle, there have been few disputes in the runup to the May 19 primary. Mr. Fox, Mr. Newman and Ms. Brown all favor abortion rights. They loathe the Internal Revenue Service.
Mr. Fox seems to be following the strategy of the Republican Congressional leaders, which is to lay low and not provoke old antagonisms toward the party's "revolutionary" class of 1994. At a breakfast here for local business men and women, Mr. Fox said he was most proud of having secured millions of dollars in the recent highway bill for local road projects and of providing constituent services.
The primary has focused on such nebulous verities as whether Mr. Fox is a career politician who has been bought by special interests, as Mr. Newman asserts, or whether Mr. Newman is a dilettante (he breeds race horses) trying to buy his way into office, as Mr. Fox asserts. Mr. Fox argues that experience counts; Mr. Newman promises to put a smarter face on the district in Congress.
Terry Madonna, a political analyst at Millersville University, said that because Republicans had opted for a nonconfrontational, don't-rock-the-boat style, the primary hinged more on personalities than issues.
"There are still big divisions in the Republican caucus in Washington," Mr. Madonna said, "but what the public is seeing is a milder, softer Republican Party, and that makes it more difficult to define the mushy middle." So mild has the Republican revolution become that Mr. Fox will be the host of Speaker Newt Gingrich, once portrayed by Democrats as the face of extremism, at a Monday fund-raiser.
Mr. Newman, 36, expressed a fervor closer in spirit to the young House conservatives. But he said at one point that they had "too hard an edge that turns people off."
Mr. Madonna said Mr. Newman had run "the most inept campaign I've ever seen." The challenger is on his third set of campaign workers. And three local chapters of the N.A.A.C.P. plan to meet on Monday night to discuss the racial implications of some of Mr. Newman's statements and a possible racial slur by a former campaign manager. Mr. Newman opposes affirmative action. He opposed the nomination of a local black judge to a Federal judgeship, saying she was soft on crime.
Mr. Madonna said Mr. Fox could benefit by having so many challengers in the primary, because they could split the anti-Fox vote.
"But make no mistake -- this guy is always one furlong away from disaster," Mr. Madonna said. "He's not aggressive. There's no focus to him. He has never been able to establish a firm base in the district."

HEADLINE: Terry Sanford, Pace-Setting Governor in 60's, Dies at 80

BYLINE: By DAVID STOUT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 18

 BODY:
Terry Sanford, who lowered racial barriers as Governor of North Carolina in the 1960's, setting the style for a new kind of Southern politician, and later became a United States Senator and Presidential candidate, died today at his home in Durham, N.C. He was 80.
The cause was complications from cancer, said Duke University, where Mr. Sanford was treated and where he was president from 1969 to 1985. 
 Until his cancer was diagnosed in December, Mr. Sanford had taught government and public policy at Duke and practiced law. He was president of the university, in Durham, after serving as Governor and before his term in the Senate. Mr. Sanford was at various times a lawyer, a member of the North Carolina State Senate, from 1953 to 1955, and, in the early 1940's, an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
Mr. Sanford was Governor from 1961 to 1965, a time when civil rights demonstrations were frequently met with violence. In a speech on Jan. 18, 1963, he called for an end to job discrimination against blacks and announced the creation of a biracial panel, the North Carolina Good Neighbor Council, to work toward that end.
"Despite great progress, the Negro's opportunity to obtain a good job has not been achieved in most places across the country," Mr. Sanford said. Opening more opportunities would be good for the state's economy, he said, but there was a far more compelling reason. "We will do it because it is honest and fair for us to give all men and women their best chance in life," he said.
By today's standards, those words seem unremarkable. But in January 1963, when Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama delivered his "segregation forever" inaugural address, Mr. Sanford's stand for civil rights was seen as particularly courageous for a governor from the old Confederacy.
Mr. Sanford established himself as one of the most liberal Southern governors -- too liberal, in the eyes of some constituents -- as he named black people to high state positions, pushed state lawmakers to raise more money for schools and started a state anti-poverty program that was a forerunner to President Lyndon B. Johnson's War on Poverty.
In some ways, Mr. Sanford was a contradictory politician. He seemed to have good timing but bad luck. He had shrewd instincts, yet he seemed to lack burning desire. His changes of mind and heart confounded ally and rival alike.
Mr. Sanford was an early supporter of John F. Kennedy's quest for the Presidency, and so enjoyed easy access to the White House in the early 1960's. The President's personal secretary, Evelyn Lincoln, later wrote in a book that President Kennedy had told her he was thinking of Mr. Sanford as his running mate for 1964.
His own liberal programs notwithstanding, Mr. Sanford preached the virtues of "state responsibility," if not states' rights, as an antidote to creeping "big Federal Government." Under state law, Mr. Sanford could not succeed himself as Governor.
He tried for the White House in 1972 and in 1976, while he was president of Duke University, offering himself as a candidate for those disenchanted with the political system and those who were part of it.
Mr. Sanford, who had declared his support for school integration, was beaten in the 1972 North Carolina Democratic Primary by Governor Wallace of Alabama. That humiliating loss in his home state effectively ended his candidacy.
Four years later, Mr. Sanford ran for President again but dropped out early. He said he had found it impossible to gain enough news coverage and to raise enough money, and that he was sick of campaigning.
In 1986, having left Duke, Mr. Sanford ran for the Senate. When President Ronald Reagan made several appearances on behalf of his opponent, Mr. Sanford knew better than to criticize a President. So he suggested instead that North Carolina did not need a "go-along Senator." Mr. Sanford won a narrow victory.
In the Senate, Mr. Sanford gained a reputation for intelligence, personal decency and, in one celebrated instance, indecision. In 1987, after President Reagan had vetoed an $87.9 billion highway bill, Mr. Sanford changed his mind three times: first voting simply "present" on a vote to override the veto, then voting to sustain the veto and finally, under tremendous pressure from other Democrats, switching again and voting to override it. His vote made the count 67 to 33, the precise margin required to override.
"Nobody in the Senate thinks I caved in," he said later.
In fact, his colleagues on both sides of the aisle were saddened at seeing him buckle.
"He's a gentleman," said Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York. "Maybe that's his problem. He's such a beautiful man."
In 1992, Mr. Sanford appeared at first to be in good position for re-election, but he was hospitalized with a heart problem during the campaign. His opponent, Lauch Faircloth, a former Democrat and onetime friend, tried to tar him with the brush of liberalism. And Mr. Faircloth deftly made an issue of Mr. Sanford's health by publicly wishing him a speedy recovery.
Mr. Faircloth's narrow victory ended Mr. Sanford's political life, one that had begun when he was 11: in a 1928 parade in his hometown, Laurinburg, N.C., Terry Sanford carried a sign for Alfred E. Smith, the Democratic Presidential candidate.
Terry Sanford was born on Aug. 20, 1917. His father was a merchant and his mother a schoolteacher.
He graduated from the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill in 1939. After a brief stint in the F.B.I., he joined the Army in 1942. That year, he married Margaret Knight of Hopkinsville, Ky.
Besides his wife, he is survived by a son, Terry Jr., of Durham; a daughter, Elizabeth, of Hillsborough; two sisters, Mary Glenn Rose of Pennsylvania, and Helen Wilhelm of Bern, Switzerland, and two grandchildren.
As an Army private, Mr. Sanford served as a paratrooper, taking part in the invasion of Southern France and later in the Battle of the Bulge, for which he received the Bronze Star and a Purple Heart.
After the war, mustering out as a first lieutenant, he received his law degree from the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill and became active in the North Carolina Democratic Party.
Whether working for himself or on behalf of other Democrats, he was known as a tireless campaigner, and a cool one. While he was running for governor, the pilot of his small plane seriously misjudged a short landing strip and came within inches of touching down in a cornfield.
Unruffled, Mr. Sanford stepped out and, grinning, helped several ashen reporters down the steps.
"Start picking corn, boys," he said before walking away.

HEADLINE: Fire Seriously Damages a Harlem Building

BYLINE: By KIT R. ROANE 

 BODY:
A building that houses a Harlem sporting goods shop was badly damaged yesterday in a suspicious fire three days after an angry customer warned an employee that the store would be gone soon, the police said.
No one was injured in the fire, which began before 6 A.M. in a three-story building at 317 West 125th Street, when the first-floor sporting goods store and a hair-weaving shop on the second floor were closed. 
 Assistant Chief Kevin Farrell, commander of Manhattan detectives, said that investigators were seeking the customer to question him. "He said something to the effect that the store wouldn't be there for very long and we would like to talk to him to see what he meant," Chief Farrell said.
The man was described as a black man with a large tattoo of an AK-47 assault rifle on his stomach and a pencil thin mustache. He stood 5 feet 8, weighed 180 pounds and wore a green army cap on his bald head, the police said.
The store, Vets Sports Shops, is less than a block from Freddie's Fashion Mart, where eight people were killed in a fierce blaze in 1995 that the police said was deliberately set by a gunman as part of a bitter landlord-tenant dispute. Like the fire at Freddie's, which raised a host of racial and economic questions in Harlem, the confrontation at the sporting goods store carried a racial element.
The customer first walked into Vets Sports Shops on Tuesday afternoon to buy a baseball cap, Chief Farrell said. But after bringing the item to a register and having it rung up, the man became enraged over the amount of tax that was charged, the police said. They added that although he finally bought the cap, the man made "anti-white remarks" to the store owner, Harvey Ludwin, 47, and before leaving, showed the man his distinctive assault-weapon tattoo underlined with what appeared to be an anti-white phrase.
The owner thought little of the altercation until the next day when one of his clerks said the man had returned. According to the police, the man apparently came back to warn the clerk, a black woman, that the store might be gone soon. The store filed a police complaint later that day, Chief Farrell said.
Fire Department officials said smoldering was reported in the building yesterday morning shortly before 6 and fire had damaged much of the first and second floors by the time it was put out an hour later. Fourteen units and 62 firefighters were called to fight the flames, said Firefighter Jack Thompson, a Fire Department spokesman.
According to the police and fire officials, an accelerant either fell or was poured onto the floor in the hair-weaving store and ignited. It then burned through the flooring, whose embers brought the fire to the sporting goods shop below. The third floor, which appears to house a writer's workshop, was not damaged.
Store owners in the neighborhood said threats of arson were common from angry customers these days and that the inferno at Freddie's was often noted in a parting shot.
Freddie's Fashion Mart, which once stood on the corner of 125th Street and Frederick Douglas Boulevard, was burned down by a lone gunman in December 1995. The fire came after a monthlong neighborhood protest over its owner's plans to expand the store, causing the eviction of a black-owned business in the building.
The arsonist, who police said had been one of the protesters, entered the building with a revolver in one hand and a can of flammable liquid in the other. He splashed the liquid over piles of clothing on tables and racks, according to police and witnesses. He also fired at four people who tried to flee, wounding all of them. Although the four shooting victims either pulled themselves to safety or were dragged from the building's entrance by officers, firefighters later found eight bodies in the building, including that of the gunman, who had shot himself.
Police in the 28th Precinct said they had received few reports of arson threats against merchants on Harlem's main thoroughfare, but store owners and workers in the area said such intimidation was common after arguments over prices or the return of merchandise.
Sami Alkhbaz, a 25-year-old owner of a nearby jewelry store, said he was not surprised to hear that such a threat might have finally been carried out on the block.
"I had a woman recently buy a gold bracelet, who after three weeks demanded that I let her return it," he said. "And when I refused, she said, 'See what happened to Freddie's. I'm going to burn you down too.' "
"The police had to take her away," he said. "It happens all the time."

HEADLINE: Latin America Fears Stagnation in Trade Talks With U.S.

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS 

DATELINE: SANTIAGO, Chile, April 18

 BODY:
President Clinton and 33 other leaders from the Western Hemisphere opened talks here today aimed at making good on their commitment four years ago to create a free-trade zone stretching from Alaska to Tierra del Fuego.
But many Latin American governments, disappointed that Mr. Clinton failed to gain so-called fast-track negotiating authority from Congress last year, expressed serious doubts that a hemispheric agreement on trade would ever be signed. 
 "There will be a lot of smiling and back-slapping this weekend," said a Latin American finance minister, who spoke on condition that he remain anonymous, "but the reality is that we are growing frustrated and more and more skeptical that the United States is really committed to free trade."
Trade experts have said that unless Mr. Clinton gets fast-track negotiating authority -- under which Congress can approve or reject trade accords negotiated by the White House, but not amend them -- there is little hope of negotiating a free-trade pact by 2005, a goal set in 1994 at the first Summit of the Americas in Miami.
Facing strong opposition from United States labor unions and members of his own party, Mr. Clinton withdrew fast-track legislation in November after it became clear it would not be enacted.
In a speech at the opening session of the summit meeting today, Mr. Clinton promised to persuade Congress to grant him the authority he wants.
"The United States may not yet have fast-track legislation but we will," he said. "I assure you our commitment to the free-trade areas of the Americas will be in the fast lane of our concerns."
Clinton Administration officials have said that while fast-track authorization will eventually be necessary to conclude a trade accord, the lack of such authority should not preclude the start of formal negotiations here.
Trade officials from Canada, chairman of the hemispheric negotiations, agreed, saying the discussions would proceed despite the lack of fast-track authority.
"Of course it would have been preferable for President Clinton to arrive in Santiago with fast track, but the reality is that much work can and will be done at the front end, without fast-track authority," Canada's International Trade Minister, Sergio Marchi, said in a speech in Toronto this week.
The immediate goal for this weekend, officials said, is to determine the objectives and composition of working commissions that will negotiate various aspects of the agreement and to select the site of a third meeting. Agriculture, services and intellectual property are expected to be among tough negotiating areas.
President Eduardo Frei of Chile, who is host of the summit meeting, said today that he hoped the weekend meetings would give a definitive push toward the creation of "a hemispheric community."
"In a globalized world, the development of our economies is based on the liberalization of trade," Mr. Frei said. "We must continue fighting protectionism. It is necessary that the talk of free trade translate into real works."
Although government and trade officials say otherwise, a major indication that talks have slowed is that leaders will spend considerable time this weekend discussing other issues, like poverty, democracy, freedom of expression, justice, education, human rights and drug trafficking.
In his speech, Mr. Clinton called on Western Hemisphere countries to do more to address the social problems that plague the region.
"Poverty throughout the hemisphere is still too high, income disparity is too great, civil society too fragile, justices system too weak," Mr. Clinton said. "Too many people still lack the education skills necessary to succeed in the new economy."
The President called for the region to undertake a second generation of reforms with priority given to providing children with education.
Administration officials said summit leaders planned to announce a package of more than $6 billion in international support for education. Of that, $3 billion would be in loans from the Inter-American Development Bank and $3 billion would come from the World Bank. Some $130 million will come from the United States Agency for International Development.
As the United States wavers on fast-track authority, Latin American countries are forging trade links among themselves, Canada, Europe and Asia -- alliances that threaten to put American companies at a competitive disadvantage.
South America's largest trading nations -- Brazil, Argentina, Chile, Paraguay and Uruguay -- have formed the Mercosur Customs Union, which accounts for two-thirds of the continent's economic activity.
Talks are already under way to merge the Mercosur alliance with the five-nation Andean pact, formed by Venezuela, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru and Bolivia. Together, the two trading groups would form a market of 310 million consumers.
In addition, investment between Latin American countries is rising as more local companies take roles in government privatization throughout the region. It is not uncommon, for example, for Chilean or Argentine companies to hold major stakes in utilities, railroads or pension funds in Brazil, Bolivia or Peru.
Ricardo French-Davis, a United Nations economist in Santiago, said regional groupings were good dress rehearsals for a hemispheric pact.
"It's much easier for the United States to negotiate with a group of countries that has already ironed out its internal problems," he said. "I suggest that everybody take a deep breath and calm down. A hemispheric trade agreement is going to take a while."

HEADLINE: April 12-18;
U.S. Trade Deficit Hits a 10-Year High

 BODY:
The nation's trade deficit rose to $12.1 billion in February, its highest level in a decade, as American exports to Japan plummeted.
The trade figures, released by the Commerce Department, confirmed other evidence of a severe economic downturn in Japan, where consumer spending on both Japanese and foreign goods, ranging from clothes to computers to cars, has slowed dramatically. 
 The figures also seem bound to increase the tension between Washington and Tokyo over Japan's slow reaction to the severity of its economic problems and the pain they can cause in other countries.
