HEADLINE: SHRUGGING OFF DOOM: A special report.;
Shops Closing, Japan Still Asks, 'What Crisis?'

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: OMIYA, Japan, April 15

 BODY:
Aside from the fact that his beloved little business is collapsing after a lifetime of effort, Mitsuo Okura is rather pleased with life.
Mr. Okura, a wry 62-year-old, sits in a little office beside his four-employee factory, which spits out gobs of black plastic that eventually end up in Toyota and Honda cars. Pictures of his grandchildren decorate the wall behind him, and he smiles amiably as he mocks his own foolishness for expanding his factory eightfold during Japan's "bubble economy" of the late 1980's. 
 His eyes crinkle pleasantly as he acknowledges that his own son and daughter have declined to inherit the business. He accepts that in the economic competition for survival of the fittest, he will end up in a more ruthless animal's digestive tract.
"People complain about the bad economy," Mr. Okura mused here in Omiya, a little town nearly 200 miles southwest of Tokyo. "But when I look around the house, I've got everything I want. I've got three cars, and most families around here have two or three as well. I've got a couple of televisions, and so do most people. I've got a washing machine, a refrigerator, and so do all my neighbors."
"Even if no one sees a bright future," he added, "there's no feeling of crisis."
And that may be Japan's problem: life is too comfortable.
The lack of a crisis mentality means that Japan cannot summon the political will to lay off surplus workers, to extinguish insolvent banks, to snuff out the hopes of the kindly old ladies who run rice shops and futon stores. It means that there is little public pressure on Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto to push for the sweeping deregulation and huge stimulus measures that the United States is urging.
Japanese and foreign economists mostly agree that such a far-reaching restructuring is necessary to invigorate the second largest economy in the world. Japan is widely seen as caught in a bramble of regulatory barriers that stifle competition in finance, retailing, transportation, medicine, agriculture, telecommunications and many other sectors, and critics often say that without deregulation Japan will continue to stagnate as it has for the last seven years, sapping strength from the United States and other countries.
Indeed, the Clinton administration sometimes suggests that Japan is on the verge of economic collapse, and it portrays Japan as a threat to the entire global economy. But sit on the tatami mat floor in a Japanese home like Masamitsu Nishi's here in Omiya, and life still seems so secure that people feel little urgency about change.
Mr. Nishi, a former Honda worker who now runs a construction company with 40 employees, says business is terrible, but he adds that his family and neighbors have been scarcely affected by the downturn. Indeed, most people in Omiya say they do not know anyone who has ever been laid off.
Unemployment in Japan is at a record high, but that is still just 3.6 percent -- more than a percentage point below the rate in the United States. Inflation is zero. Interest rates are negligible, and business bankruptcies per capita are still one-third lower in slumping Japan than in booming America.
"There isn't much feeling of a downturn among ordinary people," Mr. Nishi said, despite Japan's slightly negative growth for the last year. As he relaxed on a cushion on the floor, nursing a coffee in the tranquil night air, he added: "Even with my family, business isn't good, but we haven't cut back on our living standard."
So although Japan is enduring its worst slump in a quarter-century, political discontent is not boiling over as it would in the United States. Indeed, the ruling Liberal Democratic Party is steadily gaining strength, and people like Mr. Nishi and his wife, Kazuho, perceive the central Government as so remote that it is neither the problem nor the solution.
"As for me," Mrs. Nishi said, "I just don't see any signs of a crisis."
 
The Changes
Some Say Goodbye To the Old Values
Takahiro Tanaka is one of the few casualties of the economic downturn, and his experience underscores how overwhelming a task it will be to transform Japan into a modern market economy.
Businessmen like Mr. Tanaka, a slim 37-year-old who works as a forester in Omiya because his factory went under last year, operate in an environment that is more social than economic. Mr. Tanaka sat back in a friend's home in Omiya the other day and described his failed business as based not on contracts or prices but rather on traditional values such as "giri-ninjo," or duty and empathy.
The result has been a Japanese economy whose outward facade is skyscrapers and business suits, but whose human interactions are still rooted in traditional concepts of honor. These ways of doing business are frustrating for American officials but would be immediately understandable to any 18th century samurai.
Mr. Tanaka was in charge of a 30-year-old family business making pearl souvenirs and accessories. At its peak it had several dozen employees, but it was just the kind of inefficient factory that has become uncompetitive in Japan because of rising imports and increasing labor costs.
"It just got too hard to compete with imports," he recalled. "Chinese-made pearls come into Japan, and the finished product is the same price as the cost of our materials."
So the family business steadily declined, and it lost money year after year. But because of giri-ninjo, Mr. Tanaka did not take the cost-cutting steps that might have saved his business. "What I kept thinking about most was the employees," he said. "They depended on us. I just couldn't bring myself to dismiss the inefficient ones.
"I thought of offering the employees less money. I'm sure they would have accepted, if I'd offered. But I just couldn't bring myself to do such a thing."
So last year Mr. Tanaka finally had to close the factory, and the employees lost their work anyway. Mr. Tanaka readily admitted that his sense of giri-ninjo was misplaced and a bit foolish.
"I think a person with greater ability might have saved the company, but I wasn't fit for business," he admitted.
Mr. Tanaka and nearly everyone else in Omiya believe that the giri-ninjo economy is inevitably withering away, a process that is most evident in the disappearance of small shops. Japan, far more than Britain, is a nation of shop-keepers, and Japan has more than twice as many shops per capita as the United States.
These little shops are so inefficient that they mostly charge very high prices and survive on webs of giri-ninjo. The stores appeal not to the minds of customers or to their pocketbooks, but to their loyalty -- and these days, that is not enough.
"I have a friend near here, and I was thinking that since her refrigerator was getting old, maybe she would buy a new one from us," said Yachiyo Horie, who runs a little electronics shop with her husband, Nobuhiro. "Then one day I was at her house and I saw a new refrigerator! I thought, 'Hey!'
"Well, I was very curious, but of course I couldn't say a thing. So finally I casually said, 'I see you have a new refrigerator.' But she didn't want to talk about it."
Mrs. Horie shook her head sadly.
"Now even my sister buys electrical things in the big stores," she said. "Like her new washing machine."
Mr. Horie looked reproachfully at his wife. "And a new television," he added.
 
The Trap
A Nice Warm Bath Is Hard to Leave
There is an expression in Japanese, "nurumayu," that describes the coziness of a lukewarm bath even when someone knows that it is time to step naked out of the tub and face the chill. Many Japanese say that their nation's economy is "nurumayu," and they realize that it is time to get out -- but that the bath is so lulling that they cannot summon the energy to do so just yet.
"Frankly, I'd just as soon stay in the bath," mused Hironori Takayama, a young banker in a town near Omiya.
"But these days, even if you try to stay in the bath, the tub will crack and the water will leak out. So if you stay in you risk getting chilly and catching cold. It's not much of a choice."
For people like Mr. Takayama, the problem with economic restructuring is the price in fairness, equality and civility. To foreigners, Japan often seems virtually socialist in mindset, profoundly believing in social equality and relying on the most progressive income tax system of any major country in the world -- including a marginal rate of 65 percent on personal income taxes -- to achieve the equality.
"After the Soviet Union collapsed, I thought that socialism had failed and that capitalism was better," said Mr. Takayama, expressing an epiphany that seemed odd coming from a banker in a dark suit in what is usually thought of as the biggest capitalist economy outside of America. "But when I visited Singapore one time, I saw skyscrapers and then what looked like a slum next to them. I was surprised, and maybe that's because Japan is the only place where that kind of thing doesn't happen, the only place where everybody thinks of themselves as middle class."
Mr. Takayama brooded for a few minutes. Then he added: "I don't want to get out of this bath."
A cultural difference may also be behind the Japanese antipathy for unregulated markets. Americans are risk-takers who are taught to respect explorers and entrepreneurs, while Japanese are drilled to be cautious and to respect bureaucrats. Japan is so intuitively risk-averse that the Japanese language traditionally did not even have a good word for risk.
Japanese often turn to pop-sociology to account for these differences, describing themselves as a "farming people" in contrast to the "hunting peoples" of the West. In effect, Japanese tend to see themselves as economic herbivores, in contrast to the carnivores from Wall Street and the West.
To be sure, the image of peace-loving herbivores does not carry much weight in countries like China or Korea that were invaded and terrorized by Japanese soldiers, nor does the image resonate with American or European companies that were mauled by Japanese manufacturers in the 1980's. But within Japan, the image seems a natural one -- Japanese businesses are indeed extremely reluctant to hurt their own -- and the consequence is disdain for the economic carnage of free markets.
Shinji Hashikura, 42, who runs a five-employee factory making electrical parts in Omiya, sat at his kitchen table and expressed his feelings with a common Japanese saying, "jaku niku, kyo shoku" -- "the strong gobble up the meat of the weak." That, he complained, is a worrisome trend.
" 'Meat of the weak' -- that's me!" Mr. Hashikura said morosely. "I'm the one who's going to be gobbled up. And 80 percent of Japanese are weak meat, too. So when the gobbling begins, we'll all be dead."
Mr. Hashikura paused and exchanged a look with his wife, who sat beside him at the kitchen table.
"But that's the way of the future," he said. "There's nothing we can do."
 
The Competition
Imports Now Shove The Weak Aside
As Mr. Hashikura's comment suggests, there is broad agreement in Omiya that sweeping change is coming to create an economy based more on the concept of "the strong gobble up the meat of the weak." Indeed, many people favor it, saying that even if they themselves are consumed, economic Darwinism is in the interests of the nation.
They say this even though Omiya, which has 5,700 people, could be a loser in a more open system. As in most rural areas, Omiya's economy is largely dependent on Government spending, infrastructure projects and on inefficient little retail shops and factories -- all supplemented by farming and forestry that cannot easily compete with imports.
Kihachiro Nishimura, a silver-haired retired salaryman, sat on the tatami floor of his living room, keeping an eye out for any customers who might walk into the liquor shop that fills the front of his house. Deregulation and the rise of large markets are killing his store, he mused, but the change is still worthwhile.
"I once heard a scholar say that the mass media are very unfair to typhoons," he said. "The media always report about the damage caused, but never about the benefits of all that rain. I feel sorry for the typhoons."
An economic typhoon might destroy his store and other businesses, he said, but Japan as a whole would still benefit.
To be sure, an economic typhoon still is not on the horizon, but Japan's economic structure is clearly changing nonetheless -- not suddenly, not as much as the United States wants, but still profoundly. The change is evident in almost every conversation in Omiya, as people talk about the new supermarkets, about the decline of giri-ninjo business relationships, about the struggle to cut costs and compete with increasing imports.
The word "ability-ism" is the rage now in Japan, and, sure enough, the local bank says it is introducing "ability-ism" in evaluating employees. In other words, workers will be promoted and rewarded according to their merit, and that marks a change in a country where salaries have always risen according to seniority and a Confucian respect for the elderly.
In the nearby city of Matsusaka, a tailor named Eiichi Hashimoto has cut costs by turning to computerized custom tailoring -- the cloth is all cut by computers using Japanese software. Mr. Hashimoto is trying in every way he can to become more competitive, and he says he was particularly struck by what he heard from a friend who runs a car dealership.
"He told the mechanic, 'If you don't work harder, we won't be able to pay you so much!' " Mr. Hashimoto recalled. "I was very impressed with that attitude. I thought my friend was soft in his business management, but now we're all reaching the stage where we have to face international competition."
 
The Challenge
What Will Become Of the Obsolete?
As Japan's economic structure changes, the challenge is what to do with people like Yasuo Murata.
Mr. Murata runs a sawmill in Omiya, and he has been hard-hit by the opening up of Japan's economy. He has gone from five employees to three, and he stood glumly in a drizzle the other day in the midst of the logs.
"Unless the Government changes its policy, it'll be impossible for me to survive here," he said. "The problem is the imports."
Mr. Murata has eight children -- he wanted a son, and kept trying until he got one the eighth time around -- and he figures he can find some job to support them if his mill goes bankrupt. But he fears that it would be a job like a janitor, in a big city somewhere.
"I want the Government to stop imports of logs, but I know that it can't do that," he reflected in a bittersweet tone as he looked out over his sawmill. "Japan is selling hi-tech products to other countries, and I understand that if our Government stops the log imports then the other countries won't buy Japanese cars or hi-tech goods. I understand that the weak are eliminated.
"I'm really against deregulation. But ultimately, I have to accept it. There's no other way."
In a sense, Mr. Murata is facing what the economist Joseph A. Schumpeter called "creative destruction." This is something that Japan used to be very good at, for one of the secrets to its success in this century was its economic adaptability, its willingness to allow industrial euthanasia: Uncompetitive industries were extinguished, and the capital and labor was reallocated to rising industries.
In 1950, 45 percent of the labor force engaged in farming; now it is 3 percent. In the 1950's and 60's, Japanese workers labored in coal mines or churned out cheap clothing and shoes; now those mines and garment factories have closed down, and the children of the miners and shirt-makers have shifted to making automobiles and selling stocks.
Over the last few decades, that economic flexibility eroded sharply as the Government intervened with regulations to protect people from the destruction of inefficient shops and factories. The economy became arthritic and rigid, and the resulting misallocation of resources accounts in part for the stagnation in recent years.
But these days, flexibility is returning to Japan's economy, and the cycle of business destruction and creation seems to be starting up again. A good deal of the economic pain in places like Omiya seems to arise from that process of creative destruction, and it may eventually lead to renewed economic growth.
Take Mr. Okura, the man whose little factory churns out black plastic parts for cars and who cheerfully admits that his factory is a loser. His family underscores the cycle of economic change that is taking place in Japan.
Mr. Okura's parents were farmers, just as most Japanese were when he was born in the 1930's. Then farming became uncompetitive, and so he started his little factory in the 1960's just as the entire nation was riding a manufacturing boom to prosperity.
Now Mr. Okura's factory is likely to fade away before long, but his children have already taken the generational baton in new directions: his daughter is an interior designer and his son is a software engineer who is developing "electronic money" for a credit card company. His children's success has comforted him and reassured him that economic change, however painful and scary, is worthwhile.
"Deregulation is inevitable," Mr. Okura said. "The challenge is to figure out what to do with people like me. But if we just say that new things are no good, then Japan itself will be no good."

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Balance Sheet on China

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
Four years ago this spring, President Clinton reversed his policy on trade with China. That is enough time to draw up a balance sheet on the new policy.
Before his election in 1992, Mr. Clinton said economic pressure through raised tariffs was the best way to push China into relaxing terrorism against human rights -- and against political and religious dissidents. 
 Since June 1994 he has dropped economic penalties for Chinese human rights abuse. The new policy is to encourage trade with China, despite the huge loss to the U.S. balance of payments. He says encouraging business with China will soften Beijing's treatment of Chinese and Tibetans who talk of political and religious liberty. The Administration also says trade would bring Beijing to security cooperation with America.
This past weekend, China gave early release to Wang Dan, a leader of the Chinese democracy movement before Tiananmen Square. After the massacre there in 1989, he served seven years in prison, sleeping on concrete floors. But to keep him away from other brave Chinese, he was deported to exile in the U.S. and will be arrested if he returns.
The release of Mr. Wang is certainly a fruit of the Clintonian reversal of China policy -- Beijing's political gift to Mr. Clinton's reputation. So was the release of Wei Jingsheng -- also sent to forced exile in the U.S.
But Chinese still courageous enough to complain about religious or political regimentation go on being arrested, sentenced to long terms, handed suddenly extended sentences, put under house arrest when released, or sent far from their homes -- just as before Mr. Clinton made trade his overriding China policy.
The human rights trickle-down he promised has not been felt in the political cells, or on the torture blocks. In December 1996, Chinese officials said that 2,026 Chinese were in Ministry of Justice prisons for "counterrevolutionary" affairs, now called "endangering state security."
But the figure did not include "non-ministry" prisons: the forced-labor camps, detention centers where prisoners can be held for years before trial, lockups for Communist Party members, "old age" homes where elderly religious dissidents are sometimes imprisoned, or house arrest after completion of prison sentences.
About one kind of prison where religious and political dissidents are often sentenced, certain "re-education" camps, Chinese officials did say there was a change. They said the inmates increased from 125,000 to twice that number. Dissidents sometimes say: In China there are lots of shelves to put prisoners.
About Tibet -- the whole nation was imprisoned when Mr. Clinton made his switch. The Tibetan cell remains as deep and dark.
Before Mr. Clinton arrives in Beijing, the Communists may release more prisoners. But other Chinese will be arrested to "keep safety."
The Communists are not at all embarrassed by arrests. Earlier this year Mr. Clinton sent a three-clergy "inquiry" to China, to try to take some heat out of U.S. public anger at the persecution of Chinese Christians.
The mission reported nothing that was unknown and ignored most of what is known about religious persecution in China. Just before the mission arrived, Chinese Protestant clergymen were seized by police. After the mission left, two more Catholic priests were arrested.
Security: Mr. Clinton did his personal part for cooperation. He allowed a U.S. company to give China more of the important space and missile technology that it had already provided to Chinese specialists. The company was one of two that were already under U.S. investigation for the first transfer, which did nothing to diminish the Presidential spirit of cooperation.
After the Clinton turnaround on China, Beijing went on with its version of security cooperation. Chinese batteries dropped missiles into the Taiwan Strait to punish Taiwan for holding a fair election. And China continued selling missiles to Iran, plus chemicals that can enrich uranium in nuclear warheads.
Supporters of human rights welcome Mr. Wang, with embraces. We are glad he will not have to suffer in prison longer -- glad, but not grateful, either to the Politburo or the American President who made himself the prisoner of Beijing.

HEADLINE: Abortion Foes Are Held Liable For Harassment

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, April 20

 BODY:
A United States District Court jury today ruled that three anti-abortion leaders had violated a Federal racketeering law by conducting a nationwide campaign to intimidate abortion providers and patients.
The jury of two men and four women, who had deliberated since Thursday, found that 21 acts of intimidation, including physical violence outside clinics, amounted to a vast enterprise of extortion under the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations law. 
 The RICO Act was passed in 1970 as a way to fight organized crime, and some legal scholars have argued that it should not apply to political groups.
The civil case decided today, which was brought by the National Organization for Women, awarded $85,926 in damages to two abortion clinics that were targets of harassment. Under the terms of the racketeering act, the judge is expected to automatically triple that figure, which the individual defendants must pay.
"We cannot tolerate the use of threats and force by one group to impose its views on others," said Fay Clayton, the lawyer who argued the case for NOW.
The 12-year-old case had earlier been dismissed by a Federal judge, who ruled that the racketeering law applied only to organizations motivated by economic gain. But the Supreme Court in 1994 reversed that ruling, and ordered the case to go to trial.
The suit named as defendants two militant anti-abortion groups, Operation Rescue and the Pro-Life Action League, and their leaders, Joseph Scheidler, Timothy Murphy and Andrew Scholberg. Randall Terry, the president of Operation Rescue, had earlier agreed to pay damages in a settlement.
The suit sought damages for two clinics, in Milwaukee and Wilmington, Del., that had been targeted for harassment.
Mr. Scheidler, who has written a book about tactics aimed at shutting down abortion clinics, today promised to appeal the decision, and scoffed at the notion that the ruling could put anti-abortion groups out of business.
"There will still be picketers, maybe more picketers," Mr. Scheidler said. "This may enliven the movement."
G. Robert Blakely, the Notre Dame professor who drafted the racketeering act, said that it was never intended to apply to political groups. He expressed grave concerns that the statute could be used to chill dissent by a wide range of organizations, such as labor unions and gay rights advocates.
"If you look at this case and say it's about abortion, you're missing the point," Professor Blakely said. "Everybody who loves the First Amendment has got to sleep uneasily tonight."
Before the racketeering statute passed, Mr. Blakely recalled, liberals like Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, raised serious concerns about it, saying they feared that President Richard M. Nixon would use the law to stifle anti-war protests.
But Louis Bograd, a lawyer for the American Civil Liberties Union, said the First Amendment "does not guarantee the right to engage in violence and extortion."
In its 1994 ruling, the Supreme Court said that if the racketeering law was not intended to apply to political groups, Congress should have made that explicit.
Gloria Felt, the president of the Planned Parenthood Federation of America, said the jury underscored the nation's impatience with unruly anti-abortion protests.
"This tells me the public wants these people to grow up and stop the war games," Ms. Felt said. "And where there are differences, work them out in the public policy forum."
Many of the examples of intimidation cited in this case involved blockades at clinic doorways, a tactic that has been illegal since the passage in 1994 of the Freedom of Access to Clinic Entrances law.
Mr. Scheidler, who is among the most militant of anti-abortion leaders, vowed to appeal. A former Benedictine monk, Mr. Scheidler has used bullhorns to cheer protesters at abortion clinics. But he has insisted that he does not condone violence.
In speeches and in his book, "Closed: 99 Ways to Stop Abortion," Mr. Scheidler specifically denounced the use of violence. "I see all of these acts of violence as an admission of defeat," he has said, "that you can't do it through the proper channels."
In the past two decades, there have been an average of seven violent acts per month against abortion clinics, their providers or patients, said Kim Gandy, a spokeswoman for NOW. There are about 2,000 abortion providers in the nation.
Civil libertarians who defended today's ruling said that use of the RICO Act will not impede political protest movements.
But Professor Blakely said that all political demonstrations were going to have cases of excess. "No demonstration is perfect," he said. "Somebody's going to throw a rock. Somebody's going to step on a blade of grass."
Those transgressions should be dealt with through laws governing trespassing and disorderly conduct, Professor Blakely said. The RICO Act could quickly bankrupt many political groups, and just the threat of it could chill dissent, he said.
The law has been successfully used against abortion protesters at least once before, in a case in Philadelphia in the 1970's.
In the trial in Chicago, many abortion providers and patients talked about being physically assaulted and intimidated at clinics. One witness said she was harassed on her way into a clinic for a procedure that had nothing to do with abortion. The woman said that she was, in fact, opposed to abortion, but had testified for NOW because she loathed the tactics of the protesters.
The suit claimed that clinics were entitled to damages, in part because they needed to hire extra security forces to protect the staff and patients.
Susan Hill, the president of the abortion clinics involved in the suit, said: "I'm ecstatic, relieved and I feel safer today than I did yesterday. And I think all clinics feel safer today."

INTERNATIONAL A3-8
 
A Joint Effort to Remove Nuclear Fuel in Caucasus
The United States and Britain have begun a secretive operation to remove highly enriched uranium and spent nuclear fuel from the volatile Caucasus nation of Georgia, Western officials said. American officials feared it could fall into the hands of Iran, Chechen gangs or some other aspiring nuclear power. A1 

Sanctions Case Is Dropped
The European Union has decided to abandon its case against the United States at the World Trade Organization challenging the Helms-Burton Act, which invokes sanctions against foreign companies that make use of properties in Cuba seized by the Castro Government three decades ago. The decision is a major step toward defusing a dispute over sanctions that has troubled trans-Atlantic relations for more than two years. A1
 
Mideast Talks Set for London
Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, will go to London on May 4 for separate meetings with Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright in an effort to revive stalled peace talks. Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain, who is on a Middle East tour, announced the planned meetings after talks in Gaza with Mr. Arafat. A3
 
Taliban Leaders Refuse Talks
Leaders of the militant Islamic Taliban movement that rules most of Afghanistan refused to meet with a United Nations aid coordinator three days after promising an American envoy that they would negotiate several issues. A6

Wang Dan, a leader of the Tiananmen Square democracy movement in 1989, was given a clean bill of health in Detroit and began making plans for his new life in exile, although he expressed the hope that he would someday be allowed to return to China. A7

The leader of Germany's anti-extremist watchdog agency said that the authorities would have to wait for a scientific examination of the letter to determine whether it is genuine. (Reuters)

Jewish settlers, defying a Government order, set up a pair of trailers in the West Bank, near the spot where a settler died a day earlier in a land dispute with Palestinian shepherds. The Israeli military ordered the removal of the settlers' mobile homes and of a nearby tent in which two Palestinian shepherds and their families were staying. (AP)

HEADLINE: Spring Is in the Los Angeles Air but the Smog, Chased by El Nino, Is Not

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, April 20

 BODY:
When the Spanish explorer Juan Rodriguez Cabrillo sailed in 1542 past the coastal plain of what became Los Angeles, he was so struck by the dark haze from the Gabrieleno Indian campfires hovering over the mountain-ringed basin that he christened it the Bay of Smokes.
Four and a half centuries later, exacerbated by the internal combustion engine, smog is still a cloudy, consuming fact of life in Los Angeles, which officially has the worst air quality of any city in the United States. But as the annual summer smog season officially begins next month, something here is unusually clear: the sky. 
 On any given morning in recent weeks, the majestic San Gabriel Mountains have made a stunning and surprising backdrop to the city. It is as if a scrim has suddenly lifted on a giant stage. This is often the case in winter, but more than the typical seasonal changes are responsible for the good views this spring. Meteorologists say the unstable currents of El Nino have played the biggest part, piercing the stagnant high-pressure mass of hot desert air that usually traps marine fog and man-made pollution in a brownish, enveloping blend.
At the same time, even the most ardent environmental groups acknowledge that years of tougher controls on automobile and industrial pollution have also played their part, and last year the Los Angeles region posted its cleanest air in the four decades since official monitoring began. There was just one Stage 1 smog alert, which signifies that the air is so polluted with ozone and other substances that officials urge people with respiratory ailments to stay indoors and others to refrain from vigorous outdoor exercise. The single Stage 1 alert compared with 122 such warnings in 1977 and 148 in 1970.
"Air quality has improved dramatically in California over the last 15 years, last summer especially," said Allan Hirsch, a spokesman for the state Air Resources Board. The board sets auto emissions standards and oversees the 35 regional Air Quality Management Districts, which in turn set standards for so-called stationary sources of pollution like factories and machine shops.
"A new California motor vehicle is now more than 90 percent cleaner than a new car here was in the 70's," Mr. Hirsch said.
But the latest gains in air quality have come at a time of uncertainty. The local Air Quality Management District has suffered personnel shake-ups and has rolled back or eased some of its landmark protections of the 1980's. The state is struggling to meet Federal standards for still cleaner cars by early in the next century. And environmental groups worry that the meteorological anomalies of El Nino may be used as an excuse to let up on the fight.
"We need to hold our cheers for now," said Gail Ruderman Feuer, a lawyer with the local office of the Natural Resources Defense Council and head of its air program. "We do not disagree there has been steady progress in cleaning up the air. The problem is, if you take a snapshot in the current year, the air is still the most unhealthful in the country."
Fifty years ago, in the wave of industrialization that followed World War II, "daylight dimouts" in which smog blocked the sun were not uncommon. And 15 years ago, a person could spend a summer here without seeing the landmark Hollywood sign perched in the hills above the city. Now, the afternoon sun routinely bathes the hills in the surreal glow that has inspired artists like David Hockney.
Last year, carbon monoxide pollution levels in central Los Angeles County -- historically the area with the highest levels -- exceeded Federal standards on 15 days, compared with 20 days in 1996 and 38 days in 1987. Ozone levels exceeded Federal standards on 68 days in 1997, down from 90 the previous year.
New cars made for sale in California are equipped with pollution controls that add $50 to $300 to their price but make them the cleanest internal combustion vehicles in the world, burning the cleanest gasoline. Newcomers from the other 49 states must pay a special $300 smog impact fee to register their cars. A relative handful of perhaps 1,100 experimental electric vehicles dot the freeways, state officials say, and charging stations have sprung up at shopping malls.
The bad news is that day in and day out, pollution levels here are still the worst in the nation, followed by those in Houston and New York, with nearby San Diego's at No. 10. The Federal Environmental Protection Agency has refused to approve the local air district's updated plan for coping with pollution, calling it inadequate. State officials acknowledge that they are well behind the pace needed to meet new Federal air standards by the target date of 2010. They will also be hard-pressed to meet their goal of 10 percent of new vehicles sold being electric, or zero emission, in five years.
"The achievements to date have been remarkable," said Barry R. Wallerstein, the acting executive officer of the South Coast Air Quality Management District, the state-chartered agency that oversees the Los Angeles region. "Each of the last three years has been the cleanest year on record. Having said that, we still have a long way to go to have clean, healthful air 365 days a year in Southern California."
The board of the local Air Quality Management District, spurred by the severe regional economic downturn of the early 1990's and by a batch of conservative appointees, has adopted some 30 measures rolling back pollution controls for paints, solvents and other substances and for traffic at shopping malls, airports and concert halls. Last summer, the board ousted James Lents, its executive director for a decade, with some members arguing that he was hostile to business.
The board has yet to name a replacement, but its chairman, William A. Burke, the director of the Los Angeles Marathon, has announced an initiative called "environmental justice," aimed at toughening pollution controls in poor and minority neighborhoods that have often been disproportionately affected.
"I think the jury's still out," said Jane Hall, an environmental economist at California State University at Fullerton who resigned from the agency's advisory board in 1996 to protest the rollbacks in controls. "I think Burke's environmental justice initiative is very encouraging, and he's trying to build some partnerships with industry. But I'm discouraged by the number of times I hear the district say things have gotten so much cleaner, and it's going to be hard to go forward."
Professor Hall's own studies of three decades of pollution control efforts have shown no discernible negative economic effects on even the most heavily regulated sectors. She said the story of the past quarter-century has been that each successive step in pollution control has been declared undoable until regulation pressured industry into coming up with cleaner technologies.
"In the late 80's, when the district passed a regulation on volatile compounds for home barbecues, there was a bumper sticker saying, 'Use a barbecue, go to jail,' " she said. "That was amusing, but in fact the manufacturers came back with much cleaner ways to cook outdoors."
The big challenge, Professor Hall said, is to cope with the expected growth in population and cars now that the California economy is thriving, and to develop regulations for diesel trucks and buses.
Ms. Feuer of the Natural Resources Defense Council said there were still any number of technologically easy -- if politically unpalatable -- steps that could improve air quality, including forcing light trucks, minivans and the popular sport utility vehicles to carry the same smog controls as standard passenger cars. The state Air Resources Board is reviewing such a provision.
"There's still a lot of low-hanging fruit left," Ms. Feuer said.

HEADLINE: As Polls Rise for Ferraro, So Do Expectations for Her Message

SERIES: EARLY STEPS: The Senate Campaign

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

DATELINE: SYRACUSE, April 15

 BODY:
Geraldine A. Ferraro was sitting with a small group of Democrats in the dusty Onondaga County party headquarters here the other afternoon, handing out poll results attesting to her political strength and recounting the warm reception that she said her return to politics had received from voters and contributors alike. The evidence was overwhelming, Ms. Ferraro asserted, that she was the only Democrat who could defeat Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato.
James T. Snyder, a Democratic state committee member, waited until Ms. Ferraro finished the 15-minute review of her political credentials before raising a different issue about her candidacy. "I don't mean to make this sound simple," Mr. Snyder said, "but what is your rationale for running? Why should I back you?" 
 Ms. Ferraro paused. It was a question that she has heard more than once in recent days, but after her vigorous description of her political strengths, and her spirited attack on Mr. D'Amato, her response to Mr. Snyder sounded, by comparison, unformed.
"Why I'm running is because I really want to have an impact on what's going on in our country in the next century," she answered. "I really do. I have pictures of my grandchildren here, which I'd be happy to show you. I look at what's happening to them, I look at what's happening in our society, with the enormous difference between haves and have-nots. If we do not start investing now, by the time the have-nots are adults, it's going to be too late."
After three months of raising money from the privacy of her office, Ms. Ferraro's return to the public eye last week, in her first extended campaign outing since announcing her candidacy in January, quickly established two central dynamics of her second attempt to win the Democratic nomination to run against Mr. D'Amato.
The first is that 14 years after she came to national attention, the former candidate for Vice President continues to generate excitement and wide recognition, which accounts for the early dominance in the primary. "I wanted to come to see you," said Neil Miller, 34, a hotel room-service waiter, as Ms. Ferraro emerged from a television taping in Buffalo.
But the second is that Ms. Ferraro has, by early appearances, yet to articulate the kind of crisp and compelling political appeal -- what Mr. Snyder described as a rationale -- that both her Democratic rivals, Mark Green, the New York City Public Advocate, and Representative Charles E. Schumer of Brooklyn, have attempted to offer for their candidacies.
So far, Ms. Ferraro is surfing across the state with a series of generally uncontroversial pronouncements on health care, the economy and education, taking the safe road preferred by candidates leading in the polls.
It is, to be sure, early in the campaign, when it is not uncommon for candidates to spend more time describing problems than suggesting solutions. And Ms. Ferraro's aides said that she will offer cutting-edge ideas in the months ahead.
Nonetheless, Ms. Ferraro's evident vagueness is raising questions among Democrats about just how adventurous a campaign she intends to run, and whether she will seek to power her candidacy largely with her celebrity. There are some Democrats -- including some sympathetic to her -- who worry about how effective such a strategy would be, both because memories of her four months as a Vice-Presidential candidate have faded since her Senate campaign in 1992 and because she faces a field of opponents well versed in the details of Federal policy.
And Ms. Ferraro still has far less money than Mr. Schumer and Mr. D'Amato, forcing her to divert a good deal of energy to a schedule of fund-raising that requires her to sneak a phone call to a potential contributor at every break in her day.
"The question is, when she gets to a policy debate, will she be able to hold her own?" said Hank Sheinkopf, a Democratic political consultant who is not involved in the Senate race. "The expectation level on her is ridiculous."
Ms. Ferraro has started to lay out what she said will be the general topics of her campaign: the difficulties with New York's economy, its schools and its health care programs. She has embraced such ideas as donating surplus computers for after-school training for students, expanding enterprise zones to encourage development, hiring teachers to reduce class sizes and establishing national standards for schools ("Algebra is algebra is algebra," she told one upstate reporter).
And she repeatedly attacks Mr. D'Amato, describing him as "an embarrassment to the people of New York," mocking his wearing of a pink ribbon as an empty gesture to breast cancer victims, assailing his opposition to abortion rights and describing him as a captive of his financial contributors.
But there are moments, like that afternoon in Syracuse, when her candidacy and campaign seem a work in progress. Asked on a flight back to New York, for example, to delineate differences between herself and Mr. D'Amato, she responded: "I really do believe that Al D'Amato does not belong in the United States Senate. I think he's wrong for the state, but I also think he's wrong for this country, and I want him out of the Senate."
Clutching a copy of USA Today as her aircraft circled through clouds awaiting permission to land at La Guardia Airport, she added: "I don't need to be in the Senate to have people pay attention to me. I don't need it to get special treatment to go to a restaurant or get into a hotel. Last night, I was put in the bridal suite, which was very sweet. People really do take care of me." (She had stayed at the Buffalo Airport Radisson).
"What I need it for is because I really believe I can make a difference -- so that's the difference between me and Al D'Amato," she concluded. "As a Senator, I'm going to love the title, but the title will be secondary to what I have to get done."
Ms. Ferraro, who is 62, has taken some tentative steps to try to distinguish herself from the field, including trying to turn a central criticism -- that she has not been in government since 1985 -- into a political asset.
"My experience is very diverse," she said at Syracuse Law School. "Chuck Schumer has been in public office ever since he got out of law school. He went from Harvard Law School to working as a staff person at the Assembly. Mark has a little more diverse experience. I bring my experience as a New York City public schoolteacher so I can speak to the education system. I bring my experience as an assistant district attorney to criminal justice."
Ms. Ferraro, who has worked as a commentator on CNN, asserted that if elected, she would enjoy an immediate stature in the Senate that her two Democratic opponents, neither of whom has run for Vice President, could not match. "I go down there as a totally different person from anybody else," she said. "They go down as just another guy from the state."
With a wave of her hand, Ms. Ferraro dismissed the suggestion that Mr. Schumer might make a similar claim to instant status, given his nine terms in the House. "Why would he be able to?" she said. "Just because he knows the process?
But for Ms. Ferraro, the more significant difference is less thecandidates' backgrounds or beliefs and more their standing in the polls. "If you take a look at the polls, I'm ahead of both Mark and Chuck by 30 points and 35 points," she said. "I've never been this far ahead of anybody in my entire life. Never! I love it. But then carrying it a step further, I'm the only one who beats Al D'Amato. They both lose to him."
Ms. Ferraro's contention that she would be the strongest nominee -- as a woman, an Italian-American and, of course, as a celebrity -- is largely, though not universally, shared by most Democratic professionals.
That said, Democratic analysts noted that there is little historical evidence that voters make their primary selections based on what will happen in a general election. And there is a risk to Ms. Ferraro's strategy if the polls that she is today trumpeting as evidence of her strength begin to tighten as voters turn their attention to the race, which many Democratic analysts assume will happen.
To this day, Ms. Ferraro believes that she lost the 1992 Senate primary only because of last-minute attacks on her ethics by her Democratic opponents. So it is that at some moments, her candidacy in 1998 seems like an attempt to bring some closure to 1992 -- or, for that matter, to 1984.
"This is it," Ms. Ferraro said. "This is the last time I will do this public service. Ever. If people want me to do it, I will be the best senator going. If they don't want me to it -- I have to tell you, if I had lost that other race fairly, I wouldn't be doing this now. Because I would have felt that the public had talked."
 
Early Steps
This is the first in a series of articles examining the political appeal and early campaign strategies of candidates in the New York Senate race.

HEADLINE: Giuliani's Plan for Stadiums Uses Tax He Planned to End

BYLINE: By DAN BARRY 

 BODY:
With charts by his side and his pointer in hand, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani proposed a way yesterday to help finance new stadiums for the New York Yankees and the New York Mets without raising taxes or deepening the city's debt. But his plan left unanswered the more explosive question of where a new Yankee ballpark would be built.
The proposal, which requires City Council approval, calls for the creation of a public corporation that would receive the revenues from the commercial rent tax that is paid by large Manhattan businesses south of 96th Street. 
 The Mayor previously intended to eliminate that tax by June 1, 2001. Now, he said, the tax could be scaled back at a slower rate than originally planned and eliminated possibly in the year 2004.
The Mayor said that his proposal, which he boasted was unlike any other stadium-financing plan in the country, could raise nearly $600 million by the year 2002, and could also be used to build stadiums for professional soccer and football teams. He also emphasized that the money would cover only the city's commitment to the major capital projects; the state and private investors would also be expected to contribute. And in the case of a new Yankee Stadium, George M. Steinbrenner 3d, the team's principal owner, would also bear a share of the costs.
Mr. Giuliani declined to offer a formula for cost sharing, saying such arrangements were still being negotiated.
Estimates for the cost of a new stadium range from $600 million to $1 billion.
As the Mayor detailed his plan to a group of reporters, his aides grinned at one another, reflecting the general sense that they had scored a political coup with an approach that would not cost city residents a penny more in direct taxes.
Still, it is likely that the taxes paid by businesses will eventually be passed on to their customers. The 4.5 percent tax now applies to businesses paying $100,000 or more in rent, and the revenues go into the city's general fund.
Staff members later told reporters that Mr. Giuliani had come up with the idea on his own, two weeks before a 500-pound chunk of steel fell from the upper deck of Yankee Stadium last week, forcing a shutdown of the ballpark and the postponement of two games. (The Mayor announced yesterday that the 75-year-old stadium had passed city inspection and would reopen on Friday.)
In sports circles, the plan drew praise for its use of tax money in a way that would not outrage the public. "It sounds to me that if you can hold your nose long enough to get past the fact that it's a tax, it sounds like a creative and appropriate tax to use," said Dean Bonham, president of the Bonham Group, a sports consulting firm in Denver. "It sounds like it only affects the corporate community, and targets them above a certain economic level -- those who can afford it the most."
And Steven Spinola, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, which has been lobbying against the commercial rent tax for many years, seemed to accept the price. "It's a terrible tax," he said, and probably the only one of its kind in the country.
"On the other hand, we've gone from 6 to 4.5 percent and expect to go to 3 percent" in the level of taxation, he said. "So it's tough to be really upset about what appears to be a slowing down of the reduction."
But the plan requires the approval of the City Council, whose Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, wants to put the stadium issue to a public vote.
In addition, the Mayor's plans for "how" naturally raised the prickly question of "where." While the Mets are content to build a ballpark next to their 37-year-old home, Shea Stadium, in Queens, the Yankees are clearly eager to leave Yankee Stadium in particular and the Bronx entirely.
Although Mr. Giuliani would prefer that the Yankees remain in the Bronx, he said that a new stadium on the West Side of Manhattan might be the only way to insure that the team remains in New York City. In fact, he made no mention of using his new financing plan to renovate Yankee Stadium, which is generally considered to be a city landmark.
"I really doubt that there is in this room a bigger Yankee fan than I am," the Mayor said, "a person who started going to Yankee Stadium earlier than I did. Romantically and emotionally, I would love to keep the Yankees in the Bronx. At the same time, I have to focus on the fact that we could lose the team. I have to look at the practicalities of that."
But Mr. Giuliani's announcement came at the same time that Mr. Vallone suggested putting the question of a new Yankee Stadium before the voters in a referendum. "I believe that we need to hear from the taxpayers before we sink a billion dollars into a new stadium in Manhattan," he said. "I am committed to doing whatever is necessary and responsible to keep the Yankees in the Bronx."
Given that recent polls show that most New York residents would prefer that the Yankees remain in the Bronx, Mr. Vallone's proposal could be seen as an attempt to dash the Mayor's grandiose plans -- and that is exactly how Mr. Giuliani took it.
"That's sort of the absence of leadership," he said. "In the places that have done that, they've driven their baseball teams away. I mean, you can play that game and it'd be easy to say that, and most people in a public opinion poll probably agree with it. But I got elected to be a leader, not a panderer. And the fact is that I'm not going to see the two teams get driven out of New York."
Speaking as though a plan to build a stadium for the Yankees in Manhattan were a fait accompli, Mr. Giuliani said: "I think you've got to be a leader. I know most of the public disagrees with me. I think 10 years from now they'll say, 'Mayor Giuliani made the right decision.' "
Some aides to the City Council said later that Mr. Giuliani's harsh assessment of Mr. Vallone was politically unwise, given that the Mayor's financing plan requires the Council's blessing. But Thomas McMahon, the Council's Finance Director, said he saw the issue in starker terms, "It's not about financing; it's about location."
At the same time, the Mayor's announcement seemed to catch the administration of Gov. George E. Pataki by surprise. "We have not really heard anything for maybe a year," said Charles A. Gargano, the state's Economic Development Commissioner. Mr. Gargano said that the state would listen to any proposal the city has for a stadium for the Yankees. "But we'd prefer the Yankees stay in their historic home in the Bronx," he said.
Lastly, there arose the question of public policy: Should the city be helping to build baseball stadiums for private owners, or should it be focusing more on the city's infrastructure?
Gene Russianoff, a lawyer for the Straphangers Campaign, a mass-transit advocacy group, said he was not persuaded by the Mayor's argument that new stadiums create jobs and opportunities for the poor.
"My point is that the city's most important capital asset is the subways, and the city's long-term capital commitment to them is widely viewed as inadequate," he said. "And I'm just talking about what I know best."
Yesterday, at least, the Mayor's aides preferred to focus on the originality of their plan. They said that the Mayor made his announcement yesterday, rather than at the unveiling of his Executive Budget on Friday, because of misleading speculation that he planned to raise taxes or sell bonds to finance the stadiums.
Joseph J. Lhota, the city's Budget Director, said that the proposed corporation, to be called the New York City Sports Facilities Corporation, would not have the power to sell bonds; instead, it would simply use the money raised from the commercial-rent tax to help cover construction costs.
Other money would come from the state and from private sources, such as corporations that might buy the rights to the stadiums' names or rent luxury suites.
Mr. Lhota also said that the plan is distinguished from other stadium-funding arrangements in that there would be no debt; everything would be paid for up front. "By the time any one stadium is compete, it will be paid for," he said. "Period."
He also emphasized that the commercial rent tax will still be eliminated. "But instead of eliminating it over the next three years, we're probably going to eliminate it over the next six years, maybe longer, maybe less," he said.
Mr. Giuliani also argued that whether the new stadium for the Yankees is built in Manhattan or the Bronx, the hotels, restaurants and stores of Manhattan all will benefit.
"Where do you think the people stay who come to watch baseball games at Yankee Stadium or Shea Stadium?" he asked. "Where do you think most of them stay?"
The answer, he said, was Manhattan.

HEADLINE: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW YORK;
Gore and Democrats Honor Deputy Speaker

 BODY:
It was a long way from home for Arthur O. Eve, a Buffalo Democrat. But the Deputy Speaker of the State Assembly made the trip to Manhattan yesterday morning to be lauded for his 31 years in office by a host of his fellow Democrats, most notably Vice President Al Gore.
In a fund-raising breakfast for Mr. Eve at the Sheraton New York hotel, Mr. Gore praised the 65-year-old legislator as a crusader for economic development and education. Mr. Eve, the Vice President said, "is a leader on just about every issue that's important to families." 
 He added: "America needs you to support him and to re-elect him."
The breakfast attracted about 100 guests, including a broad spectrum of business leaders, elected officials, former colleagues from the Assembly and candidates for office this year. They included the hosts of the breakfast, United States Representative Charles B. Rangel, State Comptroller H. Carl McCall, and Percy E. Sutton, the former Manhattan Borough President.
Also present were the current Manhattan Borough President, C. Virginia Fields; Mark J. Green, the city's Public Advocate, who is a candidate for the United States Senate, and James L. Larocca, who is a candidate for governor.
Mr. Eve was cited by elected officials yesterday for his role in leading a committee of public officials who attempted to resolve a conflict between prison guards and inmates after a 1971 uprising at the Attica State Prison.
He was also cited for his role as a founding member of the New York State Black and Puerto Rican Legislative Caucus, of which he was once the chairman.
Yesterday's fund-raiser was expected to bring in about $50,000 for Mr. Eve's campaign coffers.

HEADLINE: Chase and Citicorp Report Higher First-Quarter Profits

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The Chase Manhattan Corporation and Citicorp reported higher first-quarter earnings yesterday, led by trading and corporate banking, while big regional banks such as the Banc One Corporation and Wells Fargo & Company said fee income strengthened results. All met or beat estimates.
Chase, the biggest domestic bank by assets, said profit from operations rose 11 percent. Citicorp, which is merging with Travelers Group Inc. to become the biggest financial services company, said net income rose 7 percent. 
 Banc One's earnings surged 36 percent. Earnings at Wells Fargo fell 7 percent because of a decline in loans and deposits that offset the effects of higher fee income. Two other large regional banks, the Wachovia Corporation and the Mellon Bank Corporation, also reported healthy gains.
Chase and Citicorp benefited from booming stock and bond markets and from the expanding United States economy. Their underwriting and trading fees rose, as did revenue from arranging corporate loans and selling them to other investors.
The results drew a mixed reaction in the stock market. Shares of Chase rose $4.4375, to $139.125; Citicorp increased $2.25, to $160.25; Banc One fell $1.4375, to $58.8125, and Wells Fargo declined $7, to $375.
Chase said profit from operations increased to $1.05 billion, or $2.35 a diluted share, from $949 million, or $2.02, a year earlier. The latest results beat the average forecast of $2.26 a share, based on a survey of analysts by the First Call Corporation, which tracks corporate earnings results.
Noninterest revenue at Chase increased 19 percent, to $2.47 billion. Trading revenue advanced 23 percent, to $713 million, and revenue from equity investments increased 75 percent, to $287 million. Credit card revenue rose 17 percent, to $931 million.
Net interest income rose 4.3 percent, to $2.16 billion. Chase increased its loan-loss provision to $344 million, from $220 million in the period a year ago. Net income at Chase totaled $725 million in the quarter, after a $320 million charge to cut 4,500 jobs, or 6.5 percent of its staff, in a previously announced cost-reduction plan.
Citicorp earned $1.07 billion, or $2.23 a diluted share, up from $995 million, or $2.01. Analysts surveyed by First Call had expected the bank to earn $2.22 a diluted share.
Net interest revenue increased 1.2 percent, to $2.84 billion, as net interest expense rose 13 percent, to $3.46 billion. It raised its credit losses provision 20 percent, to $507 million.
Noninterest revenue rose 16 percent, to $2.77 billion. Securities transactions revenue more than doubled, to $241 million from $108 million, and trading account revenue was up 19 percent, to $236 million. Venture capital gains almost tripled, to $264 million from $93 million.
Net income at Banc One rose to $517.6 million, or 79 cents a diluted share, from $381.9 million, or 58 cents, in the period a year earlier. That matched the estimate from analysts surveyed by First Call.
Last week, Banc One agreed to acquire the First Chicago NBD Corporation in a merger valued at $30 billion. The combined company, which would be based in Chicago, would be the fifth-largest United States bank.
Wells Fargo earned $315 million, or $3.58 a diluted share, down from $339 million, or $3.58 a share. That beat the average forecast by analysts of $3.41.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasury Prices Decrease as Several Corporations Issue Debt

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury securities prices fell yesterday amid a flood of new debt from corporate issuers drawn by low interest rates. Among the new supply was $3.25 billion of bonds priced yesterday by the Ford Motor Credit Company, its biggest global issue ever.
Treasuries also came under pressure from remarks by a Federal Reserve governor, Roger Ferguson, who suggested that an increase in interest rates might be in the offing if the Asian financial crisis did not slow the United States economy. 
 The 30-year Treasury was off 10/32, to a price of 102 15/32
Treasury Prices Decrease as Several Corporations Issue Debt. The yield, which moves in the opposite direction, was 5.95 percent, up from 5.92 percent Monday.
Prices recovered after steeper drops early in the session. Often when big corporate deals come to the market, underwriters hedge their portfolios by selling Treasury securities to protect against a rise in interest rates before the corporate sales are complete. At that point, the underwriters often repurchase Treasuries for their portfolios.
Strong demand for the Ford Motor Credit securities allowed the company to increase the size of the issue from its initial plans. The amount of five-year notes was raised by $750 million, to $2.25 billion. The notes sold at a price to yield 6.17 percent -- about 55 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point -- more than the rate of a Treasury note with a comparable maturity.
The underwriters, led by Salomon Smith Barney and Bear, Stearns & Company, also priced $1 billion of seven-year floating-rate notes for an initial yield of 5.885 percent, which will be adjusted quarterly to 18.75 basis points more than the three-month London interbank offered rate, or Libor. The Libor is a benchmark interest rate that international banks charge each other for loans denominated in dollars. Late in the day the three-month Libor was about 5.69 percent.
Robert Pugliese, senior vice president and director of the fixed-income department at J. W. Charles Securities Inc. in Boca Raton, Fla., said he was surprised that such a large offering was increased, reflecting strong investor demand.
"There's a lot of liquidity out there for corporate debt," he said. "So all the corporate paper is having a dampening effect on Treasury prices."
The success of Ford's offering was also helped by the fact that the company is a household name and that the spread of the yield compared with that of a comparable Treasury was attractive, Mr. Pugliese said. "Credit ratings are important, but it was the name that attracted buyers globally," he said.
Earlier this year investors were wary of buying corporate debt, not knowing how much the Asian turmoil might affect earnings and credit quality. But the United States economy is still humming along and inflation is not a threat, making corporate paper, which offers a higher yield to Treasury securities, attractive to many investors.
But the strength of the economy has also raised concerns about inflation and about whether the Fed will move to head it off by raising interest rates.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS;
U.S. Deficit in March Lower Than Forecast

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 21

 BODY:
The United States posted a smaller than expected budget deficit in March as the growing economy helped the Government reap tax dollars -- keeping Washington on course for the first annual surplus since the 1969 fiscal year.
March's deficit totaled $13.813 billion, compared with a deficit of $21.3 billion in March 1997, Treasury figures showed. Analysts had expected a deficit of $14.6 billion last month. 
 March revenue rose 9.1 percent, to $117.93 billion, from a year earlier. Spending rose 1.8 percent from a year earlier, to $131.743 billion.
The strong economy, stock market and efforts to slow Federal spending all pointed to an annual surplus. The White House projects a $10 billion surplus this year, though some analysts say it could be larger.
Since the start of the fiscal year on Oct. 1, the budget deficit has totaled $69.862 billion, down from the corresponding period the fiscal year before, when the deficit was running $111.162 billion.
The budget deficit now amounts to less than 1 percent of the gross domestic product, the smallest slice of the overall economy since 1974 and the smallest percentage among major industrial nations.
Still, the Treasury reports a deficit most months because it spends more money than it receives and borrows the rest. Surpluses usually come in January, April, June, September, and more recently in December, coinciding with tax payments.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Philip Morris Posts 6% Rise In Earnings

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The Philip Morris Companies said yesterday that earnings rose 6 percent in the first quarter, as it sold more than half the cigarettes in the United States for the first time, even though it raised prices to pay for legal costs.
Philip Morris, the world's largest cigarette company, said net income rose to $1.87 billion, or 77 cents a diluted share, from $1.77 billion, or 72 cents, a year earlier. Revenue rose 2.3 percent, to $18.4 billion from $18.0 billion. Earnings rose 9 percent, to 79 cents a share, matching analysts' expectations, before a charge to pay for a voluntary retirement program at its United States tobacco business. 
 Nonetheless, the company's shares fell 62.5 cents, to $39.375 on the New York Stock Exchange.
Philip Morris's cigarette sales in the United States rose 2.1 percent, helped by new Marlboro Ultra Lights, allowing the company to capture 50.4 percent of the market. At the same time, industry sales fell almost 2 percent over all, showing that Philip Morris may do better than competitors even if it continues to raise cigarette prices to pay for legislation being considered by Congress.
"They're best positioned for the vagaries of Congress," said Emanuel Goldman, an analyst at Paine Webber Inc. who has a "buy" rating on Philip Morris's shares. "They're larger and they have Marlboro," the world's No. 1 cigarette.
Full-priced cigarette brands like Marlboro cost about $2.15 a pack at the end of the first quarter, up from about $2.10 a pack in December, analysts said. The extra revenue from increased prices can be put toward the tobacco industry's legal settlements. Philip Morris is responsible for paying about half of about $30 billion over 25 years in three settlements of health-related suits brought by Texas, Florida and Mississippi. Philip Morris and other tobacco companies may raise prices even more, depending on the outcome of Congressional talks on a nationwide tobacco settlement.
International tobacco unit sales rose 4.7 percent and operating profit rose 11 percent, to $1.4 billion, even as weaker economies in Asia reduced demand.
The company's Kraft North America unit had operating profit of $802 million, up 9.6 percent, largely as it cut costs. The company said it posted double-digit unit sales gains in its Tombstone and Di Giorno frozen pizza businesses as well as its Taco Bell and Kraft Macaroni and Cheese home meals.
Profit from the company's international food business fell 2.9 percent, to $235 million, largely because of lower coffee sales and the effect of the strong dollar.
Profit from Miller Brewing, the second-largest brewer in America, rose 1.6 percent, to $128 million, on slightly higher shipments.

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON with Matthew J. Rosenberg 

 BODY:

A Coup for N.Y.U.
New York University appears to have succeeded where Columbia University failed. N.Y.U. is stealing a high-ranking professor from Harvard University. DR. ROBERT M. GLICKMAN, who has been a professor at Harvard Medical School and physician-in-chief and chairman of the department of medicine at Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center in Boston for nine years, will become the new dean of the N.Y.U. medical school this summer.
Word that Dr. Glickman had accepted the N.Y.U. job came a week after ROBERT J. BARRO, a Harvard economist, backed out of a deal to teach at Columbia for a salary almost unheard-of among academics: $300,000 a year. Dr. Glickman, a gastroenterologist who was the chairman of the department of medicine at Columbia's College of Physicians and Surgeons from 1982 to 1990, would not say how much N.Y.U. had offered him. 
 "Was money the thing that lured me?" he said. "The answer is no. It's really not a money thing."
It was, he said, "a leadership thing." At 59, he wanted to step up on the administrative ladder, and he realized that he would probably not be offered the top job at Harvard Medical School: he was a member of the search committee that chose Dr. Joseph Martin for that post a year ago.
"I never thought of it in that way," Dr. Glickman said yesterday. "But you have a certain amount of energy and excitement and this feeling you want to make something significant happen."
 
Blue Plate Special
Only 22 days are left for New York to cash in on the phenomenon known as "Seinfeld," the sitcom about New York that was videotaped in California. In the race for last-minute tie-ins, Maxim, an upstart men's magazine, has snagged a prize: it rented Tom's Restaurant, the quintessential Noo-Yawky coffee shop that inspired the generic one on "Seinfeld," for May 14, the night of the sitcom's final episode.
Maxim sent out plates as invitations -- 150 specially made silver-rimmed plates with a picture of Tom's and its blue and pink-neon sign, the view millions of "Seinfeld" watchers know from the show.
The fancy lettering promises that the evening will feature drinks and "yadda, yadda, yadda."
PAM COHEN, a spokeswoman for Maxim, said the magazine is paying Tom's "a low five-figure number" to have "the ultimate 'Seinfeld' farewell party" there.
 
A Civilized Refusal
MAYOR RUDOLPH W. GIULIANI may or may not like journalists, but he does not want to be one. Civilization magazine said the Mayor had turned down an offer to be the guest editor of its June/ July issue.
The magazine then turned to the cartoonist JULES FEIFFER, who agreed to oversee that issue and suggested that Mr. Giuliani contribute a "personal appreciation" of the jut-jawed crime fighter Dick Tracy.
But NANCY SHEED, a spokeswoman for Civilization, said a Giuliani aide had told the magazine that no one at City Hall knew enough about Dick Tracy to write an appreciation. (CURT RITTER, a spokesman for the Mayor, said that Mr. Giuliani could not squeeze in a guest-editing stint, but looked forward to working with Civilization at some point in the future.)
The current guest editor has given the Civilization staff some sleepless nights in the last few days: VACLAV HAVEL, the president of the Czech Republic, underwent two operations last week while the issue he guided was being printed. "He's had lung cancer," Ms. Sheed said, "and he's on the cover smoking a cigarette."
 
Shoes and Shows
DONALD SELIGMAN, who ran a midtown store that sold Pappagallo shoes in the 1960's, was a kind of Medici for the aspiring singers he hired as part-time sales clerks. "It began with these three girls who kept saying how good they were and that they couldn't get a break," he said. "So I rented out Carnegie Recital Hall to see if they were as a good as they said," he said. "I figured it would keep them quiet."
It didn't, he said at a reunion of former clerks at the Cornell Club. Soon they were holding recitals at the store, on East 54th Street.
"It was a great place for us," said the soprano RUTH FALCON. "You could call and say, 'I can't make it in today, I've got an audition,' and it was not a problem."
And what about celebrities who shopped there? "Greta Garbo came in once and tried on a pillbox hat, the kind that Jackie Onassis wore and was all the rage then," said NANCY KILMER. "She kind of looked in the mirror, tipped that hat, and began to laugh."
 
Quote, End Quote
"I think there are some awards that if you don't show up, you don't get, but fortunately, the Lortel is a classier outfit," said the actress CHERRY JONES, explaining why she will attend the Lambda Legal Defense and Education Fund dinner on May 4, not the Lucille Lortel Awards the same night.
"Finally I said to her, 'You're up on your beautiful appaloosa stallion. It's a fine spring day. We're riding through the woods. The bluebells are all out, and the sky is clear blue,' " said PAUL McCARTNEY, describing how his wife, Linda, died. "I had barely got to the end of the sentence when she closed her eyes." JAMES BARRON with Matthew J. Rosenberg

HEADLINE: City Study Sees Big Revenues If Yankees Play in Manhattan

BYLINE: By DAN BARRY 

 BODY:
In yet another sign that the Giuliani administration sees Manhattan as the future home of the New York Yankees, a new study by city planners suggests that a new stadium on the West Side would have an economic impact worth at least $1 billion a year, more than 10 times the impact of a renovated or new stadium in the Bronx.
The numbers in the report are so lopsided, in fact, that a high-ranking aide to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani felt compelled to say that economic impact was only one of many factors being weighed by the Mayor in addressing one of the most vexing challenges of his administration: how to keep the Yankees in New York City without forsaking the Bronx, a borough whose identity is inextricably linked to the ball club. 
 Having said that, the aide also acknowledged that the report might help to temper the considerable opposition that is likely to arise if a ball park is built above a rail yard near 11th Avenue and 33d Street. "There's a clear preference on the part of the Mayor and the city to keep the Yankees in the Bronx," said the aide, who would speak only on the condition of anonymity. "If that can be done, that's the goal. But that doesn't change the economic calculus."
Mr. Giuliani has not decided how to respond to the standing threat of the Yankees' principal owner, George M. Steinbrenner 3d, to move his team out of the Bronx -- and New York, if necessary -- once its Yankee Stadium lease expires in 2002. But the tenor of the Mayor's comments in recent days suggests that while his heart is in the Bronx, his thoughts have turned to Manhattan.
And that was clear again yesterday when Mr. Giuliani responded to reporters' questions about his proposal to use the commercial-rent tax -- assessed against large businesses south of 96th Street in Manhattan -- to cover the city's share of costs to build stadiums for the Yankees and the New York Mets.
"This spending will result in, bare minimum, at least $1 billion more for our economy and thousands and thousands and thousands of jobs," Mr. Giuliani said. "We need those jobs. And particularly those who are worried about unemployment and the change from welfare to work, we need a city that has a constantly expanding set of jobs. And I would think that those people who are trying to block this -- all of whom come out of the political philosophy that drove jobs out of the city -- would actually have some deference to the plans that we have."
But some experts say cities should be wary of of overestimating the financial impact of sports stadiums, in part because such vagaries as the economy and a team's performance cannot be predicted.
"Most economists agree that stadium deals are awful as economic development projects," said David Swindell, a professor of urban affairs at Wright State University in Dayton, Ohio. "You lose every time. The public spends far more money creating this private business venture than it'd give back to the public treasury.
"A professional sports team is the equivalent of two Wal-Marts in terms of the economy," he added.
The report, which was conducted by the city's planning and economic-development departments with participation by several consultants, said that a West Side stadium with a grass field and no retractable dome would draw 3.9 million people a year to 81 Yankee home games and to a dozen nonsporting events -- more than 1 million more people than Yankee Stadium currently attracts -- and could be expected to spur the development of two 600-room hotels, 600,000 square feet of office space and various stores and restaurants. Combined, the stadium and the related development would create 9,442 jobs and generate nearly $42 million in new taxes, the report said.
The numbers would increase slightly if the West Side stadium included artificial turf and a retractable dome, the report said, because it could be used for more concerts, revival meetings and other events.
But if a new stadium were built on or near the current site in the Bronx, the report said, the economic impact would be drastically smaller. It estimated that 255,000 square feet of the surrounding area could be developed as a result, generating 1,200 jobs, about $3.3 million in taxes, and an overall economic impact of $92.6 million. The report said that the Bronx neighborhood surrounding Yankee Stadium lent itself only to a "modest level of induced real estate development." But a very cautious analysis, it said, suggests that the West Side is wide open and ripe for investment. "A new stadium, with links to both Madison Square Garden and the Javits Center, will anchor a new entertainment-commercial core of Manhattan that includes the new Penn Station," the report said.
But the document also said that at least $300 million would also have to be spent to improve the West Side's "transportation and infrastructure," although it did not elaborate on what "infrastructure" it was referring to. Such improvements, it added, would also support the expansion of the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center.
The enormous gap between the estimates for the Bronx and Manhattan, the senior mayoral aide said, is integral to any discussion about justifying the use of public money for such a venture. "The key question is, what is the result of that investment?" the aide said.
The report -- written by Joseph B. Rose, the planning director, and Charles Millard, the director of economic development -- did not explain in detail the methodology used, a point seized upon by Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx borough president, who has criticized Mr. Giuliani for even entertaining the thought of smoothing the way for a Yankee exodus from the Bronx.
"This is not exactly Holy Writ," Mr. Ferrer said. "It's more like making up these numbers as we go along. They're just making their boss happy."
