HEADLINE: Stock Exchange Weighs Move to Battery Park City

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
Applying new pressure in its bid to expand in lower Manhattan, the New York Stock Exchange has told city officials that it is prepared to leave its historic headquarters on Wall Street and move to a new building in Battery Park City.
For several months officials of the exchange have told the city that they want to acquire three buildings across Broad Street from the exchange's existing -- and very cramped -- trading floors at the corner of Wall Street, which they would tear down and replace with newly enlarged trading operations. 
 But according to mayoral aides, Richard Grasso, the president of the exchange, told Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani at a meeting last week that a new building in Battery Park City was now being considered because the legal and financial barriers to acquiring the Broad Street properties could take too long to resolve at a time when the exchange was desperate to expand.
The aides said the Mayor and Mr. Grasso did not discuss the tax breaks that the exchange is almost certain to get for its expansion, no matter which site it chooses, but officials say the amount is likely to be substantial. Last year, for example, the New York Mercantile Exchange received $168 million in incentives when it moved to a new headquarters in Battery Park City.
Which of the two locations the exchange really favors was unclear yesterday, and its overture to City Hall may have been calculated to gain leverage in its negotiations with Broad Street property owners or possibly to push the state to consider condemnation of the buildings. But aides to both the Mayor and Gov. George E. Pataki said without reservation yesterday that they wanted the exchange to remain where it is.
"Both the Mayor and the Governor prefer that the exchange remain in the Wall Street area," said Randy Levine, the Deputy Mayor for finance and economic development, who said that last week's meeting was one of several that Mr. Grasso and the Mayor have had since the exchange began its effort to expand a year ago.
But Mr. Levine said the Mayor considered a new exchange building in Battery Park City to be an acceptable second choice if terms could not be reached quickly in the exchange's attempt to acquire the Broad Street properties. Although the potential bargaining positions of the Broad Street property owners remain unclear, one of the owners is known to look unfavorably on a proposed deal. "The key is to keep them downtown, and I think we have accomplished that," Mr. Levine said.
Officials of the exchange declined comment on the meeting with the Mayor, saying only that they had no alternative but to find more room for their growing trading floors and that they planned to make a decision soon on where that would be.
"We can only confirm that there are ongoing discussions with the city and we expect to make a decision in the coming months," said Richard Adamonis, an exchange spokesman. He declined to be more specific about the timing of the decision.
John LaMura, the president of the Battery Park City Authority, said that neither he nor other officials had been contacted about the stock exchange proposal.
The Battery Park City site proposed by the exchange would be just north of the main towers of the World Financial Center and northeast of the New York Mercantile Exchange, which was completed last year.
A decision to move to Battery Park City could be expected to provoke political tension, both for the exchange and the Mayor, since it could undermine the city's ambitious plan to revitalize the Wall Street area with more housing, residential services and businesses.
"The loss of the exchange would obviously be a blow to the area," said one executive in lower Manhattan who spoke on condition of anonymity. But at City Hall, an official close to the discussions, who also insisted on anonymity, said some form of backfill, including the offices of city agencies, might fill the economic void at the traditional core of the city's financial district.
Since it began its effort to expand, the exchange has encountered repeated roadblocks. Its most ambitious plan was to build a glass-enclosed atrium from its current trading floors across Broad Street to a landmarked city building, greatly expanding its existing space.
That proposal was dropped after fierce resistance from preservationists. An earlier plan, to build a pedestrian walkway high above Broad Street that would connect the existing exchange building with another landmark structure, was dropped because of worries over terrorism and other security concerns.
The exchange's proposal to acquire and tear down properties across Broad Street would not include any structures with landmark status.
But among the three buildings, officials point to one that would be the most difficult for the exchange to acquire: a former office tower at 25 Broad Street that became one of the first examples of the Mayor's plan to revitalize the Wall Street area last year when it was converted to 340 luxurious apartments.
Russell W. Galbut, the president of Crescent Heights Investors, a Miami development concern that owns 25 Broad Street and spent $100 million on its conversion, declined comment yesterday when contacted at the company's office in Atlanta.
But an executive close to the company and its Broad Street project said it had not been approached by Mr. Grasso or other stock exchange officials.
One option for the exchange if the owners of any of the three Broad Street properties refused to sell would be the seek the help of Governor Pataki in having their property condemned. But that approach could backfire -- as was demonstrated in the state's arduous 10-year effort to condemn property in Times Square, which succeeded only after dozens of lawsuits were resolved.

HEADLINE: The Rush to Finance Stadiums

 BODY:
Baseball fans and New Yorkers who appreciate the place the Yankees and Mets occupy in lore and in the city's social history wholeheartedly support Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's goal of insuring that both remain within the city limits. But the method the Mayor selected to signal that desire on Monday is quite worrisome. His plan to open the city's tax vaults and place nearly $600 million in commercial rent tax revenue on the negotiating table for stadium financing is premature. It could also damage the city's bargaining position with club owners. More important, there is no immutable law that says stadium financing deals must be heavily sweetened with public subsidies or taxpayer support in any form.
In San Francisco, the Giants have chosen to finance a new baseball stadium with more than $200 million from private-sector sources and only a sprinkling of city aid, a minuscule $10 million. New York's list of pressing infrastructure needs -- schools and rapid transit come immediately to mind -- is quite long and expensive. The Mayor and the teams should adopt the San Francisco ethic: The teams should first exploit the myriad financing sources in the private sector. Indeed, some of them -- luxury boxes, stadium naming rights, charter seats -- flow from lucrative aspects of remodeled or new stadiums. What better place to craft such deals than Manhattan, the epicenter of world finance? 
 The Mayor's scenario for subsidies is politically artful. Rather than mimicking cities that have saddled taxpayers with new debt or higher regressive taxes, he would draw revenue from an existing city tax on large Manhattan businesses, albeit one that is being phased out at a molasses-like pace. His proposed stadium finance corporation would siphon off about $600 million in tax revenues in its first four years and $300 million a year thereafter, as long as it had projects to pursue. The open-ended nature of all this does not augur well for other city needs.
Last week's falling-beam incident at Yankee Stadium rekindled interest in its future and in the plans of the club's principal owner, George Steinbrenner. In public, Mr. Steinbrenner has been Sphinx-like. He should state what his club wants now, not when the city lease expires in 2002. Without that, financing talk is academic. It leaves the city negotiating against itself. Although the proposed financing could be used for construction or renovations anywhere in the city, the Mayor's comments about a possible Yankee Stadium on the West Side of Manhattan suggest the real danger of a premature decision to abandon the Bronx.
Nationwide, decision-making about stadiums is frequently messy and irrational, as a recent comprehensive Brookings Institution study of stadium financing and economics shows. More often than not, the value of publicly subsidized financing is distorted and the economic impact touted by proponents rarely materializes. If and when it is time to discuss public dollars as part of any stadium deal, including infrastructure-related spending, the choices made by the Mayor, the City Council and New Yorkers should abide by the following principle: A public subsidy should be commensurate with real, not imagined, public benefits.

HEADLINE: Doctors' Pay Regains Ground Despite the Effects of H.M.O.'s

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN 

 BODY:
The nation's physicians still complain that managed care organizations drown them in paperwork and meddle with their prerogatives in treating patients. But their fears for their own livelihoods, that managed care would reduce their wages or drive them out of medicine, are proving overdrawn.
Doctors' incomes have rebounded from the nearly 4 percent decline four years ago that was reported by the American Medical Association in early 1996. That decrease was widely attributed to the impact of managed care. A survey of 1996 incomes, which was reported just last month, showed physicians' average earnings rising to the threshold of $200,000 for the first time. 
 That is $18,000, or almost 10 percent, more than in 1994, and $70,000, or about 50 percent, more than in 1987, when managed care was just beginning to spread; it is a rate of increase surpassing the gains of most other working Americans. Consulting firms' less comprehensive surveys for this year and last show physician incomes stabilizing or slightly rising. When inflation is taken into account, doctors are little better off than they were a decade ago.
"If you're well-trained and don't have something lurking in your past, you can make a pretty darn good living," said Dr. William L. Mason, a pulmonologist and internist in Little Rock, Ark. "The question physicians have to ask themselves now is, 'How much do I want to make?' Medicine never promised to make us millionaires."
To be sure, doctors aren't realizing the 10 percent annual gains in income they sometimes saw in the old days of fee-for-service medicine, when they could essentially bill compliant insurance companies whatever they wished for care. The managed care revolution has clearly taken hold, forcing doctors to justify their services, negotiate their fees and learn the bookkeeping and accounting tools that are anathema to many.
Among the specialties, income changes have often been volatile. Anesthesiologists and pathologists have suffered acute declines in income and are only now seeing them recover somewhat.
Dr. Richard F. Corlin, a gastroenterologist in Santa Monica, Calif., and speaker of the A.M.A.'s House of Delegates, says that doctors are working exceptionally long hours to maintain their incomes and that the marketplace remains "'extremely volatile."
However, he said, it is short-sighted for physicians to look at themselves as victims, because their prospects remain promising. "I'd give one of my paired organs to any of my three sons who wanted to go into medicine," he said.
David Gans, survey director at the Medical Group Management Association in Denver, which represents 183,000 members of 9,000 physician groups, said, "I've not yet seen a physician on a street corner with a sign saying, 'Will do surgery for food.' They are working harder, but there's virtually zero unemployment among doctors."
Part of this rebound, recruiters and industry consultants say, is a big change in the relationships among the institutions that compete and collaborate in providing care.
Health maintenance organizations, they say, have reached the limit in hammering down costs, and physicians, who like many patients depict themselves as victims of managed care, are banding together into big, multispecialty groups, attempting to recapture the control of the health care system, which they lost to H.M.O.'s.
Consultants and physician recruiters add that predictions of an oversupply of physicians, fed by immigration of foreign doctors and by managed care organizations' use of nurse practitioners for some physicians' services, is, at worst, some years off.
Young specialists, they say, must often look for work beyond the doctor-glutted meccas of medicine, like New York, Boston and San Diego, but they all find work. One good prospect is Kaiser Permanente, the nation's biggest nonprofit health maintenance organization, with hospitals and clinics in 18 states.
"We have to hire 1,200 physicians just to meet the growth of 1997 and 1998 in California," said Dr. Francis J. Crosson, executive director of Kaiser's physician organization.
Paul R. Dorf, director of the Hospital and Healthcare Compensation Service in Upper Saddle River, N.J., said of the physician marketplace, "Frankly, I think it's going to get better." Mr. Dorf, who is an industry consultant, added, "Is there turmoil? Yes. But are physicians going to be poor? I don't think so."
For a decade, health maintenance organizations and the insurance companies that own many of them were able to rein in the cost of care by cutting the fees they paid physicians to treat their enrollees and by denying patients services that they deemed excessive or unnecessary.
Physicians lost some of their autonomy and had to work harder to make ends meet, seeing more patients during shorter visits. Only those with reliable stables of rich patients could shun H.M.O.'s and survive.
But in many states, and particularly in California, Minnesota and Massachusetts, physicians have begun turning the tables on H.M.O.'s.
They equip their new provider-sponsored organizations with testing laboratories and operating rooms for same-day surgery and strike alliances with hospitals for longer term care. Then they devise procedures for managing the cost of care, typically by paying group members bonuses or other incentives for keeping patients healthy and satisfied.
Thus organized, the physician groups compete head-to-head with H.M.O.'s in bidding for contracts to cover workers. The big California Public Employees Retirement System says it is looking into leapfrogging H.M.O.'s and contracting directly with physicians' groups to treat the state's 340,000 employees.
Other employers are considering delegating all patient-care responsibilities to the groups and using H.M.O.'s only to handle bookkeeping, marketing and other administrative tasks for health care programs.
Such a shift in power poses a special threat to the nation's predominantly for-profit health organizations, which are owned by stockholders. Those organizations must charge enough for their services to cover the cost of care and pay dividends to stockholders. One sign of a shift is the H.M.O. industry's financial losses last year, the first ever, and the recovery of physicians' incomes, which include fees, salaries and bonuses.
"Physicians are getting smarter," said Daniel Zismer, health practices specialist at the Towers Perrin consulting firm. "When they aggregate in large group practices, their business opportunities expand exponentially."
In offering services that no solo practitioner can afford, Mr. Zismer said, "their revenues and incomes expand." Dr. Corlin of the A.M.A. said, "What we are going to see is, for-profit H.M.O.s will be gone."
The H.M.O.'s see their prospects as less ominous but still see big changes. Karen Ignagni, president of the American Association of Health Plans, which represents 1,000 of the organizations, says a major transformation" in health care, driven by the reduction of cost, is over. She sees new efficiencies arising from collaboration among physicians and the plans to improve the quality of care, which often means less expensive care in the long run.
The worst-case fears for physicians, in short, seem far less justified than they did two years ago, when the A.M.A. reported the first decline in doctors' incomes in the 14 years it had been keeping track.
For several years, the gains in physicians' incomes have been pronounced among internists, family practitioners, pediatricians and gynecologists. Roberta Margolis, senior vice president of Weatherby Health Care, a recruiting firm in Norwalk, Conn., that last year found jobs for 1,088 doctors, most of them primary-care physicians, said, "No bleeding hearts are needed here."
"They are making good money," Ms. Margolis said. "We know they are going to do fabulously." She said obstetrician-gynecologists, whom the A.M.A. found in a study last year to be fully employed, are taking jobs in New York state this year at a salary of $145,000, or $13,000 more than last year, and at $150,000 in Massachusetts, an increase of $16,000.
Among the Weatherby firms's clients is Dr. Tracey Davenport, a graduate of Wellesley College and of the medical school at Southern Illinois University. Now completing her residency in internal medicine at the Bay State Medical Center in Springfield, Mass., Dr. Davenport has signed on with a 60-physician practice in New Bedford, Mass., for an annual salary of $110,000.
Dr. Davenport said she could have picked nearly anyplace in America to work, but was drawn to New Bedford, in part, because of its proximity to the sea. In some ways, managed care will intrude. "Thursday is paperwork day," she said. "And I think it's going to be a lot of hard work and long hours."
But she is sanguine about the issue that doctors rail about most -- green-eye-shade intrusions into her professional prerogatives. "What they're looking for is good medical care," she said. "I've been told it's up to me how much time a patient will need."
The picture is murkier for some specialized physicians and for older doctors still toiling in solo practices. A survey of salaried physicians completed this month by the Hay Group, a management consultant, shows income trends ranging from a slight decline of less than 1 percent in dermatologists' incomes during the last three years, to $166,500, and a 15 percent increase in the incomes of orthopedic surgeons, to $273,500. Incomes of cardiovascular surgeons, the best paid of the major specialities, rose 7 percent, to $363,300.
While physicians can find work, recruiters say a urologist or a pulmonologist, unlike more widely sought primary-care doctors, might have to settle for Syracuse, N.Y., or Utica, N.Y., instead of physician-glutted Manhattan. But even then, there's a silver lining: Recruiters report that doctors earn more in smaller communities than they can in nation's big urban centers of medicine.
"You're always going to have to pay someone extra to go to Minot, N.D., said Mr. Dorf, the consultant.
Andrew P. Diffenbaugh, a recruiter in Norfolk, Va., who specializes in psychiatry, said a psychiatrist who insists on a job in Norfolk will earn $110,000 but if he moves south to the Army town of Fayetteville, N.C., he said, "he'll get $160,000."

HEADLINE: I.M.F. Loans to Rights Violators Are Attacked in Congress

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 21

 BODY:
Every year, the State Department's human rights report dwells at length on Indonesia's many forms of political repression, from its use of torture and killings to silence dissenters to its widespread military control of East Timor.
So Indonesia's record might appear, at first glance, to require the use of a law compelling the United States to vote against lending billions of dollars through the International Monetary Fund to gross violators of human rights. But the United States favored a $40-billion I.M.F. bailout of Indonesia, and even offered to throw in $3 billion of back-up American financing if Indonesia needs more. 
 Today, defending that decision during two hours of hostile questioning by a Congressional committee, Treasury Department officials asserted that in the pantheon of human rights violators the Government of President Suharto did not rank among the worst of the worst.
"The State Department makes these judgments, and Indonesia did not meet the standard to be on the list they send us," Timothy F. Geithner, an Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, said in testimony today, as he urged Congress to approve an additional $18 billion for the monetary fund.
The debate over providing additional funding has turned into one of the hottest foreign policy issues on Capitol Hill this year. It has become a magnet for human rights activists, abortion opponents and critics of the monetary fund's role as the world's lender of last resort.
The testimony today called into question whether the Administration, in its race to contain the Asian financial crisis, skirted a law that requires the United States to use its "voice and vote" to deny assistance to countries that "engage in a pattern of gross violations of internationally recognized human rights."
The State Department insists that it keeps no official list of human rights violators that should be denied such loans. But, responding to questions today, Mr. Geithner said there were five countries that the United States would likely oppose for such aid: China, Sudan, Equatorial Guinea, Iran and Mauritania.
"I concede," one senior Administration official said, "that to the uninitiated it is a bit of a strange list."
Clearly, it has a number of gaping holes. For example, Nigeria, a country that has seen widespread violence and political repression since a 1993 coup, would not be automatically denied American support. Nor would Iraq, which is barred from borrowing money from the I.M.F. because it has not repaid loans for the last eight years.
At the hearing before the House Banking subcommittee on general oversight and investigations, Representative Bernie Sanders, the Vermont independent who ranks among the fiercest critics of the monetary fund in the House, charged that the Administration violated the law. "You are funding a vicious dictator who jails his opponents," he said. "It seems to me you very clearly disobeyed the law."
Mr. Geithner and Karin Lissakers, the United States representative to the monetary fund, insisted that the Administration, working behind the scenes, has used its influence to promote both human rights and labor rights. It has blocked the I.M.F. from considering loans to Iran and the Sudan, they said, and held up money for Croatia while it was harboring war criminals.
The human rights argument is part of a broader examination of the workings of the fund that has never before taken place in Congress. The fund is known for its secretiveness, in large part because it offers confidential advice to its 182 member countries, many of which turn over sensitive economic data to the fund.
But that secretiveness has also made it difficult for the United States to defend its support of the fund, or discuss specific decisions. Now, increasingly fearful that the funding it seeks could be denied, Washington has begun to turn over thousands of pages of data about its interactions with the fund.
Each disclosure, though, has raised new objections. Some Republicans argue that the I.M.F. should not provide below-market-rate loans to recipient countries; Mr. Sanders argued the opposite today, maintaining that the fund has turned into a "loan shark" burdening deeply indebted countries with even more interest payments.

HEADLINE: U.N. Panel Defeats U.S. Move to Censure Cuba on Human Rights

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH OLSON 

DATELINE: GENEVA, April 21

 BODY:
An effort led by the United States to rebuke Cuba for its human rights practices was voted down today by the United Nations Human Rights Commission.
The defeat appears to reflect a growing sentiment, particularly among Europeans and Latin Americans, that Cuba cannot be isolated forever and that it is making efforts to meet its international human rights obligations. 
 The United States-sponsored resolution called on Havana to "promote and protect human rights and fundamental freedoms" and to "release numerous persons detained for activities of a political nature."
Nineteen countries voted against the proposal -- including China and Russia -- and 16, including the United States, Britain, France and Germany, voted in favor. Another 18 members, including many Latin American countries, abstained.
"This vote has repaired a historic mistake and has ended selective and disciminatory treatment against us," Maria de los Angeles Florez, Cuba's chief delegate, said after the vote.
Also today, the rights commission criticized Iraq, adopting a resolution that "strongly condemns the systematic, widespread and extremely grave violations of human rights," which it said resulted "in an all-pervasive repression and oppression sustained by broad-based discrimination and widespread terror."
The resolution was approved, 32 to 0, after Russia failed to muster support for diluting it by removing some of the tougher wording. Russia and China were among the 21 countries that abstained.
In Cuba's case, an independent United Nations investigator, Carl Johan Groth of Sweden, told the commission last month that President Fidel Castro's Communist Government systematically and brutally repressed its domestic critics.
But he added that the nearly four-decade-long United States economic embargo against Cuba was partly to blame for the situation, causing a "tragic shortage of material goods" and "untold hardships."
The United States effort to keep pressure on Cuba has been steadily losing allies. Beginning with the first United States resolution in 1992, support has been dwindling. This year Italy and France, which co-sponsored the American resolution in 1997, refused to do so again, although they did vote for it.
France declined co-sponsorship because of Washington's hard line on Cuba, said the French delegate, Marion Paradas-Bouveau. "Cuba has cooperated with the U.N. human rights bodies," she said. Failure to include amendments sponsored by the European Union also weakened support, further isolating the United States on Cuba, she added.
Disenchantment with United States policy has been fueled by European objections to the Helms-Burton Act, which imposes penalties on companies that use United States properties in Cuba that were seized by the Castro Government three decades ago.
Cuba's overtures toward the Roman Catholic Church, particularly the visit of Pope John Paul II in January, and the country's increasing acceptance at international and regional forums bolstered its campaign to portray itself as a victim of a vindictive United States, a diplomat said.

LENGTH: 1547 words

HEADLINE: Questions of Excellence In Consortium Ranking

BYLINE: By JO THOMAS 

DATELINE: GLENCOE, Ill.

 BODY:
The fourth-grade classroom in this affluent Chicago suburb might be more spacious than most, with room for computers and a red plaid sofa, but there was nothing costly about the way Glen Werner began her science class. She turned off the lights.
"What did I do?" she demanded of her West School class. 
 Jamie Freedman had his hand up first and said, "You opened up the circuit." And how could they tell when the switch was connected to a conductor? Andy Schaye answered, "Because the lights go on."
Mrs. Werner teaches in a public school district north of Chicago that has banded together with 19 other districts to improve math and science education.
When the Third International Math and Science Study earlier this year reported a dismal showing for the United States, Richard W. Riley, the Secretary of Education, pointed to these districts as a shining exception. Grandly named the First in the World Consortium, they had made special arrangments to take the test as if they were a country. As such, their eighth-grade students performed nearly as well in science as top-scoring Singapore. They ranked No. 5 in math, substantially higher than the United States, at No. 28.
While it may not be surprising that children who have books at home and parents who went to college perform well, the test showed that students in countries with fewer advantages still outperformed Americans. Scholars say that once affluence is taken into account, some schools still do better than others. Why the differences? It is a question educators across the country are trying to answer.
They have some clues: half of the consortium's eighth-grade students take algebra, compared with only 20 percent nationally. All eighth-grade students in Japan have taken or are taking algebra.
Educators are also questioning the value of homework and tracking. Others have taken issue with the amount of time math teachers spend going over old material; surveys taken for the international study showed that two-thirds of American teachers spent only 10 minutes introducing a new concept in math, far less than high-achieving countries.
"We don't have to look overseas for what's right," said Richard Laine, an associate superintendent for the Illinois State Board of Education. Acknowledging that the consortium schools are in wealthy districts, Mr. Laine added that they "are doing something we can learn from."
The consortium, which began three years ago, grew out of a superintendents' reading group and now includes 37,125 students. The name refers to a goal set by the President's Goals 2000 program: "That U.S. students will be first in the world in mathematics and science achievement."
But the results of the Third International Math and Science Study, which in the 1994-95 school year tested hundreds of thousands of students in 41 countries at ages 9 and 13 and in their last year of high school, showed that goal to be a dream. After the fourth grade, American students of all economic levels fell behind their counterparts in other countries.
Using teacher discussions, research projects and seminars, the consortium hopes to pinpoint what it is doing right. It also hopes to learn what needs to be changed. The consortium's study will compare its test results with data gathered by the international study, about teaching practices, textbooks, curricula, student attitudes, and how students spend their time. Findings will soon be posted on the Internet. Superintendents from consortium districts have already described their project in meetings of educators around the nation and have been invited to discuss it with school districts in Ohio and Minnesota.
"We've got a myriad of questions staring us in the face," said Jean McGrew, superintendent of Glenbrook High School District 225 and a member of the consortium.
Homework, Mr. McGrew said, is one issue the country should grapple with. "We tend to give more homework than many of the other countries, especially Germany and Japan," he said, mentioning two countries that outperformed the United States. "We have this almost-religious belief in homework. Is it producing anything? Maybe we ought to give less homework and make it more focused."
In "Facing the Consequences," a discussion of the findings scheduled for publication this summer, William H. Schmidt, the national research coordinator, and other scholars associated with the National Research Center for TIMSS at Michigan State University, warn that "American children are not getting the science and mathematics education they deserve."
The international study showed that American children spent no more time watching television than children in countries that scored better. And American teachers also taught more hours of math and science. The problem, Mr. Schmidt and other scholars believe, is in the classroom itself.
In fact, a point noted by the State of Illinois in an analysis of the international study's tests was that a school's instructional program could make a difference even when other factors were not ideal. For example, in Hong Kong, where 55 percent of the students reported that neither parent finished high school, the average score in mathematics was 584, far higher than the average scores in the United States in both math (513) and science (527) among children with a parent holding a college degree.
Experts at the University of California at Los Angeles who analyzed eighth-grade mathematics lessons videotaped for the international study rated 23 percent of the lessons in Germany and 30 percent in Japan as high quality. None of the lessons in the United States was rated highly. In fact, 87 percent were rated low quality.
The international study found that American teachers demanded less high-level thought from students and instruction was less focused.
The study also called into question the American practice of separating children into groups on the basis of academic ability, noting that the practice, called tracking, "may well have sacrificed the attainments of more average students in an attempt to bolster the performance of better students, especially in mathematics."
That effort has failed, Mr. Schmidt contended, saying, "Even the best U.S. students were not among the best from all TIMSS countries."
In both fourth and eighth grades, the best American students fell near the median for Singapore in mathematics and close to average for Austria, the Czech Republic, Korea and Japan.
"This is not something we can say, 'Aha! Let's fix it!' " said Daniel P. Johnson, superintendent of Glenview School District 34. "It comes back to: What are we doing? What are our expectations? What are our strategies?"
Mr. Johnson said he saw no justification for holding students back by tracking them in the early grades, arguing that "we shouldn't be in the sorting and selecting business."
To help improve instruction, teachers in the consortium are replaced by substitutes in the classroom to give them time to meet with other teachers to discuss instruction models, curriculum, technology and testing.
"We're always looking for things that will make us better teachers," said Deb Bailey, who teaches middle school mathematics at Central School in Glencoe and has 22 years of experience.
"We sit and share things that work and talk about things that don't work," Ms. Bailey said. "Normally, I hate leaving the classroom. I never call in sick. But the First in the World is such a big thing -- you see the kinds of things we can do."
At West School, Mrs. Werner said she was "working my own way to problem-based learning."
"I give children a messy problem, and they try to find ways to solve it," she said.
On a recent April afternoon, Mrs. Werner showed 21 students a pile of homemade circuit boards, aluminum foil sandwiched between cardboard that had been punched with holes labeled A to M.
"Promise me not to look inside," Mrs. Werner said. "Show me you know which holes are connected. Create your own tester. Take a couple of minutes and brainstorm with your partner."
A buzz filled the room. "I heard some good ideas," she said as a child from each team picked up testing equipment -- wires, flashlight batteries and tiny light bulbs. The children went to work, not always with success.
"We did everything right," one girl wailed. "It still doesn't work."
Across the room, Carolyn Goldschmidt and two other girls connected two holes and lighted a bulb. "We got one!" cried Carolyn, clapping.
Mrs. Werner stopped them. "Let's take three seconds, and give me some feedback. Sam, freeze! Your eyes, they belong to me. What did we find out?"
Jamie was the first to venture an answer, "They have to be connected under." Mrs. Werner shot back, "With what?" and he answered, "Foil -- a conductor."
Mrs. Werner told her fourth-grade students to open their circuit boards and look inside. Some of the holes were connected. Some were not. She handed out more cardboard squares. "Here's a board," she said. "Create your own. I have a roll of tinfoil. Create your own puzzle, make an answer key, then exchange it with someone else."
As the students worked, their teacher seemed everywhere at once.
"I forgot I was going to put on Mozart," she said. "It's supposed to stimulate the brain."

HEADLINE: G.O.P. Leaders Link Teen-Age Smoking Measure With Anti-Drug Bill

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 21

 BODY:
Hoping to seize the political initiative from President Clinton, Republican leaders in Congress suggested today that legislation to keep teen-agers from smoking should be linked with an antidrug bill.
Without specifying what such legislation would entail, Speaker Newt Gingrich said at a news conference, "I think that we should look seriously at including an anti-teen-smoking provision in an omnibus bill designed to bring down illegal drug addiction." 
 At a separate news conference, Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the majority leader, said he agreed with the Gingrich approach.
But the White House rejected it out of hand. "If this is their way of copping out on tobacco, we're not for it," said Bruce N. Reed, the President's chief domestic policy adviser. "We want to see comprehensive tobacco legislation, not cosmetic legislation."
Other officials emphasized the observation this week by C. Everett Koop, the former Surgeon General, that 20 times as many Americans die each year from smoking as from narcotics.
Republicans have been on the defensive all year on the tobacco issue. Mr. Clinton and Democrats in Congress have been trumpeting anti-smoking measures, and both parties have polls showing that this has worked to the Democrats' advantage. The Republicans' standing has been further damaged by their being the main beneficiaries of campaign donations from cigarette manufacturers.
Republican spokesmen have fretted that if a strong antismoking bill passes, the President will gain the credit and that if one fails, the Republican Congress will be blamed.
The party's problems have been enhanced by Mr. Gingrich's propensity to make off-the-cuff statements about smoking that can be construed to mean he is sympathetic to the cigarette companies.
At a fund-raiser in Pennsylvania on Monday night, for instance, Mr. Gingrich suggested that Joe Camel, the R. J. Reynolds cartoon character who was banished from billboards because critics thought he was too appealing to children, had been given a bum rap.
"In order to understand what's happened with teen smoking," Mr. Gingrich said, speaking extemporaneously, "this is not complicated -- it has nothing to do with Joe Camel."
A worse problem, he said, was smoking on screen by Hollywood stars like Leonardo DiCaprio, the leading actor in "Titanic."
The Speaker's remarks were reported by the Reuters news agency.
For the second consecutive day, Mr. Clinton leapt at the opening Mr. Gingrich had provided. At the outset of a statement this afternoon in the White House Rose Garden about his legislative agenda, the President declared: "Now, some in Congress say that teen smoking has nothing to do with Joe Camel. Medical science and common sense make it plain: teen smoking has everything to do with Joe Camel -- with unscrupulous marketing campaigns that prey on the insecurities and dreams of our children."
The Speaker denied at his news conference that he was making excuses for the tobacco companies. "They clearly were trying to addict 14-year-olds," he said, "and they were clearly lying to the United States Congress and the American people about their behavior."
Mr. Gingrich, who does not smoke, said that his father and his adoptive father had died of lung cancer and that he wished young people who were starting to smoke could visit a hospital and see someone who was dying from having smoked.
He also read aloud a newspaper column by Hillary Rodham Clinton in which the First Lady denounced smoking in films.
The Speaker's suggestion today that antismoking and antidrug legislation should be linked was in the context of trying to gain political advantage from the Clinton Administration's announcement on Monday about needle exchange programs. The officials announced that programs to distribute clean needles to drug addicts could save lives by reducing the spread of AIDS but that Federal money should not be used for such programs.
Mr. Gingrich interpreted this to mean, "Well, as long as your needle is clean, what's a little heroin or cocaine among friends? Your Government would like to give you a free needle but doesn't have the courage to do it."
The Republican position, Mr. Gingrich said, was, "If we're going to communicate with teen-agers, we want to communicate across the board; we don't want to drive them from one addictive substance to another."
At another news conference today, Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the House majority leader, said he was skeptical of whether a steep price increase, which the President favors, would inhibit smoking by young people.
A smoker and an economist, Mr. Armey said that his "rational intuition" told him that the demand for tobacco was "inelastic." That is the word economists use to describe products for which the demand does not fall when the price rises.
Mr. Armey said that he was unalterably opposed to a tobacco bill approved this month by the Senate Commerce Committee, but he refused to explain why.
The chief sponsor of the Commerce Committee's bill, Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, met at the White House this afternoon with the top Presidential advisers on tobacco matters, and Mr. Clinton joined the discussions part of the time.
The McCain bill would raise the price of cigarettes, strengthen regulations and penalize the tobacco industry if goals for reducing smoking by young people are not met. This is essentially what the President wants. But neither he nor Senator McCain sees it in his advantage to embrace the other's position entirely.

HEADLINE: TV Notes;
Cultivating A 'Seinfeld' Heir

BYLINE: By BILL CARTER 

 BODY:
Several networks are scrambling to find comedies that are direct descendants of "Seinfeld," but one network already has a show created by a "Seinfeld" graduate, and it is taking unusual steps to try to keep it alive.
The network is WB and the show is "Alright Already," the product of Carol Leifer, a longtime writer on "Seinfeld," one of Jerry Seinfeld's friends from stand-up comedy and, according to Seinfeld legend, a model for the character of Elaine. 
 Despite what have to be called marginal ratings (a 2.1 national average, good for just over 2 million homes), Garth Ancier, the head of programming for WB, said, "There is a 95 percent probability" that the network will bring the comedy back next season.
WB believes so strongly in the show, he said, that he is actively searching for the right "smart comedy" to add to the schedule to help build "Alright Already" into a hit. And that search is going to include whatever comedies Mr. Ancier can find in the remainder bin next month.
"We may take a show off another network," Mr. Ancier said, "depending on what becomes available."
He said he has already thought about such likely cancelees as NBC's "Fired Up" and CBS's "Gregory Hines Show." He even considered a much more high-profile candidate.
"I thought seriously about going after 'Ellen,' " Mr. Ancier said, expecting, as most television executives now do, that ABC will drop the groundbreaking Ellen Degeneres series. "But economically it just didn't make sense for us."
Why all this effort for such a low-rated show? Mr. Ancier cited the show's "smart writing" (despite its less-than-smart spelling of "all right") and the fact that few comedies now emerge quickly as hits, forcing networks to identify those with real promise and "be incredibly patient with them."
In the series, Ms. Leifer plays a Miami Beach optician surrounded by a suitably quirky cast of friends and relatives. She cited her four years writing for "Seinfeld" under its co-creator Larry David as a huge influence. "Watching the way Larry structured the show was great for me," she said. "I think our show has its own flavor -- kind of mocha almond."
"Alright Already" played most of the year on Sunday nights but this week moved to Mondays. "Not a whole lot better," Ms. Leifer said. "First we faced 'The X-Files,' now it's 'Ally McBeal.' "
Starting up the show meant a return to performing for Ms. Leifer, who this week also signed to star in a stand-up comedy special for HBO sometime next year. BILL CARTER

LENGTH: 1839 words

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Wish You Were Here;
Marxist Cuba Beckons, And U.S. Capitalists Champ at the Bit

BYLINE: By JIM CARRIER 

 BODY:
Last month, two Caterpillar Inc. executives had the kind of face-to-face meeting with a national leader that salesmen dream about -- except the leader was Fidel Castro, and they weren't allowed to sell him anything.
At a dinner the Cuban leader gave in Havana for several American business people, Mr. Castro asked the Caterpillar managers about bulldozers. They told him the largest Cat exceeded 1,000 horsepower. His bushy eyebrows shot up; Cuba's Russian machines are only 100 horse and are notoriously unreliable. "I can't comprehend" bulldozers like the ones his guests were describing, Mr. Castro said through an interpreter. 
 At about the same time, a high-ranking Cuban diplomat traveled to the world headquarters of the Radisson Hotels, a unit of the Carlson Companies, in St. Paul. He assured Peter Blyth, Radisson's president, that three sites eyed by Radisson years ago in Havana and Varadero, a resort on the northern coast, were still available for hotel development. The properties have no claims against them by foreigners forced out of the country after Mr. Castro took power in 1959, he added, and the Cuban Government was eager to do business with Radisson.
These two recent contacts between capitalist America and Communist Cuba represent a small but growing movement by American companies to prepare for the day when doing business with Cuba is not trading with the enemy, as most such transactions are now legally defined. In spite of the 36-year-old United States embargo that prohibits all but a narrow range of commercial activity, and in spite of discouragement by the State Department, American executives are circling the island like Navy gunboats once did, and, in increasing numbers, actually landing.
Cuba's needs are certainly monumental. American executives who have visited Cuba recently estimate the market just for basic goods and services like food, medicine and road repair at $2 billion to $4 billion annually. Mr. Blyth of Radisson Hotels predicts Americans would flood Cuba in the unlikely event that travel restrictions were eased -- driving up the number of annual foreign visitors to 10 million from the current mostly European crop of 1.2 million. Under current law, Americans are free to travel to Cuba, but cannot spend a dime unless they are licensed by the State Department or are the guests of officially designated hosts, like the Cuban Government or some foreign company.
"You could run brake shoes over for '53 Chevys and make a fortune," said Rob O'Neill, manager of the Key West, Fla., harbor, who often talks with associates about the money-making opportunities that will open up when the embargo ends.
Before Americans can sign deals, however, Congress must lift the embargo. And that is unlikely to happen as long as Mr. Castro remains in power. "Castro has to leave, vertically or horizontally," said Marc Thiessen, press spokesman for Senator Jesse Helms, the North Carolina Republican who is chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee. Even so, he suggested, Mr. Castro's departure may not be so far off. "We're so close," Mr. Thiessen suggested. "Castro's revolution is dead."
Still, with the prospect of the bars coming down to the hemisphere's last forbidden market, an island of 11 million people just 90 miles south of the Florida coast, American business is straining at the leash. "It's not even controversial in our membership," said John Howard, director of international policy for the United States Chamber of Commerce. "There is a widespread and growing sentiment that our policy toward Cuba makes no sense."
For now, American business is pretty much limited to advocating a change in American policy, which has been dictated for decades by the mostly anti-Castro Cuban-American community, to slipping through the few fissures that Washington has allowed to develop in the ban, and to keeping up a dialogue with Cubans.
The number of American business representatives traveling to Cuba -- legally, but in most cases without State Department sanction -- has quadrupled to a projected 2,000 this year from 500 in 1994, according to the U.S.-Cuba Trade and Economic Council of New York.
Just last month, a delegation of midlevel officers from major corporations -- including the Mobil Oil Corporation, Texaco Inc., Pharmacia & Upjohn, Bristol-Myers Squibb, Continental Grain, the Case Corporation, a unit of Tenneco, and Caterpillar Inc. -- was the official guest of Mr. Castro and his top ministers in Havana, and a follow-up trade show is proposed in September, said the organizer, Kirby Jones of Alamar Associates. Another trade show for American companies, this one for medical products, is planned within the year by PWN Exhibicon International, based in Connecticut. For the most part, participants in such events describe them as fact-finding tours, though American companies are allowed to take such measures as signing nonbinding letters of intent with Cuban groups or registering trademarks and brand names.
Meantime, President Clinton has widened ever so slightly some small cracks in the trade embargo. On March 20, he announced a measure to expedite shipments of drug and medical equipment, which are already exempt from the ban. At the same time, he authorized the resumption of direct flights to Cuba and of remittances of up to $1,200 by Americans to relatives in Cuba, a measure that should increase sales for the approximately 100 American companies given special dispensation to trade with Cuba.
Those companies do a combined $100-million-a-year business in Cuba -- a drop in the bucket compared with the inroads being made by some of America's trading partners. The Cuban Government reports that companies from 25 countries have committed $2 billion to 340 joint ventures and associations with the Cubans, and have announced other deals worth an additional $4.5 billion.
Canada is the biggest foreign investor, accounting for one-third of the money flowing into the country, followed by Italy, Mexico, Spain, France and the Netherlands. The Sherritt International Corporation of Toronto is reportedly the single most active foreign company, with $800 million committed. The company produces 40 percent of Cuba's oil and is also involved in mining, power generation, cell phones, tourism and agriculture, said Patrice Merrin Best, senior vice president.
Mr. Castro, one of the world's last avowedly Marxist leaders, has made a series of concessions to the capitalist West since the collapse of the Soviet Union and the end of Moscow's $3-billion-a-year subsidy to his economy. He has liberalized agriculture, allowed tourists to spend dollars, and even invited the Pope for a visit in February. In 1995, his Government created free trade zones and allowed up to 100 percent foreign ownership in many sectors.
This year, the Cuban Government will be host to 250 trade fairs, a turnabout 38 years after Mr. Castro began the nationalization of hundreds of foreign companies that led to the trade embargo. The first property seized, on June 29, 1960, was a Texaco refinery. The rest followed on Aug. 6. President John F. Kennedy imposed the embargo Feb. 7, 1962.
Nearly 6,000 property claims have been certified by the United States; more than half of them, with a 1972 value of $1.8 billion, are held by 30 corporations. Under the Helms-Burton Act of 1996, the embargo can be lifted only after those claims are settled by a democratic government that does not include Fidel or Raul Castro.
Rather than cowing American companies keen on doing business in Cuba, however, that requirement has galvanized them to speak out against the embargo, according to John Kavulich 2d, president of the U.S.-Cuba Trade and Economic Council, a nonprofit business organization that describes itself as nonpartisan. "Large companies moved from just gathering information about Cuba to finding out what they could do in Cuba today, and then doing it," he said.
Even some companies with big compensation claims are cautious about making an issue of them as they eye the Cuban market. Texaco hopes to resolve its demand "if the opportunity represents itself," said Chris Gidez, director of external communications. Meantime, the company sent a member of its Latin American business team to Havana last month to meet with Government officials.
Until now, most American corporations have feared approaching Cuba's shores, even when it was legal. Medical sales, for example, have been allowed for years, but only 40 transactions have been licensed since 1992, and medical companies have given away more than they've sold. Another 10 exploratory licenses have been issued.
Medical companies appear reluctant to jump into Cuba; Eli Lilly & Company said it had no plans to apply for a license as long as the full embargo remained. Part of the reason for their hesitation is the endless paperwork that awaits them. Any pharmaceutical company wishing to exhibit products at the planned trade show by PWN Exhibicon International, for example, must first get a permit from the Federal Government, then a separate license to sell any product, be it an X-ray machine or a box of surgical gloves.
Even more daunting is a prohibition on high-technology exports so broad that it basically includes anything with a microprocessor. "They think it's going to be put in the nose of a cruise missile and sent back our way," said W. Bradford Gary, a board member of the Medical Device Manufacturers Association, who visited Cuba last month. As a result, he said, Cuban doctors wash and re-use surgical gloves and operate 1950's kidney-dialysis machines with no spare parts.
At the moment, the largest licensed transaction with Cuba is AT&T's annual payment of $23 million for access to the Cuban market, part of $66 million in fees from nine long-distance companies. (Most of the long-distance calls that AT&T makes money on originate in the United States.) American airlines pay another $6 million to fly over Cuban air space en route to South America.
Other transactions range from Western Union Moneygrams to three charter flights a week from three Miami charter airlines, which last year were permitted to fly 17,000 journalists, academicians and humanitarians and 43,000 Cuban-Americans home for their once-a-year family visit.
After two American civilian planes were shot down by Cuba in 1996, direct flights to the island were banned, and American visitors had to travel first to Mexico or the Bahamas and board foreign airlines there for the final leg to Havana. President Clinton's reversal of that policy is expected to reduce the round-trip fare to about $300 from $400, while increasing the traffic handled by American charter companies by 50 percent, to 90,000 passengers a year, said Vivian Mannerud. president of the Airline Broker Company.
"Since the Pope's visit, we've seen an increase in visa applications, nearly doubling," Ms. Mannerud said. "People are saying it's time to visit their families, some who have waited 30 years."

SECTION: Section G; Page 8; Column 1; Circuits 

LENGTH: 1026 words

HEADLINE: Behind Headlines on Study, a Couple Married to Their Work

BYLINE: By KATIE HAFNER 

 BODY:
LAST Friday, Donna L. HoffmanDonna L. Hoffman started the day knowing it would be far from routine. The journal Science had just published an article she co-wrote, a groundbreaking report demonstrating that lower-income black Americans are far less likely to have Internet access than whites of similar economic status. News reports about the study had already appeared.
Dr. Hoffman is no stranger to sensitive topics. She and her husband and fellow researcher Thomas P. Novak, in their studies of the Internet, have touched on subjects like pornography. So, she expected her phone to start ringing early (most calls were from reporters) at her home in Nashville and at her office at Vanderbilt University, where she is an associate professor. 
 Then she checked her E-mail in box, which was quickly filling up. While some messages were requests for more information, many others were bilious, racist attacks. They not only questioned the study's validity but also expressed anger that such a study would be conducted at all. One man, saying he was "sick of quotas, whining, cultural sensitivity, etc.," remarked, "Why not put a Nike Swoosh on the computer boxes and sell them in Sneaker King?" She was used to strange E-mail, but not to hate.
Gary Chapman, director of the 21st Century Project at the University of Texas at Austin, who has worked to bring computer access to low-income communities, said the E-mail was no surprise to him. "The Internet attracts racist speech," he said. "It's unacceptable to say these things in normal public discourse, but on the Internet it can be vented on a system that is essentially anonymous."
The import of the Hoffman-Novak study, Mr. Chapman said, was that it pointed not just at who lacked Internet access but also at what was lacking on the Internet. "The results seem to suggest that content on the Internet isn't compelling enough to the African-American community," Mr. Chapman said. "They want to see something that reflects their view of the world, which is often hard to find on the Internet."
Dr. Hoffman said few of the people sending racist comments appeared to have read the paper itself, which is available on the Web (www2000.ogsm.vanderbilt.edu/paper list.html), even though they had gone to some lengths to find her E-mail address.
"It was stunning," Dr. Hoffman said of such messages. "It points out that there clearly is a problem here, and much of the problem has to do with people's attitudes."
The recent study published by Dr. Hoffman and Dr. Novak is not the first of theirs to attract attention. At the forefront of their field -- Internet marketing, an area in which they were pioneers -- the two scholars have a knack for picking topical subjects.
For nearly 20 years, Drs. Hoffman and Novak, both 42, have intensely combined work and marriage. Not only do they specialize in the same area -- market segmentation and commercialization of the World Wide Web -- but they also conduct their research together and publish all papers jointly. "Some people might think it's overkill," Dr. Hoffman said. "But we've found it's really efficient to work together and play together."
The couple started their careers as statisticians studying behavior. They met in 1978 as graduate students at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. "I thought Tom was too much of an Oberlin hippie, and he thought I was really snotty," Dr. Hoffman said. The frost thawed, however, and one night after a movie date, Dr. Hoffman went to Dr. Novak's apartment and "never left." They married in 1979.
After stints at universities in New York and Texas, they ended up at the Owen Graduate School of Management at Vanderbilt University in 1993. Soon after their arrival at Vanderbilt, they downloaded Mosaic, an early Web browser, for the first time and were immediately captivated by the potential of the Web.
IN 1994 they started Project 2000 to study the marketing implications of commercializing the Web, and the program has become a pre-eminent research center for studying electronic commerce. Their recent study is the first to attach numbers to a situation that many people had only suspected.
"Donna Hoffman and Tom Novak have brought serious quantitative methods to many of the tough social issues facing the Internet," said Marc Rotenberg, executive director of the Electronic Privacy Information Center in Washington. "They have set themselves apart from the pundits, market analysts and commentators."
In 1995, Drs. Hoffman and Novak were the first to discredit the research of Marty Rimm, an undergraduate who asserted that the Internet was awash in pornography. "They put him through a Cuisinart," Gary Chapman said. They drew attention to themselves again later that year when they challenged the methodology underlying a demographic report that led to inflated estimates of the numer of Internet users.
Dr. Hoffman, who has become something of a household name in computing circles, has eclipsed Dr. Novak in the limelight. She travels extensively, lecturing and attending conferences. When reporters call, she answers. Less outgoing by nature, Dr. Novak said he preferred to stay home and do research.
Dr. Hoffman said she was completely taken aback by the invective that has poured into her computer over the past week. As of Tuesday, she had received close to 50 E-mail messages, about 30 of them negative. Many critics have taken their opinions to the Net itself. More than 170 postings -- many similar in tone to the E-mail Dr. Hoffman received -- have been made to a discussion forum on ZDNet (www.zdnet.com/zdnn/content/msnb/0417/ 307772.html).
Given the speed with which things change on the Internet, Dr. Novak said, the data in the paper, collected more than a year ago, are already out of date. New numbers being gathered appear to paint a more optimistic picture.
"We would expect that many more African-Americans will be on line when we look at the more recent numbers," he said. It will be interesting, he added, to see what kind of E-mail the researchers receive once they publish the follow-up study, which they plan to do later this year.

HEADLINE: Computers Are Starting to Listen, and Understand

BYLINE: By ANNE EISENBERG 

 BODY:
IN January, Deborah Bauder bought a new dictation program for students with various disabilities at a center she directs and found it so effective that she was soon using it herself to handle daily writing chores.
"I gradually switched from typing and clicking to speaking," she said. "Now I turn on my PC, put on the headset and talk my reports or E-mail. I'm retraining myself to save my hands from repetitive stress injury. It's also a fast, accurate way to work." 
 Dr. Bauder had tried and rejected earlier dictation products as inefficient, but she and many others have recently discovered a new generation of markedly improved speech-based products. They are popping up everywhere: to switch on the pot for morning coffee, to open word processing files, to read E-mail.
Computers can now recognize what is said to them, and even talk back, thanks to relatively recent advances in speech recognition programming combined with powerful and ever-cheaper computer processing power.
New users need time and patience to learn the ways of voice-driven technology -- out of the box, the programs make mistakes that would get most typists fired.
But, flaws and all, conversational technology is so useful that it is already changing the way many people interact with computer chips. Consumers who are ready for the switch will find a new generation of speech-based products that stand prepared to talk about E-mail or the latest mortgage rates while mimicking the solicitousness and tact of a Jeeves.
Dictation may well be the way that automatic speech recognition conquers the nation's desktops, as experiences like Dr. Bauder's are repeated. Until about 15 months ago, dictation programs required a pause between each word, reminding many users of the Bob and Ray routine "Slow Talkers of America," in which Bob maddens Ray by s-p-e-a-k-i-n-g v-e-r-y s-l-o-w-l-y. Now, two companies, Dragon Systems and International Business Machines, have programs priced under $200 for "continuous dictation," the name for programs that will listen to and reproduce words spoken by someone talking at a steady rate in phrases or sentences.
There is a catch: the systems are "speaker dependent" -- a new user has to train the programs to recognize the quirks in a voice, like how a Southerner pronounces "house" or how a Boston resident says "yard." While the programs are not free of errors, a big leap in voice-recognition technology in the last year allows the system to learn the patterns of the speaker quickly, whether the English is standard or has the lilt of another language or dialect. The process takes about 20 to 30 minutes for those who sound like broadcast news anchors and a bit longer for everyone else. The new owner must also introduce the speech recognizer to on-the-job jargon.
After an hour or so of training, the programs will type at a fair clip: 75 to 80 words per minute are common, with accuracy steadily increasing as the program masters the cadences of the speaker and adds frequently used words to its base vocabulary.
The other hot application for speech technology lies in voice-automated phone transactions, which are sorely needed, as anyone who has negotiated touch-tone choices for anything like a train schedule knows. (Press 1 if you are human. Press 2 if you are no longer sure.)
People dislike such phone menus, said Joe Yaworski of the Unisys Corporation in Paoli, Pa., which sells Natural Language Speech Assistant, a toolkit that companies use to link automatic speech recognition, called interactive voice response systems, to their call banks. "The common phone menu these days averages 69 choices -- although 27 are optimal," Mr. Yaworski said. "People have to drill their way down four or five levels to get information. We've found it's typical that up to 70 percent of callers bail out and hit 0 for the operator."
Automated speech recognition systems permit callers to ask a complex question like, "Do you have flights to Nashville from La Guardia today?" rather than punching in answers to questions about the date of flight, origin of flight and destination.
The speech recognition systems are possible because they work within narrow contexts like airline reservations or mortgage rates, restricting the size of vocabulary and extracting the core meaning from a person's natural answer to a specific question. The programs use many tactics, including word-spotting algorithms that can handle variations like "on Sunday," "this Sunday" and "ummm, Sunday."
"Because of the range of what people can say -- the natural language problem -- initially all of these products will work by limiting vocabulary and possible answers," said Jackie Fenn, an industry analyst at the Gartner Group, based in Stamford, Conn. "They'll focus on highly constrained situations. This means you can't talk to your microwave about the weather, but you can discuss dinner."
Applied Language Technologies, called Altech, a Boston company that focuses on automating over-the-phone transactions like those in banking, travel and investing, tries to make its programs more accurate by getting them to approximate human responses. "Even humans don't achieve 100 percent accuracy when they talk on the telephone," said Bill O'Farrell, co-founder and chairman of the company. "We all need a fair amount of clarification, like, 'I'm sorry' or 'Could you run that past me again?' A good speech user interface mimics these qualities." If Altech's speech recognizer misses a beat, it politely says: "I didn't catch that. Did you say yes or no?"
Altech's Speech Works technology is used by the E-Trade Group of Palo Alto, Calif., which has about 1,000 telephone lines for its electronic brokerage business. On a given day, 15 percent to 20 percent of the brokerage's business comes in by interactive voice responses. "Of that percentage, 20 to 30 percent is handled via speech recognition software," said Michael Welton, who manages the company's voice-response products. "The system has a 50,000 word vocabulary -- quite a recognition challenge." At every step, the program confirms what the customer says (e.g., "I think you said buy 300 shares at the market. Is that correct?").
The people who telephone E-Trade and decide to buy stock through a speech recognizer instead of a person deal with what is called a speaker-independent program. No training time is possible when thousands of people are calling and each one speaks differently. Speaker-independent systems improve their accuracy, in part, by limiting the vocabulary in the possible answers callers can give.
Input, what the speaker says to the machine, is only one side of the speech recognition coin. On the other is output, called text-to-speech in the trade. For now, machines remain better listeners than text-to-speakers: they can talk intelligibly, but few would mistake the sound for a human voice.
"The technology here has lagged," said Paul Saffo of the Institute for the Future, a research organization in Menlo Park, Calif. "I'm still waiting for a voice that will pass the Turing test -- although, come to think of it, I have some friends who would not pass this test." (The Turing test is named for Alan Turing, who said true artificial intelligence would be shown when a machine's conversation could be mistaken for a person's.)
In either case, said David Nahamoo, director of speech technology at I.B.M.'s Thomas J. Watson Research Center in Yorktown Heights, N.Y., "conversational technology is going to become the mode of any device you can imagine embedded in the office, at home or in the car." He added, "Speech is the interface of the future."
With either the I.B.M. or Dragon Systems programs, accuracy improves substantially if users accustom the program to their voices and vocabularies. People with bad colds can count on five minutes of retraining but can always save those voices for the next time they have the flu and insist on working.
These systems can be used not only for dictating E-mail and memos -- in English, French, German, Italian, Spanish and Chinese so far -- but also for editing them. Voice commands open files and permit revisions. Sentences like "move the last sentence to the end of the paragraph" can now be understood by some programs.
Both I.B.M.'s Via Voice Gold and the Dragon System's Naturally Speaking Preferred let people use voice -- or a combination of voice, mouse and keyboard -- for editing and formatting. Lernout & Hauspie Speech Products expects to introduce a moderately priced continuous dictation program, called Voice Xpress Plus, in early May, a company spokeswoman said. There are also dictation products for Macs, but they require pauses between words.
While the new systems are good, it is probably not time to throw away the mouse and keyboard yet. Erik Chesla, a computer consultant who specializes in speech technology, said any shift to voice-driven computing took time. "Training a dictation program to recognize a speaker's voice and vocabulary is the first step; learning the voice commands is the second step," he said. "You can't just say 'file' when you want to open a file, for instance; you have to say 'click file.' There are dozens of these tricks people have to learn."
Mr. Chesla said voice-activated products also required a change of habits. "Ten years ago, people had trouble freeing their right hand from typing to use the mouse to navigate," he said. "Now -- wearing a brace -- they want to leave the mouse behind, but they have to learn a new routine. Give it a month or so. It won't happen overnight, but it's worth learning."
Mr. Saffo agrees that conversational technology is imminent but he is not entirely cheerful about it. "Faster chips plus better algorithms have given us this acceleration effect where voice recognition is popping up everywhere," he said. "My fear is what happens with every new toy: you try to use it for everything. If we're not careful, we'll end up with a world in which all our devices are jabbering away at us. I for one don't want to have a conversation with my espresso machine in the morning."

GRAPHIC: Photo: John Ford dictated into a computer under Dr. Deborah Bauder's supervision. (Michael J. Okoniewski for The New York Times)(pg. G8)
 
Charts: "Matching Spoken Sounds With Words"
More powerful computers have enabled speech recognition programs to become more accurate. Current programs, which do not require any special hardware, rely on a mathematical process of matching the spoken sounds with words in a database.
 
The Sound Is Digitized . . .
The user speaks into a microphone attached to the computer. The computer breaks the sound into tiny pieces that it can convert from a sound wave into digital audio, like that stored on a CD.
 
Then the Pronunciation Is Analyzed . . .
Strings of digitized sounds are compared with a dictionary of phonetic word spellings. Strings of words are a more accurate way of figuring out what was said because people tend to blend the endings of some words with the beginning of the word that follows.
 
And the Right Word Is Chosen.
Finally the computer makes sure that the word makes sense in context. The computer can make an educated guess about what the user's next word will be by analyzing what was just said. It searches a database of millions of words from representative texts to derive a list of probable word choices. Then it chooses the word that best matches the pronunciation and context.
