HEADLINE: Museum Exchanges Looted Art for a Show

BYLINE: By JUDITH H. DOBRZYNSKI 

DATELINE: HARTFORD

 BODY:
Almost as soon as the Wadsworth Atheneum here purchased Jacopo Zucchi's "Bath of Bathsheba" in 1965, there was trouble. The painting turned out to be stolen, ripped from the walls of the Italian Embassy in Berlin in the waning days of World War II. The Italians, naturally, wanted the 16th-century work back, never mind that the Atheneum had bought it in good faith from a Paris dealer.
All these years later, "Bathsheba" will soon be Rome-bound, but not until the Atheneum plays host to "Caravaggio and His Italian Followers," an exhibition opening tomorrow that is drawn mostly from Italy's national collections and that was sent by Rome in exchange. 
 The swap is not quite even. The Atheneum is out the $35,000 it paid for the painting, which today might fetch $500,000. But the museum saves the estimated $350,000 cost of the exhibition, said Peter C. Sutton, its director, who did the deal despite some grumbling from Hartford residents about returning the spoils of war.
Besides, the show, which runs through July 26, is important not only because it is a happy ending to the dispute. It may have repercussions for other museums and art historians as well as the Atheneum, which in recent years has retreated from a trail-blazing past replete with adventurous acquisitions and exhibitions.
With the search for war booty intensifying, as a result of the opening of many wartime archives, the publication of several books on the issue and the creation of organizations to pursue lost art, other museums may use the Atheneum's deal as a model. "This is the first case we brought to a good end, and I hope it sets a precedent," said Mario Bondioli Osio, the president of the Interministerial Commission for Artworks, which Italy created in 1995 to recover its lost patrimony.
Mr. Osio is seeking looted art at other museums in the United States, France and Germany that he declined to name. And Mr. Sutton said he had received "several calls" from other museum directors. "They say: 'Can I speak to you privately? I have this little problem,' " he said.
In a small way, "Caravaggio" breaks new art historical ground, too. With just 40 paintings, including 5 by the master, it is far less ambitious than the Metropolitan Museum of Art's "Age of Caravaggio" in 1985, which boasted about 100 pictures, including roughly 40 by or attributed to Caravaggio.
But scholars are keen to see the Atheneum's juxtaposition of two Caravaggios called "St. John the Baptist in the Wilderness," one from Italy and one borrowed from the Nelson-Atkins Museum of Art in Kansas City, which have not been together since they were painted in 1604-05, if then. "We will be able to see, given the subject of St. John, what does Caravaggio do with it -- what are the differences, when one was for an altarpiece, a focus of worship, and one was for a private collector?" said Keith Christiansen, the Metropolitan's expert in Italian paintings.
There is a new attribution to ponder, too. As the Italians prepared to send the 29 paintings they are lending, they found that "The Fortuneteller" was executed by Simon Vouet, a 17th-century Frenchman, not by Bartolomeo Manfredi, the Italian who became the most important exponent of the Caravaggio style of genre painting. Mr. Christiansen called the discovery astonishing. "It poses questions of Vouet's relation to Caravaggio and Caravaggisti in a new light," he said.
If "Caravaggio," which also includes works from the Kimbell Art Museum in Fort Worth, a private collection and the Atheneum's permanent holdings, creates as much excitement as Mr. Sutton hopes, it may do the most good of all for the Atheneum, whose annual attendance has been stuck at about 160,000.
"Caravaggio" is the first test of Mr. Sutton's plan to transform the Atheneum. By offering more clever special exhibitions, conceived locally instead of borrowed from other museums, he believes the Atheneum will draw local crowds, earn respect from its bigger brethren and see its example imitated by other museums that have stagnated.
It once was so. Founded in 1842, the Atheneum is America's oldest continuously operating museum. Besides being known for a distinguished permanent collection (bounteous in Hudson River school landscapes, Baroque art, and decorative arts), the museum claims an illustrious history, full of innovation.
It was the first American museum to buy a Caravaggio (1943) and the first to buy a Dali (1931). It presented the first comprehensive retrospective of Picasso in this country (1934), and the first exhibitions here of Surrealism (1931), Italian Baroque paintings (1930) and Neo-Romanticism (1931). It gave many contemporary artists their first solo show in an American museum, including Gerhard Richter, Keith Haring, Sherrie Levine, Cady Noland, Richard Tuttle, Neil Jenney and on and on.
J. P. Morgan, a Hartford native, gave it a building, as did Elizabeth Hart Jarvis Colt, of the firearms family. For a while in the 1970's, annual attendance reached 260,000.
But that was years ago.
The museum's fortunes sank as Hartford's did. "Metropolitan Hartford is one of the nation's weakest economies in the 1990's," said Mark Zandi, chief economist at Regional Financial Associates, a consulting firm. Jobs, which peaked at 662,000 in October, 1988, bottomed out at 584,000 in January, 1996, and each year, 5,000 to 10,000 people moved away, Mr. Zandi said.
Mr. Sutton, 49, arrived at the Atheneum in November 1996 after stints as an expert on Old Masters (particularly Northern European) at Christie's and as a curator at the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston and the Philadelphia Museum of Art. It was good timing. The city's economy was starting to expand again, and with it hopes by officials for a Hartford renaissance.
Under Mr. Sutton's orders, the museum's curators are organizing at least three exhibitions a year. A few did not like the new standard and have left. But in September there will be a big show comparing, for the first time, the development of Australian and American landscape paintings, organized with the National Gallery of Australia. Then comes the first solo show of Pieter de Hooch, a painter from the Dutch Golden Age, organized with the Dulwich Picture Gallery in London.
In 1999 a show of Alfred Stieglitz, Georgia O'Keeffe and their circle is on the docket. And for 2000, there will be Dali in the 1930's, Picasso's paintings of his studio, and "The Impressionists at Argenteuil," organized with the National Gallery of Art in Washington.
Mr. Sutton's extensive contacts in the art world have surely helped. It was he who called Paul Hayes Tucker, a Monet expert at the University of Massachusetts at Boston, to organize the Argentueil show and who enlisted the National Gallery as co-organizer.
"These things allow us to play in a bigger league," said Elizabeth Kornhauser, the chief curator. "I am trying to make it more exciting," Mr. Sutton said. "A lot of people don't walk in the door because museums are perceived as highbrow institutions that have nothing to do with modern life."
That is why he worked hard to convince the Italians to lend their treasures from the Palazzo Barberini and Palazzo Corsino in Rome.
Initially, Mr. Osio offered not "Caravaggio" but an exhibition of Neopolitan paintings. "They wanted to lend from the basement," Mr. Sutton said. "So I went back and asked for their greatest hits -- Caravaggio, Raphael . . . "
Both sides seem happy with "Caravaggio." "These are paintings of the highest quality that are normally on view here," Mr. Osio said from Rome. Mr. Sutton is sure the public will respond. "Look at the image on our Caravaggio poster," he said, referring to a depiction of St. Cecilia with a lute, by Saraceni. "Anyone could love it. This is not a decapitated saint or anything."

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
How the American Left Lost Hope

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER LEHMANN-HAUPT 

 BODY:

ACHIEVING OUR COUNTRY
Leftist Thought in 20th-Century America
By Richard Rorty
159 pages. Harvard University Press. $18.95.
 In his philosophically rigorous new book, "Achieving Our Country: Leftist Thought in 20th-Century America," Richard Rorty raises a provocative if familiar question: Whatever happened to national pride in this country? Not what he terms "simple-minded militaristic chauvinism," but the sort of pride that "is to countries what self-respect is to individuals: a necessary condition for self-improvement."
What in particular has happened to the pride instilled by Walt Whitman and John Dewey that, Mr. Rorty says, "was ubiquitous on the American left prior to the Vietnam War"? This was a pride that envisioned the American experiment as secular, anti-authoritarian and infinite in possibilities that Whitman idealized as loving relationships and Dewey as good citizenship. It was a pragmatic pride, demanding action rather than mere spectatorship, which is why it was essential to what motivated the "Old Left," or what Mr. Rorty prefers to call the "reformist left." 
 What happened to this activist pride? Mr. Rorty, the neo-pragmatist philosopher who teaches at the University of Virginia, offers an answer in "Achieving Our Country," which is based on the William E. Massey Sr. Lectures in the History of American Civilization he delivered last year at Harvard University. He argues that in the 1960's the reformist left was eclipsed by the New Left, which rejected it for supporting the cold war and, by extension, Vietnam.
But because of the Marxist strain in its thinking, Mr. Rorty writes, the New Left was too pure to take up the reformist left's causes, which demanded a willingness to compromise principles "in order to form alliances with groups about whom you have grave doubts."
While crediting the New Left for being instrumental in ending American involvement in Vietnam, Mr. Rorty blames it for retreating from pragmatism into theory. This has led members of the left "to give cultural politics preference over real politics, and to mock the very idea that democratic institutions might once again be made to serve social justice," he writes. "It leads them to prefer knowledge to hope."
Meanwhile, he argues, "leftists in the academy have permitted cultural politics to supplant real politics, and have collaborated with the right in making cultural issues central to public debate." While he credits what he calls "the new cultural left" for ameliorating the harm done by sadistic treatment of women, racial minorities and homosexuals, he also blames it for working to preserve "otherness" instead of ignoring it, for stressing the one issue to the exclusion of others, for cutting itself off from the remnant of the reformist left and for clinging to a view of America quite the opposite of national pride.
So what does Mr. Rorty offer as a solution besides exhorting the left to change its ways, get involved and shed what he calls its "semiconscious anti-Americanism, which it carried over from the rage of the late Sixties"? Not really very much. "Achieving Our Country" is more a critique of the left than a prescription for its rehabilitation in his terms, and given the sharpness of the critique, the book is unlikely to win over those who are the subject of his disapproval.
Trying to reform the left, Mr. Rorty even resorts to a form of intellectual bullying. He warns that if the cultural left continues to ignore what he calls the declining economic condition of American workers, they will become vulnerable to the demagogy of some fascist strongman, who will play on their fears and prejudices with the result that "all the sadism which the academic left has tried to make unacceptable to its students will come flooding back." Yet earlier he argues that such sadism has turned out not to be the result of "economic inequality and insecurity," and that the belief of the American left in such economic determinism was "too simplistic."
At the same time, so uncritical is his celebration of the left as, "by definition, the party of hope" and the right as inevitably selfish and committed to the status quo, that independent thinkers are unlikely to be persuaded by his reasoning. He writes: "The right thinks that our country already has a moral identity, and hopes to keep that identity intact. It fears economic and political change, and therefore easily becomes the pawn of the rich and powerful -- the people whose selfish interests are served by forestalling such change." Yet it never seems to occur to him that the left, in seeking change for its own sake, by peaceful means as well as violent, might as easily become the pawn of the nihilistic and destructive.
Still, if Mr. Rorty doesn't quite lead the way to a revival of national pride on the left, he offers a persuasive analysis of why such pride has been lost. As a philosopher, he is particularly thought-provoking in his readings of Whitman and Dewey as prophets of the American religion. Speaking of acts like the massacring of American Indians who stood in the settlers' way and our conduct in Vietnam, he asks, "is there then nothing incompatible with American national pride?"
He responds: "I think the Dewey-Whitman answer is that there are many things that should chasten and temper such pride, but that nothing a nation has done should make it impossible for a constitutional democracy to regain self-respect. To say that certain acts do make this impossible is to abandon the secular, authoritarian vocabulary of shared social hope in favor of a vocabulary which Whitman and Dewey abhorred: a vocabulary built around the notion of sin."
For Mr. Rorty, like Whitman and Dewey, the sin is suicidal guilt and despair. Anything short of such sin permits hope in the darkest hour and the beginnings of self-forgiveness, which leads on to a renewal of pride.

HEADLINE: In America;
Giuliani's Wild Pitches

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
"Purely from a financial analysis point of view," said Mayor Rudolph Giuliani back in April 1996, "the place where the city could build a new stadium at virtually no cost to the taxpayer or very little cost to the taxpayer would be in Manhattan."
State officials chuckled in private at that one. Said one: "Somebody has got to tell him to stop saying that because, you know, it's not true." 
 On Monday the Mayor crawled a little closer to the truth. With lots of charts but little in the way of specifics, he announced a plan that would dedicate hundreds of millions of tax dollars to begin -- just to begin, mind you -- financing new stadiums for the Yankees and the Mets.
This money would come from the commercial-rent tax, which is paid by large businesses south of 96th Street in Manhattan and which the Mayor had said was a terrible tax and ought to be phased out. Now we should keep it, but not to fix our crumbling, overcrowded schools, or to offset the effects of looming budget deficits. No, we should hang onto this tax so the revenues can be handed over like a Valentine each year to George Steinbrenner, principal owner of the Yankees, and Fred Wilpon, co-owner of the Mets.
The Mayor's admission that trainloads of tax dollars would be needed to finance the stadiums was not, however, an indication that he is ready to be significantly more candid with the public about these matters.
"The proposal they put out this week was amazingly vague," said Thomas McMahon, the City Council's finance director. "People don't know what we'd be paying for, what we'd be buying. Is it one stadium, two stadiums, three, four? Nobody knows."
The Mayor, his imagination running rampant, suggested on Monday that his tax proposal could be used to help build stadiums for football and soccer as well as baseball. How this would happen he didn't say.
Mr. Giuliani's primary goal is to secure a stadium on the West Side of Manhattan for Mr. Steinbrenner. He has seemed willing to say anything and pay any price to achieve that. In 1996, when the Mayor was making his preposterous claim that a West Side stadium could be built with little or no cost to the taxpayer, he was also saying that the "revenue stream" from such a stadium would be "off the charts."
Now, even as he's admitting that the use of public money is essential, and that tax dollars will have to go to the Yankees and the Mets, the Mayor continues to insist that this giveaway would realize a fabulous return.
"This spending," he said, "will result in, bare minimum, at least $1 billion more for our economy and thousands and thousands and thousands of jobs."
If the new stadiums are such gold mines, then why aren't private interests rushing to finance their construction? The answer is that private interests can make a lot of money from the stadiums as long as they don't have to pay to build them. The real gold mine is the city treasury, and Mr. Giuliani has graciously invited Mr. Steinbrenner and Mr. Wilpon to come in and stake their claims.
In an era when Republicans especially are screaming about the wonders of the free market, it is comical to watch G.O.P. politicians across the country line up in support of the giveaway of public resources to prospering private businesses. Free indeed.
A major reason that baseball owners like George Steinbrenner are so anxious to get their hands on new ball parks is the additional revenue that comes from the sale or lease of luxurious skyboxes, or stadium suites. The boxes, used for "entertaining" by corporations, have proved enormously popular and can enhance the value of a franchise by many millions of dollars.
The public subsidizes the construction of the stadium, but it's the team owners who get richer from the luxury suites. This is a matter of public policy that deserves some further discussion.
In any event, the general public and nearly all the elected officials in Manhattan and the Bronx are opposed to the construction of a stadium for the Yankees on the West Side of Manhattan. The sentiment citywide for keeping the Yankees in the Bronx is overwhelming.
But Mr. Steinbrenner wants a stadium on the West Side and Mr. Giuliani is running interference for him.
Whose town is it anyway?

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Japan's financial woes are real, but not insurmountable.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
PITY the bewildered politicians floundering for a way out of the mess in Tokyo. The Japan that could once do no wrong has morphed into the Japan that can do no right, with every effort to turn around the lagging economy dismissed as too little, too late. "This is a market that sees only bad news," said Richard Medley, managing partner of Medley Global Associates in New York.
Cooler heads do not minimize Japan's economic woes. But they still think a cure for the cyclic downturn, which is making the economy's long-term problems far more difficult to tackle, is within reach. Indeed, some predict that the tax cuts proposed by the administration of Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto, to be detailed tomorrow, will contain the seeds of Japan's economic redemption. 
 The muscular Japanese economy these days is more likely to be compared to a beached whale than an 800-pound gorilla. Consider Japan's notoriously clubby capital markets. There is no particular reason to think they have grown less efficient over the years. But inefficiency is now a greater liability.
'When Japan was playing catch-up, virtually any investment had a big payoff," said Gary Saxonhouse, an economist at the University of Michigan. "But in a developed economy, top-down allocation doesn't work." Indeed, the return on corporate equity in Japan averages a miserable 4 percent -- one-quarter the rate in America.
By the same token, Japan faces a chilling demographic reality -- a 20 percent decline in the working-age population combined with a huge jump in retirees over the next two decades -- a certainty that makes America's looming problems with Social Security and Medicare financing seem modest. While saving rates are extraordinarily high, they are not nearly high enough to support the elderly as long as the return on capital remains in single digits.
To cope with these problems, Japan has been moving rapidly, at least by Japanese standards, to raise the productivity of capital while building a nest egg for future retirees. "Hashimoto thought he had struck a grand bargain with the Ministry of Finance," Mr. Saxonhouse said. "Deregulation to make capital markets more competitive, combined with taxes on consumption to increase national savings."
But the timing could hardly have been worse. The prescribed increase in the national sales tax, pounded through the Diet against popular opposition, took effect last April, just as the economy was entering a downturn. Output fell sharply, the already ailing stock market plummeted and, in the aftermath of the financial market crash in parts of Asia, Japan's badly undercapitalized banks virtually closed their lending windows. Expansionary monetary policy, which has pushed interest rates close to zero, has done little to ease the crisis.
Yet while pessimism is all the rage, most economists still have faith that Japan can dig its way out using traditional tools. "Fiscal stimulus is especially effective when interest rates are on the floor and there is a need to jump-start confidence," noted Lawrence H. Summers, the Deputy Treasury Secretary.
And while Prime Minister Hashimoto has burned a lot of credibility by exaggerating the value of past fiscal initiatives and by funneling much of the money into projects that benefit well-connected construction companies, there is some reason to believe the Government now gets the point.
"Ideally," argued Robert Z. Lawrence, an economist at Harvard's Kennedy School of Government, "Japan would enact temporary cuts in the consumption tax." Unlike a temporary income tax cut, he points out, households would have no incentives to sock away the proceeds. And unlike a permanent income tax cut that raised household spending, a temporary consumption tax cut would not undermine long-term efforts to increase national savings.
A temporary rollback in the national sales tax is widely seen as a nonstarter: The Hashimoto administration spent too much political capital raising that tax a year ago to flip-flop. But Mr. Medley predicted that a good portion of the "targeted" income tax cuts to be introduced by Tokyo would amount to temporary consumption tax cuts by another name. A prime candidate is income tax credits for purchases of new cars and houses.
A growth rate of 2 percent to 3 percent would be no panacea. But it would make financial reform that drove thousands of unprofitable concerns into bankruptcy less traumatic. And it would give Japanese households a positive return on their savings.
The biggest stumbling block, Mr. Medley suggested, is the skepticism that greets every effort to rebuild economic confidence. "The way the Hashimoto Government has been treated, it would be hard not to be paranoid," he said.

HEADLINE: Hail to the Turkmen Dictator

 BODY:
For a textbook illustration of the intoxicating power of oil and gas, consider the visit of the President of the Central Asian Republic of Turkmenistan. Saparmurat Niyazov concludes his three-day visit to Washington today with a luncheon with President Clinton and a visit with Vice President Gore. Mr. Niyazov's trip has been full of such triumphal pomp. He gets these diplomatic goodies because he has two things Washington wants. One is political neutrality -- Turkmenistan offers a bulwark against the influence of its neighbor Iran. More important, Turkmenistan has the world's fourth-largest natural gas reserves, and Washington wants American companies to pump the gas through friendly nations to the West.
Yesterday President Niyazov signed an agreement with Energy Secretary Federico Pena to work together to develop Turkmenistan's oil and gas industry. Mr. Niyazov agreed to let the United States finance a feasibility study on the construction of a pipeline for oil and gas under the Caspian Sea. He also signed deals with Mobil and Exxon, and has been feted by American energy companies. A sycophantic Mobil advertisement published recently in The Washington Post bore the headline "Turkmenistan: Setting a Course for Prosperity." 
 Turkmenistan bought an eight-page advertising section in this week's Time magazine, touting itself as "Central Asia's stable state." Stable it is, as Mr. Niyazov continues to rule in the same way he did when he was head of Turkmenistan's Communist Party. There has been virtually no economic reform, and last year the country's economy contracted by more than 25 percent.
While other dictators deflect criticism by permitting a token opposition, Mr. Niyazov has no patience for such niceties. There is no dissent of any kind, and political opponents are sent to psychiatric hospitals. In 1994 Mr. Niyazov held a rigged referendum on whether to suspend the next presidential elections and simply extend his term until 2002. It passed with 99.9 percent of the vote.
American officials have consistently raised human rights concerns with their Turkmen counterparts, and Administration officials say that Mr. Niyazov has promised to be more democratic. Yet an unreformed Mr. Niyazov still enjoys a cozy relationship with Washington. Any talk about loosening his hold on his country has been lost in the din of the welcoming trumpets.

HEADLINE: An Equal Chance

BYLINE: By Lani Guinier; Lani Guinier is the author of "Lift Every Voice: Turning a Civil Rights Setback Into a New Vision of Social Justice."

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA

 BODY:
Now that the results are in, some opponents of affirmative action are having second thoughts. One year after California passed a referendum banning the use of race and ethnicity in public college admissions, the number of blacks, Hispanics and American Indians admitted to the University of California's two top campuses has dropped precipitously, leading to concern about the resegregation of higher education.
But while the news from California is dismaying, a different, more encouraging story is being written in Texas, a state with political leaders who see diversity as a rich resource that benefits everyone, not only people of color. 
 Last year, a Federal court outlawed consideration of race in higher-education admissions in Texas. At the time, the state had been using high school grades and Scholastic Assessment Test scores along with affirmative action criteria to decide admissions.
After the ruling, a panel of professors and community activists joined a group of Hispanic and black lawmakers to persuade the State Legislature to adopt what has come to be called the 10 percent plan.
This eliminated the use of S.A.T. scores for Texas students in the top 10 percent of their high school class and automatically admitted them to the two most selective public schools, the University of Texas at Austin and Texas A & M University.
At first, some critics objected that S.A.T. scores were indispensable measures of future success. But, as the advisory group of professors and activists pointed out, the best way to predict how a student will do in college is by measuring classroom performance in high school. This was borne out when achievement tests administered to the thousands of minority students admitted through the program showed that only a handful needed remedial education.
So far the Texas plan has produced many winners. As of March of this year, 7 percent more black and 21 percent more Mexican-American applicants were eligible for enrollment under this system than under the old affirmative action guidelines. And access to public education has increased for white high school graduates in rural parts of Texas -- students who also tend not to do well on the S.A.T. and so had been refused admission to the most competitive public colleges under the old system.
No wonder a number of moderate white legislators joined the coalition in supporting the plan. As State Representative Irma Rangel pointed out, the 10 percent plan treats all groups equally, giving them "the respect they deserve." Similarly, when Gov. George Bush, a Republican, signed the bill, he declared, "We want all our students in Texas to have a fair shot at achieving their dreams, and this legislation gives them that fair shot."
Texas officials recognize that there is more to be done beyond rethinking college admissions policy. They have also formulated new ideas for improving primary schools. Schools and districts are now required to report test scores, attendance and dropout rates by race, ethnicity and economic standing. Each school is then rated according to the performance of the various ethnic and economic groups. This means more attention is paid to every student, and the entire class benefits.
As a result, black, Hispanic and economically disadvantaged students are closing the achievement gap. On a national math test given in 1996, Texas fourth graders in various categories -- white, black and poor students -- all ranked first in the country. By contrast, California, where politicians have demonized issues of race, education and immigration, saw its fourth graders, including white students, finish near the bottom, ahead of those in only two other states.
Texas's innovative approaches, and its less polarized environment, are helping to shift an increasingly narrow debate over affirmative action into a wider public discussion on education. This also sends the message that access and diversity are not the enemy of excellence.

HEADLINE: Americans, Flouting U.N. Embargo, Organize Relief for Iraqis

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, April 22

 BODY:
Little by little, in small efforts linked by new networks, Americans are beginning to react against a policy of continued sanctions against Iraq by organizing their own relief projects for the Iraqi people.
Today, Americares, a private relief organization based in New Canaan, Conn., announced the largest mission to date. Over three days next week, with the help of the Royal Jordanian Air Force, the organization says it will carry out the first American airlift of more than 75,000 pounds of medicines and hospital supplies to Baghdad, where nearly eight years of sanctions have crippled the civilian medical system. 
 Guy L. Smith 4th, a vice chairman of Americares, said at a news conference this morning that it was purely coincidental that the American goods would begin arriving in Iraq on Monday, just as the Security Council prepares to renew the sanctions for another six months. "Americares goes where there is a need, irrespective of race, creed or political persuasion," he said.
Other organizations are giving a more political slant to their activities, withholding any criticism of Iraqi policy while condemning the United States and the United Nations for continuing to impose a tough embargo on Iraq. The sanctions have been in place since Saddam Hussein invaded Kuwait in August 1990.
Voices in the Wilderness, a Chicago-based organization that has been sending groups to Iraq with some medical and other supplies permitted under Security Council regulations, organized days of protests earlier this year outside the Baghdad headquarters of the United Nations team charged with destroying Iraq's major weapons systems. The sanctions cannot be lifted until the commission declares Iraq free of prohibited arms.
In New York, a coalition called the Iraq Sanctions Challenge is being formed by Ramsey Clark, United States Attorney General in the Johnson Administration. The coalition intends to defy American policy wherever it can on this issue. It also plans to send volunteers and medical supplies to Iraq and to stage a week of protests in the United States from May 6 to 13.
"In the spirit of the civil rights movement, we refuse to abide by unjust U.S. laws or U.N. resolutions that result in death and destruction for Iraqi children, women and men," says a flyer being circulated to potential coalition members around the United States. It alleges that more than 1.5 million people have been killed by the sanctions.
The Iraq Sanctions Challenge has attracted the support of groups like Pastors for Peace, the Middle East Children's Alliance and the Bruderhof, a communal movement in New York, Pennsylvania and England, which has produced a graphic videotape of dying children in Iraq, asserting that they were killed by sanctions, which they label as "genocide." The video juxtaposes shots of Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, speaking in another context, calling the sanctions policy "worth the price."
Absent from virtually all of the calls for action circulating in the United States is any blame for President Hussein, who chose for more than five years not to buy medicine or food through the controlled sale of oil, which he was permitted to do by the Security Council. No mention is made of his marble-lined palaces, stables full of luxury cars, or of the human-rights record of the Iraqi Government, which a United Nations monitor recently reported had executed at least 1,500 people over the last year for political reasons.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place -- Tightening the Faucet;
How U.S. Filter Is Consolidating the Waterworks

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: PALM DESERT, Calif.

 BODY:
Richard J. Heckmann knows the value of water. And it is not just because he lives here in the desert.
In a few short years, Mr. Heckmann has created the nation's largest water-related company, the United States Filter Corporation. Through more than 130 acquisitions, U.S. Filter has soared from $20 million in revenues in 1990 to a projected $5 billion in the coming year, making it more than 10 times the size of its nearest competitor. 
 In doing so, Mr. Heckmann, a former stockbroker who is so glib he could sell water to a fish, has set off a consolidation trend in the sleepy and highly localized water business and brought it to Wall Street's attention.
"How could it be that there is no Intel, I.B.M., General Motors or Toys 'R' Us in the water business?" he asked. "You can live without all those things. Five days without water you're dead."
Since early 1997, U.S. Filter has made more than 75 acquisitions, culminating in February with its agreement to pay $1.5 billion in stock for Culligan Water Technologies, a leader in residential water treatment devices and bottled water. That deal will bring Mr. Heckmann close to his goal of creating a one-stop shop, with everything from bottled water to filters, valves and pipes.
U.S. Filter is also building and running complete water and waste-water treatment plants to take advantage of one of the big trends of the business -- outsourcing. Companies like Dow Chemical and the chip maker LSI Logic, which once ran their own water treatment systems, are entrusting that job at some of their factories to U.S. Filter and paying by the gallon for water of a specified purity. And municipalities like Atlanta, Milwaukee and Buffalo are turning over water treatment to private companies to preserve capital and cut costs.
Many have been won over by Mr. Heckmann's vision. But others view him as the Pied Piper of the water business rather than its Moses, as someone much better at hawking his own company's stock than at selling reverse osmosis equipment.
But the skeptics also say that U.S. Filter has assembled a grab-bag of companies, some not very good ones and some for which it overpaid. It has yet to prove, they say, that it can run them as a cohesive business and earn back the cost of capital it took to buy them. "They're huge, and it's happened in a very short period," said Norm Miranda, president of Americas' Water Service in Naperville, Ill., who left a previous company after U.S. Filter acquired it. "It's kind of wait and see to see how all the pieces come together."
Once the acquisitions slow or stop, U.S. Filter will have to depend on internal growth, and the fundamentals of its business -- now obscured by the acquisitions -- will come into clearer view. And that, detractors predict, is when the house of cards could come crashing down.
Mr. Heckmann and some of his executives have leather-bound copies of a book about Waste Management Inc., a role model for U.S. Filter. But Waste Management ran into problems when it ran out of acquisitions in the solid waste business. Another risk of rapid acquisitions was experienced last week by the Cendant Corporation, which saw its stock lose nearly half its value after accounting irregularities appeared in a company it had acquired.
The day of reckoning, if it is to come, is probably not far away, since U.S. Filter is getting so big it will be harder to grow by acquisitions. And investors are becoming wary of the former Wall Street darling. U.S. Filter's stock rose from pennies a share in 1990 to more than $30 in 1996, despite the dilution from all the mergers, allowing the company to pay for its acquisitions in stock rather than cash. But the stock price has been stagnant for the last year and a half. It closed at $34.4375 on Wednesday, up 68.75 cents, putting the stock at about 22 times earnings, about the same as the broad market.
Supporters say Mr. Heckmann has defied skeptics so far and should continue to do so. "When I first heard him speak in 1992, he said by 1996 he'd have a billion in revenues," said Rod Lache, an analyst at Deutsche Morgan Grenfell. "When you hear a $40 million company say something like that, you take a skeptical eye." But Mr. Heckmann achieved his plan. "He's a visionary," Mr. Lache said.
Mr. Heckmann, 54, studied politics at the University of Hawaii and founded the Tower Scientific Corporation, a manufacturer of prosthetic devices, which he sold in 1977, giving him financial security.
Although he is a Republican -- former Vice President Dan Quayle and the former Reagan economic adviser Arthur B. Laffer sit on U.S. Filter's board -- Mr. Heckmann served two years as an official in the Small Business Administration under President Jimmy Carter.
After leaving Washington, he was elected mayor of Sun Valley, Idaho, but quit because of conflict of interest accusations about his ownership of the city's taxi service and a hotel.
In 1982 he moved to the Palm Springs area and became a stockbroker. In 1988, he saw a business plan for American Toxxic Control, a company that wanted to consolidate the water treatment business. Mr. Heckmann bought stock at $2.50 a share that promptly fell to about a penny. Still intrigued with the concept, Mr. Heckmann put together an investment group that bought the company for $1.6 million and renamed it U.S. Filter.
What attracted him to the business? The world's supply of water is fixed, Mr. Heckmann explains, yet demand keeps growing as population and economic activity increase. That means higher prices for water and more spending on treatment.
The Environmental Protection Agency has estimated that American communities will have to spend about $140 billion the next 20 years to upgrade the systems that supply drinking water. And, Mr. Heckmann said, 56 percent of Americans now drink contaminated water, according to the E.P.A. The fast growth of bottled water shows consumers will pay dearly for clean water. "Evian costs $350 a barrel," Mr. Heckmann said. "Oil is only $16 a barrel."
Industries like microelectronics and pharmaceuticals need ever-purer water to make increasingly sophisticated products. And there is a potentially big market in developing areas that need water and sewage systems. Globally, he said, water is a $300 billion business growing to $500 billion by the turn of the century.
But Mr. Heckmann is prone to exaggeration. He contends he was a founder of Callaway Golf, famous for Big Bertha clubs, but was actually an early investor after the company had been running for two years. The E.P.A. says it believes only 19 percent of Americans, not 56 percent, drink water from systems that have violated a standard.
And there are obstacles to Mr. Heckmann's ambitions. The water business "never turned out to be the really dynamic story that people have touted intermittently over the years," said Walter Morris, an analyst at Robert W. Baird & Company in Milwaukee, who has followed the business for 25 years.
Despite its size, U.S. Filter does face some well-heeled competition. According to Public Works Financing, a newsletter, U.S. Filter is No. 3 in the outsourcing of municipal water and waste-water treatment behind Professional Services Group Inc. of Houston and United Water Resources Inc. of Harrington Park, N.J., both of which are backed by huge French conglomerates.
The tangled politics of water can also interfere with business. Last year, U.S. Filter paid the Bass brothers $250 million in stock to buy land, mainly 45,000 acres of farmland in the Imperial Valley in the southeast corner of California. The deal made the Texas billionaires major shareholders of U.S. Filter, with a stake now of 8 percent. The land comes with valuable water rights. "This is the Saudi Arabia of water," Mr. Heckmann said. So Mr. Heckmann plans to save irrigation water, by conservation and recycling, and sell it to San Diego. Other water districts object to the plan, and the issue has become a political minefield.
The biggest question about U.S. Filter, though, is whether it can run the business as well as it built it. Its headquarters has fewer than 50 people, remarkably small for a $5 billion company. Mr. Heckmann leaves detailed operations to a cadre of lieutenants, most of whom have been with him for years and have become rich from their stock. They seem to idolize their boss but also fear him because he can lose his temper with people who disagree with him.
For water business expertise, U.S. Filter relies on managers of the acquired companies and induces them to stay by giving them U.S. Filter stock, too. The company prides itself on this decentralized approach, but it may also interfere with achieving synergies. To unify the disparate cultures, U.S. Filter has hired Lou Holtz, former football coach at Notre Dame, to travel to its more than 600 sites and give pep talks.
Mr. Heckmann insists the company, excluding acquisitions, is growing 10 percent a year. As an example of synergy, U.S. Filter cites its 1996 acquisition of WTS, a company with about $5 million in sales. By pushing WTS's products through U.S. Filter's big distribution network, WTS sales tripled by the end of its first year.
And Mr. Heckmann said U.S. Filter was still so small compared with the overall water industry that it could keep making acquisitions. But it is becoming harder to find companies big enough to make much of a difference. The largest publicly traded American water treatment equipment manufacturer, for example, is Ionics Inc. of Watertown, Mass., with sales of about $350 million and growth of about 17 percent a year.
Other public companies with revenues over $150 million are Osmonics, CUNO and Calgon Carbon. The Pall Corporation and Millipore are bigger than Ionics but are involved in filtration for other industries.
Potential targets might also become less willing to accept stock. Memtec, a membrane manufacturer in Australia, resisted U.S. Filter's stock offer last year, forcing the company to pay $400 million in cash in a hostile takeover. U.S. Filter took a big write-off of $440 million related to that and other acquisitions, producing a loss of $374 million for the quarter ended Dec. 31.
Mr. Heckmann knows the risk of not growing. "These roll-up strategies," he said, "run into trouble when they run out of things to roll up."

HEADLINE: Red Army Faction Disbands, Saying Its Cause Is 'Now History'

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: BONN, April 22

 BODY:
Heroes unto themselves, but reviled and once feared by the bulk of Germans, the last remaining urban guerrillas of the Red Army Faction announced this week that they had dissolved their organization because they and their cause were "now history."
A statement sent anonymously to Reuters on Monday confirmed what investigators had long believed -- that the organization, which drew strength from cold-war ideology and an international terror network stretching to the Middle East, was effectively defunct. 
 But the statement, which German authorities have since said was authentic, raised many troubling issues ranging from a slew of unsolved killings to the question of whether tough anti-terror legislation drawn up in the 1970's and 1980's should now be struck from the law books.
At the height of its notoriety in the 1970's, the Red Army Faction was seen as Europe's most deadly urban terror group, built on clandestine cells and fighting what it termed an armed struggle. It attacked not just Germany's rich and powerful, but also United States military installations that left-wing ideology termed emblems of American imperialism.
The group grew from Europe's dissent in the 1960's against the Vietnam War. But, specifically in Germany, its often middle-class members were seen as emblems of a new generation's revolt against a West German state that they characterized as Nazism's linear successor.
In the eight-page typewritten statement delivered to Reuters, which ended with the guerrillas' emblem of a five-pointed star, a stylized machine-pistol and the letters RAF, the authors said: "Today we are ending this project. The urban guerrilla group in the form of the RAF is now history."
"We are stuck in a dead end," the statement said, acknowledging that the group had made strategic errors, but expressing no contrition or regret toward the more than 30 people who died as its victims. Officials at the Federal Criminal Office in Wiesbaden said the document had been certified as genuine.
The last terror act ascribed to the Red Army Faction was in 1991 when Detlef Rohwedder, the head of the Treuhand privatization agency, was killed -- a crime that remains unsolved. In 1992, the organization formally abandoned acts against "leading representatives of the economy and state."
Such quiescence contrasted strongly with the way in which the group held the land in thrall in the 1970's, when terrorism flourished not just in Germany but also in Italy and in many parts of the Middle East.
In Germany, "wanted" posters adorned public buildings, and anyone who might be a target took to bullet-proof cars and bodyguards. Not only that, liberal principles in postwar German law were upended in legislation that stripped terrorism suspects of access to defense lawyers and enforced their separation in prison. Those laws are still on the books and government officials have rejected opposition demands for their repeal, maintaining they are still needed to fight organized crime.
Five fatal attacks ascribed to the Red Army Faction dating from 1985 remain unsolved. And while some members of the group now live ostensibly normal lives, have died or are among the nine terrorists still serving prison terms, its actual membership is believed by investigators to be no more than 10 people.
"With this statement, the Red Army Faction has put up its own tombstone," said Horst Herold, a former leading investigator.

HEADLINE: Similar Styles May Thwart a Deal

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Thomas A. Renyi and Frank V. Cahouet, the executives who respectively run the Bank of New York Company and the Mellon Bank Corporation, are both considered tough, focused and cost-conscious individuals who have strong ideas about how to manage their organizations.
The strength of their convictions may be what thwarts the completion of a merger the two institutions have discussed for years. 
 "They are both hard-headed guys," said Lawrence W. Cohn, director of research at Ryan, Beck & Company, a securities firm. "They are so similar that they are either going to love each other or hate each other."
Since Mr. Cahouet and Mellon's board of directors rejected Bank of New York's $90-a-share merger proposal yesterday and said the bank intended to remain independent, it seems the Pittsburgh-based banking institution has no desire to find out.
In truth, however, if Mellon's large base of institutional shareholders pressures the board to consider the offer, Mr. Cahouet and Mr. Renyi would coexist at the top of the merged Mellon Bank of New York Corporation for only a short time.
Under terms of the Bank of New York's proposal, Mr. Cahouet, 66, would serve as chairman of the merged bank, which would have more than $100 billion in assets, making it one of the 10 biggest banks in the country. Mr. Renyi, 52, would be chief executive.
But Mr. Cahouet, who came to Mellon in 1987, is scheduled to retire at the end of the year.
By contrast, Mr. Renyi took over as chairman at Bank of New York in early February, when J. Carter Bacot, the bank's strong-willed chairman and chief executive, retired after serving for 16 years.
Succession issues are no stranger to Mellon and Mr. Cahouet. Earlier discussions with Bank of New York, and with Corestates Financial, which Mellon tried to buy last year, foundered on what role Mr. Cahouet would play in the merged company.
Those failures did not sit well with shareholders, who in the past have criticized Mr. Cahouet for doing more to protect his own position than enhancing shareholder value.
Analysts said that in spite of his agreement to leave, Mr. Cahouet may also be blocking this offer.
"My belief is the sticking point on this is that Frank Cahouet wants to be chairman for as long as he wants," said one analyst, who spoke on condition that he not be identified.
During his tenure at Mellon, Mr. Cahouet has not only pulled the company back from the severe financial crisis it had been facing when he arrived, but also transformed it.
In 1992, after spending almost five years wading through bad energy and real estate loans, Mellon began to shift away from traditional banking and toward asset management with the purchase of the Boston Company.
That deal was followed in 1994 by the purchase of the Dreyfus Corporation.
Before coming to Mellon, Mr. Cahouet spent nine months in Washington as president and chief operating officer of the Federal National Mortgage Association. From 1984 to 1986, he was president and chief executive of Crocker National Bank. And prior to joining Crocker, Mr. Cahouet was vice chairman and chief financial officer at Security Pacific National Bank, which he joined in 1960.
Mr. Renyi, by comparison, has spent his entire banking life at the Bank of New York, which he joined as a trainee in 1971.
Over the last two decades Bank of New York, unlike Mellon, has been relatively trouble-free and regarded by Wall Street analysts as one of the country's best-managed financial institutions.
"They have a day-to-day focus on expense management and business management," said David S. Berry, director of research at Keefe Bruyette & Woods, the bank research firm.
Bank of New York temporarily misplaced that focus in the late 1980's, during its protracted but successful hostile takeover battle for the Irving Trust Company.
In 1989 Mr. Bacot had put Mr. Renyi in charge of the transition team responsible for merging the two companies because of his broad knowledge of the bank and its operations.
"He knows the nuts and bolts," said Diane Glossman, an analyst at Lehman Brothers. "And he is at least as careful with his pennies as Carter was."
The deal was a strategic coup for Mr. Bacot and Bank of New York. But analysts said the experience left scars, and may be a big reason Mr. Renyi said he would withdraw his offer if a friendly merger with Mellon was not possible.
"In the past I have spoken with Carter, but not Tom, about the impact of doing unfriendly transactions," said Mr. Cohn from Ryan, Beck. "The Irving deal distracted the entire organization for the better part of two years, and management feels they lost a lot of opportunities because they were so focused on getting the deal done."
Mr. Renyi may be counting on Mellon shareholders.
"The Mellon shareholder list is dominated by institutions," Mr. Cohn said. "There will be a lot of pressure brought to bear" on Mellon's board.

HEADLINE: A Gush of Profits From Water Sale?

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
While Warren E. Buffett, America's second-richest man, is taking a well-publicized flier in silver, the Bass brothers of Texas are betting on a humbler commodity: water.
This latest investment by the Basses -- billionaires many times over by virtue of their investments in oil, real estate and the Walt Disney Company -- has been very good to them indeed. 
 Last year, Edward P. and Lee M. Bass traded a three-year-old, $60 million investment in rights to irrigation water largely in the Imperial Valley in California for $250 million worth of stock in the United States Filter Corporation, the world's largest seller of water treatment equipment. Teamed with U.S. Filter, they are leading an effort to sell water now set aside for farming to the parched San Diego area.
The very idea of marketing nature's bounty to the highest bidders raises hackles in the American West, where subsidized water has made the desert bloom with crops, cities rise from bare ground and the economy barrel ahead. And the tentative agreement has reignited a political firestorm.
But advocates say water sales are inevitable.
"Private property owners already provide timber, oil and food," said Ardon Moore, who manages the Bass interests in the Imperial Valley, the Western Farms and Cattle Company. "We didn't invent free markets in water, but we certainly support them."
The deal, which would move enough water to support two million suburbanites, is being cheered on by an unusual coalition of businesses and environmentalists, who view water efficiency as a key to eco-friendly growth in California.
"This is the win-win model we've been waiting for," said Tom Graff, a lawyer for the Environmental Defense Fund. "Voluntary, large-scale water transfers that make everyone better off."
Some of the water that has permitted the rapid urbanization of semi-arid Southern California since the 1940's comes from elsewhere in the state. In fact, Los Angeles's capture of the water from the Owens River hundreds of miles away was the theme of the movie "Chinatown." But the region's real lifeline is the Colorado River.
Under a 76-year-old pact, California is entitled to a minimum of 4.4 million acre-feet of Colorado River water annually (the amount that would cover 4.4 million acres, a foot deep). And since no one else is using the surplus flow, the state routinely takes 5.3 million acre-feet -- enough to supply triple the current needs of Southern Californians.
Of the guaranteed 4.4 million acre-feet, however, just 550,000 are set aside to fill bathtubs and swimming pools in the great suburban sprawl. The rest goes to irrigate farmland in the southeast corner of the state. In the Imperial Valley, by far the largest of the three irrigation districts in the area, farmers grow two and three crops a year in the rich desert soil to yield $1 billion worth of fruit, vegetables, and livestock.
But new supplies of water in Southern California are increasingly problematic. And the state cannot count on the amount of water it now takes from the Colorado River: Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt has put it on notice that as demand for water grows in neighboring states, California will be cut back to its guaranteed 4.4 million acre-feet. San Diego, in particular, is imperiled because Los Angeles has first claim to most of the water from Northern California.
That's why California farmers have been under pressure to conserve water. It's also why the Imperial Irrigation District agreed in 1988 to give 100,000 acre-feet annually to Southern California's Metropolitan Water District in return for $130 million to patch up canals that were leaking at least that much water into the desert. The "Met," which supplies water to some 16 million people, also paid the Palo Verde Irrigation District to let 20,000 acres of farmland sit fallow in 1993 and 1994 and divert the conserved water to the Met's reservoirs. But further initiatives to transfer Colorado River water from farm to city have stalled.
One reason is that the Met has taken a hard line on financial incentives. "Why should farmers profit from reducing the amount of water they waste?" asked John R. Wodraska, general manager of the Metropolitan Water District.
Another reason is that the administrators of the Imperial Irrigation District, who are elected, fear a loss of local jobs and income if less water is available for agriculture. "The valley is already coping with 25 percent unemployment," noted Mayer Malone, editor of The Imperial Valley Press. "What's going to happen if land is fallowed in order to sell the water?"
A study this year by the David Dornbusch consulting firm and commissioned by the irrigation district found that farmers would probably adjust by growing less-thirsty crops and using other conservation techniques that would increase employment. But in the face of local opposition, few landowners were prepared to stick their necks out in support of water sales until the Bass brothers bought 45,000 acres of farmland in the valley.
The theoretical case for selling some of the irrigation water is impressive. Farmers in the Imperial Valley pay $13.50 an acre-foot for water and, on average, use six acre-feet for every acre of land they cultivate. By contrast, customers of the Met pay at least $350 an acre-foot. If farmers could sell their water at that price, they could net about $2,000 an acre -- a spectacular, risk-free return on land that sells for less than $4,000 an acre.
More modest proposals still show a lucrative business. If the farmers in the Imperial Valley and the other two irrigation districts dependent on the Colorado River sold just 10 percent of the 3.85 million acre-feet of water at the $350 price, they would net about $130 million a year.
With such figures no doubt in mind, the Bass brothers pressed the irrigation district to negotiate a deal with San Diego, under which the district would transfer 200,000 acre-feet annually for a starting price of $250 an acre-foot. They then hedged their bets by exchanging their 45,000 acres -- nearly one-tenth of the valley land under cultivation -- for an 8 percent stake in U.S. Filter and a seat on the company's board.
U.S. Filter paid a premium for the land, but it incurred no debt in the transaction and stands to earn a big bonus on ancillary businesses.
Rod Lache, a securities analyst for Deutsche Morgan Grenfell, suggests that executives at U.S. Filter have grand goals. "They expect to bundle the whole package for municipalities -- the water treatment equipment, the maintenance and even the water itself," he said. The ability to offer "one-stop shopping" he added, should give the company a big edge in finding customers in other water-scarce countries, where the recycling of waste-water from agriculture seems the only viable option for meeting urban demand.
A major issue, though, highlights the difficulty of creating a market for water. The old agreements setting aside 3.85 million acre-feet to the Imperial, Palo Verde and Coachella Valley irrigation districts did not specify how the water was to be divided among the three. Coachella argues that it, not San Diego, has the right to any water conserved by Imperial.
California must decide who owns what before the U.S. Filter -- or any other -- water sale goes through, and Mr. Graff of the Environmental Defense Fund wonders whether politicians are up to the challenge. "The biggest problem in creating water markets has been the lack of state and Federal leadership," he said.
Richard J. Heckmann, chairman and chief executive of U.S. Filter, is confident that stagnant supplies and rising demand for water will shift the politics decisively in favor of urban consumers. "The day Sacramento is forced to tell people they can't water their lawns," he predicted, "is the day it will all be over."

HEADLINE: U.S. Revoking Licenses to Export Firearms to Britain

BYLINE: By RAYMOND BONNER 

DATELINE: VIENNA, April 22

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration notified the British Government today that it was revoking all pending licenses for the export of American firearms to British companies, American officials said.
The revocation is the first step, the officials said, in a plan to halt the sale of firearms by American companies to all 15 members of the European Union. Licenses to export firearms will not be issued for European Union countries until the Governments have adopted laws to guarantee that the weapons are not re-exported "to the bad guys," as one senior official in Washington put it. 
 In recent years, American firearms sold to European companies have ended up in the hands of terrorists and organized criminal gangs and in war zones like the former Yugoslavia, Turkey and Central Africa, according to American and European law-enforcement officials.
The Administration's actions in Europe are part of a broader, and growing, concern about the easy movement across borders of light weapons, which include handguns, automatic rifles, grenade launchers and hand-held missile launchers.
Here in Vienna this week, delegates to the annual meeting of the United Nations Commission on Crime Prevention and Criminal Justice are expected to call for a binding international instrument to curb weapons trafficking.
The Clinton Administration is fully backing the effort, American officials at the meeting said. And next month, the major industrial powers, the so-called Group of 7, plus Russia, are expected to adopt regulations on exporting and importing firearms, American officials said today.
American officials said the controls, pushed by Washington, have been agreed to by working-level officials from those countries, leaving only the heads of state to endorse them officially at their meeting in Birmingham, England. Although the regulations would restrict just eight countries, they include the five largest arms-producing nations, which account for 90 percent of weapons exports.
Action by those industrialized countries is therefore seen as a major breakthrough in a campaign to curb the trade in so-called small arms and light weapons.
"It would be a political commitment from influential states that indicates a significant groundswell of support in favor of a multilateral light-weapons-control regime," said Geraldine O'Callaghan, an arms-trade expert at the British American Security Information Council, a nongovernmental agency in London.
While the Clinton Administration's principal concern is to keep handguns out of the hands of criminals and drug dealers, organizations like Ms. O'Callaghan's and the United Nations are concerned about all light weapons, which they want to keep out of war zones.
Most victims of small arms are not the soldiers who carry them, but women and children.
For the Clinton Administration, and many countries, the model for international regulation is a treaty signed in November by the United States and other members of the Organization of American States.
Among other items, the treaty requires that before a country issues an export license, the importing country has to approve formally the movement. The treaty also requires that the importing country mark the weapons.
"This establishes an international system for tracing that does not exist today," said Jonathan Winer, Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for Narcotics and Law Enforcement. "It means that when weapons get diverted, and inevitably some do, they can be traced back to the last seller."
It is the lack of such measures, and the consequent lack of control over weapons after they have left the United States, that has led Washington to revoke export licenses.
When asked about the Clinton Administration's action, Andrew Molchan, president of the National Association of Federally Licensed Firearms Dealers, said, "It is the traditional attack on the Second Amendment gone international."
In a telephone interview from the headquarters of the association in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., Mr. Molchan said that "as far as worldwide crime and international terrorism, the impact is going to be none at all," because many guns are available in other countries.
In Britain, a nongovernmental relief organization, Oxfam, applauded the United States move and said British controls over small-arms exports were too lax. In a report to be released on Thursday, "Small Arms, Wrong Hands," the organization said that British companies had sold small arms in more than 100 countries. Twenty-seven countries were in Africa, mostly suffering from political violence or open warfare, Oxfam said.
American officials say they believe that many of the weapons first came from the United States. In 1996, the State Department issued licenses to export to European Union countries nearly 140,000 handguns and slightly more than 100,000 rifles, according to the latest report by the Office of Defense Trade Controls.
Washington has acted first against Britain, not necessarily because it was guilty of the most serious abuses, American officials said, but because the problem there was presented in the starkest terms.
On March 1, one of the strictest handgun-control laws in the world went into effect in Britain. As a result, American officials realized that weapons sold to British companies were almost certainly not going to remain there.
Germany is most likely the next target of Administration action, a senior State Department official said. The State Department issued licenses for the export of 68,000 rifles to Germany in 1966, putting it far above any other European Union country, according to the State Department report. Licenses were also issued for 32,000 pistols and 89 million cartridges.
Most of the weapons bought by German companies do not enter Germany, except for the ports, where they are loaded onto another ship for another destination, American officials said. Germany has also been a transit point for weapons smuggled into the former Yugoslavia and Turkey.
The Clinton Administration is also looking closely at France, where there are 22,000 valid unfilled licenses, and Italy, where there are 18,000.

HEADLINE: With Orders Slowing, Chip Maker Will Cut Jobs

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, April 22

 BODY:
Facing a slowdown in chip orders, the National Semiconductor Corporation said today that it would cut 1,400 jobs worldwide, or about 10 percent of its employees, through a combination of layoffs and attrition.
National said the cuts would center primarily on the company's headquarters in Santa Clara, Calif., and would include 560 employees affected by the previously announced closings of some older manufacturing operations. National said recent softness in the worldwide semiconductor market, with a corresponding decrease in orders for new chips, made it necessary to cut costs beyond what could be achieved through closing the older plants. 
 The cuts will result in a one-time charge of $60 million to $70 million before taxes, equivalent to 27 to 32 cents a share in after-tax earnings, in the fourth fiscal quarter, ending May 31. On March 12, National reported a decline in third-quarter revenue and earnings, and said it anticipated a loss in the fourth quarter.
National shares closed at $24.1875, up 62.5 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.
The announcement comes about a week after the world's largest chip maker, the Intel Corporation, said it would cut about 3,000 jobs, amid a buildup in inventories in the distribution channel for personal computers.
National has struggled in recent quarters, in part because the Asian economic crisis has sharply curtailed sales of some key products, and partly because of manufacturing problems at the Cyrix Corporation, which National acquired last year for about $550 million. Cyrix's partner in a manufacturing venture, the International Business Machines Corporation, has not been able to meet demand for higher-speed versions of microprocessors. But National said last month that it had begun its own production of these products at a plant in Portland, Me.
Last quarter's shortfall was the first sign that National may have trouble executing the strategy articulated by Brian L. Halla, the company's chairman and chief executive, of moving from high-volume, low-priced commodity chips to more specialized products that generate higher profit margins. Since Mr. Halla joined the company in May 1996, National has steadily improved its earnings and profit margins. As part of his strategy of creating new markets, National recently announced that it would develop a single-chip PC by mid-1999.
Jonathan Joseph, an analyst with Nationsbanc Montgomery Securities, said that while pursuing this strategy, National had lost market share and sales in its core businesses of making chips for computer networking devices and analog chips for cellular telephones. "One has to wonder if they have disaffected their cash cow," he said.

HEADLINE: Bank of New York Bids $23.7 Billion for Mellon

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY L. O'BRIEN and LAURA M. HOLSON 

 BODY:
The Bank of New York Company, moving to stay near the top of the heap in the rapidly consolidating banking industry, announced an unsolicited $23.7 billion takeover offer yesterday for the Mellon Bank Corporation of Pittsburgh.
But Mellon spurned the offer, setting up the possibility that Bank of New York may mount a hostile takeover for Mellon -- a highly unusual step in the banking industry and a signal that the huge mergers that are transforming the nation's financial landscape threaten to get nasty. 
 Hostile takeovers, which require a bidder to convince a target company's board and big shareholders that an acquisition makes financial and strategic sense, are difficult to complete in any industry. They are even harder to do in banking because regulators are loath to approve deals that may disrupt the vital economic role banks play in communities where they operate.
A hostile bid by Bank of New York would be further complicated by the fact that Mellon is based in Pennsylvania, which has some of the country's toughest anti-takeover laws, and is headed by Frank V. Cahouet, a chief executive whose unwillingness to let go of the company's reins has scuttled previous merger talks.
Even so, the possibility that Bank of New York and Mellon may begin trading corporate America's version of jabs, punches or body blows to achieve their separate visions for the future is yet another vivid illustration of how determined some banks are to survive consolidation.
Over the last two and a half weeks, agreements to pursue the three largest mergers in United States banking history have occurred. A merger agreement between Bank of New York and Mellon would be the fourth largest. The breathtaking speed and size of these transactions are a testament to the importance of scale in an industry choked by more nimble nonbank competitors and left reeling by seismic shifts in how corporations and consumers manage their finances.
Bank of New York, the 18th-largest bank in the country, is betting that a combination with Mellon, the 23d largest, would assure its pre-eminence. The combined bank would rank 8th if all pending mergers were completed.
Analysts said a combination of Bank of New York and Mellon made great sense. It would give the new bank strong positions in asset management, securities processing and mutual funds and would expand the banks' respective branch networks.
Thomas A. Renyi, Bank of New York's chief executive, said he had no intention of pursuing a takeover of Mellon on anything other than a "consensual basis." Nonetheless, Mr. Renyi said he was undeterred by Mellon's clear rejection of a takeover.
"I don't necessarily accept Frank's reaction as the final word," Mr. Renyi said. "We have every intention of trying to make everyone aware of how compelling this story is."
Mr. Renyi said that he had called Mr. Cahouet on Monday to outline the takeover offer but that Mr. Cahouet had declined to meet with him. The two banks, both known for their stubbornness and determination to chart their own courses, have had merger discussions over the last several years. Merger talks between the banks ended last December after disagreements over the roles to be played by Mellon executives in a merged company.
"As a result of our discussions with Bank of New York last year, we are firmly convinced that any combination of the two organizations would be contrary to the best interests of our shareholders, employees, customers and -- in particular -- the communities we serve," Mr. Cahouet said in a news release responding to the takeover bid.
By making the takeover offer public, Bank of New York is letting analysts, investors and the media know why it thinks its bid makes business sense. Moreover, it is publicizing how much money it is willing to pay.
The bank said it would issue 1.4 shares of its stock, worth about $90, for each Mellon share, a 28 percent premium to Mellon's closing price on Tuesday of $69.75 on the New York Stock Exchange. Mellon's shares shot up $8.125 yesterday, to $78, while Bank of New York's shares fell $1.6875, to $62.0625, also on the Big Board. The fact that Mellon's share price failed to rise to $90 may reflect skepticism in the stock market over whether Bank of New York's bid will be successful.
Mr. Renyi has stopped short of a full-blown hostile bid for Mellon by not placing his bank's offer before Mellon's shareholders and forcing the board to vote on the merger. If he should choose to take that step, the obstacles are formidable.
Only two previous hostile takeovers have been successful in banking, and one of them involved Bank of New York: its 1988 acquisition of the Irving Trust Company. In the other, Wells Fargo & Company of San Francisco acquired the First Interstate Corporation in 1996.
In both cases, the buyers benefited from the weak positions of the targets. Neither Irving nor First Interstate had "poison pill" provisions, which allow a target's shareholders to buy additional stock at a deep discount in the event of a hostile takeover, thus making the cost of a takeover prohibitively expensive. Neither of those banks had staggered terms for their boards, which make a takeover more difficult because it takes longer for an acquirer to gain control of the board. Finally, both of those banks were in the same state as the acquirer, meaning that state regulators were less likely to feel that an outsider was poaching on home turf.
Mellon, in contrast, has a poison pill provision and a staggered board and is in a different state from Bank of New York. Pennsylvania law makes it difficult for outsiders to take over in-state concerns by requiring that the boards of companies based there can weigh factors other than shareholder interests when considering a merger.
"Pennsylvania has the toughest takeover laws in the country," said Lee Meyerson, a lawyer at Simpson Thacher & Bartlett who specializes in banking mergers and acquisitions. "The 'just-say-no' defense is incorporated into their statutes."
Bank of New York was recently thwarted by state regulators elsewhere. Last week, it withdrew an effort to increase its holdings in the State Street Corporation, based in Boston, after regulators in Massachusetts forbade it to do so.
Nonetheless, Bank of New York is attempting to stir up shareholder interest in a merger with Mellon by disclosing its offer publicly.
"This is an attempt to draw a wedge between Cahouet, who just won't leave, and directors who are a little tired of him," said one banking lawyer who is not involved in the transaction. "Mellon shareholders will make it known whether they like this deal. If they have an open insurrection, Mellon will start looking for a white knight."
Bank advisers say it is unlikely that Mellon will find a white knight riding to its rescue from among the nation's largest banks. Mellon could, however, seek to merge with smaller banks like the Fleet Financial Corporation or the BankBoston Corporation. And, of course, Mellon could sit out the merger wave and try to remain independent -- a perilous strategy in today's banking world.
If Bank of New York were to take over Mellon, the new bank would be called the Mellon Bank of New York Company, but Bank of New York would have a majority of seats on the board. Mr. Renyi proposed a dual headquarters in Pittsburgh and New York, with Mr. Cahouet as chairman until the end of the year, when he plans to retire, and Mr. Renyi as chief executive. Mr. Renyi would assume the chairman's title upon Mr. Cahouet's retirement.
Despite the hurdles facing the Bank of New York, some investors lauded the proposal. Brian Rogers, a fund manager with T. Rowe Price Associates Inc., which owned 6.7 million Mellon shares as of the end of last year, has already expressed his approval to both banks.
"Our basic position is the Mellon side can't dismiss this out of hand," Mr. Rogers said. "Our message is the Mellon directors have some responsibility to consider this."
But Ray Garea, a fund manager who works with the investor Michael Price, a catalyst in other big bank mergers, expressed skepticism that Bank of New York would truly engage Mellon in any kind of battle, hostile or otherwise.
"I don't think this is going to happen," Mr. Garea said. "Mellon isn't interested, and I don't think Bank of New York is really going after them."
