HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Technology Stocks Surge On Run-Up in Microsoft
Technology stocks extended their rally on a correct bet by investors that Microsoft would report better-than-expected earnings after the market closed. Microsoft shares rose 4.2 percent, to a record high, and the Nasdaq index rose 13.74 points, to 1,917.61, its fourth straight record.
Bank shares also strengthened on further speculation about takeovers after the Bank of New York announced an unsolicited offer for Mellon. But the broader market was mixed, and the Dow Jones average fell 8.22 points, to 9,176.72. Page D8. 

Disney Posts Strong Results
Walt Disney reported a 21.5 percent gain in quarterly earnings to $384 million, or 55 cents a share, a surprisingly robust performance that reflected strong theme-park attendance and advertising sales at its ESPN network. It also announced a 3-for-1 stock split, and its shares rose 4.5 percent, to $122. D4.
 
Job Cuts at Chip Maker
National Semiconductor said it would cut 1,400 jobs, or 10 percent of its worldwide work force, through layoffs and attrition. The reduction reflects a slowdown in chip orders. D7.
 
Lucent Earnings Surge
Lucent Technologies, the telecommunications equipment maker, said quarterly earnings more than doubled, excluding a charge. The results exceeded expectations. D4.
 
Boeing's Trouble Persists
Boeing said its earnings plunged 91 percent in the first quarter, falling below analysts' estimates, as the company was unable to benefit from a surge in output of commercial jets. Contributing to the weakness was another big charge related to production problems on the 737 jetliner. D2.
 
Mixed Results for 3 Airlines
UAL, the parent of United Airlines, and US Airways reported earnings that exceeded analysts' estimates. But T.W.A. reported a loss that was slightly greater than estimates. D2.
 
Shake-Up at Warner Studio
Bill Gerber, the joint president of production at Warner Brothers, left his job after a series of high-profile flops, marking another high-level shuffle at a movie studio. D4.
 
Bad Switch Caused AT&T Problem
AT&T said one of its switches caused the April 13 failure of the long-distance company's nationwide network for high-speed data services. The company said it had changed the procedure for upgrading switching software to prevent future breakdowns. D2.
 
Energy Company's Hard Sell
Enron has temporarily stopped trying to sell electricity to residential customers in California, demonstrating the difficulties that many power marketers face in trying to attract business. Fewer than 1 percent of California customers have switched away from local power companies. D3.
 
Hope for an Ailing Economy
The Japanese economy, once the world's 800-pound gorilla, now is more likely to be compared to a beached whale. But many economists think a cure for the cyclic downturn is within reach.
Peter Passell: Economic Scene. D2.
 
I.M.F.'s Enigmatic Shadow
In Asia, the International Monetary Fund is viewed as a mysterious outside force that is suddenly reshaping the lives of millions. But after more than nine months of financial crisis in Asia, there is no consensus on whether the lending agency is friendly or hostile. D3.
 
Italian Financier Vindicated
Italy's high court threw out the conviction of the former chairman of Olivetti, Carlo de Benedetti, in the 1982 collapse of Banco Ambrosiano, one of Italy's biggest corruption scandals. Mr. de Benedetti, who had long denied charges of wrongdoing, faced four and a half years in prison. D3.

HEADLINE: '96 Stadium Study Found Fewer Benefits

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
An unpublished 1996 study found that a West Side stadium for the New York Yankees would generate $102.5 million a year for the city's economy, far less than the $1 billion projected by city officials in a new report.
The March 1996 report by KPMG Peat Marwick, a major accounting firm with a large sports consulting unit, said that a proposed 45,000-seat stadium built over a rail yard near 11th Avenue and 33d Street would generate $102.5 million in spending at the stadium and in neighborhood hotels, bars and restaurants. The report, which was obtained by The New York Times from a planner formerly connected with the city, said that a refurbished stadium at the Yankees' historic home in the Bronx would have an economic impact of $96.4 million a year. 
 But an April 17 report by city planners projected far greater economic benefits from building the proposed stadium on the West Side. The report -- which comes as the Giuliani administration faces increasing pressure from a threat by the Yankees' principal owner, George M. Steinbrenner 3d, to abandon the Bronx -- put the economic impact of a Manhattan stadium at more than $1 billion a year, 10 times the impact of renovating the Bronx stadium. The cost of building the stadium could run as high as $1 billion, according to the city's own study.
That report, cited in an article yesterday in The Times, came under heavy criticism from economists, urban planners and municipal bond analysts and even some real estate developers who said that the analysis went far beyond even the rosy forecasts usually made by team owners and politicians.
"It's utter gibberish," said Andrew Zimbalist, a professor of economics at Smith College in Massachusetts and co-author of "Sports, Jobs and Taxes."
"There has not been an independent study by an economist for any stadium built over the last 30 years that suggests you can anticipate a positive economic impact," he said. "One has to take these claims with a grain of salt. The overwhelming majority of any new revenue generated by a stadium would go to Steinbrenner and the Yankees players."
Team owners and the players benefit from the revenue generated by the luxury boxes, premium seats and other amenities that accompany a new stadium. For the most part, Professor Zimbalist said, new stadiums and sports arenas change how consumers spend money on entertainment, rather than generate new revenue. Most people have a limited budget, he said, and the money they spend on baseball tickets is money they don't spend on theater tickets or movie tickets, or at a bowling alley.
Moreover, he said, stadiums and nearby restaurants and bars generally offer seasonal, low-wage jobs that have little impact on the local economy.
The 249-page report by Peat Marwick was a companion piece to a report by Hellmuth, Obata & Kassabaum, the stadium architects that examined the feasibility of building or renovating a stadium at three sites in the Bronx and one in Manhattan. The entire $600,000 study was paid for by the Yankees, the city and the state. While the city released the Hellmuth assessment study, it never distributed the Peat Marwick report.
Joseph B. Rose, the chairman of the city's Planning Commission, said that the city's draft report in April was based on the report by Peat Marwick. The new analysis, however, also takes into account the effect of building a stadium that would attract local residents and tourists to the area, and of building new transportation links to an area that is several long blocks away from Pennsylvania Station or the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.
A West Side stadium, the latest report says, would foster the development of new restaurants, retail stores, movie theaters, two 600-room hotels and three 200,000-square-foot office buildings in an area now occupied by factories, warehouses and vacant lots. Mr. Rose said he estimated that the West Side had about 18.9 million square feet of space open to development.
"We're assuming a modest 2.25 million square feet of development," Mr. Rose said, "that would result from the stadium being an anchor for new development and the transportation and infrastructure improvements designed to make the stadium work."
Those developments, said Charles Millard, the president of the city's Economic Development Corporation, would parallel what has happened in Times Square, which has been flooded over the past two years with plans for theaters, hotels, theme restaurants and office buildings. "This is less than half of what is happening or slated to happen on 42d Street," Mr. Millard said.
Others were skeptical of any projected benefits. "Generally, stadiums don't spark hotels or office development," said Mark Zandi, the chief economist for Regional Financial Associates, a consulting firm whose clients include banks and real estate developers. "Hotels tend to cluster around convention centers or airports. The economic impact of sports stadiums and arenas ends up being much smaller than originally estimated."
The latest report estimates that a West Side stadium with a grass field would attract 3.9 million people a year to 81 games and 12 concerts or other events, 600,000 more than Peat Marwick estimated. The project would generate $41.7 million annually in taxes and 9,442 jobs, the report says.
The Peat Marwick report, however, said that the stadium would generate 1,600 jobs, while the state and city would reap $5 million in taxes.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A rail yard on either side of 11th Avenue, looking north from West 30th Street, has been proposed as a new home for the New York Yankees. But estimates on the economic benefits of such a stadium vary widely. (Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Texas Business Foundation To Pay for School Vouchers

BYLINE: By CAROL MARIE CROPPER 

DATELINE: DALLAS, April 22

 BODY:
A foundation started by business leaders in San Antonio announced today that it would provide $50 million for a voucher program to allow poor students in one city district to attend private or parochial schools over the next 10 years.
Under the program, any student who qualifies for the Federal lunch program -- 93 percent in the district do -- will be eligible for up to $3,600 a year through eighth grade and up to $4,000 a year in high school to attend a private school within the Edgewood Independent School District, which has 14,000 students. 
 If they choose to attend private school outside the district, beginning in the 1998-1999 school year, the students would receive slightly less money in what would become the nation's largest privately financed school voucher program.
The district, with a largely Hispanic population of about 40,000, includes at least four private schools whose tuition ranges from about $1,000 to $3,000. Although other business leaders around the country have provided the families of poor children with the money to attend private school, the San Antonio effort is the first to provide tuition for an entire district.
The scholarships will "raise the bar for everyone" and, the business leaders hope, will promote economic development in the district, said Robert Aguirre, the managing director of the Children's Educational Opportunity Foundation, which is providing the $50 million and which has been financing some district students since it was founded in 1992 by business leaders who support vouchers as a way to force public schools to improve.
The money is being provided by one of the organization's founders, James Leininger, a doctor who started Kenetic Concepts, a company that makes hospital beds, and by the C.E.O America Foundation, a national umbrella group for local voucher programs.
Fritz Steiger, president of C.E.O. America, which says it has more than 500 corporate and individual contributors across the country, said he expected educational researchers to focus on Edgewood to see the effects of a voucher program.
But opponents like the Texas Federation of Teachers, the teachers' union, said it believed that the vouchers would allow private schools to select the best students.
"It shortens the honor roll," John O'Sullivan, secretary-treasurer of the union told The Associated Press. "One of the strengths of the public school system is is puts everyone together."
Others say the vouchers would drain money from public schools.
"I'm very concerned because it will have a major impact on the district's providing a good education for the entire population that we still have," said Dolores Munoz, superintendent of the Edgewood district.
The district's schools have been improving with changes made in the last five or six years, Dr. Munoz said, adding, "We don't have any low-performing schools."
Last year, of the district's 27 schools, 6 won the Texas Successful Schools award for academic improvement and 2 were recognized for high test scores, said Edna Prez-Vega, a district spokeswoman.
Because of the improvements and parental support, Dr. Munoz predicted that fewer than 500 students would take the scholarships -- a number that she said the system could adjust to. If the departures grow closer to 1,000, she said, it could lead to teacher layoffs and school closings.
Edgewood was not chosen because it was the city's worst school district, Mr. Aguirre said, but because it was small enough to make a concentrated effort where results could be measured but large enough to make a difference.
Clint Bolick, litigation director for the Institute for Justice, a nonprofit organization based in Washington that provides legal assistance to advocates of school vouchers, said opponents would have a tough time challenging the legality of the Edgewood experiment because it is financed with private money.
"Edgewood," Mr. Bolick said, "could be as important for the school choice movement as Little Rock was for the school desegregation movement."

HEADLINE: City Now Puts Budget Surplus At Record High Of $2 Billion

BYLINE: By NORIMITSU ONISHI 

 BODY:
New York will end its fiscal year with a surplus of more than $2 billion, the largest ever recorded by the city and $800 million more than the Giuliani administration predicted just three months ago, officials said yesterday.
Despite the surplus -- largely the result of the continuing boom on Wall Street -- officials said the money would not be used to vastly expand spending in the $34 billion budget that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani will present tomorrow. Joseph J. Lhota, the Mayor's budget director, said that most of the money would be set aside to reduce future budget gaps, with the rest going to spending increases and tax cuts. 
 Among those cuts could be a reduction in the personal income tax, Mr. Lhota said. But he declined to specify how big a cut the Mayor might propose.
The idea was first proposed in January by Peter F. Vallone, the City Council Speaker, and at first Mr. Giuliani strongly rejected it. But since then, the Mayor has expressed a willingness to negotiate the issue with Mr. Vallone. And now Mr. Vallone has an added bit of leverage: he holds what amounts to veto power over the Mayor's plan to use a business tax to help finance a new ballpark for the New York Yankees.
The surplus is the second in a row for New York City; last year's amount was $1.4 billion. In January, when he presented his first draft of next year's budget, Mr. Giuliani had predicted that the surplus for the current fiscal year, which ends June 30, would be $1.2 billion.
But the city government has received unusually strong tax revenues in the last three months, prompting it to re-estimate the size of its surplus.
"Our estimate is that approximately 50 percent of the increase is coming from Wall Street," Mr. Lhota said.
Alan G. Hevesi, the City Comptroller, said that the continuing bull market, large bonuses on Wall Street and the tourist boom could push the projected surplus even higher.
"This is still a conservative number," Mr. Hevesi said of the $2 billion figure. "There's no reason this boom won't be sustained over some period of time."
The Giuliani administration released few details about the final budget that it would propose for the 1999 fiscal year, except to say that the breakdown of the surplus would hew to the plan proposed in January. Back then, Mr. Giuliani said that he wanted to spend the surplus by devoting 8 percent of it to make up for revenues lost to tax cuts; 19 percent for new spending, mostly for educational and anti-drug programs, and 73 percent to close future budget gaps.
Despite the substantial surpluses this year and last, budget gaps are expected to occur because the city's spending is growing faster than its revenues. Budget officials anticipate a $1.5 billion deficit for fiscal year 2000 and a $2.1 billion gap for the following year. The city is legally bound to balance its books every year.
Although most experts praised the spending plan that Mr. Giuliani presented in January, others said that he should have used much more of the surplus to retire some of the city's $30 billion in outstanding debt. (The city will use $50 million of the surplus to do so, Mr. Lhota said.)
Dean Mead, a senior researcher at the Citizens Budget Commission, a nonpartisan watchdog group, said Mr. Giuliani was wasting an opportunity to make a sizable reduction in the outstanding debt. Mr. Mead added that the city is also underestimating the size of future budget gaps, because it is not accounting for wage increases that would be counted in new contracts with city workers in the year 2001.
The draft the Mayor presented in January included spending increases of 3 to 4 percent -- slightly more than the local inflation rate -- and the final proposal is likely to have similar increases.
After the Mayor presents his final plan, it goes to the City Council for approval. Given Mr. Vallone's fiscally conservative record, the Council is not expected to press for spending on new programs, despite the huge surplus. But one likely subject of negotiation is cutting taxes.
In January, Mr. Vallone urged that a 12.5 percent surcharge on the city's personal income tax -- approved in 1990 to help the city balance its books and reauthorized in 1991 to help hire thousands of new police officers -- should be allowed to expire at the end of the year. Linking himself to a tax cut is an important goal for Mr. Vallone, who is seeking the Democratic nomination for Governor.
Mr. Giuliani, who favors eliminating the sales tax on clothes, opposed Mr. Vallone's suggestion; both sides agreed that the city cannot afford to cut both.
Two weeks ago, the State Legislature rejected Mr. Giuliani's request to do away with the clothing tax, instead eliminating it only for clothing items under $110.
Thomas L. McMahon, the Council's finance director, said he believed that the Council had the upper hand now because the Legislature had rejected the Mayor's proposal. "We look forward to negotiating a tax program with the Mayor in the best interest of the city," Mr. McMahon said.
Mr. Lhota said yesterday that on Friday the Mayor "will be presenting a personal income tax reduction as well," but he did not provide specifics.

INTERNATIONAL A3-13
 
U.S. Revokes Licenses To Ship Firearms to Britain
The Clinton Administration acted to revoke all pending licenses for the export of American firearms to British companies, American officials said. Licenses to export firearms will not be issued for Britain and other European Union countries until governments adopt laws to insure that the weapons are not re-exported to terrorists and war zones. A3 

Irish Republic Embraces Deal
The Irish Parliament approved the peace agreement for Northern Ireland reached in Belfast by leaders of the Protestant majority and the Roman Catholic minority. A6
 
Grass Roots Help for Iraqis
Americares, a private relief organization, said it would carry out an airlift of medicine to Baghdad, where nearly eight years of international sanctions have crippled the civilian medical system. It was a further sign that Americans were beginning to react against the policy of continued sanctions by organizing their own relief efforts for the Iraqi people. A13
 
Outcry on Nuclear Waste Plan
Prime Minister Tony Blair defended a decision to store and reprocess nuclear material in Scotland from an old Soviet reactor in Georgia, after he faced an outcry from political opponents, environmental groups and Scottish interests. A6
 
French Right Abstains on Euro
The identity crisis besetting President Jacques Chirac's conservative movement deepened with a decision by his party to abstain from a parliamentary motion of support for French participation in the euro, the common European currency. A8
 
Mexican Lawyer Is Slain
A Mexican lawyer, Tomas Arturo Gonzalez Velazquez, who accused generals and relatives of President Ernesto Zedillo of narcotics graft was shot to death. A6
 
Chernobyl Disease Lingers
Ukrainians have suffered almost four times more radiation-related diseases since the Chernobyl nuclear disaster in 1986, the Health Ministry said. According to the Health Ministry, the death rate in 1997 among those who remained in contaminated zones was 18 percent higher than the national average. A5
 
China-Taiwan Talks
After a nearly three-year freeze in high-level contacts, a negotiator from Taiwan landed in Beijing for talks that could reopen a dialogue between the two governments. Jan Jyh-horng of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation and his Chinese counterpart will discuss an exchange of visits by higher-level officials. (AP)
 
Iranian Cleric Killed in Iraq
A gunman shot dead a 70-year-old Iranian cleric in the Shiite holy city of Najaf in southern Iraq, the official Iraqi News Agency said. "The intelligence service of a foreign nation was behind the incident," the report said, citing a Government statement. The gunman escaped. (Reuters)
 
NATIONAL A14-22
 
House Leadership Relents On Campaign Finance
The House Republican leadership, bowing to pressure from insurgents, reversed itself and agreed to allow a debate and vote on campaign finance laws by late May. A1
 
Doctors and Assisted Suicide
Nearly 1 in 5 doctors who care for seriously ill and dying people reported that they had been asked for assistance in speeding a patient's death. A little more than 3 percent said they had written prescriptions for lethal drugs, mostly to patients who had less than six months to live. Just under 5 percent said they had administered lethal injections to patients on their deathbeds. A1

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
New Office for Sumitomo

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN 

 BODY:
Anticipating an increase in the number of Japanese executives seeking to buy or rent homes in Fairfield County, Conn., Sumitomo Real Estate Sales of New York will open a five-person office in Greenwich on May 1, the company said yesterday.
About 35 percent of the Japanese nationals working in the metropolitan area live in either Fairfield or Westchester County, said Hirofumi Murabayashi, a spokesman for the Consulate General of Japan. Sumitomo also has an office in Scarsdale, employing 12 people. Last year, about 85 percent of its real estate transactions involved Japanese clients, said John J. Gilmore, a spokesman for the real estate company. 
 Sumitomo recently represented Asahi Breweries U.S.A., the Japanese beer company, in negotiations to lease space for an East Coast sales office at 11 Martin Street in White Plains. The office will employ a dozen people, two of them from the company's Milwaukee headquarters.
After declining slightly for several years, the Japanese population in the New York metropolitan region increased 5 percent from 1995 to 1997, the latest year for which figures are available, and is now about 55,000, Mr. Murabayashi said. He said the economic problems in Japan were partly responsible for the rise.
Mr. Murabayashi said he expected a growing number of executives from his country to choose the suburbs over the city, even though they are used to living in cramped apartments. "Because of that, when we are assigned to a foreign country, we want to live in a house," he said. "We want to make it different." TERRY PRISTIN

HEADLINE: Profits More Robust Than Expected at UAL and US Airways

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The UAL Corporation, parent of United Airlines, and US Airways Group reported first-quarter earnings yesterday that exceeded Wall Street analysts' estimates. A third carrier, Trans World Airlines, reported a loss slightly greater than estimates.
In releasing its results, UAL warned that second-quarter earnings would fall short of analysts' estimates because of continuing weak demand for travel in Asia. 
 The Chicago-based UAL earned $61 million, or 34 cents a fully diluted share, down 42 percent from $105 million, or 92 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier.
On a fully distributed basis, the company earned $218 million, or $1.68 a share -- greater than the average estimate of $1.55 a share reported by the First Call Corporation, an investment research firm. On the same basis, UAL earned $215 million, or $1.61 a share, in the comparable quarter in 1997. The fully distributed earnings figures assume all shares owed to employees are distributed, excluding employee stock compensation. UAL employees own 55 percent of the airline.
UAL said it compensated for problems in Asia by suspending some flights in the region and cutting costs throughout the company. Like other airlines, it also got a boost from the lowest fuel prices in almost a decade, a cut in commissions paid to travel agents and rising business fares.
Still, the economic crisis in Asia reduced UAL's pretax operating profit by about $75 million, compared with the quarter a year earlier, Douglas Hacker, the chief financial officer, said.
United said it expected to earn "slightly less" in the second quarter than the average First Call estimate of $3.07 a share. It said it still expected to "slightly exceed" analysts' full-year estimate of $10.26 a share, helped by the strong United States economy and low fuel prices.
"The bottom line is that Asia is holding back the upside at United," said Glenn Engel, an analyst with Goldman, Sachs & Company.
US Airways Group said first-quarter earnings fell 36 percent, to $98.3 million, or 96 cents a diluted share, from $152.7 million, or $1.45, in the quarter a year earlier. Still, the gains topped the 94-cent estimate in a survey by First Call.
US Airways, based in Arlington, Va., had warned analysts that its costs would increase this year as tax breaks expired and its accounting tax rate rose to 40 percent, from 8 percent last year.
The company also said yesterday that it had postponed a plan to begin serving Gatwick Airport in London from its hub in Charlotte, N.C., bowing for now to British Government in a dispute over landing rights.
US Airways says the off-hour slots that the British authorities have offered would make it impossible for the airline to compete effectively for passenger traffic. The airline had planned to begin the service May 7.
The first-quarter loss at Trans World Airlines narrowed from the comparable quarter a year earlier as the airline cut expenses.
The company, based in St. Louis, reported a loss yesterday of $55.5 million, compared with a loss of $71.6 million in the 1997 quarter. Before one-time charges, it had an operating loss of $54.1 million, or 76 cents a share, compared with $70.0 million, or $1.49, in the period a year earlier. T.W.A. was expected to earn 75 cents a share in the quarter, according to First Call.
The airline, which has been in bankruptcy court twice since 1992, is attempting to raise profits by increasing passengers per plane and by attracting more high-fare business fliers while cutting overall costs. 

CORRECTION-DATE: April 24, 1998, Friday

 CORRECTION:
An article by Bloomberg News in Business Day yesterday about the first-quarter results for three airline companies misstated the figure Wall Street analysts had forecast for Trans World Airlines. The prediction of 75 cents a share for the quarter was for a loss, not a profit. (On Wednesday, T.W.A. reported a loss of 76 cents a share.)

HEADLINE: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Film;
Finnish Fortitude Behind the Despair

BYLINE: By STEPHEN HOLDEN 

 BODY:
The Finnish director Aki Kaurismaki, one of Europe's most celebrated directors, has described the continuing theme in many of his films as "the extraordinary phenomenon that is mistakenly described as Finnish national character, in other words the peculiar desire for self-destruction that haunts this semi-Western, semi-Slavic nation, something that's not without its comic aspects."
That mood of fatalistic gloom, and its deadpan comic side, haunts Mr. Kaurismaki's 1997 film, "Drifting Clouds," which is having its first American showings tonight at 8 at the Museum of Modern Art and on May 2 at 3 P.M. "Drifting Clouds" is one of the high points in the series "Baby It's Cold Outside: Films From Finland, 1917-1997," which begins today at the museum and continues through May 31. 
 The film's dour, neo-realist portrayal of contemporary Finland suggests a country whose middle class is struggling to maintain a foothold, where alcoholism is rampant, and where economic jitters have contributed to a bitter social climate in which petty corruption flourishes. Within a space of days, a couple who have just bought their first television set on the installment plan lose their jobs through downsizing. The husband is a streetcar driver whose route is suddenly canceled, his wife the head waiter at a restaurant that is sold to new management.
"Drifting Clouds" follows these two decent, hard-working people through their humiliating rounds of job hunting. When the husband finds work driving a tour bus to St. Petersburg, the future briefly looks bright until he flunks his medical exam. The wife takes a job in a grubby little diner in which she is both chef (on a hot plate) and waitress. The job ends in disaster.
Neo-realist in attitude but highly stylized with its washed-out colors, wan wintry light and a foreboding expressionistic sense of the characters' profound isolation from one another in tormented private worlds, the movie builds a mood of haunting despair before it takes a sudden 90-degree turn near the end and suggests that pluck pays off.
"Drifting Clouds" is the most recent film in this series, a sweeping history of Finnish cinema that includes 32 movies, most of which are having their American premieres. The oldest film in the series is "Traveling in the Arctic," Sakari Palsi's 18-minute silent movie from 1917, which is a documentary about explorers adrift in the Bering Strait.
Like the couple in "Drifting Clouds," Finnish cinema has survived and even flourished on hardiness and pluck, a quality called "sisu," which, loosely translated, means guts.
"Baby, It's Cold Outside: Films From Finland, 1917-1997" runs through May 31. "Drifting Clouds" can be seen tonight at 8 and on May 2 at 3 P.M. Tickets free with admission: $9.50, $6.50, students and the elderly. The Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street, Manhattan (212) 708-9400.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Kari Vaananen and Kati Outinen in the film "Drifting Clouds," at the Museum of Modern Art. (Museum of Modern Art)

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Clinton Policies Explained

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
Sometimes critical Americans complain that human rights policies of the United States have become so peculiar that there is no understanding what the Clinton Administration is doing or why.
That is not fair. If those critics would apply the perspective of the Administration, everything would be clear. Allow me to help. 
 One spring day this year the U.S. withdrew its annual U.N. resolution criticizing the Chinese Communist Government for its human rights abuses. Good show, said our allies.
But a couple of weeks later, the U.S. again put forward its annual resolution critical of Cuba on human rights. For the first time, the resolution was defeated, by third-world, Communist, former Communist and dictatorial countries; some are all in one.
Our Western allies voted for the U.S. resolution although they do business with Fidel and are always scolding away at the U.S. for its embargo against Cuba.
Think hard and one perspective will come to you in a snap of inspiration. Money talks!
President Clinton abandoned the resolution critical of Beijing because business has persuaded him that hundreds of billions in trade can be scooped up in China.
Now it happens that America loses about $50 billion a year in its trade balance with China. Chinese seem more keen on getting U.S. money than giving us theirs. Still, some U.S. companies do make money; do not get unpleasant with questions about which American hides are aching from the trade losses.
So, what with a Clinton trip to Beijing coming up and Communist warnings about getting impudent about human rights, drop goes the resolution.
Cuba: Many Clintonians want to do business with Fidel. Anti-Castro Cubans in America have the gall to fight for their convictions. But Cuban trade would be a drop compared with the dream profits in China. So let people say the U.S. now only picks human rights quarrels with small or poor countries; who cares?
But surely money does not determine willingness to fight religious persecution of Christians and other hounded minorities? No, not just money.
The Administration is struggling fiercely to destroy a morally powerful but economically mild bill against religious persecution. The bill would cut out U.S. taxpayer money for non-humanitarian aid and for loans to persecuting countries. The President would be on the spot -- agree or waive the penalty.
Representative Frank Wolf and Senator Arlen Specter, both Republicans, introduced the bill. Recently it won a major bipartisan committee vote in the House, 31 to 5, under the helpful chairmanship of Benjamin Gilman, Republican of New York.
The Administration will fight until the final House vote, and in the Senate, where water-down efforts are likely. For a documented lesson in how the Administration, lobbyists and business organize against the bill, see a dissection by Ken Silverstein in Mother Jones, current issue.
Money is involved -- the trade threats of Beijing. But now, thanks to Secretary of State Albright, we can understand Clintonian political philosophy, too. In a speech knifing Wolf-Specter she said:
"Even the most patriotic among us must admit that neither morality nor religious freedom nor respect for human rights were invented here -- nor are they perfectly practiced here. . . . If we are to be effective in defending the values we cherish, we must also take into account the perspectives and values of others."
Moral equivalency. We heard it raised against fighting South African apartheid, against fighting female genital mutilation and, not terribly long ago, against freeing slaves.
What "perspectives and values" must we take into account about religious persecution -- the value of arrest, torture, forced labor, the perspective of the Communist bureaucrats and police who oversee the "patriotic" churches where Chinese Protestants and Catholics must worship if they want to stay out of prison?
Or the perspectives of governments that do not permit Christians to worship openly at all, as in Saudi Arabia, or make war against them, spelled Sudan?
Most Americans, I believe, prefer the perspectives and values of Wolf-Specter and of politicians, churches and organizations that are creating a conservative-liberal coalition for religious and political rights -- which thrive together or die together.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
RJR Nabisco Posts 16% Drop in First-Quarter Earnings

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS 

 BODY:
The RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation reported a 16 percent drop in first-quarter earnings yesterday, attributing the decline to economic troubles in Asia and Brazil, a stronger dollar, higher marketing costs and increased legal expenses from the proposed tobacco litigation settlement.
For the three months ended March 31, RJR said net income fell to $179 million, or 52 cents a diluted share, from $213 million, or 62 cents, a year ago. Revenue rose 4 percent, to $3.95 billion from $3.78 billion. 
 The results were in line with Wall Street's diminished expectations, and RJR shares fell 25 cents, to $28.50 on the New York Stock Exchange.
"We do expect performance to improve as we move through the year, but we expect little change in the full-year results versus last year, excluding the impact of foreign-exchange translation," said Steven F. Goldstone, the company's chairman and chief executive.
A stronger dollar makes American products more expensive abroad and means corporate profits earned in foreign currencies translate into relatively fewer dollars.
Analysts said the company's tobacco sales grew impressively in some areas, like Romania, where they more than doubled. But overall tobacco earnings fell 11 percent, from $575 million last year to $513 million this year.
"While there was extremely good volume and market-share growth in Eastern Europe and Russia, it did not translate into greater profits," said Martin Feldman, a tobacco analyst with Salomon Smith Barney.
Earnings by the domestic tobacco business declined 11 percent, partly because of the increased costs of marketing the Winston brand, which was repositioned in the second half of 1997 with a "No Bull" ad campaign that is generally considered a success. Legal costs associated with the proposed tobacco settlement "outweighed higher selling prices," the company said.
On the food side, earnings decreased from $253 million to $238 million this year. Sales of several products in the cookie-and-cracker division remain soft, and major problems exist with a Brazilian dairy business owned by Nabisco, analysts said.
Food earnings from abroad fell 41 percent, from $54 million to $32 million, although sales rose slightly, from $577 million to $582 million. "It's hard to look at these international earnings without believing that Dr. Kilts will have to perform surgery, particularly on the Brazilian milk business," said John McMillin, a food analyst with Prudential Securities. He referred to James M. Kilts, the president and chief executive of Nabisco Holdings Corporation, who is not a medical doctor.
In the United States though, the company faces other problems, notably its weakened sales of hot cereals -- attributed to an unusually mild winter -- but also the slump suffered by products like the low-fat Snackwell's line of cookies and snacks.
"Their whole cookie business is down compared to Keebler's," said Emanuel Goldman, an industry analyst with Paine Webber in San Francisco. "It's extraordinary. For RJR's cookie business to be losing share is like the canary eating the cat."

HEADLINE: $6.15 Minimum Wage Approved in Hartford

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, April 23

 BODY:
In the state with the highest per-capita income, lawmakers today passed a measure aimed at helping Connecticut's low-income workers: they raised the minimum wage.
The measure, which Gov. John G. Rowland has promised to sign, will raise Connecticut's hourly minimum wage to $6.15 by the year 2000, a dollar above the $5.15 minimum wage set by the Federal Government last September. The increase will give Connecticut the second-highest minimum wage in the country. 
 Although some Republicans expressed concern today that the measure would hurt small businesses and eliminate the jobs of some low-income workers, Democrats disagreed and said that as the economy improves, those in the bottom-income brackets deserve to benefit.
State Representative Christopher G. Donovan, a Democrat from Meriden, who was the measure's chief proponent, said that Connecticut's poverty rate tripled, to 10.7 percent from 3.5 percent, between 1989 and 1996. "We need to halt this decline of our working people and stop this slide into poverty," Mr. Donovan said.
"It's time we give hard work its due," he added.
The measure raises Connecticut's $5.18 minimum wage to $5.65 on Jan. 1, 1999, and to $6.15 on Jan. 1, 2000.
The measure passed this year without the partisan wrangling that occurred two years ago when Democrats tried to pass a similar bill. At that time, Mr. Rowland threatened to veto a minimum-wage measure, and Senate Democrats staged an hours-long filibuster when Republicans, who then controlled the Senate, refused to bring the bill to a vote.
A spokeswoman for United States Representative Barbara B. Kennelly, Mr. Rowland's likely Democratic opponent in the governor's race this year, said Mrs. Kennelly was pleased that the minimum-wage bill passed. But she said that Mr. Rowland's earlier opposition to the bill indicates that his change of position was election-year politics.
"I wonder if he would have made this decision if we weren't 28 weeks before the election," the spokeswoman, Lisa K. Cutler, said today.
Dean C. Pagani, Mr. Rowland's spokesman, said the Governor would sign the bill because the economy is healthier than it was two years ago, even though he still feels that the minimum wage should be set by the Federal Government.
The House passed the bill 124 to 23 today, and the Senate passed it 27 to 8 on April 2.
The move comes as Congress is considering raising the minimum wage and at least two other states, Massachusetts and Washington, are considering ways to increase the minimum wage there.
Only six other states and the District of Columbia have a minimum wage higher than the Federal standard, said Edward B. Lazere, a policy analyst for the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a Washington advocacy group that researches government policy affecting low-income people. Oregon is the only state whose minimum wage will remain above Connecticut's after this measure fully takes effect; Oregon's current minimum is $6 per hour, and is scheduled to rise to $6.50 in January 1999, Mr. Lazere said.

HEADLINE: New Jobless Claims Higher in Mid-April

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 23

 BODY:
New claims for jobless benefits rose 29,000 in mid-April to the highest level in two months, erasing sharp declines from the previous week, the Labor Department said today.
Government figures showed 317,000 newly idled workers filed for unemployment insurance benefits at state offices around the country in the week that ended last Saturday, exceeding economists' forecast for 308,000 claims for the week. 
 In the previous week, new applications were revised downward to 288,000 from 289,000, the lowest since 276,000 in late July, the Labor Department said.
But the department was still unclear whether the drop was linked to Passover and Easter holidays falling at the end of the week in which many applicants may have delayed filing claims. It was not a Federal holiday.

HEADLINE: Iraq Again Threatens to Halt Arms Inspections

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, April 23

 BODY:
President Saddam Hussein made his most direct threat today to provoke another crisis over arms inspections unless an economic embargo on Iraq is lifted next week by the United Nations Security Council.
The United States would "pay dearly" for not heeding the warning, a statement from the Iraqi Cabinet said. Last November, Iraq threatened to stop all cooperation with the arms inspections by May, and some officials here fear the Iraqis may follow through on that threat if events in the Council do not go their way. 
 The Cabinet statement, issued in Baghdad after a meeting presided over by President Hussein, came as the Deputy Prime Minister, Tariq Aziz, formally demanded in a letter to the Security Council that sanctions be lifted "immediately without any new restrictions or conditions." The letter was sent to Hisashi Owada, Japan's representative and this month's Council president.
Mr. Aziz dismissed the latest report from the United Nations Special Commission -- the arms inspectors -- which criticized Iraq for withholding information on arms programs, as full of "tremendous and flagrant fallacies and lies."
Iraq will get an opportunity to deliver its message directly to Council members on Monday in an informal session requested by Russia, which may also propose that intrusive inspections for nuclear weapons in Iraq be stopped and replaced by passive monitoring, diplomats said. The International Atomic Energy Agency reported last week that Iraq had successfully accounted for most of its nuclear program.
Iraq would like help from its friends, particularly Russia and France, in finding ways to whittle down the power of the inspection process, assuming that sanctions remain, diplomats said. Today at a House subcommittee hearing in Washington, Bill Richardson, the United States representative at the United Nations, said without elaborating that he expected to face "efforts to weaken the disarmament provisions of the Security Council resolution."
James P. Rubin, the State Department spokesman, said in an interview that Iraq should have learned that there can be no quick technical fixes to hasten the end of sanctions, which were imposed in 1990 after Iraq invaded Kuwait.
"Unfortunately Iraq continues to make threats instead of coming clean with the requirements of U.N. Security Council resolutions," Mr. Rubin said. "Sanctions will stay on, as long as Iraq continues to flout U.N. resolutions. That is not the view of the United States; that is the view of all the members of the Security Council."
Mr. Rubin noted that a military force remained in the Persian Gulf area and said the United States was still prepared to use it.
In his letter to the Council, Mr. Aziz accused the commission's executive chairman, Richard Butler of Australia, with conducting a political vendetta against Iraq while gathering intelligence for Washington.
United Nations and Clinton Administration officials expected Iraq to press for a lifting of sanctions before the end of the year.
But few expected the high-pitched campaign to force a debate now, during the first major review of sanctions since the crisis in January and February that brought the United States and Iraq close to war.
To a large extent, Iraq is using familiar tactics: attacking Mr. Butler while testing the level of support the United States will have in the Council. The Iraqi move comes only a few months after Washington failed to win much backing for a military attack during the last crisis.
The last unalloyed United States victory in the Council occurred last fall, when a resolution was passed that demanded a ban on international travel by senior Iraqi officials. That resolution has never been put into effect: the Foreign Minister, Mohammed Said al-Sahaf, and the Oil Minister, Amir Mohammed Rashid, are in New York for the Security Council meetings.
On Monday the Security Council begins one of two comprehensive reviews of sanctions scheduled for this year; the second is planned for October. Diplomats and United Nations officials have assumed the sanctions would be continued during the current review.
In his 22-page letter to Mr. Owada, Mr. Aziz demanded a public hearing of all charges against Baghdad to permit Iraqi officials to clear up any outstanding issues.
The Iraqis also hoped to do this during "technical experts' meetings" that were called earlier this year at Baghdad's request to get an independent review of evidence. They were disappointed when experts from a wide range of countries -- including some on the Council sympathetic to Iraq -- wrote reports similar to that of Mr. Butler, who said last week that there had been no progress in the last six months in closing files on biological, chemical or missile programs.
Under Council resolutions, when files are closed the United Nations can continue to monitor Iraq but can no longer conduct intrusive inspections at will. A complex high-technology monitoring system is in place, but it is lightly guarded and could be easily seized or disabled by Iraq.
Mr. Aziz said Iraq objects to Mr. Butler's reluctance to accept Baghdad's declarations of compliance.
"In more than one part of the report," Mr. Aziz wrote of Mr. Butler's account, "the executive chairman attacks Iraq's statements and declarations that it no long has prohibited weapons, mentioning the expression 'in contrast with the evidence available.' "
Mr. Aziz says that to demand verification while withholding evidence "is a police procedure, and not one pertaining to the work of the United Nations."
Mr. Butler -- who like his predecessor, Rolf Ekeus, a Swedish diplomat who is now Ambassador to the United States, has presented evidence to Iraq on numerous occasions -- says the Iraqis are trying to claim "disarmament by declaration."

 
 
Iranq Protests Killing
 TEHERAN, Iran, April 23 (Reuters) -- Iran protested to Iraq today over the assassination of a 70-year-old Iranian cleric in the holy city of Najaf in southern Iraq, the Teheran radio said.
It said Iraq's charge d'affaires in Teheran was summoned to the Foreign Ministry over the killing on Tuesday of Sheik Morteza Ali Mohammed Ebrahim Borujerdi.
In London, the Iraqi opposition Al Khoei Foundation accused Iraqi Government agents of shooting Sheik Borujerdi, whom it described as a senior candidate for the position of grand spiritual leader of Shiite Muslims worldwide. The foundation said that there had been two previous attempts on the sheik's life and that Iraqi officials had threatened him if he did not stop leading prayers in public. Iraq reported the killing on Wednesday and blamed the intelligence services of a foreign country, which it did not name.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Corestates Settles Bond Case With U.S. for $3.7 Million

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
The Corestates Financial Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to pay $3.7 million to settle Federal allegations that its brokerage firm unit grossly overcharged investors and the Federal and local governments in a series of municipal bond deals in the early 1990's.
The settlement is the first time a financial institution has agreed to pay a fine for "yield burning," what Federal investigators call a fraudulent marking up of bond prices. 
 The settlement -- reached with Securities and Exchange Commission, the Justice Department and the Internal Revenue Service -- may serve as a formula for future agreements as the Government steps up investigation of municipal bond practices. "Yield burning is a fraud perpetrated on local governments and taxpayers that compromises the integrity of of the municipal securities market," said Arthur Levitt Jr., the S.E.C. chairman. "This case signals to municipal finance professionals that this conduct will be vigorously prosecuted."
In the case, the Government had accused Meridian Securities, a Reading, Pa., brokerage firm that was acquired by Corestates in 1996, of illegally marking up the price of Treasury securities and reselling them to local government agencies in Pennsylvania and West Virginia.
In agreeing to the settlement, Corestates did not acknowledge any wrongdoing. The company said it simply wanted to resolve any securities and tax questions related to dozens of Pennsylvania transactions from 1992 to 1995. The deals involved the raising of funds for county and local governments and school districts. "We inherited this controversy," said Thomas Dooney, chief executive of Corestates, whose merger with the First Union Corporation is scheduled to be completed later this month. "We looked at the cost of the settlement versus the good will of our clients and the disruptive effect of multiple litigations. All things considered, we made a rational business decision to put this matter behind us."
The settlement is a victory for the S.E.C., which has accused another firm, Rauscher Pierce Refsnes, of yield burning and is investigating dozens of still other cases involving Wall Street firms.
Federal regulators have been looking into accusations that brokerage firms, big and small, illegally overcharged state and local governments in the early 1990's by selling them Treasury bonds at artificially high prices to make hefty profits.
The scheme worked this way: when interest rates fall, state and local agencies often refinance old debt by issuing new municipal bonds. The proceeds are placed in an escrow account, which by Federal law is usually stocked with Treasury bonds. Firms handling the account typically buy the Treasuries.
But in marking up the prices of Treasuries sold to the state and local governments, some firms, investigators say, thereby lowered, or burned down, the yield -- which moves in the opposite direction of the price -- so that the yield appeared to conform with Federal regulations.
In doing so, those firms may have jeopardized the tax-exempt status of many municipalities and also pocketed hundreds of millions of dollars that the local governments would have otherwise forwarded to the Federal Government.
Some investors had feared that the investigation of such practices would cause the I.R.S. to withdraw the tax-exempt status of some bonds. But because of the settlement announced yesterday, it appeared less likely that the I.R.S. would penalize bondholders.
Yield-burning investigations started in 1994, when Michael R. Lissack, an investment banker at Smith Barney, got in touch with Federal law enforcement officials.
Mr. Lissack, who was dismissed from Smith Barney in 1995, filed under the False Claims Act, which permits any individual with knowledge of fraud against the Federal Government to file a suit and, if successful, to recover a percentage of the damages. Indeed, it was Mr. Lissack's False Claims suit that brought the Justice Department into a yield-burning case that was being handled by the S.E.C., which regulates financial markets, and the I.R.S., which was seeking to recover money it believed it had been denied.
Because the Justice Department joined the case, Mr. Lissack -- who had earlier filed claims against Lazard Freres and many other firms for yield-burning practices -- could recover 15 to 25 percent of the Corestates settlement of $3.4 million to the Treasury. Corestates was ordered to pay a further $420,000 to two Pennsylvania municipalities.
The S.E.C. said yesterday that it had also reached a settlement with Martin J. Stallone, who worked on many of the bond deals for Corestates. Mr. Stallone was ordered to pay $100,000 to the Treasury and a $15,000 civil penalty and was suspended from the securities industry for a year.
Steven T. Snyder, head of Meridian's public finance department during most of the deals, was also charged, but he denied wrongdoing and refused a settlement agreement.
"He categorically denies that he violated securities laws," said Mr. Snyder's lawyer, Michael Mixell. "Everything he did was in accordance with corporate policy and with the knowledge of his supervisors."
In Treasury trading yesterday, prices ended lower for the fourth straight session. The price of the benchmark 30-year bond fell 9/32, to 102 1/32, pushing its yield up to 5.98 percent from 5.96 percent Wednesday.
The results of yesterday's Treasury auction of one-year bills came in as expected. Following are the results of the auction:

HEADLINE: Atlanta Mayor Ousts Airport Chief and Hires Newark Official

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, April 23

 BODY:
Mayor Bill Campbell today dismissed the well-regarded but tenaciously independent general manager of the city's bustling airport, the second busiest in the world, and appointed the general manager of Newark's airport to replace her.
Mr. Campbell, a Democrat who was elected to a second term last year, said he did not dismiss the manager, Angela Gittens, because of any dissatisfaction with her performance. Rather, he said, the planned expansion of Hartsfield Atlanta International Airport demands a different style of leadership, and the new manager, Benjamin R. DeCosta, is better suited to the task. 
 But aides to Mr. Campbell and other officials familiar with the operation of the airport said the Mayor had grown frustrated with Ms. Gittens's unyielding style and her refusal to take direction from City Hall. They said she had alienated important political leaders, airport concessionaires, and officials of leading airlines, including the airport's leading carrier, Delta Air Lines, which is based in Atlanta.
"The Mayor's got to feel comfortable with his people," said a mayoral aide, who noted that Ms. Gittens was appointed in 1993 by Mr. Campbell's predecessor, Maynard H. Jackson.
Ms. Gittens, a 51-year-old native of New York City, could not be reached for comment today.
Mr. Campbell refused to critique Ms. Gittens at a news conference today, calling her "a very able airport director" who had "done a good job." He also denied that he had any professional disagreements with her and said it was "absolute nonsense" to say she had been too independent. But the Mayor also made a point of repeatedly extolling Mr. DeCosta as a "consummate diplomat."
"Let me use a sports analogy," Mr. Campbell said. "Sometimes teams trade their stars when they decide to embark on a different course. The need for the airport over the last four years has been rebuilding. The need over the next few years is expansion. It's my belief that Ben DeCosta has a particular skill set that will allow him to be a diplomat in negotiations with our neighbors as well as in working closely with the airlines in making this expansion process a reality."
That being said, Ms. Gittens had, by all accounts, including Mr. Campbell's, compiled an impressive record. And so the Mayor's move provoked puzzlement and disappointment by many political and business leaders, particularly given that Ms. Gittens had a reputation for competence in an administration that has suffered severe management problems in areas like finance and sewage disposal.
Ms. Gittens effectively cleaned up the debris left by a major bribery scandal that resulted in the convictions of several City Council members and airport concessionaires. She oversaw $250 million in renovations before the 1996 Summer Olympics, and won widespread praise for the airport's handling of 3.6 million travelers during the Games. She also directed the planning for the construction of a fifth runway and has started the process of studying future expansion.
A number of City Council members and business leaders said today that they had encouraged Mr. Campbell to retain Ms. Gittens after hearing several months ago that he was considering dismissing her.
"I admired her integrity and strength of character, putting the city and the citizens and the airport first," said Councilwoman Julia Emmons, the chairwoman of the transportation committee. "I had let the Mayor know how I felt."
Another Council member, Doug Alexander, said he probably would vote against Mr. DeCosta's confirmation in protest. "I don't know Mr. DeCosta but he will be more beholden to the Mayor and I don't like that," he said. "I think what he's done here is taken somebody who's shown incredible leadership and vision and just tossed her aside."
Sam A. Williams, president of the Atlanta Chamber of Commerce, said he, too, was disappointed that Ms. Gittens would be leaving. "The business leadership that deals with Hartsfield was impressed with her," he said.
Several City Council members said today that they were also impressed with Mr. DeCosta, who won plaudits at Newark International Airport for diminishing long flight delays, overseeing speedy construction projects and reducing car thefts in airport parking lots.
"If the Mayor had tried to appoint some ex-Council member or some old friend of his, it might have been a problem," said Councilman Vern McCarty. "I think he made some points today by appointing a person who seems to have excellent credentials and qualifications for the job."
Atlanta's airport has long been central to the rapid economic expansion of the region in the last three decades. With 68.2 million passengers in 1997 its volume was second only to Chicago's O'Hare International Airport. The airport and its carriers, vendors and related businesses employ 35,000 people, with an annual payroll of $1.55 billion.

HEADLINE: G.O.P. Snubs White House On Billions For the I.M.F.

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 23

 BODY:
Congressional Republican leaders dropped the Administration's request for $18 billion for the International Monetary Fund from a popular spending bill today, delivering a potentially fatal blow to one of President Clinton's top foreign policy goals.
Supporters of the financing had hoped Congress might vote on it by the end of this month. But today's decision, made at a stormy hourlong meeting of House and Senate Republican leaders, removed the funds from a fast-moving legislative train, delaying any vote at least until next month. 
 The House and Senate have each approved vastly different versions of the bill, which provides emergency military spending and disaster relief. The Senate bill includes the financing, which is intended to replenish the Fund's capital after it was drained by the Asian economic crisis; the House bill does not. Republican leaders met today to determine which approach to take.
When supporters of the Fund in the House tried to reverse the decision, both sides rolled out their heavy artillery.
"We have an obligation to the people of America to look critically at the International Monetary Fund," Speaker Newt Gingrich said.
The Administration, however, has argued that the Asian crisis is hurting American exports to the region. "The crisis in Asia isn't over and every delay with respect to the I.M.F. is taking an extra risk," said a senior Administration official.
The new financing for the Fund was not intended to aid countries currently in crisis, but to bolster resources to contain future economic malaise.
The action today could send a message around the globe. The Fund's members agreed last year to increase their contributions, but because the United States is the largest contributor, other nations await a cue from Congress.
Mr. Gingrich promised a vote on the financing later this year, but only after the House holds hearings on the Fund and sets conditions on the release of the financing. The conditions are expected to include greater accountability by the I.M.F., which has kept many documents about its internal operations secret.
But in the first major test vote tonight, the House rejected a Democratic-led procedural maneuver to reverse the earlier decision to drop the financing provision. The vote was 222 to 186, with 28 Democrats joining 193 Republicans and an independent in opposing the motion; 22 Republicans voted with 164 Democrats in favor.
"The longer we delay, the greater the likelihood is that the problem deepens and widens," said Representative James A. Leach, Republican of Iowa, who heads the House Banking Committee.
Senate supporters of the financing tried to improve the measure's prospects last month by attaching it to a must-pass bill to pay for military operations in Bosnia and the Persian Gulf, and disaster relief for storm-stricken Americans.
But House Republicans insisted on dealing with the I.M.F. money in a far less popular bill that includes nearly $1 billion in back dues owed to the United Nations. Republicans also vowed to add an anti-abortion provision strongly opposed by Mr. Clinton.
With the House opposition to the Fund threatening to delay approval of the military spending, which the Pentagon says it must get by May 1 or begin laying off thousands of workers, Senate leaders agreed today to drop the I.M.F. financing from House-Senate negotiations next week.
The Senators agreed to this approach, but only if a speedy vote on the new financing was assured. Republicans are sharply divided over the new financing, so it is unclear if and when the House will consider the measure.
"This is not good news," said Senator Chuck Hagel, a Nebraska Republican and I.M.F. supporter who helped steer the bill with the financing to an 84-16 victory in the Senate. "It's a serious problem."
Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin and his Deputy Secretary, Lawrence H. Summers, stepped up their campaign of phone calls to lawmakers, but as one senior lobbyist who has fought for the financing in recent weeks said today, "The momentum seems to be swinging away."
For weeks an unusual coalition of Fund supporters, including business leaders, farmers' groups and bankers, have lobbied legislators to support the new financing.
The approach worked in the Senate but the House was a much tougher sell. Earlier this month, Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the majority leader, urged House Republicans to reject the Administration's request. He argued that the new money would encourage an unchecked expansion of the Fund's lending, costing the United States billions of dollars and weakening world financial markets.

HEADLINE: HEALTH INSURERS SEEK BIG INCREASES IN THEIR PREMIUMS

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
For the first time since 1992, many employers are facing double-digit increases in the cost of their health insurance next year, the highest inflation rate since the majority of employees moved into managed care.
In early negotiations with employers about next year's rates, many insurers are seeking increases for 1999 far above this year's, when most premiums rose in single digits after four years of stability. 
 With such increases, many Americans covered by employee-sponsored health plans may see a larger share of their paychecks go to health insurance or see coverage cut back.
Critics of managed care say the magnitude of the increases undercuts a basic appeal behind managed care: savings from lower costs. The steep proposed increases are reminiscent of the double-digit rises in premiums common before managed care became the health insurance system for most American employees in 1993. Last year, 85 percent of employees were enrolled in managed-care plans.
Some critics say managed-care companies have run out of easy savings and will now have to prove that they can produce high-quality care at reasonable prices. "The low-hanging fruit has been plucked in terms of getting savings by eliminating fat that was in the system," said Margaret Stanley, the health care administrator of the California Public Employees Retirement System.
At least some employers in states including New York, New Jersey, California, Illinois and Minnesota are facing demands for increases of 10 percent or more. Benefits consultants estimate that the increases will average about 7 percent nationally, or five times the current 1.4 percent consumer inflation rate.
In perhaps the most dramatic case, Kaiser Permanente, the nation's largest health maintenance organization, is seeking a 12 percent increase from large employers in California, where it is based.
Managed-care companies say they still offer the best chance of reducing the cost of care because of their ability to monitor the health histories of millions of members, enabling doctors to provide the most cost-effective and highest quality care.
They also point out that rate increases next year are likely to be even bigger for the minority of employees covered by traditional insurance plans, known as fee-for-service, in which patients pay more costs out of their own pockets and are partly reimbursed later. Some managed-care insurers are also raising prices to compensate for huge losses in 1997. Others defend rate increases by arguing that their costs are growing, especially for prescription drugs, as they bow to consumer demands for more services and fewer restrictions.
Oxford Health Plans, the managed-care giant based in Norwalk, Conn., and Kaiser belatedly discovered embarrassing losses for last year. Oxford, Kaiser and other big insurers are spending heavily for computer systems that they say will make their forecasts more accurate and steer physicians toward better medical decisions.
Some insurers say costs are also growing because of costly Government requirements like two-day hospital stays for new mothers and, for Kaiser, structural repairs to protect California hospitals in earthquakes.
Basic costs for health services are rising, fueled by advertisements for drugs like Prozac and several new cholesterol treatments; the introduction of widely used new technology like stents -- tiny metal tubes that prop open clogged arteries -- and insistence by consumers on broad choices among doctors and hospitals. In addition, physicians' incomes are rising again after a one-time decline in 1994.
Managed-care companies are also struggling with higher costs generated by older patients and treatments for chronic illnesses. The Government Medicare and Medicaid programs, meanwhile, have taken steps to slow the growth of payments that were lucrative in some states.
"Many health insurers didn't do a good job of managing care, and now they are bleeding red ink," said Blaine Bos, a principal in Chicago with the William Mercer benefits consulting firm. "The only place they can go is the employer-sponsored health plans."
Employers said many managed-care companies would have to find new ways to contain health costs. Ken Reifert, global benefits director of Merrill Lynch, said managed care had largely been limited to "negotiating discounts and curbing access to higher-priced specialists. We've gone almost as far as we can go in that direction," he said.
"Now the health care companies have to come up with the next rabbit," he said, "and get serious about managing costs and managing quality of care."
Mr. Bos, the consultant, said big employers were likely to see rate increases of 9 percent to 14 percent in most parts of the country.
Individuals and small companies are facing even bigger increases. Kurt Owen, who runs an auto supply retailer in Little Falls, Minn., said his insurance agent warned him to prepare for an increase of at least 15 percent after three years of 6.5 percent raises.
Similarly, a law firm with 20 employees in Kenilworth, N.J., was recently notified by Aetna U.S. Healthcare that monthly premiums would rise 19 percent for single employees and 28 percent for families with children. A spokeswoman for Aetna said such increases could be higher or lower, depending on location, the age of employees and type of coverage.
In New York, the state said it would provide $110 million in subsidies to insurers to keep a lid on requests from Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield and Oxford Health Plans for increases as high as 59 percent for individuals buying their own insurance.
Empire said premiums for large employer groups in its health maintenance organizations would rise 6 percent to 8 percent downstate and 10 percent in the Albany area. For traditional insurance, reflecting costs that typically rise faster than for H.M.O.'s, the increase for large groups in New York will be about 12 percent next year after a 12 percent increase in 1998.
Empire, for example, said its spending for prescription drugs rose 20 percent in 1997. Kaiser said that its drug costs rose 15 percent in California and that the hospital stays of its members were up 4 percent, reversing a three-year decline.
Jack Hudes, a Kaiser vice president, said another problem was a new Government ceiling on payments for Medicare H.M.O.'s that will not cover rising medical costs in California.
But economists said the insurance company increases, if they held up, could ripple through the economy.
Although government employees and workers at big industrial companies typically pay only a small share of premiums, some employers say they may ask their workers to go without a raise in 1999 or pay a larger share of monthly insurance premiums. "Something has to give," said Mr. Owen, the small-business operator in Minnesota.
Two of the biggest health care purchasers in the country, the California Public Employees Retirement System and the Pacific Business Group on Health, denounced the Kaiser increase last week and said it was unacceptable. They said Kaiser had refused to compromise and had threatened to discontinue service to 380,000 California government employees and dependents if they did not pay up.
"When health care premiums go up, it lowers the standard of living for employees," said Ms. Stanley of Calpers.
"This is very frightening news for purchasers and employers, when you think about the other organizations that may see that as an umbrella under which they might ask for increases," said Helen Darling, a consultant in Stamford, Conn., with the Watson Wyatt health care consulting firm.
Kaiser officials said their 1999 increases would be smaller in other regions -- 6.9 percent for Massachusetts employees for 12 months starting in July, for example. But the big H.M.O., which has 9.1 million members nationwide, expects to be recovering losses for "the next couple of years," said Kathy Swenson, a senior vice president with Kaiser. In California, she said, that will mean increases in the "high single digit to potentially low double digits."
Kenneth S. Abramowitz, a Wall Street health care analyst with Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, said the increases reflected growing national costs -- 3 percent for inflation, 3 percent because more elderly Americans need more medical care, plus 1 percent each for drugs and new technology.

HEADLINE: Newsstand Operators Sue Over New Rules

BYLINE: By JOSEPH P. FRIED 

 BODY:
A group of New York City newsstand operators, seeking to block new city regulations that limit the number of adult magazines they can display and sell, filed suit yesterday in Federal District Court in Brooklyn.
The newsstand dealers' suit also seeks to block a sharp increase in fees they pay to the city to operate their sidewalk businesses, fees that the operators contend are exorbitant. The new city regulations go into effect today. 
 In papers filed late yesterday, lawyers for the operators contend that both the limit on sexually oriented magazines and the higher fees infringe on the newsstand dealers' constitutional right to distribute published material. If the newsstands exceed the limits, the dealers say, they will be considered adult bookstores, subject to a stringent new zoning law that the city is seeking to use to exclude X-rated businesses from residential neighborhoods and prohibit them from operating within 500 feet of homes, schools, churches and one another.
The news dealers asked the court to declare these provisions -- part of a wider new regulatory plan for the city's approximately 300 sidewalk newsstands -- to be unconstitutional. They also asked that a temporary restraining order be issued to hold off enforcement of the disputed provisions until the court can rule on the merits of the suit.
Judge Allyne R. Ross put off until today a decision on whether to issue the temporary order, said Richard D. Emery, a lawyer for the five Manhattan newsstand operators who brought the suit.
"The imposition of limits on what newsstands can carry violates the news dealers' right to sell what he or she wants," Mr. Emery said in an interview. The new fees also violate this right, his court papers maintain, because the First Amendment to the United States Constitution allows the city to charge news dealers only fees that cover the cost of administering the licensing program. But the new, higher fees are revenue-raising measures "at the expense of free speech," he said.
A lawyer for the city said that although he had not seen the papers filed in the lawsuit, the administration of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani believes that the new regulations do not violate "anybody's First Amendment rights."
"We are aware of a case coming out of Chicago where a Federal appeals court expressly held that there is no First Amendment right to operate a newsstand on a public sidewalk," said the city lawyer, Gabriel Taussig, chief of the administrative law division in the city's Law Department. "While someone does have a First Amendment right to disseminate printed matter, that right doesn't extend to the ability to build a structure on a city sidewalk."
Mr. Emery said that the previous licensing regulations contained no restrictions on the number of adult publications a newsstand could sell and display. The new regulations, he said, in effect limit newsstand sales of adult magazines to less than 40 percent of the stand's total sales and restrict the number of adult magazine displayed to less than 25 percent of display space.
But in an April 14 letter to the New York City Newsstand Operators Association, Randy M. Mastro, the city's Deputy Mayor for operations, said the new newsstand restrictions were needed "to address the possibility that some operators may attempt to circumvent restrictions in the city's new adult-use zoning law by seeking to specialize in the sale of adult magazines from their newsstands."
The lawsuit notes that under the expired system, all street newsstand operators across the city paid $538 a year for their licenses, whereas under the new concession system they will pay $2,500 to $5,000 annually, based on a system of zones that takes into account the location and the amount of traffic there.
