HEADLINE: No Ruse Is Too Rash To Get a Reservation;
Desperate Diners Lie, Cheat and Steal To Eat in the Hottest Spots in Town

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS 

 BODY:
The staff of the Grand Tier Restaurant in the Metropolitan Opera House waited expectantly, as it always does, on Paul Newman night.
The actor and his wife, Joanne Woodward, visit several times a season, and Erik Rothman, the tuxedoed manager, had set aside a prime table with a perfect view of the Chagall murals. 
 Placido Domingo was performing that night in "Samson et Dalila," so tables had been booked for weeks at the restaurant, where only operagoers who have paid up to $200 a ticket have the privilege of dining for an average cost of $80 a person.
Promptly at 6 P.M., a nondescript man with black hair sidled up the grand staircase and presented himself to Michelle Tanhoff, the hostess. "I'm Mr. Newman," he said.
"We always wonder whether the real Paul Newman will show up, and we take bets on it," Ms. Tanhoff said. "That night, I lost. It was Mr. Impostor again. He's done this before." (And he got a table every time.)
The faux Newman, whoever he is, is hardly a criminal genius operating in splendid isolation. More and more, maitres d'hotel and restaurateurs say, people will do just about anything to get a table at the hottest restaurants in the nation's most competitive foodie town.
They lie. They cheat. And yes, they steal.
"The chutzpah was incredible," said Jeffrey Toobin, a writer for The New Yorker who arrived at Bouley Bakery on West Broadway last month only to discover that a party of six had, well, fibbed about their name so they could take the table from Mr. Toobin's party of six. The impostors seemed to have read the reservation book upside down and backward. "The restaurant people asked them to give up the table. They refused."
He sighed. "It was one of those possession-is-nine-tenths-of-the-law situations," said Mr. Toobin, a legal analyst who wrote a best-selling book on the O.J. Simpson trial. "We didn't want to make a scene, and finally the restaurant improvised a table for us. All we wanted to do was eat dinner."
Unfortunately, that is all that everyone in New York seems to want to do these days, at least in certain celebrated spots.
"The demand is greater than at any time in the last 20 years," said Tim Zagat, publisher of the Zagat Restaurant and Hotel Surveys. "It's the economic boom. There is strong domestic demand from young financial wizards for whom price is no object, plus strong international demand from those accustomed to paying twice as much for a meal in Europe or Asia."
All that demand has turned getting a reservation into a trial by frustration, and often by busy signal -- for the simply star-struck diner as well as for the plainly larcenous one. To make matters worse, some restaurants will not accept reservations more than 30 days in advance.
And so, scarcity has prompted some to adopt the old end-justifies-the-means mentality, and Mr. Zagat himself could be a poster boy for victimization: dozens of maitres d'hotel have called to tell him that diners have made false reservations under his name. Now when he makes reservations he tells restaurants to confirm with his office.
"I was unprepared for the very great amount of lying," said Alain H. Michel, restaurant director of Jean Georges, the star chef Jean-Georges Vongerichten's New French bastion in the Trump International Hotel on Central Park West. "So many people say that they called for a reservation and then claim that we lost it." They feign shock and indignation, he said, when the restaurant does not have the reservation that was never made.
Jean Georges has been forced to treat its reservation holders as if they were Holiday Inn customers: they are required to phone a special line on The Day, validating their call by offering a confirmation number.
These days, the bestiary of shameless restaurant prevaricators includes not only Celebrity Impersonators and Outright Thieves, but also Owners' Best Pals, Name Droppers, Epic Bards, Bribers and Great Intimidators.
The Celebrity Impersonators practice their craft in all manner of ways. Call it lying a la carte. At the Grand Tier, the staff doesn't even know if the pseudo Paul Newman's name really is Paul Newman, "because he always pays in cash," Mr. Rothman said.
Some impersonators have a right to the names they use, though perhaps not to the tables they command.
"We took a reservation asking for a great table for Bill Cosby," said David Ruggerio, chef and owner of Le Chantilly on East 57th Street. "When he arrived, he was obviously not the comedian. But his credit card said he was William Cosby."
And then there are those who have a penchant for appending the words "princess," "duke" and "lord" to their names, which are revealed unadorned on their credit cards. A variant is the secretary-of-the-important-man gambit. "We get lots of calls from people who say, 'I'm calling from the president's office," said Marco Maccioni, a co-owner of Osteria del Circo on West 55th Street. "They never say the president of what."
In Mr. Ruggerio's opinion, impersonators are more forgivable than Outright Thieves, like the group that took Mr. Toobin's table. "These people inch to the front of the line, wait until the maitre d' is gone, then look in the reservation book and pick out a name," he said.
Which has prompted many maitres d'hotel to close the book when they show people to the table. This works only as long as you have the book.
"At Christmastime 1994, someone stole our reservation book," said Jean-Jacques Rachou, owner of La Cote Basque on West 55th Street. "A young man came into the restaurant, asked about a reservation and -- when the maitre d' went to seat someone -- the man left with the book. Maybe he couldn't get in, maybe it was a prank, but it caused a very great confusion at our busy time, and made it so difficult for us to tell who had a reservation."
As always, New York's connivers are using the Owner's Best Pal stratagem -- or, at least, trying to.
Sirio Maccioni, owner of Le Cirque 2000 on Madison Avenue and Marco Maccioni's father, said that "many times people have come up to me and asked for a reservation claiming they are a dear friend of the owner, Sergio," he said with a laugh.
"What am I going to say, 'You are a liar?' No, sometimes I put on my glasses and say, "Oh yes, I'm Sergio, I didn't recognize you."
The Epic Bards are a more exotic group of Outright Liars who spin wondrous fables to get reservations. "We got a frantic call from a C.E.O. who said he was desperate for porterhouse, he was unable to get a reservation in our Minneapolis restaurant, and he was landing his jet soon at Teterboro, so could we fit him in," said Seth D. Bromberg, maitre d'hotel for four years at Morton's of Chicago on East 45th Street, which caters to many captains of industry.
"I thought, 'Who would make up a story like that?' and gave him a table," Mr. Bromberg said. "A few minutes later he came in with his wife. I asked, 'How did you get here so quickly?' and they sheepishly admitted that the story was a ploy. But I was charmed. I think he deserved the table, and he's become a good customer."
Then there are the Epic Bards who never look back. "I told one walk-in that he'd have to wait an hour for a table," Mr. Bromberg said. "He said, 'I can't wait that long.' I asked, 'Why?' He said, 'I only have six months to live, and every moment is precious to me.' How could you not give that guy a table?"
In a way, all of this dirty rotten dishonesty is a backhanded expression of regard. "We are in a service business, and it is our pleasure to be nice to people," Sirio Maccioni said. "The restaurant should be thankful to these people for trying so hard to get in. It would be so much worse if they didn't want to come in."
But restaurant managers draw the line when it comes to bribery and intimidation. "One evening a gentleman arrived at 8 P.M. waving several hundred dollar bills in my face and loudly saying that if I got him a table, then this is for me," Mr. Michel of Jean Georges said with a frown at the sheer tastelessness of the spectacle. "I honestly had absolutely no room for him. What kind of a reputation would we have if we accepted such inducements?"
Maitre d'hotels say that boors offer money in exotic and sometimes hilariously contrived ways, secreting bills between fingers and in their palms "as if they'd seen it done in a bad movie," one manager said.
When lying fails, a not-inconsiderable number of prevaricators and bribers resort to intimidation. Owners and maitres d'hotel report that the Rejected Ones threaten to complain to the Mayor, the Department of Health, the Zagat Survey and even The New York Times.
"We hear a lot of swear words, when we're not hearing weeping," said Josh Goodman, the restaurant manager at Balthazar, a Spring Street retro bistro that gets from 1,000 to 3,000 calls per day and has eight reservation takers to field calls.
The staff has even received death threats. On Valentine's Day, when Balthazar had been totally booked for more than a month, one rejected caller, who had failed to connive his way into the restaurant, said, "I'll be down there, and I'm going to hurt you in ways the likes of which you've never bleeping seen, and then I'm going to bleeping take you out," Mr. Goodman recalled. Perhaps Cupid took pity and intervened.
However skilled they may be at duplicity, New Yorkers hardly have the depth of audacity of Parisians, some of whom have raised celebrity impersonation to the level of art.
"Two months ago I got a call saying that Monsieur Chirac would be coming to dinner," said Jean-Claude Vrinat, owner of Taillevent, an 80-seat restaurant that has had three Michelin stars since 1973, the longest streak of affirmed excellence in Paris.
The request was not unusual, since President Jacques Chirac has been a frequent visitor. "They said he was to be a secret guest, and that we should mention it to no one," Mr. Vrinat said. "But when the party of eight arrived, Monsieur Chirac was not present. We asked where he was, and they said, 'He's coming for coffee.' By then I knew perfectly well that this was untrue. And indeed, M. Chirac never did manage to arrive."

HEADLINE: Senators Endorse Tax Breaks For Education Savings Accounts

BYLINE: By LIZETTE ALVAREZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 23

 BODY:
The Senate today narrowly passed a showcase Republican bill that would provide a modest tax break for parents who save for elementary and secondary school expenses, including private school tuition.
But even as the Senate Republicans tried to seize the education initiative from Democrats, they faced a veto threat from President Clinton on their legislation. 
 The measure passed 56 to 43 on a near party line vote after days of biting partisan debate that displayed the deep differences on education policy. The Republicans want Federal money available for private education, while Democrats fear any subsidy that would reduce commitment to public schooling.
The bill, sponsored by Paul D. Coverdell, Republican of Georgia, and Robert Torricelli, Democrat of New Jersey, would allow family members, charitable groups or private donors to contribute up to $2,000 a year for each elementary or secondary student into special savings accounts that could be used for education-related expenses, including tutoring, computers and private school tuition.
The interest on the money and withdrawals from the account would be tax free and could be rolled over for college expenses. The accounts, which would cost the Federal government $1.6 billion over 10 years, would be phased out for individuals who make more than $95,000 a year.
Senator Pete Domenici, Republican of New Mexico, called the legislation "revolutionary" while Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, excoriated the bill as an attempt to "privatize education."
The House passed similar legislation last year, and now the two chambers must craft a final bill to send to Mr. Clinton.
With Democrats denouncing the legislation as a first step toward using Federal funds to subsidize private schools, Mr. Clinton this week vowed to veto it. The President has opposed the tax break since last summer, when he threatened to veto the entire balanced budget agreement if Republicans did not remove the provision. They did but vowed to resurrect it.
"It would disproportionately benefit highest-income taxpayers," Mr. Clinton said Tuesday, explaining his expected veto. "Families who are struggling to make ends meet would never see a penny of it."
Today's slim victory indicated that the Senate would not be able to override Mr. Clinton's veto of the bill. Even though the proposal is modest in scope, it gives Republicans a symbolic victory as a well as popular education measure to wield on the campaign trail, one that resonates among middle class parents who send their children to parochial and private schools. And it gives Democrats the chance to portray themselves as the guardians of public education.
The intensity of the debate waged on the floor this week comes at a time when polls show the American public increasingly interested in education as other concerns, such as the economy and the Cold War, have waned. The Democrats have long held the political advantage on the issue, and Mr. Clinton has made education one of the centerpieces of his domestic agenda.
But the Republicans, who just three years ago were trying to eliminate the Department of Education, have tried to recoup with an education agenda of their own. The agenda centers on tuition vouchers that would allow parents to switch their children from public to private schools, an idea that is gaining in grass-roots popularity. Republicans would also like to diminish the Federal government's role in education.
They succeeded in passing two such proposals on Wednesday. By a vote of 50 to 49, the Senate approved an amendment to the tax incentive bill by Senator Coverdell that would convert nearly all Federal money for education programs into block grants for participating states. The Senate also passed a separate provision that would ban voluntary math and reading testing, which Mr. Clinton favors.
"The Federal government has been doing too much dictating for the 7 percent of the resources it gives to the states" for education, Mr. Domenici said.
The two measures were considered so extreme by Democrats, who claimed they would obliterate Federal education policy, that several Democratic supporters of Mr. Coverdell's plan withheld their support. Five Democrats voted for the measure today, but three of them, including Mr. Torricelli, said they would reverse their votes in the future if the amendments were not dropped from the final bill. Three Republicans opposed the bill today.
Democrats put forth 12 of their own amendments, among them Mr. Clinton's ideas to promote school renovation and to hire 100,000 teachers, but none passed.
Throughout the four-day debate, Democrats and Republicans took turns blasting each other's proposals while acknowledging that the nation's schools, and its children, are in trouble.
"The one chance they have to escape the plight that they live in is being denied them because people want to maintain the status quo, and the status quo is bankrupt," said Senator Dan Coats, Republican of Indiana.
Senator Kennedy proclaimed that the bill "hangs the sign for all to see on the front door of public schools of America," Mr. Kennedy said. "Abandon hope all ye who enter here. Get out while you can."
One frustrated Democrat complained that the whole debate was nothing but political posturing. "The Senate is busy talking past each other and setting up 30-minute spots for campaigns," said Senator John F. Kerry of Massachusetts.
Another, Senator Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia, warned his colleagues: "The public school system ought to shape up or public support will continue to erode."
Mr. Torricelli, who broke with his party to become a lead sponsor, said he believes that Democrats are exaggerating the bill's negative impact on public schools and underestimating its value.
The Democrats, armed with figures from a recent assessment done by the Joint Committee on Taxation, said the annual savings in interest amount to peanuts -- $7 to $37. But Mr. Coverdell preferred to highlight the larger picture. Basing his calculations on a compounded interest rate of 7.5 percent, he said a family that saves $2,000 a year for 10 years would build up $8,294 in interest -- none of it taxed -- and would have an additional $2,322 in tax savings.
He also argued that the measure simply expanded an existing tax break signed into law by the President last year that allows families to set aside $500 a year for college.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "AT A GLANCE: Senate's Education Savings Account Bill"
 
Following are highlights of the education savings account bill passed yesterday by the Senate:
 
MAJOR PROVISIONS
*Tax-free savings accounts would be allowed to cover expenses for elementary and secondary education, including that of children in private schools and those taught at home. Qualified expenses would include (1) tuition, tutoring, books and supplies, computers and equipment and (2) room and board, uniforms, transportation and supplementary items (including after-school care).
 *Up to $2,000 a year could be contributed by parents, other relatives, charities, foundations or employers. The bill expands on savings accounts enacted last year that allow tax-free savings of $500 a year for college only.
*Withdrawals and accumulated interest would be tax-free, but contributions would not be deductible. The savings accounts would be phased out for individuals earning more than $95,000 a year and couples making more than $150,000.
*Companies would receive a tax deduction for employee education assistance.
*Prepaid college tuition plans would be completely tax deductible.
*About $10.3 billion in education programs would be converted into block grants, under an amendment approved by the Senate, if states vote to choose block grants over Federally administered programs.
*Voluntary national tests in reading and mathematics would be prohibited, under an amendment approved by the Senate, unless specifically approved by Congress.
 
COST
The savings accounts would cost the Treasury $1.6 billion over 10 years. The total cost of the bill would be $6 billion over 10 years.
 Supporters say the bill will encourage a huge private investment in education. Opponents say that most of the tax benefits will go to the top 20 percent of all income earners and that this money should be spent on school construction, teacher hiring or other benefits to public education.

HEADLINE: MOMA to Get $65 Million From the City

BYLINE: By JUDITH H. DOBRZYNSKI 

 BODY:
With the city's strong economy providing an opportunity for largess, Mayor Rudolph W. Guiliani pledged yesterday that the city would contribute $65 million over the next three years to help pay for a major expansion project at the Museum of Modern Art.
The money, part of the capital budget proposal the Mayor will propose today for fiscal year 1999, represents about 10 percent of the Modern's $650 million capital campaign. 
 Heralding the Modern as "one of New York City's greatest cultural resources," the Mayor announced his financial-aid plan in the musuem's sleek, sixth-floor boardroom, standing amid a series of colorful Andy Warhol prints of Marilyn Monroe.
The Modern announced in December that it had hired Yoshio Taniguchi, a Japanese architect, to design its expansion and renovation, which is scheduled to begin in 2000 and be completed in time for the museum's 75th anniversary in 2004. Besides nearly doubling the Modern's exhibition space to 650,000 square feet, the expansion will add new facilities for education, research, retail and storage.
Facing a huge price tag, trustees from the museum's expansion committee, including David Rockefeller, Donald Marron, the chairman of Paine Webber Inc., and the real estate developer Jerry Speyer approached the Giuliani administration.
Mr. Rockefeller, whose mother, Abby Aldrich Rockefeller, was a founder of the Modern, said the city money was "the financial cornerstone" of the expansion. Of the remaining $585 million the museum must raise, he said that about $200 million had been pledged by "the family and trustees." Then he quickly added a qualifier: "When I say family, I mean the museum family, not my family."
Mr. Giuliani justified the city's contribution, saying that the museum expansion would provide its own economic benefits. "The reason for this investment is that the city makes its investment back in about two years," he said.
The rewards would come from the increased economic activity sparked by the Modern's expansion. Although such indirect economic benefits are notoriously difficult to predict and are open to wide interpretation, the Modern said that its expansion project would create between 1,800 and 1,900 permanent jobs at the museum and in the hotel, restaurant, retail and service industries. The figures come from a study conducted for the Modern by George Wachtel of Audience Research and Analysis.
The Modern's expansion, which would also create construction jobs, is expected to increase museum attendance to 2.5 million a year from 1.5 million now, the study said. Many are tourists who, the Modern's research shows, come to New York City expressly to visit the museum.
Mr. Rockefeller said the city would gain in other ways. "Of the benefits to the city," he said, "none will be greater than the impact on education." Indeed, with the expansion, the Modern said it would be able to serve every public school in the five boroughs with visits, gallery tours, lectures and other programs. The Modern now works with about 450 of the city's roughly 1,100 schools.
The Mayor also cited benefits to schoolchildren as justification for the $65 million grant. "Someone could say, 'Why not spend this on schools?' " he said. "For some young people, this could be even more important than school."
But City Councilman Herbert E. Berman, a Democrat from Brooklyn who is chairman of the Council's Finance Committee, criticized the Mayor for his generosity to a private institution when he was proposing a cut in the budget of city-run cultural institutions. The first draft of the Mayor's budget included an 11 percent cut for the city's Department of Cultural Affairs.
"These are very important quality-of-life services run by the City of New York," he said, "and it would seem to me that before we start giving money to non-city institutions, we should look to restore dollars to the city-operated cultural institutions, libraries and parks."
And among private institutions, Mr. Berman said he could see no reason for singling out the Museum of Modern Art. "There is a peculiarity here that has to be dealt with," he said. "All of our cultural institutions also generate enormous revenues for the City of New York, also are major tourist attractions."
But Schuyler G. Chapin, the city's Commissioner of Cultural Affairs, said yesterday that this was not a cause for concern, and suggested that the final budget for fiscal 1999 would be more generous to the arts than the draft. "Between the announcement of the Mayor's budget and June, the Department of Cultural Affairs will find itself in a pretty good condition," he predicted.
The capital grant to the Modern is just a proposal, but Mr. Guiliani said that "by June, I'm sure it will be an absolute reality."
Unlike the controversial idea of aiding a new baseball stadium with city money, which would divert tax money that has been going into the general operating budget, the Mayor's pledge to the Modern would use money from the city's capital budget. That budget, which is generally for major long-term projects, is financed through borrowing.
Mr. Chapin said the city similarly contributes to capital projects of other private cultural institutions like the Brooklyn Academy of Music, usually providing about 10 percent of the cost. For the Modern, which has received such grants in the past, $65 million is the largest amount ever.

HEADLINE: Mets Unveil Model Stadium: Its Roof Moves, as Does Grass

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR 

 BODY:
The Mets, who have quietly planned to replace Shea Stadium for several years, unveiled a model yesterday of a $500 million ball park that blends nostalgic design elements from Brooklyn's beloved Ebbets Field with modern features like a retractable roof and a removable grass playing field.
As the rain outside pelted the tarpaulin covering the Shea Stadium infield, Fred Wilpon, the Mets co-owner, stood inside the Diamond Club, a restaurant at the stadium, conducting a guided tour of the ball park model with the tiny red beam of a penlight. 
 "This is a stadium you can put your arms around," Mr. Wilpon said, "with memories of Ebbets Field."
Mr. Wilpon's announcement made clear that despite the Yankees' well-publicized quest for a new home to replace the 75-year-old Yankee Stadium, the Mets lead the city's stadium race by having a design and a site -- the parking lot next to their existing stadium.
Yesterday's unveiling came three days after Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani gave details on a proposal to help pay for new stadiums for the Mets and Yankees with nearly $600 million in tax money from large Manhattan businesses.
But it was unclear how much the city would contribute to a new Mets stadium and how much of the cost the team would bear. Previously, Mets officials have indicated that they expected the city and state to shoulder three-quarters of the costs. And like the current arrangement, New York City would own the stadium.
Mr. Wilpon said only that the Mets would help pay the costs. "We've given the city an idea of where we'd like to be," he said. But he expressed optimism that the financing negotiations could be completed in the next few months.
Mr. Wilpon also said the timing of his announcement was coincidental and was not accelerated by the Mayor's action on Monday.
"When we got to the point of completing this model about a month or two ago, we felt it appropriate to do this," Mr. Wilpon said, adding that he got the Mayor's approval before showing the model. A statement from Mr. Giuliani's office described it as "a very exciting and promising plan."
Designing the stadium to evoke Ebbets Field has been Mr. Wilpon's driving passion for five years. Mr. Wilpon grew up in Brooklyn, attended Lafayette High School and occasionally pitching batting practice for the Brooklyn Dodgers.
Ebbets Field was the Dodgers' home from 1913 to 1957, until the team moved to Los Angeles. And 38 years after the stadium was felled by a wrecker's ball, memories of the stadium and its features have endured: the Romanesque arches, the rotunda enclosed in Italian marble, the quirky dimensions and the 3-foot-by-30-foot Abe Stark outfield sign that promised a free suit to batters who hit it.
The proposal, designed by Hellmuth, Obata & Kassabaum and Jack Gordon, a local architect, echoes Mr. Wilpon's reverie: the exterior is brick and limestone combined with exposed steel trusses that are commonly used in new ball parks that seek to invoke the style of old stadiums. It has a rotunda at the entrance that looks much like the one at Ebbets. The outfield fences have peculiar nooks and crannies but do not copy Ebbets' slanted right field wall.
The right field upper deck sports pillars that allow it to be cantilevered over the field, evocative of old ball parks like Tiger Stadium. An elaborate steel bridgework design across the outfield evokes the Triborough Bridge.
A few outfield dimensions were painted on the miniature walls. Jeff Wilpon, Mr. Wilpon's 36-year-old son and partner in Sterling Equities, which Mr. Wilpon said would be the developer for the stadium, said, "Fred is still playing with them."
More practically, the new stadium includes many of the money-making features of modern stadiums, including 78 luxury suites, some no more than 20 rows from the field, and more than 5,000 high-priced club seats. The retractable roof would guarantee against rainouts.
"You think of bringing a wife and two kids from Suffolk County," Mr. Wilpon said. "If they think it's going to rain, they might not come. If they knew there was a retractable dome, they'd come."
The most unusual feature of the design is the "roll-in, roll-out" grass. The portable grass platform not only provided a way for the stadium to accommodate other events without harming the natural grass but also resolved the problem of how to grow grass under a roof that will be closed during cold, inclement weather and when the stadium is utilized for other events.
With a flick of a switch, stadium workers can move the grass platform within 15 minutes from inside the stadium to an outdoor parking lot.
The idea came from a Toronto company. "It was a little bit of 'Eureka!' " Jeff Wilpon said. "And it was simple. Fred likes simple."
Mark Bingham, the team's senior vice president for business affairs, added: "The grass is essentially in a bathtub. At certain places, you detach the irrigation system from the root system and slide the platform out." He said a stadium in Amsterdam has a similar system.
The retractable roof transforms it from a single-use stadium to a facility capable of hosting concerts, track and field meets, tennis matches and the National Collegiate Athletic Association's men's and women's basketball tournaments. Under the design, it could scaled down to 30,000 seats or expanded to 60,000.
Mr. Wilpon, who acquired the Mets with Nelson Doubleday in 1980, said he and Mr. Giuliani had also discussed the possibility of expanding the stadium to 80,000 seats if the city can lure a pro football team to Flushing. The Jets' lease in New Jersey expires in 2008.
Mr. Wilpon said he hoped the stadium would be ready by the year 2002. But before the team can proceed much further, the financial arrangements must be worked out.
Most stadiums being built in the United States have a major public investment. According to a study by David Swindell, a professor of urban affairs at Wright State University in Dayton, Ohio, 78.8 percent of the cost of football and baseball stadiums built between 1990 and 1998 was borne by state and city governments.
In an interview earlier this year, David Howard, the Mets' general counsel, said the team would like the city to pay a similar share of the new ball park.
Mr. Wilpon said, "We're hoping to get approval on the city saying, 'Here's the deal,' in the next few months."
Although economists have long cast doubt on the economic impact of public investment in new stadiums, Mr. Wilpon said, "The reason to do it is, empirically, the data will show it's good business."
He also said that his search for a site for a new stadium had taken him to Mitchel Field and Belmont Park, on Long Island, the Sunnyside Yards in Queens, a commercial space in Manhattan that he would not identify and the rail yards on the West Side of Manhattan that have been mentioned as a future home for the Yankees.
"We didn't seriously consider going outside New York," he said.
"It wasn't a question of a downside on the West Side, but it was timing and what you think you can get done," he said.
He said that building next to Shea Stadium "is fortunate," adding: "I'm not degrading the West Side. Under certain circumstances, we'd have liked it."

SECTION: Section A; Page 26; Column 6; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 228 words

HEADLINE: Japan Can Solve Its Economic Crisis

 BODY:

To the Editor:
I wonder how Thomas L. Friedman's fondness for sushi has led him to the idea of inciting a "revolution" in Japan (column, April 7). 
 The Japanese people are engaged in a democratic debate about how to put the economy back on track to sustained growth. Mr. Friedman is right insofar as he suggests that part of this debate is over how to get out of the pattern in which "Japanese consumers won't spend and Japanese banks won't lend." However, they would be justifiably wary about the prospect of a "revolution" that could result in land prices soaring to the unsustainable levels of the late 1980's, in the traditional virtues of thrift and saving being shattered, and in the national budget being bankrupted.
It is easy for outsiders to talk about closing Japanese banks, but have they seriously thought about how closures might dent rather than restore public confidence in the future?
In truth, Japan is the second-largest absorber of imports from Asia after the United States. And it is through much-maligned Japanese savings that investments are made in the United States, supporting its economy. "Hammering" a friendly country can in fact instill a fixed mind-set, which can vitiate the effects of the policy decisions made to restore confidence.
 
SADAAKI NUMATA
Spokesman, Ministry of
Foreign Affairs
Tokyo, April 20, 1998

HEADLINE: Japan Can Solve Its Economic Crisis

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Japan's refusal to accept our idea that it should have a crisis (front page, April 21) speaks well for a different measure of health than economic growth. If a society is measured by life expectancy, Japan has been on top since 1976. The United States ranked 26th in 1994. 
 How does Japan achieve such health? Not by following the usual advice given in the United States. The proportion of Japanese males who smoke is twice that in the United States, yet their death rates from smoking are far less. Japan does not need increased competition in medicine, as your article suggests. It spends less than half of what we do per capita on health care and achieves far more.
The notions of "giri-ninjo," duty and empathy, account for Japan's health. Social cohesion, not medical care, is the magic potion. It is measured by income distribution, which is more closely associated with life expectancy than any other indicator.
 
STEPHEN BEZRUCHKA, M.D.
Seattle, April 21, 1998
 
The writer is an affiliate assistant professor of public health at the University of Washington.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;
Thailand Plans to Sell $1 Billion in Bonds

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Thailand plans to sell at least $1 billion of international bonds next month, Government officials said yesterday, in the nation's first sale in a year and a key test of investor confidence in the country. Thailand will probably hire investment banks to arrange the sale after Finance Minister Tarrin Nimmanahaeminda returns from the Asian Development Bank's annual meeting in Geneva next week, officials said. Mr. Tarrin returned this week after two weeks in the United States, where he met with numerous bankers. 
 The sale will be a vital step in reopening the capital markets to the Thai Government and Thai companies after a devaluation of the country's currency last year set off Asia's financial crisis.

SECTION: Section A; Page 6; Column 3; Foreign Desk 

LENGTH: 883 words

HEADLINE: Oilfields in Mind, White House Woos Turkmenistan's Chief

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 23

 BODY:
President Clinton and Vice President Gore met for several hours today with the authoritarian leader of a tiny Central Asian republic, hoping that a warm welcome, several nights at Blair House, a Marine honor guard and a $750,000 grant would win his cooperation in an economic struggle over control of the region's oil and gas.
The honored guest was President Saparmurat Niyazov of Turkmenistan. Less than four months ago, he stood next to President Mohammad Khatami of Iran and opened a short pipeline to send Turkmenistan's natural gas across the Iranian border. 
 Today, he stood next to Mr. Gore in the Roosevelt Room of the White House and signed an agreement under which Washington will pay for a study of another pipeline that circumvents Iran, cutting west into Turkey.
Mr. Niyazov is a former Communist Party chief who has refused incessant demands from the West and the International Monetary Fund that he privatize his centrally controlled economy. He has also suspended presidential elections.
Asked today about recently arrested political opponents, he told reporters at the White House: "We do not have any opposition parties. You are misinformed."
But for today, White House officials put aside their reservations about Mr. Niyazov's tactics, or the cult of personality he has built in his country of four million people. Instead, Vice President Gore hailed the agreement to study a new pipeline and deals Mr. Niyazov has signed recently with American oil companies, saying they contributed to "security and stability" and efforts to "diversify world energy sources."
The greeting for Mr. Niyazov is part of an immense and increasingly complicated chess game that involves American access to some of the world's largest untapped oil and gas reserves, Washington's efforts to isolate Iran and its initiatives to balance power among Russia and the former Soviet republics.
All those subjects came up during Mr. Clinton's 45-minute meeting with Mr. Niyazov, followed by a lunch for more than an hour, and a subsequent meeting with Mr. Gore. One official familiar with the sessions called the meetings "a start," describing Mr. Niyazov as "stronger on geopolitics, weaker on economics."
Indeed, he spent part of his trip here fending off suggestions from the president of the World Bank, James Wolfensohn, and the managing director of the International Monetary Fund, Michel Camdessus, that he bring an end to the old Soviet-style command of his country's economy.
Mr. Niyazov also maintained his silence today when the subject turned to his iron control over his country. "The President and I raised our concerns about democracy, human rights and the rule of law," Mr. Gore said. A communique issued after the meeting committed Turkmenistan to "free and fair elections for parliament and the presidency" in 1999 and 2002, respectively.
Mr. Gore said the United States and Turkmenistan "need to continue to engage with each other." This puts Turkmenistan in the category of countries, including China, that the United States says stand the best chance of change if economic interaction with the rest of the world is encouraged. There is another class of countries -- including Cuba, Iran, Iraq and Myanmar -- that Washington is isolating economically, also to promote change. Most of the countries in the first category have major investment opportunities that American corporations desperately want.
This week, Washington has pressed its interests in economic engagement with Turkmenistan to new heights. It is sending the president of the Export-Import Bank of the United States, James A. Harmon, to Turkmenistan next month to help finance the export of American goods.
The $750,000 grant, issued by the Trade and Development Agency, which also assists American companies pursuing business opportunities overseas, will pay for a feasibility study of alternative pipeline routes. The study must be conducted by an American company, which has not yet been selected.
Mr. Niyazov signed a parcel of small deals here. Mobil Corporation and a British partner, Monument Oil and Gas, signed an agreement forming a strategic alliance with Turkmenistan to explore and develop oil and gas in Western Turkmenistan. Separately, Mobil has asked the Clinton Administration for an exemption from the ban on transactions with Iran that would allow it to swap crude oil from Turkmenistan for crude oil from Iran.
It is unclear how the Administration will rule on that application.
Exxon signed an agreement for a "technical study as an opportunity to demonstrate Exxon's capabilities and interest" in the country.
The biggest player so far, though, is Unocal, a company that has never shied away from dealing with repressive regimes, including one with Myanmar, formerly Burma, for a pipeline project the Clinton Administration blocked last year.
Unocal has been working for several years on a pipeline project that would send Turkmen gas to Pakistan in a route that would run through Afghanistan. Unocal insists that the project is still alive, but fighting between the ruling Taliban government and opposition in the north has imperiled the project. It is unlikely that Unocal would be lent money for the pipeline if the political stability of Afghanistan remains uncertain.

CORRECTION-DATE: April 25, 1998, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about Caspian Sea oil referred incorrectly to the status of a pipeline project under construction in Myanmar, formerly Burma, by Unocal and Total. Because the project began before the United States imposed a ban on investments in Myanmar last year, it is exempt from the American restrictions, and Unocal expects it to begin operations this year.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Dollar's Rise Against Yen Helps to Lift Treasuries

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Treasury prices ended higher yesterday for the first time this week, lifted in part by the dollar's rally against the yen.
The dollar gained on disappointment over the Japanese Government's latest economic revival plan, which was announced yesterday. 
 The currency and bond markets in the United States have "grown weary of these proposals," said Vic Thompson, who oversees about $150 billion in bonds for State Street Global Advisors in Boston. "We've taken the Missouri stance: Show me it's going to work before I believe it."
Japanese investors have flocked to Treasury securities for higher returns than those available on domestic bonds and that is not likely to change, traders said yesterday. At 5.65 percent, United States 10-year notes yield 385 basis points more than the 1.80 percent yield on the 10-year Japanese Government bond. (A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.)
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 15/32 , to 102 1/2. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.94 percent from 5.98 percent.
Bond prices were also bolstered by short-covering as traders who had sold Treasury securities short in the belief that the Japanese plan would be strong and that Treasury prices would fall were forced to buy securities to limit their losses. In a short sale, an investor borrows a security and sells it, hoping to replace it at a lower price later, pocketing the difference. If prices rise, the investor faces a loss.
"Six percent has held" as an upper limit for bond yields, said Marcello Frustaci, a trader at Daiwa Securities America Inc.
Yesterday's gains were not enough to offset losses earlier in the week. Treasury prices have been pressured by demand for corporate bonds as General Motors, Ford Motor and Dell Computer came to market with large debt offerings. In addition, the Treasury is auctioning new two-year and five-year notes next week.
In when-issued trading yesterday, the new two-year note was being offered at a price to yield 5.57 percent and the five-year note at a price to yield 5.62 percent.

HEADLINE: Bulldozing to Cuba

 BODY:

To the Editor:
If Fidel Castro is truly interested in obtaining Caterpillar bulldozers (Business Day, April 22), all he needs is cash and a little knowledge of the gray market. Business Week noted recently that because the Asian recession has halted construction projects in countries like Malaysia and Japan, Caterpillar equipment is available for as little as 60 percent of American dealers' wholesale prices. 
 A Cuban purchase of a few bulldozers would place no liability on Caterpillar for breaching American laws on trading with Cuba. And if parts aren't available from a Mexican or Canadian distributor, Cuban mechanics ought to be able to keep the bulldozers operating as effectively as they have thousands of 1950's Chevys.
 
MICHAEL WALLACE GORDON
Gainesville, Fla., April 22, 1998
 
The writer is a professor of law at the University of Florida.

SECTION: Section B; Page 7; Column 4; Arts & Ideas/Cultural Desk 

LENGTH: 1582 words

HEADLINE: A Prometheus Yielding to Newer Lights;
Paz Defined Mexico's Soul; Now Comes a Pluralism

BYLINE: By JULIA PRESTON 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, April 24

 BODY:
Many of Mexico's finest writers and thinkers gathered in sorrow around the coffin of the poet Octavio Paz when it lay in state on Monday, draped in a Mexican flag, in the great domed hall of the Palace of Fine Arts, the high temple of Mexican culture.
His death was not a surprise, since he was 84 and had been ill with cancer for months. Yet the intellectuals who attended the wake the day after his death seemed to be in shock as well as mourning. 
 They not only had lost a Promethean figure whose poetry, literary criticism, cultural essays and political polemics won him a Nobel Prize in 1990 and were the standard against which the rest of them were measured. They recognized that Paz's passing also marked the end of a way of cultural life in Mexico, with the reign of a few prophetic minds giving way to a pluralism of lesser voices. "The death of Paz closes a chapter in our history," said Christopher Dominguez Michael, a literary critic who was in Paz's inner circle. "It is the end of the age of the intellectual as the master of his era."
Paz's poetry spanned a vast range from surrealism to intimately personal images drawn from Mexican life. He was a tenacious advocate of democracy even when it was out of fashion.
One Mexican writer was conspicuously absent from the funeral rites. The novelist Carlos Fuentes continued on a trip that took him this week from New York to a book fair in Buenos Aires, and he remained silent about Paz's death. He refused to answer a barrage of press phone calls and suspended his normally prolific production of articles for Mexican newspapers.
For at least four decades the two men had dominated Mexico's intellectual horizon. "The Labyrinth of Solitude," Paz's lyrical but defining examination of Mexico's idiosyncrasies, was published in 1950. This year Mr. Fuentes, who is 69, celebrated the 40th anniversary of the publication of his first novel, "Where the Air is Clear," an intimate chronicle of modern Mexico City.
But 10 years ago, the two men, who were avid friends, had a furious falling out over an essay in which a Paz protege, the historian Enrique Krauze, belittled Mr. Fuentes's novels. The critique was published in The New Republic in the United States and in Vuelta (Turn), Paz's monthly literary magazine, in Mexico.
The rift polarized Mexico's literary world and saddened friends of both men. Their hopes that the two proud personalities would reconcile before Paz died were not realized. Now Mr. Fuentes has the upper floors of Mexico's cultural edifice all to himself. But both friends and critics of Mr. Fuentes said they did not expect him to assert his influence as Paz did. Mr. Fuentes is more of a loner who centers his activity squarely on writing his novels and political commentary. He has not cultivated a group of literary acolytes or opened a school of political argument as Paz did at Vuelta.
At the same time, the landscape behind Mr. Fuentes has changed. In this decade Mexico has opened its economy and started to dismantle the single-party state that had monopolized power since the 1920's. Critics of the Government, whose views could be found only in esoteric publications like Vuelta, are now prime-time television commentators and outspoken newspaper columnists.
"Since the 16th century there have been towering figures like Paz who served as the voice of the voiceless," said Jorge Castaneda, a political analyst. "Now, finally, the voiceless begin to have a voice. The country needs towering figures less and less."
Carlos Monsivais, a writer and social critic, said the changes have transformed the cultural establishment. "With Paz we had an aristocracy of thought," Mr. Monsivais said. "Now we are becoming a democracy of thought."
 
An Attack on Students Leads to Pluralism
 It was Paz himself who, in the early 1970's, introduced pluralism to the political debate. Paz, a Mexican diplomat in India, resigned from the Government in 1968 to protest its violent attack on a student demonstration in Mexico City. He returned home, but instead of leading the leftist intellectuals who spearheaded the anti-Government movement, Paz took an independent course. He founded a magazine (which evolved into Vuelta) that was equally critical of the authoritarian Government and the socialist left.
That started an often rancorous, decadeslong feud between Paz and Mexicans who sided with socialism, a feud that subsided only after the cold war ended.
"He broke the unity of the Mexican republic of letters," recalled Mr. Krauze, who was the publisher of Vuelta for two decades and remains on its board. "A cultural monopoly is no longer possible."
 
The Prestige of Paz Amounted to Control
 Yet some Mexican intellectuals who are grieving for Paz the poet and philosopher said they would not miss the control he exercised over Mexico's cultural institutions by virtue of his prestige. Homero Aridjis, a poet and novelist, said Paz sometimes determined by whim which artists would win prizes, publish books and receive scholarships and sidelined those who didn't suit his taste.
Mr. Aridjis also criticized Paz for his rapprochement with the Mexican Government, which began in the 1980's. "After 1968, Paz wrote an essay criticizing what he called the pyramid of power in Mexico, the first serious critique of the political system," he said. "But in the last years of his life he became part of the pyramid of power. It was his great contradiction."
An immediate question is what will happen to Vuelta, now in its 22d year. Its circulation of about 10,000 has been shrinking even though it is probably the pre-eminent literary magazine in Latin America. Mr. Krauze said he had thought it was "poor taste" to discuss the magazine's future with Paz when he was still alive. He and several others among the poet's followers said they now thought it was time for a new "turn," although they were not sure what it might be.
"Vuelta has won many of its battles," Mr. Dominguez, the critic, said. "The Berlin wall fell and the democracy Octavio sought is a reality we live every day in Mexico. But we still have the task of criticizing the open society and protecting it from self-destructive impulses."
Indeed, Paz's death highlighted the shift of intellectual debate away from small reviews and salonlike groups. Through Vuelta, Paz engaged in a running duel with an archrival left-leaning magazine called Nexos, which is most closely identified with one of its founders, the novelist Hector Aguilar Camin. At one point in 1992 a controversy over what kind of support intellectuals should take from the Government brought the two magazines into a verbal war so fiery that it became front page news.
But political differences between the two camps narrowed after the collapse of Communism, and editors on both sides acknowledged -- but did not lament -- that their disputes had become increasingly rarefied.
"The central factor is that Mexico now has a more educated, independent, critical mass media," Mr. Aguilar Camin said. "For the first time we have the possibility of well-informed public opinion." Both magazines paid a price with their readers for the support they gave separately to Carlos Salinas de Gortari when he was President. Both men praised changes begun by Mr. Salinas to modernize Mexico. But Mr. Salinas fell into disgrace shortly after leaving office and was forced into exile in 1995, leaving behind a public convinced that he had enriched himself through corruption.
With the exception of Mr. Fuentes, no living Mexican intellectual approaches the stature Paz enjoyed. Rising novelists like Sergio Pitol and Angeles Mastretta have not sought to sway the course of events in Mexico as Paz did.
But the new generation of Mexican thinkers is considerably more diverse than earlier ones. On Sunday, a weekly series of 104 hourlong television documentaries produced by Mr. Krauze, 55, one of Paz's most direct intellectual heirs, will begin on Televisa, the largest national network. The series will give Mexicans an uncensored panorama of their country in the 20th century unlike anything ever displayed on Mexican television.
 
Away From Analysis, Closer to the Public
 Mr. Aridjis, 58, the poet, is also a prominent environmental activist and president of PEN International. Mr. Castaneda, who is 44, besides being a tireless anti-Government gadfly, published a scholarly biography of the Cuban revolutionary Che Guevara last year.
"You will no longer see those lyrical and insightful but unscientific analyses of the Mexican soul" like those that distinguished Paz and Mr. Fuentes, Mr. Castaneda said. "You no longer have figures of their dimension, and not too many people care what others say about the soul of the country. That includes me; what do I know about the soul of the country?"
Yet there are signs that the new Mexican intellectuals are drawing closer to the public than Paz ever did with his dense and cerebral verse. Mr. Monsivais, who is 60 and cuts the frumpy figure of a Mexican Woody Allen, arranged to meet an interviewer at a coffee shop not unlike a Howard Johnson's. At one point the waitress, dressed in a starched pink uniform, interrupted the interview by peering at Mr. Monsivais.
"Aren't you a writer?" she said with delight. When Mr. Monsivais identified himself, she pumped his hand energetically.
"Do you think you might write about Octavio Paz?" she wondered. "I guess he was a pretty good writer, too."

HEADLINE: A $50 Billion Surplus? Doubtful, Report Says

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 24

 BODY:
Projecting ever bigger Federal budget surpluses has become almost a parlor game here, with politicians and economists pushing the number in the last few weeks to more than $50 billion for this year, a stunning windfall for a nation that long had a reputation for spending away its future.
Today the Congressional Budget Office put a damper on the fun. After studying the tax receipts flowing into the Government's coffers in the days following April 15, the budget office found that while there would be a significant surplus this year, it was unlikely to be as big as the $50 billion that the conventional wisdom has come to assume. 
 Instead, the budget office is standing by its prediction of a surplus from $8 billion to $18 billion, which in itself would make this the first year the Government has been in the black since 1969. The deficit last year was $22 billion.
The budget office, on whose judgment Congress relies to set tax and spending policy, has repeatedly proved too pessimistic in its analyses over the last few years. And even if it is proved right this time, there will be few serious policy ramifications from the lower surplus: the trend toward considerably larger surpluses in coming years remains, portending a pool of money that could go toward shoring up Social Security or addressing a host of other priorities advanced by both parties, from cutting taxes to improving education.
Still, the budget office's analysis today offered a telling counterpoint to a new post-deficit psychology that seems to have taken hold in Washington, where pleasant surprises are assumed by many to lurk around every corner and where the possibility of economic downturns or fiscal crises is all but ignored.
Earlier this month the budget office said the surplus would be $18 billion if the economy's performance for the next six months matched that for same period last year. White House officials have said they expect the surplus to be larger than $18 billion, but have not specified a number and have been dubious about projections in the $50 billion range.
A senior Clinton Administration official said today that the Treasury Department itself did not have a good handle on the size of the April tax receipts and could not yet offer any new estimates.
Many private economists and politicians have been less guarded. Senator Pete V. Domenici, the New Mexico Republican who is chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, said on Sunday that he expected a surplus of $45 billion to $55 billion this year. Speaker Newt Gingrich said on Monday that he expected the number to be $50 billion.
Economists at investment firms that analyze the Treasury Department's daily and monthly accounting statements have been predicting a $50 billion surplus for months, with some saying privately that the number could be even higher.
The budget office did not release any formal analysis today, and told Congressional staff members only that it was not prepared to issue a revised surplus estimate. Aides to Mr. Gingrich and Mr. Domenici did not return phone calls about their earlier predictions, and with Congress not in session today there was little reaction to the budget office's findings.
But June O'Neill, the director of the budget office, elaborated on her position in an interview. She said she was reluctant to come to any final conclusions about the surplus at this point, especially since she badly underestimated revenues last year. But she said that tax receipts recorded so far in April -- especially the type of tax receipt that includes payment of capital gains taxes from profits in the booming stock market -- provided little evidence to support hopes of a $50 billion surplus.
"Having experienced last year where we understated revenue by $70 billion, I would hesitate to rule anything out," Ms. O'Neill said. "But it's in the unlikely category that we would have a $50 billion surplus."
In particular, she said, there is little evidence so far of an "April surprise" of the magnitude that the nation enjoyed last year, when so-called non-withheld payments -- taxes that are not withheld from regular paychecks -- came in $25 billion higher than expected for the month, presumably because of a surge in capital gains from the stock market.
"The non-withheld payments as best we can tell are not much higher if higher at all from last year and are more or less in line with what we've been projecting," she said.
Ms. O'Neill said the budget office would continue to monitor tax receipts in coming days and would issue an informal update early next month.
She said the good news was that revenue from wage and salary income this year had been stronger than expected, a trend that if continued could help push the surplus higher. But most economists are predicting that the economy will cool this year, and the number of jobs in the economy actually declined in March, the first time that has happened in any month in more than two years.
"The big question for the year," Ms. O'Neill said, "is what is going to happen to wage and salary income."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Japan Offers New Package For Economy

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 24

 BODY:
Digging deeper into its purse, the Government announced a record $128 billion program of spending and economic stimulants today aimed at pulling the economy out of a seven-year slump and easing apprehension that Japanese weakness will cause a global slowdown.
In raising spending more than $15 billion beyond amounts in a blueprint of the package released a few weeks ago, the Government seemed to be trying to demonstrate its resolve to the world. American officials have been badgering Japan to revive its economy through large and long-term tax cuts that would prompt consumers to spend more, but the package contained no permanent or major tax reductions. 
 Officials from the United States and elsewhere around the world have been watching the slumbering Japanese economy with increasing alarm. Japan's $600 billion in bad and doubtful debt has dragged down economic growth since 1991 and the Japanese appetite for imports has diminished, posing a threat to other economically troubled countries in Asia.
Today, Clinton Administration officials expressed modest enthusiasm about the package but emphasized, as other economists did, that now deregulation is necessary to achieve sustainable growth.
The amount of spending will be $92 billion, about the size of the economy of Poland, and almost all of it will be rushed into the economy within 12 months. Indeed, the spending portion of the package has been creeping up as criticism from around the world kept pouring in and investors kept battering the markets here.
Now, the Government says the package could add 2 percent to growth, though private economists are less optimistic.
"This is the largest package we will have ever implemented," said Eisuke Sakakibara, Vice Finance Minister for international affairs. "I haven't heard of any package like this in the rest of the world. I'd argue -- for any criticism that this is too small -- that this may be too big."
In an embarrassing about-face, Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto also began the process of amending the nation's controversial austerity law so as to lay the groundwork for the tax cuts, worth about $35 billion.
Just five months ago, Mr. Hashimoto had championed a plan to cut the budget deficit to 3 percent of gross domestic product by the year 2004 to help Japan prepare for its aging population.
Now that target year will be delayed to 2006, and the Government tried to present its program today as a strategy for ushering Japan into the 21st century on a solid economic footing. But the transition is unlikely to be smooth. Many economists estimate that Japan's economy shrunk for the first time in a quarter-century during the fiscal year that ended March 31.
Other statistics paint a bleak picture: company profits, industrial production and consumer and business sentiment are falling, while unemployment, bankruptcies and stockpiles of unsold products are rising.
Though the package has been padded again, some economists still worry the spending will be misused on large public-works projects that do little to stimulate the economy once they are completed.
"The package itself is a huge mistake," said Brian H. Rose, senior economist at SBC Warburg Japan Ltd. "They are spending 9 percent of G.D.P. on public works in a country that has no population growth, that doesn't need any more schools or libraries or bridges or roads. Now, they don't need to pave the bottom of the river beds."
The Government defended itself by saying most of the spending on public works would go into projects for the environment and new energy, information and science technology, and social welfare and education.
The Government said it would also give nearly $5 billion in tax incentives to stimulate corporate investment and the purchase of homes.
Tax cuts, however, are less effective than public works spending in causing immediate growth, particularly in this case because everyone knows the cuts are only temporary and the Government expects households will save most of the money. For the current fiscal year, each taxpayer is expected to receive a rebate of about $223 beginning in August, and a typical household of four would enjoy a tax cut of a total of $558 in the current fiscal year.
Still, altogether, Japan's Economic Planning Agency says the package will add 2 percent to growth for the year ending next March 31.
In contrast, Robert Alan Feldman, chief economist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter in Japan, predicts the economy will contract by four-tenths of a percent in the current fiscal year, but he says the package is still comforting.
"It puts a floor under the economy," Mr. Feldman said. "The risk of a real deflationary spiral is largely removed by the package."
But for many critics, the economic problems go way beyond what can be solved with spending. The key, they argue, is that Japan must undertake broad restructuring and deregulation.
"It's just a one-off shot in the arm," said Peter Morgan, senior economist at HSBC Securities (Japan) Ltd., of today's package.
Some economists say the Government must rework its tax system, where the highest individual income tax rates are effectively 65 percent -- down from 88 percent a decade ago. Corporate tax rates have dropped from 49.98 percent last year to 46.36 percent this year, but they are still higher than rates in America and Europe.
Though the Government plans to bring down the corporate tax rate to international standards within three years, some economists want it done more quickly. Moreover, many economists are calling for flattening out Japan's highly progressive tax system and for a comprehensive overhaul of the tax system.
In another crucial area of the economy, the Government also said it would offer subsidies to allow for "employment adjustment," a sensitive measure that would encourage workers to switch jobs. Japan's lifetime employment system is fraying at the edges, but layoffs are virtually illegal, unless a company is going bankrupt. The Government would have to revise its labor regulations to create a more mobile labor force and today's plan made little mention of that.
Still, the package offered a number of measures viewed as encouraging. It would ease the criteria for extending Government housing loans to encourage more home ownership, offer debt guarantees for new ventures, expand financing for small and medium businesses and extend $5.4 billion in loans and support programs in Asia.
The Government also said it would invest about $30 billion of postal savings funds in the stock market, though it did not count these funds as part of the overall package.
Mr. Sakakibara said banks were planning to write off more than 60 percent of their bad debt in the fiscal year ended on March 31, but unless the property market recovered, the bad debt could grow.
Consequently, the Government said it would try to revive the property market by spending $18 billion to buy land and help banks dispose of bad loans. More important, the Government said it was considering using public funds to create a market in asset-backed securities, similar to what was done in the United States in the early 1990's to help alleviate its savings and loan crisis.
"I personally don't like to emulate the United States all the time," Mr. Sakakibara said, "but this is the time to emulate the United States."

HEADLINE: Compliments of U.S. Investors;
New Activism Shakes Europe's Markets

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
When a French utilities conglomerate, Compagnie Generale des Eaux, proposed taking over the country's largest media group, it did not reckon with Colette Neuville. Mrs. Neuville, a soft-spoken woman in her 60's, filed a suit contending that shareholders in the target company were getting a raw deal.
Though she lost the court fight, she chalked up a major victory last month. 
 The founder of France's biggest minority shareholder group, she was invited to dine with Generale's chairman a week before the formal takeover offer was announced. The company then sweetened its bid, for Havas S.A., with a cash premium of $817 million, equal to $10 a share, or 14.5 percent more than the original offer.
"A corporation is in business for its shareholders," Mrs. Neuville said, displaying her combativeness over breakfast recently. "It's not a cooperative; it's not a kibbutz."
Let there be no doubt about it, the American brand of shareholder activism is spreading abroad. European companies are under pressure from small investors, like Mrs. Neuville, and from foreign investors. Taking such interests into consideration is more important as these companies find themselves in a global competition for capital. Activist American groups like the Lens Fund and the California Public Employee Retirement System are planting seed money in aggressive European funds; other investors, like Fidelity Investments and Templeton, are increasingly putting pressure on European managers and standing up for their rights.
In Europe, investors with only a minority stake have special obstacles. Governments are often majority shareholders, big companies own stakes in each other to protect managers from outside challenges, and universal banks may have conflicts of interest since they serve as lenders, shareholders and pension funds.
But if the new activism takes hold, it could add value by driving European corporations to overhaul their capital structures, shed unprofitable lines of business and put independent directors on corporate boards. It will certainly solidify the rights of junior investors, who often get pushed around in ways that American stock owners can only imagine.
In Germany, minority shareholders are struggling with a number of companies, including Borg-Warner and the Tech Data Corporation of Clearwater, Fla., which are absorbing other companies in which they own majority shares. Minority investor groups, objecting that they are not receiving full value for their shares, say their rights are being trodden.
In Italy, junior investors are suing over the recent Government bailout of Banco di Napoli, the money-losing bank in Southern Italy, and over a bankruptcy case involving a Genoa construction company. In each case, the investments of minority shareholders were wiped out.
In Switzerland, the maverick investor Martin Ebner harasses corporations and banks to provide greater shareholder value. Several pension funds, including the Geneva public employees fund, recently formed a group called the Ethos Fund to stimulate long-term investor value.
But some of the most bitter battles have been fought in France, where protectionism, government traditions and corporate cronyism pose a particularly tangled web.
Take Generale, which has been trying to transform itself from a cumbersome utility to a nimble telecommunications company with television and telephone businesses. In the late 1980's, Jean-Marie Messier was a civil servant who helped write legislation to privatize Havas, a publishing group with a holding in Europe's biggest cable network, Canal Plus. Later, as chairman of Generale, Mr. Messier accumulated a third of Havas, and last year he proposed taking it over and making it the linchpin of Generale's telecommunications ambitions. Because Generale effectively had management control, few obstacles seemed to be in the way.
Generale's approach was typical of French companies. Minority investors were asked to accept Generale's valuation of Havas shares, rather than submit them to auction. Mrs. Neuville's lawsuit argued that French rules required Generale to seek outside bids, given that it had effective control of Havas management. Though the court ruled in favor of Generale, Mr. Messier wanted to avoid further negative publicity, hence the $10 cash premium for each Havas share.
In the end, the executive and the shareholder watchdog parted amicably. Mrs. Neuville said she even went out and bought Generale shares. "I told him he convinced me of his project," she said.
Practices such as bullying minority investors into accepting evaluations undertaken by the majority shareholders were once common in the United States, said Nell Minow, a principal of the Lens Fund in Washington. They were used frequently in the 1980's wave of mergers and acquisitions but are much less common now in the United States because of legislative reform and shareholder resistance.
In March, Lens announced it was joining one of Britain's largest asset managers, Hermes Pensions Management, to form a fund that will put pressure on British corporations to clean up their acts. Earlier, Calpers said it would invest $200 million in Active Value Capital L.P., another activist fund in Britain. Taking a cue from such examples, the pension funds of large German banks, like Deutsche Bank and DG Bank, have begun speaking out at shareholder meetings, said Reinhild Keitel, spokeswoman for the Association to Protect Minority Shareholders in Frankfurt.
"The drive is coming from the United States and taking up steam in Britain," said Corinna Arnold, director of global shareholder services at the Investor Responsibility Research Center in Washington, which promotes shareholder self-help. Now, she said, the spark is set to jump the English Channel.
The French Government, pressed for cash to meet the fiscal requirements of Europe's planned single currency, has for years been gradually selling off shares in banks, insurance companies and industrial groups. Now, one-third and more of the equity of large industrial groups like France's largest oil company, Elf Aquitaine, and Rhone-Poulenc, the chemicals giant, are owned by foreign investment funds. But to maintain control, the Government created what it called noyaux dures, or hard cores, blocks of shares that state-owned banks, insurance companies and other industrial enterprises hold in each other. This intertwined ownership is gradually breaking up, but the Government still resorts to it when, for example, large numbers of jobs are at stake. At times, even national security can be the issue.
Take the case of Eramet S.A., a mining company in which the French Treasury holds a stake after a partial privatization in 1994. Last summer, minority shareholders led by a group of British and American investment funds successfully ended a yearlong struggle with the French Government, which sought to swap a nickel mine that Eramet owned in New Caledonia, a French territory in the South Pacific, for a less profitable one controlled by local separatists, to appease the independence movement.
When the Eramet chairman, Yves Rambaud, resisted, the Government threatened to pack the Eramet board and dismiss him. Only after big foreign funds, including Fidelity Investments and the College Retirement Equity Fund, warned the Government that its proposal would have long-lasting negative effects on foreign investment in France did the new Socialist-led Government that took office early last year reverse the decision.
"It takes a little bit of inventiveness, and you must understand the differences" between American and French corporate law, said Sophie L'Helias, a French lawyer who represented the funds.
In France, 60 percent of French institutional investors questioned in a recent survey by the executive search firm, Russell Reynolds Associates, said they favor standardized corporate governance rules like those proposed by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development. In Germany, new laws require universal banks acting as brokers to inform shareholders that someone else can represent them.
In Italy, the Government approved new rules this month for mergers and acquisitions, disclosure and insider trading that bear the name of their author, Mario Draghi, the Deputy Treasury Minister. Adamo Gentile, a broker who heads Assorisparmio, dismissed them as a "elegant way to confirm the status quo." But the Treasury Minister, Carlo Azeglio Ciampi, called them a "decisive step forward" toward a "more competitive and more open" financial system.
Some experts say the threat of criminal sanctions is adding to the pressure from foreign funds for change.
Dominique Schmidt, professor of law at Strasbourg University who advises Mrs. Neuville, said that "until the start of the 1990's criminal lawsuits were seldom." But in 1996, he said, French investigators arrested the former head of Elf Aquitaine, Loik Le Floch-Prigent, on suspicion of fraud and receiving stolen assets, and a Paris judge is investigating possible criminal behavior at several companies, including the state-owned bank, Credit Lyonnais.
Mrs. L'Helias, who set up a company in 1994, Franklin Global Investor Services, to mediate between investment funds and corporations, relies more on the persuasive power of big foreign funds, though she acknowledges that court action can occasionally help. "Even if you lose," she said, "it sends a strong signal to the market that people are not happy."
But she notes that the absence in Europe of a dense regulatory network like that of the Securities Exchange Commission in the United States leaves room for inventiveness by concerned shareholders. In 1996, for example, she organized minority investors in the indebted Channel Tunnel project by publishing proxy solicitations in a French newspaper and attracted 25,000 responses, even though colleagues said the action was illegal. "Show me the rule forbidding it," was her reply.
Mrs. Neuville agrees. "New laws cannot change things; the shareholders have to do it themselves," she said. "They are a minority in power, not in numbers."

The head of an Italian minority investor association, he dismissed recent legislation designed to prevent abuses in the securities industry as inadequate. (Dino Fracchia for The New York Times)
