HEADLINE: U.S.-Russia Impasse Is Said to Delay a U.N. Debate on Iraqi Arms Inspections

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, April 24

 BODY:
A standoff between the United States and Russia has apparently derailed plans for a Security Council debate early next week about changing the level of nuclear inspections in Iraq, diplomats said today.
The Security Council meets on Monday to review sanctions on Iraq, imposed after its 1990 invasion of Kuwait, following renewed Iraqi demands that the embargo be ended and weapons inspections restricted. The sanctions are expected to be renewed for another six months. 
 In what looked like a small gesture to Iraq and its supporters on the Council, it seemed likely early today that the Council was moving toward allowing the International Atomic Energy Agency to shift the level of its surveillance from searching for and destroying prohibited material to long-term monitoring. Last week the survey team reported that it had found no evidence of prohibited nuclear activity in Iraq.
But in the highly charged atmosphere surrounding the sanctions review -- coming on the heels of a protracted arms-inspection crisis that nearly brought the United States into war against Iraq -- there was no agreement today on how and when to make the move. Russia had planned to introduce a formal resolution "closing the file" on the Iraqi nuclear program. The United States and Britain opposed that plan.
Moreover, Bill Richardson, the United States representative, said in an interview today that he had qualms about changing the status of nuclear inspections, in large part because of a much less positive report on Iraq's biological, chemical and missile programs by Richard Butler, whose Special Commission covers those areas.
"We have serious concerns about closing the nuclear file, given Butler's testimony that there's been little progress on the other disarmament fronts," Mr. Richardson said in an interview today. He said that Iraq was still concealing crucial information.
Britain, the strongest ally of the United States on the issue, seems prepared to follow the lead of the atomic energy agency, its representative, Sir John Weston, said in an interview.
"If the I.A.E.A. are saying that the best way for them to conduct their work at this point is to transition from a disarmament phase to on-site monitoring and verification," he said, "the United Kingdom would certainly listen to arguments on that score."
But he agreed with other Council members that a formal resolution was not necessary, and that a simple Council statement would be adequate to mark the change.
An end to the disarmament phase of nuclear accounting in Iraq would still leave the atomic energy agency with considerable powers to inspect any suspect Iraqi sites.
The concern of some diplomats and scientists in the arms-control movement is that Iraq will seize the moment to increase pressure to reduce the level of inspections in other areas, and that President Saddam Hussein will find ways to limit or block inspections.
David Albright, president of the independent Institute for Science and International Security in Washington and a former atomic agency monitor in Iraq, said that Iraq is likely to insist that future inspections be no more stringent than the agency's ordinary checks on any country that has signed the treaty to halt the spread of nuclear weapons. Iraq signed the pact -- and then proceeded to try to make nuclear weapons anyway.
"There is a slippery slope here," Mr. Albright said today of the move to change the disarmament status of Iraq. "How steep it is is hard to measure now. But Iraq may soon try to push inspections down to the level of routine I.A.E.A. safeguards. Even with improvements, I.A.E.A. safeguards are not sufficient in the case of Iraq, given its intentions and its history."
Some diplomats say that it is necessary to weigh fears of future action against the need to start giving the Iraqis some encouragement and sense of accomplishment if Baghdad is to be prodded into greater cooperation in problem areas.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Blue Chips Retreat 78.71 On Concern About Growth

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
The stock market finished the week on a down note yesterday, falling sharply just days after hitting new highs across the board.
First-quarter earnings reports have been coming in a little better than expected, but the growth rate compared with that of a year ago is still slow. A number of companies, including Kellogg yesterday, have warned that the near-term outlook is not all that positive. 
 This environment has made investors jittery, especially because the Dow Jones industrial average and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index have moved up nearly 15 percent this year even though earnings growth for the first quarter may not break 3 percent.
"It is a market taking a pause, digesting recent earnings news and waiting for more data points on Asia," said Thomas M. Galvin, chief investment officer at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.
What is not clear is whether the jitters, which so far have made the market volatile on a steady trip higher, could turn into a broader uncertainty about the outlook that would put the stock market on hold for a while. Such a pause could last until investors are sure that earnings will pick up in the second half of the year and that the drag from the Asian economic turmoil is passed.
The Dow was down 123 points in the afternoon but partly recovered to close with a loss of 78.71, at 9,064.62. The S.& P. 500 fell 11.68, to 1,107.90, while the technology-heavy Nasdaq dropped 12.43, to 1,868.96.
Stocks were led lower by Microsoft and Intel in technology, J. P. Morgan and American Express in banking, Merck in pharmaceuticals and Sears, Roebuck in retailing.
Christina Heuer, the drug analyst at Salomon Smith Barney, said Merck was undermined by the reminder that it would soon have to share the profits of Cozaar, with DuPont, which invented the popular heart drug but let Merck commercialize it. "Merck does not comment on this much," she said.
The reminder, she said, came from DuPont in discussions with analysts after it reported earnings on Wednesday. In an answer to a question, an executive said the profit-sharing agreement could take effect in the fourth quarter of 1999. "We knew there was a profit-sharing agreement but not when it would go into effect," Ms. Heuer said.
This news, she said, also reminded investors of the large number of Merck drugs that lose their patents in 2000 and 2001 and came just after Merck fell short of first-quarter earnings estimates while some rivals were beating theirs. The stock fell 3 7/8, or 3.2 percent, to 116 1/2.
For Sears and American Express, the declines came after they both beat earnings expectations in reports released on Thursday. Sears's loss was less than expected, while American Express's profits rose more than forecast.
Some analysts suggested that Sears was not resolving its credit card delinquency problems fast enough. Sears fell 1 13/16, to 57 9/16.
American Express was harder to explain. Susan L. Roth, financial services analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, said she thought the stock just declined with the overall market, which was led lower by financial stocks.
Banking and other financial stocks have been volatile recently because of speculation about takeovers after the announcement of major banking mergers, including the proposed wedding of Travelers and Citicorp. "The stock is a tough one to interpret because there is so much talk over takeovers," she said. American Express finished off 1 3/16, at 101 7/8.
Kellogg, which fell 1 1/4, to 39 3/4, met forecasts with its earnings of 42 cents a diluted share. But it also said that price cutting in the cereal business would hurt second-quarter earnings.
Walt Disney gave up almost all the gains it made on Thursday, after it posted better-than-expected earnings and a 3-for-1 split late on Wednesday. Yesterday, it dropped 1 9/16, to 122 1/8.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Stocks End Week Lower, Hurt by Earnings Doubts
Anxiety over the health of corporate earnings later this year dragged the stock market down yesterday just days after it hit new highs across the board. Stocks were led lower by Microsoft and Intel in technology, J. P. Morgan and American Express in banking, Merck in pharmaceuticals and Sears in retailing. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average closed at 9,064.62, down 78.71 points for the day and 102.88 points, or 1.1 percent, for the week. D4.
 
Treasury prices rose for the first time this week, lifted partly by the dollar's strength against the yen. The 30-year Treasury yield fell to 5.94 percent from 5.98. D4.
 
Short interest in Nasdaq stocks rose 3.3 percent, to a record 1.99 billion in the month through April 9, reflecting a bet that stocks would fall. But short interest in many large technology stocks declined. D4.
 
Large Loss at Hitachi
Hitachi, Japan's largest maker of electronics, will report a $905 million loss for the fiscal year that ended March 31 to reflect the costs of restructuring its chip business and increasing its pension fund. D3.
 
Nomura, Daiwa and Nikko, Japan's three biggest investment houses, reported bleak earnings results for the latest year because of a racketeer payoff scandal and the prolonged slump in the Japanese stock market. D3.
 
Russia's Economic Course Affirmed
Russian legislative opposition to President Boris N. Yeltsin's choice for Prime Minister collapsed, ending a fractious political brawl and keeping the country on course toward building a free-market economy. A1.
 
Slower Growth in China
China's economic growth slowed to 7.2 percent in the first quarter from 8.8 percent in 1997, for which the Government partly blamed the effects of economic problems elsewhere in Asia. But it said growth would likely increase to an 8 percent rate this year, which Chinese leaders believe is the minimum needed to keep unemployment low. D3.
 
Earnings Gain at U S West
U S West Communications reported a 2.4 percent gain in quarterly earnings to $347 million, or 61 cents a share, on strong sales of Internet services and demand for more phone lines. The results exceeded estimates of 69 cents a share, but the company's stock still ended slightly lower. D2.
 
Regulators Approve Market Merger
The Commodity Futures Trading Commission approved the merger of the New York Cotton Exchange and the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange. The combination forms the second-largest United States agricultural exchange behind the Chicago Board of Trade. D2.
 
Extending Viagra Boon to Women
About 100 scientists from drug companies, academia and the Food and Drug Administration met to discuss how to apply the success of Pfizer's Viagra male impotence drug to women. As every drug company scientist at the meeting realized, if a drug like Viagra is effective in women as well as in men, the market could be doubled. A9.
 
Waste Hauler Expands
Allied Waste Industries said it would acquire the Rabanco Companies, one of the largest waste haulers in the country. Terms weren't disclosed, but the acquisition significantly expands the reach of Allied Waste, which provides collection, disposal and transportation services in 18 states. Its shares rose more than 11 percent, to $26.1875. D2.
 
Financial Sanctions on Yugoslavia
Clinton Administration officials said the United States would seek a freeze on hundreds of millions of dollars in Yugoslav assets held overseas and a stiffer ban on trade with the Belgrade Government as a punishment for ethnic fighting in Yugoslavia that threatens to spill into Albania. A4.

HEADLINE: Layoffs Rupture Tie Between Giuliani and Labor Leader

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
To many New Yorkers, Stanley Hill, head of the giant union representing 120,000 city workers, had long been something of an enigma: He has the power to make mayors quake, yet he had been remarkably docile toward Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and conspicuously silent about the city's much-criticized workfare program.
Until now. 
 All of a sudden, the giant -- some would say, the pussycat -- has stirred. All of a sudden, Mr. Hill, executive director of District Council 37, denounced Mr. Giuliani's workfare program as slavery and went to court to have it declared illegal.
Mr. Hill's abrupt about-face stemmed largely from the Giuliani administration's layoff of 905 public-hospital workers. (The pink slips went out Monday.) And on Thursday, after several days of rising union protests, it led a Mayor not known for backing down to do a pirouette of his own and remove all workfare workers from the public hospitals.
Beyond the somewhat surreal notion of the city effectively laying off people ordered to work for their welfare checks, though, the week's events upset a close relationship between two of the city's most powerful men, a relationship that has made Mr. Giuliani's years in power far less rocky than they might otherwise have been. The rupture in their relationship could make life difficult for the Mayor -- it could mean more lawsuits, poisonous labor negotiations, thousands of grievances filed against the city and Mr. Hill's union campaigning against Mr. Giuliani if he seeks higher office.
To several labor experts, the Mayor's action appeared to be both an olive branch to Mr. Hill and an effort to defuse the union's lawsuit, which charges the city with illegally displacing city workers with workfare participants. On Thursday, the administration denied that withdrawing the workfare workers proved the city had been using them to replace regular workers.
Despite that seeming peace offer, Mr. Hill said that move would not end the feud, insisting, as he had all week, that he would patch things up with the Mayor only if the 905 layoffs were rescinded.
"This is not a bump in the road -- this is a real serious problem," Mr. Hill said. "You're talking about people's livelihoods, people who are going to be laid off. Probably a majority will, after exhausting unemployment insurance, have to apply for public assistance."
In an interview the other day, Mr. Hill offered three reasons for his new combativeness toward Mr. Giuliani and workfare: the Mayor, he said, has gone back on several promises; has failed to fix the flaws Mr. Hill sees in workfare, and has hurt union members with the hospital layoffs, the first suffered by his union under Mr. Giuliani.
The layoffs, the union leader said, were nothing less than a double-cross, given that his union had endorsed Mr. Giuliani in last November's mayoral election and made $600 million in concessions to help balance the city's budget.
"We helped bail out this Mayor when he had a fiscal problem, to the tune of $600 million," Mr. Hill said. "He has not fulfilled his part of the bargain by helping us when we're in need."
The help he gave the Mayor -- in those contract negotiations and in his silence as workfare participants did work once done by union members -- had brought Mr. Hill considerable heat from other union leaders and from his rank and file. The hospital workers were an especially sensitive case: Two years ago, many of them fumed when he left them vulnerable to layoffs by signing a contract that lacked the no-layoff clause provided to other District Council members.
Now, those who even a week ago saw him as cozying up to the Mayor are giving him considerable applause. And that, in turn, has left City Hall suggesting that Mr. Hill attacked workfare not out of principle but to protect his political flanks.
"When we negotiated the municipal labor agreements and all our agreements, Stan has said it over and over again, one thing we always do is keep our word," said Randy Levine, Deputy Mayor for finance and economic development. "Now he's changing his tune because he's in a difficult internal situation."
To Daniel Walkowitz, a labor historian at New York University, Mr. Hill is "trying to save face."
"He's never shown a profound understanding of workfare in the past, and he's never shown a willingness to break with the Mayor," Mr. Walkowitz added. "What he has shown is his sense that the union's interest is best tied to the Mayor. This is the first time that balance has seemed to shift."
Still, anyone who knows Mr. Hill well knows he is a proud man who takes the notion of trust very seriously. After tens of thousands of city workers were laid off in decades past, Mr. Hill was proud that no District Council 37 members had been laid off under Mr. Giuliani.
Now, he says he is angry that Mr. Giuliani breached a relationship of trust -- a trust that Mr. Giuliani's administration worked assiduously to develop beginning in its first year. According to city and union officials, Mr. Giuliani told Mr. Hill his door was always open, while Mr. Levine, the Mayor's first Labor Commissioner, spent scores of hours with Mr. Hill and other union officials to cement their ties. In addition, the Mayor's staff took pains not to renege on its word in any negotiations.
Mr. Giuliani's aides were mindful of Mr. Hill's rupture with former Mayor David N. Dinkins. Mr. Hill, whose union played a major role in electing Mr. Dinkins in 1989, felt betrayed when Mr. Dinkins laid off hundreds of park workers.
During the interview this week, Mr. Hill did little to hide his anger, repeatedly accusing the Mayor of lacking good faith and breaking various laws and agreements.
The Mayor, he asserted, is violating a state law that bars communities from using workfare participants to displace city workers. The Mayor, he said, is violating a promise to provide the 34,000 workfare workers with training that leads to permanent jobs. The Mayor, he argued, violated a promise to exhaust all alternatives before public hospital workers were laid off. "I don't want to get personal with the Mayor, but I don't think the Mayor has followed through in good faith the way he has in the past," Mr. Hill said.
Norman Adler, a Democratic political consultant, explained Mr. Hill's concern this way: "My own sense from conversations with Stanley is he thought they'd go through the year 2001 without seeing layoffs, especially in light of the city's good financial situation."
Mr. Hill said that with the city enjoying a nearly $2 billion surplus, the layoff decision was political, not economic. "He's got a national agenda," Mr. Hill said. "He's showing people he can be tough."
Mr. Levine called that nonsense, asserting that the layoffs had been carried out not by the Mayor but by the Health and Hospitals Corporation, which runs the public hospitals. "There hasn't been one city worker who's been laid off," he said. "There have been layoffs in H.H.C., but everyone understood there might have to be because its hospitals were overstaffed and underutilized."
Mr. Levine insisted that as an alternative to layoffs, the city had proposed buying out the hospital workers or redeploying them to other departments -- proposals he said Mr. Hill rejected. Mr. Hill said the city had made no such proposals.
Mr. Levine also denied that workfare was displacing city workers.
Earlier this month, in a series of articles on workfare, The New York Times reported that many workfare participants -- in the hospitals and in other agencies -- were doing work once done by civil servants. In an interview for that series, Mr. Hill had also denied that workfare participants were displacing city workers.
But this week, he acknowledged that he had already concluded back then that such displacement was going on. He said he had long shied away from publicly criticizing workfare because he was negotiating behind the scenes with City Hall to improve the program. The lack of progress in those talks, he said, coupled with the hospital layoffs, caused him to turn against workfare.
"I have no choice but to come in hard," he said, "because the Mayor has violated the law and violated something else we've had for years: good faith and good communication."

HEADLINE: Iran Nearly Got A Missile Alloy From Russians

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON with ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, April 24

 BODY:
A truck laden with 22 tons of stainless steel that could be used to make missiles has been intercepted on its way to Teheran, raising new questions about Russia's determination to end assistance to Iran's missile program.
American officials warned the Russian authorities several days in advance that a shipment of steel, which they said was a special alloy particularly suited for use in making fuel tanks for Scud missiles, was expected to leave Moscow, based on United States intelligence reports. 
 But the Russians say that the American information was not detailed enough and that they were unable to stop the truck in time. It was impounded late last month after leaving Russia when customs officials in Azerbaijan stopped it from crossing the border to Iran.
Russia's failure to stop the shipment has become an issue in a broader debate about Moscow's promise to clamp down on the sale of missile technology to Iran.
President Boris N. Yeltsin issued a decree in January tightening controls on the export of missile-related technology to Iran. Moscow insists that it is doing its best to prevent the seepage of such technology to Iran and that the Americans are too quick to politicize the issue.
But American officials say troublesome cases still remain. "It would not be accurate to say they are stonewalling us," an American specialist said. "But it is a hard issue for them, technologically and politically. They want to preserve a relationship with Iran. Some of the cases have gone away, but others remain on the table for us to discuss."
The issue has important military implications for the Middle East, where Israel has expressed alarm that it may soon be within the range of Iranian missiles.
It is also emerging as the major obstacle in the already frayed American-Russian relationship.
American lawmakers have threatened to impose economic sanctions on Russian enterprises or institutions that aid Iran's missile program if Russia does not fulfill its pledges to block the assistance. But the Clinton Administration strongly opposes that step, saying it would disrupt sensitive discussions between Washington and Moscow.
"It's a very serious problem for our relationship with Russia and for the security of the region," Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the majority leader, said in an interview this week. He said the Senate would vote next month on a resolution to impose sanctions "if there's not major progress made in the next 30 days."
The United States has long been anxious about Moscow's close ties with Teheran. Washington has complained that Russia's plans to sell Iran up to four nuclear reactors will make it easier for the country to carry out a clandestine program to develop nuclear weapons, allegations that Moscow rejects.
But the flow of Russian technology to Iran's missile program has also been a cardinal worry.
Iran has begun a program to build a missile dubbed the Shahab 3, which has a range of about 800 miles -- more than twice the range of a Scud missile and long enough to reach Israel, Saudi Arabia and Turkey. The missile is based on a North Korean design, but Iran has also turned to Russia to develop the technology.
But the key question is whether Russia is cracking down as promised.
"The 13 cases which our American colleagues have so nicely informed us of have been considered, and we have provided detailed explanations," said Yuri Koptev, the head of Russian Space Agency and the top Russian official on the missile issue, earlier this year. "In the cases where we saw some doubtful aspect, these contacts were severed."
But when Robert Gallucci, the special American envoy on the missile issue, met with Russian officials this week, a number of cases remained unresolved. American officials, for example, are concerned that Iranians are still receiving training in propulsion and guidance technology at Baltic State Technical University in St. Petersburg and perhaps at the Moscow Aviation Institute.
The Russians have yet to complete their investigations of enterprises called Polyus, which is suspected of providing navigation and guidance technology to Iran, and Ni Grafit, which makes material used to coat ballistic missile warheads. A shipment of the material from Ni Grafit was intercepted by the Austrians on its way to Iran.
The Russians have taken some steps. The Government has expelled an Iranian student who was trying to buy missile technology and intervened to cancel an Iranian contract with NPT Trud, which makes missile engines.
American officials say the case is more important as a political test of Moscow's will to act than for its military implications.
American lawmakers, who have been briefed on the steel incident, portray it as an example of Russian incompetence or duplicity. Russians say the critics are insensitive to the difficulties of preventing smuggling in a vast and unruly nation.
The case began when American intelligence learned about the plan to smuggle stainless steel to Iran. The steel can resist high temperatures, and Americans experts say they believe that the Iranians intended to use it to make fuel tanks for Scud missiles. American sources say it was to be transported by company called Moso.
American officials alerted Russian intelligence in March that the steel was to be shipped. But American officials concede that they did not know all the details.
The truck left Moscow several days later for the long drive to Iran and managed to get out of Russia successfully.
Azerbaijan notified the United States on March 26 that its customs officials had detained the truck at Astara on its border with Iran.
Officials in Azerbaijan say the shipping documents misrepresented the type of steel. The shipper was identified as Europalas-2000, which American officials say was a front company.
A sample of the steel was sent to the Americans for analysis. After Azerbaijan stopped the shipment, the Russian authorities arrested three men from Tajikistan in connection with the smuggling effort.
One American specialist said the case was complex.
"It is not clear that we directed the Russians to the right place," he said.
But Congressional critics are likely to ask why customs officers in Azerbaijan were able to stop the shipment when the Russians failed.
Two Senators who met with senior Russian officials on a trip to Moscow earlier this month came away with different impressions on Russia's role in the steel seizure case.
Senator Orrin Hatch, the Utah Republican who heads the Judiciary Committee, said the Russian Government "could have done better," but in general "jumped right on" the case. Senator Hatch said the problems with Russian cooperation stemmed form the fact that the Russian Government was in a state of disarray after Mr. Yeltsin's decision to dismiss his Cabinet a month ago.
But Senator Gordon Smith, an Oregon Republican on the Foreign Relations Committee, had a more skeptical view. "They held up this incident as an example of cooperation on the proliferation issue," he said. "However, it is important for us to verify with whom they are cooperating, the U.S. or Iran."

GRAPHIC: Map of Azerbaijan showing location of Astara: A truckload of missile-grade Russian steel was stopped at Astara. (pg. A4)

HEADLINE: On Workfare or in Union, Mourning Over Lost Jobs

BYLINE: By IAN FISHER 

 BODY:
For the last three months, Paula Delinois, 32, has shown up at Queens Hospital Center at 10 A.M. to work for her welfare check. She registered patients at the clinic and learned how to use the computers. She had hoped it would lead to a full-time job. But like 1,000 other workfare workers in hospitals around the city, she was told on Thursday that her assignment was over.
For the last 25 years, Catherine Washington, 56, has worked as a regular nurse's aide at Harlem Hospital Center. Since she was told she would be laid off on May 1, friends have told her not to bother picking up the plaque waiting for her at the personnel office to mark her years of service. But she still wants it. 
 "I worked hard to get it," Ms. Washington said. She is upset about many things after so much time at Harlem Hospital, but one detail stands out: "Management has not come to face us and say, 'Well, we're sorry.' They didn't say anything."
Ms. Delinois and Ms. Washington are the two faces of the turmoil at New York City's public hospitals. The dismissals have affected roughly equal numbers of union and workfare workers, mostly women, many from the same neighborhoods, who labored side-by-side in the hospitals with a mutual mixture of suspicion and understanding.
This week, both groups were told they had to leave. On Monday, layoff notices went out to 905 paid union workers like Ms. Washington. Then on Thursday, facing a lawsuit that claimed the city was using workfare employees like Ms. Delinois to do the tasks of union employees, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani ordered roughly 1,000 workfare workers out of the hospitals.
In interviews yesterday with both laid-off hospital employees and workfare workers -- at the end of a week of increasing bitterness between the angry unions and the Giuliani administration -- it was clear that neither group was happy about leaving the hospitals.
Regular workers mourned their jobs; some welfare workers mourned the expectation of permanent jobs.
Both sides said that, contrary to the Mayor's long denials, workfare workers had been used to perform jobs currently or formerly handled by unionized workers.
And both sides also said they believed unequivocally that the quality of patient care would decline as nearly 2,000 workers leave the public hospital system within a week.
"Are they going to hurt patient care?" asked Donna Alonzia, 35, who has worked at Harlem Hospital since 1988 as a nurse's aide and was among those laid off. "Who is going to take care of them?"
As an example, Ms. Alonzia said, the city may be able to get by with fewer nurse's aides -- nearly all of whom at Harlem Hospital were laid off -- but the work force will be stretched so thin that patients will go unwashed, unfed and with dirty linen for longer than they do now. And there will be fewer workers around in emergencies.
"We do everything," she added. "Who is going to be there when that patient goes into cardiac arrest?"
City officials said the layoffs were necessary because of a steep decline in the use of the 11 public hospitals, causing what they said was vast overstaffing, particularly at Harlem Hospital.
On Thursday, Mr. Giuliani took that argument to an extreme, saying he would also remove the 1,000 workfare workers to prove that the hospitals are so overstaffed that they can do without both the laid-off employees and the welfare workers.
And, mayoral aides argued, the quality of patient care would not be diminished, as they combined jobs and worked toward what they said were needed efficiencies.
"As far as the future is concerned, the public hospitals will continue to provide high-quality care in a cost-effective and accountable way," said Jane Zimmerman, a spokeswoman for the City Health and Hospitals Corporation, which manages the public hospital system.
Mr. Giuliani's removal of the welfare workers came in reaction to a lawsuit filed by District Council 37, an umbrella organization that represents more than 120,000 municipal workers. The lawsuit claimed that the layoffs were illegal because the Mayor intended to replace regular employees with workfare workers.
City officials said this week that given the skills of many people laid off -- 150 of them were doctors or nurses -- such a replacement could not have been their plan.
But in the interviews yesterday, there was no disagreement among either the laid-off or workfare workers that in many cases, they were doing the same jobs.
"When they knew I was there they went to the bathroom, they went to McDonald's," said Ms. Delinois, who registered patients entering the Queens Hospital's clinics. "They did what they wanted to do because I was doing what they were paid to do."
But, in support of one of Mr. Giuliani's several rationales for the workfare program, several workfare workers in the hospitals said they believed that they were learning skills they could use elsewhere, but they were upset that it would not be at the hospitals.
"I learned computers," said Josianne Trahan, 45, a workfare worker who had been at Queens Hospital for about a year. "I mingled with doctors. I learned about psychiatry.
"I was in process of maybe being hired as permanent," she added. "We felt we're able to do the job."
The biggest difference between the two groups is what comes next. The workfare workers are now back at home, looking for jobs, awaiting their next assignment, or both.
The unionized workers are attending rallies, fighting for their jobs and figuring out how they will survive without their paychecks.
Yesterday, several hundred attended a seminar sponsored by the city on resume writing skills and how to apply for unemployment.
"I feel bad," said Debra Toran, 50, who has worked as a nurse's aide at Harlem for nearly 30 years. "I can't believe it."

HEADLINE: Cuts as Political Art

BYLINE: By DAN BARRY 

 BODY:
In the political petri dish of City Hall, inhabitants learn to communicate in ways that do not always translate well beyond its walls. What is said is not always what is meant; what is meant is not always said.
Yesterday, for example, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani presented a $34 billion executive budget that proposed significant cuts to the library system and to his Department of Cultural Affairs. Such cuts would seem particularly ruthless when the Mayor has been blessed with a record-breaking surplus of $2 billion and when he is also proposing to use taxes to build "stadia" -- the favored City Hall term for stadiums -- including one for a wildly profitable baseball team that now finds its Bronx home somewhat inconvenient. 
 Mr. Giuliani's proposed cuts to the "culturals" -- another City Hall term -- may indeed say something about his priorities, or how he feels about the people he dismisses as typical liberals. But the advocates and City Council members who self-righteously denounced the cuts knew the truth also known to the Mayor, but which no one verbalized for the benefit of the public: The fight over the "culturals" is political Kabuki.
"Cutting libraries and culture is a ritualistic maneuver between the Mayor and the Council," Councilman Archie Spigner said yesterday evening. "I'm in my 25th year on the Council and it has always been that way, whether it was a Democratic mayor or a Republican mayor. The Mayor proposes the reduction and the Council makes restitution. It's the reality of politics. I don't think the Mayor is serious."
These reflections from the Democrat from Queens were especially refreshing, given that just a few hours earlier he used a microphone to denounce the Mayor's proposal to cut about $16 from the libraries and more than $20 million from cultural affairs. "This likely will result in reduced services and possibly a reduction in hours of operation at local branches," he said, "and will be particularly harmful to our children."
Councilman Stanley E. Michels, a Democrat of Manhattan, then seized the lectern and the moment to equate the library system with Ellis Island. "The library has always been a refuge in this city, for all people in all boroughs," he said. "It has been a means to integrate people with our culture. It was a supreme tool for melting pot, the great mosaic. For us to target the library, of all things, is really shameful."
At the same time, the strange ritual helped the Mayor to hold himself out as the leader who has to make tough choices -- even in times of plenty. Mr. Giuliani said that he planned to withhold an additional $5 million that he would turn over if the library system was able to raise a matching amount from private sources.
"This is a good thing to do for them," he said. "They're just not going to see it that way right away. About four or five years from now, when they start doing their private funding, and they're able to put even more money in the libraries and they're not totally dependent on the city, they're going to really be very thankful."
Silence, rather than thankfulness, was the response of library officials around the city.
But Schuyler G. Chapin, the cultural affairs commissioner, acknowledged last night that the annual ritual comes at a cost: "It's always a very trying time of year."
In the end, what does this say about Mr. Giuliani? Mr. Chapin and Randy M. Mastro, the Deputy Mayor for operations, are quick to point out the financial support that the Giuliani administration has given to a number of educational and cultural programs, from $125 million to Project Read, a literacy program for third graders, to $50 million to Project ARTS, which pays for an arts curriculum in the city's schools.
"There are dozens of pieces to a budget, and they're integrated into a whole," Mr. Mastro said in defending the proposed cultural cuts. "To isolate one or two pieces is to not appreciate the entire, integrated package -- to insure the city's financial future, to advance economic development, and to see that the city lives within its means."
In fact, Peter F. Vallone, the speaker of the Democrat-controlled Council, agreed that the Republican Mayor's budget "is a good budget," albeit one that needs to be made better.
Still, the prospect of this Mayor proposing cuts to the library system conjures up memories: of those staged moments in which he sits in a library, reading to wide-eyed children; of his heroic rescue of Winnie-the-Pooh earlier this year, when some British lawmaker threatened to remove the doll from a small Manhattan library. This, too, is the Mayor who holds himself out as the anti-politician, loath to participate in typical political gamesmanship.
Herbert E. Berman, the chairman of the Council's finance committee, called the process a "very unfortunate and very misguided annual dance" that causes unnecessary heartache for low-paid employees in the arts and library worlds.
"The exercise is so that the Council has something to sharpen their teeth on, so that we feel satisfied that we've accomplished something," he said. "The hope and the anticipation of the Mayor's office is that we'll focus on that and ignore something else. But it just doesn't work that way anymore."
But it does, yesterday's City Hall experience would suggest.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Playing and Paying: Fans Debate the Issue

BYLINE: By WILLIAM C. RHODEN 

 BODY:
THE City of New York has given its assurances that everything is fine and dandy at Yankee Stadium. Now I'm scared: the wolves are guarding the hen house and telling us, "All's clear."
Who are they reassuring? The hens or the other wolves? 
 The Yankees reopened their doors yesterday, 11 days after a 500-pound extension joint crashed through the upper deck and fell on seat No. 7 in Row A of Section 22. Fortunately, Giacamo Turano's seat was empty then. Last night he returned for the game against Detroit, and this time he was joined by George Steinbrenner, the Yankees' principal owner. Steinbrenner sat with the fans in that section for five innings, trying to provide assurances that everything was fine.
Steinbrenner, no doubt, was probably thinking that everything was safe, but not fine. The Yankees still need a new home. You wonder what's next: a stink bomb in the press box? Hamsters in the lavatory? This is not to suggest that the expansion joint that crashed into the seats was anything but an accident. But with Steinbrenner, nothing is beyond suspicion. Especially at a time when his eyes are set on securing a new House That Ruth Built.
In the wake of the accident, the debates and threats surrounding the future of the stadium have been taking an enormous emotional toll on longtime Yankee fans trying to balance nostalgia with pragmatism. Two fans attending last night, Dave and Peggy Garbier, spoke with great passion about the lore and tradition, not merely of the stadium but of its location in the Bronx. Bill Teskey spoke of fears about the common man being shut out by soaring prices to support a greater corporate presence. Joe Cable talked about coming here as a youngster with his dad. Last night, he brought his wife and daughter to the stadium for the first time.
Precisely because of these memories, and the powerful spell they cast, the fans are being held hostage by the Mayor and the Boss. The two of them can shove a new stadium down our throats. If they build a stadium on the West Side, if they move to New Jersey, if they move to Timbuktu, the fans will follow.
"Fans will adjust," Denise Cable said.
"Diehard Yankee fans will go whereever the Yankees are," Joe Cable said. "So, in a way, we are held hostage."
The fundamental question in this hostage situation is who will pay, and how much. "He should pay," Michelle Gubber said of Steinbrenner as she herded her three children to their seats. "If he wants it, he should pay for it."
The Yankees seem destined to have a new home. The Mayor has replaced the late Billy Martin as the Boss's straight man, and the two have formed an alliance to build a new stadium, replete with luxury boxes. The Yankees will become an extension of the Times Square/Disney motif.
The Mayor speaks of the financial benefits of a new home, of how the Yankees and the Mets -- provided they draw like the teams in Cleveland and Baltimore have -- could make the money back in a few years. But a University of Chicago economist, Allen Sanderson, said that it was impossible for cities to earn back the hundreds of millions of dollars they initially spend for a modern baseball stadium.
This is the latest example of politicians and owners trying to strong-arm the public, though there are encouraging signs of resistance.
In Minnesota, the state may proceed with an investigation about whether the Twins and Major League Baseball illegally tried to force it to build the team a new ball park. The issue in that case is whether major league owners are conspiring to pressure fans and public officials into paying for new stadiums, thus giving the owners higher returns on revenue producers like luxury boxes and concession sales.
There is resistance in New Jersey, too, enough to potentially eliminate it as an option for Steinbrenner.
In a recent poll, only 27 percent of New Jersey residents said they wanted the Yankees to move to their state. Nearly half said they wanted the team to stay in New York. Six of 10 residents polled said that Steinbrenner -- not the state or an independent authority -- should pay for a new stadium.
The reality is that the time has probably come for the Yankees to move. The time has come for Steinbrenner to strip-mine somewhere else. He's raked as much as he can get out of the Bronx. Save Yankee Stadium. Better yet, free Yankee Stadium.
Just do it with the Boss's money.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The message on a sign on the side of Yankee Stadium last night tried to quell any fears fans might have had about returning to the Bronx ball park. (Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times)

INTERNATIONAL A3-6
 
In Reversal, Legislature Backs Yeltsin's Candidate
President Boris N. Yeltsin's opponents in Russia's fractious legislature abruptly abandoned their posture of defiance and approved his nominee for Prime Minister, Sergei Kiriyenko, thus avoiding new parliamentary elections. A1 

Russia Shipment to Iran Halted
A truck with 22 tons of stainless steel that could be used to make missiles was intercepted in Azerbaijan on its way to Teheran, raising new questions about Russia's determination to end assistance to Iran's missile program. American officials warned Russian authorities several days in advance that such a shipment was expected to leave Moscow. A1
 
U.N. Resolution on Firearms
The Clinton Administration is co-sponsoring a United Nations resolution aimed at curbing the illicit trafficking in firearms. It is the first time the United States has endorsed a United Nations resolution on firearms, American officials said. A3
 
Sanctions for Yugoslavia
Reacting to warnings that heavy fighting in Yugoslavia was on the verge of spilling over into Albania, Administration officials said the United States would seek a freeze on Yugoslav assets held overseas and a stiffer ban on trade with the Belgrade Government as punishment for the bloodshed in Kosovo. A4
 
Refugees Spark Croat Riot
Croats rioted in a town they dominate in western Bosnia, burning a United Nations police station and setting fire to other buildings in an outburst of anger linked to the return of Serb refugees. Fourteen people were injured, a police officer said. A4
 
Standoff Delays Iraq Debate
A standoff between the United States and Russia apparently derailed plans for a Security Council debate next week on changing the emphasis of the Iraqi nuclear inspection process from active disarmament to a long-term monitoring system, diplomats said. A6
 
Aid Workers Freed in Somalia
Eight aid workers held hostage for 10 days in Somalia were freed along with two pilots held with them. The nine men and one woman were hustled into a jeep and taken to a Red Cross hospital in northern Mogadishu. Later they flew back to their headquarters in Kenya, where they were welcomed by relatives. A6
 
Nuclear Shipment Lands in U.K.
A shipment of nuclear material from Georgia arrived in Britain to be stored at a Scottish nuclear plant. The nuclear material was transported by truck to the remote Scottish plant at Dounreay, the police said. (Reuters)
 
U.S. Veterans Accuse Mexico
A group of American veterans accused the Mexican Army of using American military equipment intended to stop drugsmuggling to intimidate Indians in southern Mexico. The four-member delegation of the group Veterans for Peace said it spent 10 days monitoring military activities in the southern Mexican states of Oaxaca and Chiapas. (AP)
 
NATIONAL A7-10, 16
 
Bomber's Lawyer Faces A Grand Jury Subpoena
Court documents showed that the local grand jury investigating the Oklahoma City bombing wants to subpoena Stephen Jones, formerly the lead lawyer for Timothy J. McVeigh, the convicted bomber who was sentenced to death. Mr. Jones said in an interview that he would refuse to testify, citing lawyer-client confidentiality. A7
 
H.I.V. Infections Stabilizing
The rate at which people are being infected with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, is relatively stable, but new drug treatments are slowing the increase in AIDS cases, Federal health officials said. A9
 
Lowering the Bar on the Surplus
The Congressional Budget Office said that while there would be a healthy surplus this year it would probably be considerably less than the top estimate of $50 billion. A9
 
Early Intervention Programs
A Rand Corporation study of nine early intervention programs for disadvantaged children found that participants in most had higher long-term school achievement than similar children who did not participate in such programs. Some programs helped keep children out of special education and made it less likely that they would become delinquents, spend time in an emergency room or depend on welfare. But most of the programs did not increase I.Q. scores over the long term, improve children's behavior or decrease the odds of teen-age pregnancy or a child's having to repeat a grade. A8

Mr. McLarty, widely known as Mack, also served as chief of staff during his more than five years in the White House. A8

Arrow Air, a cargo airline based in Miami, has agreed to pay fines and restitution of $5 million for flying planes with unapproved parts, Federal prosecutors said. The airline's record includes safety violations, a major crash and a two-month license suspension. A10

HEADLINE: GIULIANI PROPOSES $34 BILLION BUDGET WITH CUT IN TAXES

BYLINE: By NORIMITSU ONISHI 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani proposed a $34 billion spending package for New York City yesterday, setting the stage for a fight with Peter F. Vallone, the Speaker of the City Council, over which taxes to cut and whether to use city money to help build two new baseball stadiums.
Benefiting from the largest surplus in the city's history, Mr. Giuliani called for a $312 million cut in personal income taxes for city residents over three years. The figure fell short, however, of the $1.4 billion reduction that Mr. Vallone has proposed for the same period. 
 Under the Mayor's plan, the city would provide a married taxpayer an income tax credit of about $40 a year during the next three years, regardless of income. The figure for single taxpayers would be slightly lower. The Speaker's proposal, by contrast, would mean a tax break of $174 a year to the average taxpayer earning between $25,000 and $50,000; for people making more than $200,000, the annual saving would be nearly $1,000.
The Mayor emphasized his readiness to negotiate with Mr. Vallone on the size and nature of the tax cuts as part of a broader discussion on the budget, including the use of a business tax to help finance new stadiums for the Yankees and Mets. And even as Mr. Vallone described his own eagerness to negotiate, he drew the lines of battle.
"No one person dictates what happens in this town," said Mr. Vallone, who is seeking the Democratic nomination for governor and whose City Council has the final say on both the budget and the Mayor's stadium plans. He added: "As for the Mayor's proposal to use the city's commercial rent tax to help fund new stadiums, fine. We'll listen to that."
Aside from his tax proposal, the Mayor hewed to a budget plan he first announced in January. He said he wanted to use most of a $2 billion surplus from the current fiscal year to reduce future budget gaps and a sizable chunk of it to finance law enforcement and educational programs.
He proposed a 10 percent increase for the Board of Education, for a total of $4.9 billion in city money for the public schools, the highest level ever. The money would be used to give the system's 1.1 million students more arts and music classes and after-school programs for intensive reading lessons.
Yet at the same time, Mr. Giuliani called for steep cuts to the city's libraries and cultural institutions.
The Mayor also intensified his criticism of the city's six community colleges, whose standards he has often derided as lax. Holding a notebook in the air as he stood before an audience of several hundred city office workers, Mr. Giuliani threatened to withhold the $110 million that the city provides to the colleges' budgets unless they started taking attendance.
In addition, Mr. Giuliani repeated his wish to continue a commercial rent tax on big businesses below 96th Street in Manhattan; at his urging the Council had previously agreed to phase it out. During the next several years, at least $600 million from that tax would be used to help build new baseball stadiums, including, possibly, a new ball park for the Yankees, in midtown Manhattan on the West Side.
The budget proposal for the next fiscal year, which begins on July 1, also includes $14 million to add new beds for children in foster care and $7.2 million to help the child welfare agency recruit and retain workers.
But some advocates for children complained that the city failed to invest enough money to provide enough day care for the thousands of welfare mothers who must work for their welfare checks. Others saw inequality in a budget willing to give millions to rich business people at the expense of services used by the ordinary New Yorker.
"One beam fell at a stadium, but school buildings are crumbling every day," said Gail B. Nayowith, the executive director of Citizens Committee for Children of New York, a 54-year-old advocacy group. "I don't think in a year where there's a big budget surplus, kids should be traded off against cultural interests or libraries or tax cuts. We have to think bigger. Are we going to rebuild schools or rebuild stadiums?"
As tax revenues keep flowing from the boom on Wall Street, the debate inside City Hall has centered on how to use the city's growing surplus. Yesterday, the debate between the Mayor and Council zeroed in immediately on what taxes to cut -- not on increasing spending on popular programs -- underscoring how much things have changed in a city that once stood as the symbol of generous social programs.
This year's budget dance began on an unusual note, as the Democratic Speaker pushed for far bigger tax cuts than the Republican Mayor.
"There is irony, if you want to say it right, which is that my proposal helps the poor and their proposal helps the rich more," Mr. Giuliani said. "That's an irony, because the stereotype is that Democrats care about the poor and Republicans care about the rich. My proposal is a bigger break to the poorest New Yorkers."
Mr. Vallone's aides disputed the Mayor's statement. They acknowledged that under the Speaker's proposal, the tax breaks grow as income does, but they said the cuts, as a percentage of income, are bigger for working and middle-class taxpayers.
The Mayor's proposal would work by linking the tax break for city residents with a state tax cut approved in Albany last year. The state cut gradually goes into effect in the next four years, and Mr. Giuliani has proposed using city money to fill in the gaps during the next three years. By the fourth year, when Albany will provide all of the cut -- $125 a year to couples, regardless of income -- the city portion of the tax cut will be zero. In effect, New York City's tax break will end.
By contrast, Mr. Vallone's tax reduction, which he first proposed in January, would be permanent. At the heart of his plan is the elimination of a 12.5 percent surcharge for residents on the city income tax that was approved in 1990 to help the city balance its books, and reauthorized in 1991 to hire police officers.
Attaching himself to a tax cut is an important goal for the Speaker, his aides have said. They believe that in a gubernatorial race, Mr. Vallone's legislative record will be scrutinized for any tax increase he has backed.
The Mayor, who has said that eliminating the surcharge would take away too much revenue from the city, wants the surcharge to be renewed at year's end.
Both tax changes would require approval from Albany. But Mr. Vallone seems to have the upper hand, since many believe that he could kill the surcharge simply through inaction.
In his budget, Mr. Giuliani, for whom keeping growth below the inflation rate is important, boasted that city-financed spending would grow by only half of one percentage point. But Mr. Giuliani reached that number by counting the budget surplus, which he uses for next year's expenses, as having been spent in the current year. That artificially depresses the spending rate, but it was not an issue in the past because surpluses were never this large.
Most analysts, however, say the spending is really growing at a few digits above the local inflation rate of about 2.5 percent. The State Comptroller's office and the Independent Budget Office, both of which monitor the city budget, said yesterday that the spending in Mr. Giuliani's proposed budget was actually up by 6 percent.
In general, the Mayor's proposal was received favorably yesterday by government and Wall Street analysts. At the same time, though, some cautioned that because of the $2 billion surplus this year and the $1.4 billion surplus last year, the Mayor was not taking the right steps in correcting inherent problems in New York's budget.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's shadow fell across a chart during his budget presentation for fiscal year 1999 yesterday at City Hall. (Marilynn K. Yee/The New York Times)(pg. B4)
 
Graph: "KEEPING TRACK: After a Pause, Spending Goes Up" shows New York City's operating expenditures each fiscal year from 1982 through a projected 1999. (Source: New York City Office of Management and Budget)(pg. B4)
 
Chart: "SORTING IT OUT: Tax Plans: Base Rates and Surcharges"
 If you earn money in New York City, you probably pay income tax on it. The tax's base rate is 3.1 percent at the lowest incomes and rises to 4.46 percent.
 But many taxpayers who live in the city have been paying more than that since 1990, when city and state officials approved a temporary tax surcharge to help the city balance its books during the recession. These charges, added to the regular tax rates, range from 0.51 percent to 0.55 percent. This surcharge was reauthorized the following year, when violent crime was surging, with the money dedicated to hiring more police officers. It is scheduled to expire at the end of 1998.
 The surcharges are not applied to taxpayers in the lowest brackets. Individuals begin paying when their annual incomes exceed $14,850. For a single head of a household, the starting point is $19,500, and for a married couple filing jointly, it is $28,500.
 The surcharge means that most taxpayers are paying roughly 12.5 percent more in city income taxes, so many government officials refer to it as the 12.5 percent surcharge.
 
The Competing Proposals
 
PETER F. VALLONE, CITY COUNCIL SPEAKER Proposes letting the surcharge expire on schedule at the end of the year. He is also proposing that the base rates be changed.
 
MAYOR RUDOLPH W. GIULIANI Proposes that every city taxpayer get an identical tax credit from the city for three years. In the first year, all individuals would get a credit of $50.50; couples filing jointly would get $113. In the second year, the numbers would drop to $32.50 and $90, and in the third year they would be $17.50 and $40.

HEADLINE: On Language;
The Emerging Word, Actually

BYLINE: By William Safire 

 BODY:
'I have noticed a proliferation of the word actually in telephone conversations," writes Richard J. Durbin, the junior Senator from Illinois. "Without exception it is surplusage and often used to mask deception, as in 'Senator, I'm sorry Mr. Jones cannot come to the phone to discuss your fund-raiser, but actually he is away from his desk on safari.'
"Next to inane voice-mail messages," continues the Senator, "and unconscionable delays before the tape recorder engages, I find this use of the word actually to be the latest scourge of telephone life. Sincerely (actually), Dick Durbin."
He is not asking about the real actually, an adverb meaning "truly, in reality," as used by Thomas Hobbes in his 1651 "Leviathan": "Christ shall come to judge the world, and actually to govern his owne people." Instead, he wonders about what the philologist John Algeo calls a "discourse signal -- a device to relate what the speaker is saying to what someone else has said, or to the situation in which the conversation is carried on." Americans pronounce it with all four syllables and place the discourse signal in the front of a sentence; Britons use it either at the start or, more typically, at the end. 
 H.W. Fowler called it a meaningless word, similar to of course: "The superior-indulgent of course. It seems absurd to tell you but he half-hopes you do not know."
Alistair Cooke, now among the untiring retired, calls them tics, filler words as ubiquitous and unnecessary as I mean and y'know. (Cooke has just been named chairman of Olbom -- On Language's Board of Octogenarian Mentors -- though he insists on calling it OGPU -- Octogenarians Guarding Proper Usage -- because his acronym recalls an old Soviet spy organization.)
But it is not always meaningless. "The British tic," Cooke explains, "can also be used to show that all alone, the speaker has come through a rather difficult personal conflict and made a positive, mature decision, e.g., 'What would you like to drink?' 'I'd like a Scotch, actually."'
The proper use of the word -- in its true, actual meaning -- would go, in Cooke's second example, like this: "What would you like to drink?" "I'll have a Scotch. No, actually, I'd like a martini."
Sometimes the tic is used in mock modesty. To "Do all women succumb to your charms?" the answer might be "They do, actually." Norman Schur, in "British English," notes that the word -- pronounced EK-chill-ee -- may also be used in veiled reproof, as if the speaker feels forced to say it: "Actually, we don't do things that way," or "I was coming to that, actually."
It can be used to mark a contradiction of what the other person has just said. Algeo supplies this: "The director doesn't seem to understand what the play's about." "He's a very good director, actually." Or it can mark the unexpected, vouching for what may seem surprising: "Who won?" "Well, I did, actually."
The Senator from Illinois has asked for a vote. Should we condemn actually as meaningless, overworked and obfuscatory, an affected form of y'know?
No. In its nonliteral form, and when not interjected as mere filler, actually is a subtle device, used differently in British and American English. E. Ward Gilman, editor of Merriam-Webster's Dictionary of English Usage, argues that words like actually often improve the rhythm of a sentence and help set off the more important words effectively." I disagree, and would not use it to smooth the flow of a sentence, because that is "surplusage," to pick up Senator Durbin's legal usage. But I would readily use actually (more in speaking than in writing) as a signal conveying a shade of meaning outside the normal semantic rules.
Like a raised eyebrow, a shrug or a pleased wriggle, actually contributes to understanding the speaker's meaning. For example, what's another way to say "Come to think of it"? Actually. ...
 
EMERGING NATIONS
First they were undeveloped nations. That was a put-down, so they became LSD's -- less developed nations. Still patronizing. Finally emerged emerging nations. Now they're still undeveloped and nobody has emerged, but everybody's happy.
Who dreamed up this latest name? The answer can be found in "Commanding Heights: The Battle Between Government and the Marketplace That Is Remaking the Modern World," by Daniel Yergin and Joseph Stanislaw. (My own next opus will be titled "Subtitling Books: The Desperate Need for Publishers to Explain Everything on the Front Cover.")
In 1979, a Dutch banker named Antoine van Agtmael went to New York to launch what he wanted to call a third world investment fund. Back in bipolar 1952, the sociologist Alfred Sauvy coined tiers monde, "third world," to describe nonaligned nations that wanted to position themselves between the Soviet and Western blocs. (Tiers was chosen rather than troisieme on the analogy of the French tiers etat, "third estate," referring to the commoners.) In time, third world gained a connotation as much economic as political, and was made up mostly of have-not nations.
"No one wants to put money into the third world investment fund," the banker recounts he was told. Write Yergin and Stanislaw: "Underdeveloped markets was a complete nonstarter. Third world wouldn't do. Nor would the World Bank's favorite, developing nations. 'I knew we needed something positive, uplifting, not negative,' van Agtmael said. And by the time he came to work on Monday morning, he had the answer: emerging markets." In 1984, he wrote a book and titled it "Emerging Securities Markets," which didn't sell too well because it had no exhaustive subtitle, but did establish his claim to the coinage (which will stand until I get an earlier written citation).
Commanding heights, by the way, is a military term that was adopted by Lenin. Attacked by militant Communist comrades in 1922 for the New Economic Plan that seemed to turn back toward capitalism, Lenin assured them he was not backtracking. Why? Because the Bolshevik state would still control the strategic sectors of the economy -- what the Marxist leader called the commanding heights. From that we got the command economy, since replaced by the despised market economy.

LENGTH: 1054 words

HEADLINE: Low Jobless Rate Aside, a Lot of Job Hunters

BYLINE: By NANCY POLK 

 BODY:
THOUGH the state's economy is roaring ahead with an official unemployment rate of just 3.8 percent, there are still more than 10,000 managerial, technical and professional workers looking for jobs according to the Department of Labor. Why?
Tony Drapelick, with Drake Beam Morin, an outplacement firm with Hartford and Stamford offices, observed, "This is a unique economy where low unemployment doesn't mean high employment. There is a tremendous amount of churn. Companies are changing, finding new markets, merging, buying and selling. People are a resource. When that resource is not needed you get a big front door and a big back door. A lot of people are leaving and a lot are being hired." 
 He speculated that while the unemployment figure remains fairly constant, there are considerably more people unemployed and then re-employed in one year than indicated.
James K. Smith of Canton has been unemployed for five months. With an undergraduate degree in industrial engineering and a master's in business administration, Mr. Smith is the kind of worker in demand. He described his field as operations financial management.
He said he last worked for Rexam Graphics Inc., a British-owned firm in Massachusetts. The company was reorganized, Mr. Smith's boss was transferred and the section eliminated. He helped to phase out his position over several months. He is over the age of 50. "I think age has been a factor," he said, "but a number of companies are looking for more maturity." He also finds companies want to hire him to do exactly what he did before, but "I want to take on more responsibility, do something new." He uses the Internet to check classified ads but sees the same ads month after month. He belongs to a support group sponsored by the Financial Executives Networking Group in Westport. Members trade biographies, telephone numbers and so on, to help each other find work. "I'm coming out O.K. but I'm not sure it will be in Connecticut," he said.
Some members of Mr. Smith's group are tied to Connecticut. They have children in school or relatives in the state. He himself rejected an offer from a company in Kansas because, he says, he did not want to move for that particular job. Still, he thinks he may leave the state.
Mr. Drapelick says that "today the average job lasts for three years; no longer do we have a job for life." At the same time he finds no one remains unemployed for a long time. "The time to find a new job is cut in half from 3 to 4 years ago," he said. "People are getting jobs at small to medium companies. They're the big drivers in this economy."
Another factor in finding a job in Connecticut can be lack of up-to-date contacts in the state. Sameek K. Ray, the managing director for the Indian operations of Stanley Works was an expatriate for many years. When his company changed its market, Mr. Ray lost his job and returned to Connecticut. He says he is eager to work overseas again, offering fluency in German, French and two Indian languages as well as some Japanese; he was learning Russian when Stanley Works closed the Indian operation. He has been unemployed about a year.
Also over 50, he too suspects age may be a factor. "I get a little discouraged," he said. "With all my experience I wonder why I haven't got a job yet. Then I think it might be age or national origin. In a global economy it might still take a few years for American companies to get that idea."
In a twist, companies have a difficult time finding employees willing to go overseas largely because of working spouses. A Coopers & Lybrand study shows that close to half of expatriates leave their companies within two years of repatriation.
Mr. Drapelick said flatly, "Becoming an ex-pat is a high-risk decision because it's a case of out of sight, out of mind." Mr. Ray said he had written countless letters to corporate chiefs, has a couple of promising opportunities and won't give up. "This has been a retirement and I don't think I like it," he said.
Both Mr. Smith and Mr. Ray have offices at Drake Beam Morin and say they are at work full time seeking new employment.
Peter Swan, who worked for Barnes Engineering selling electro-optical products, left the company in 1987 to form his own and said he had eight good years. Now he is back in the job market, with no luck so far.
"Employers want an applicant to have the exact requirements for a job and preferably experience working for a competitor or a close associate," he said. "They don't want to train or assign a mentor. They want someone to be productive from the first minute." To keep his spirits up, Mr. Swan works out; he says he does two miles every day on the treadmill and sticks to a strict regimen of weight lifting.
Janine Johnson, director of the Fairfield County Information Exchange at the Southwest Area Commerce and Industry Association, said there is always some unemployment when people leave voluntarily or their companies merge. "I sometimes wonder," she said, "how many people have started their own business or joined a start-up company. A large percentage of these businesses fail," she said.
Diane Dawson-Brown, who runs an agency called All the Best People in Hartford (it specializes in communications, marketing and advertising jobs), said she sees "some unemployed people who are very pro-active about finding their next position, typically single Moms or someone without a second income."
"Most major corporations, given the same attributes and skills, look carefully and longingly at a minority candidate," said Ms. Dawson-Brown, adding, "I place as many women as men, but there is an old boys' network."
She faults women for not participating enough in professional associations where they would meet other professionals. She says that when men get together they discuss business and it is a good way to find out about new openings.
Ms. Dawson-Brown finds jobs in her areas are in the middle level of companies. "During the 10 years of the recession it was the middle level employee, $40,000-$65,000, who got downsized," she said. "Now that companies are making money again they need them back because their people are overworked and profits are good again."
She added that she finds top-level executive positions, $100,000 and up, are scarce.

HEADLINE: Winegrowing Entrepreneurs To Cultivate Other Fields

BYLINE: By HOWARD G. GOLDBERG 

 BODY:
TWENTY-FIVE years after the Hargrave Vineyard was established on the North Fork, stimulating the creation of Long Island's modern wine industry, the founders have put it on the market.
The owners, Alex and Louisa Hargrave, are asking for at least $3.3 million for the property, located on Route 48 in Cutchogue. 
 Mr. Hargrave said serious offers were being considered, but declined to give details. Mrs. Hargrave said the couple had hoped to find a buyer who intended to continue the estate's tradition of small-scale production of high-quality wines.
"We would like to have a sense that the buyer won't turn it into a bottling plant," she said. "I would hope that they would have their heart in it."
As a result of the risks the Hargraves took in 1973, many in the wine industry consider Long Island the most prominent and important wine region in the East, with the Finger Lakes in upstate New York ranking second and Virginia third.
The Hargraves asked Marion R. King Realty, an agent in Cutchogue, to screen all inquiries. Their entire property has been put up for sale, including a portion of the wine inventory. It consists of 84 acres, 20 of them under vines; a building housing the salesroom, reception area and stored wine; the fermentation cellar, in another building; several outbuildings, and the Hargraves' rambling house, at the rear of the sprawling property.
The real estate agent has placed advertisements in The New York Times and Newsday, and said she intended to advertise in Wine Spectator. "We've had many calls," she said.
How long have the Hargraves talked about leaving the business? "About 15 years," Mrs. Hargrave said with a laugh. "Actually, it's hard to answer that. Some days you don't want to be in it. Some days you don't want to be anywhere else."
Mr. Hargrave, who is 52 and has long had a scholarly interest in Chinese studies, said he and his wife, 50, wished to turn to other, personal pursuits. "This was a difficult decision in the face of a booming wine market," he said.
Mr. Hargrave, who received an undergraduate degree from Princeton and a master's degree from Harvard in East Asian studies in the 1960's, said he wanted to return full time to his first love. "I'm just exchanging one dusty field for another," he said jokingly.
"I have gotten very involved in historical linguistics," he continued. "For about seven years, I have been writing a detailed comparison of the relationship of archaic Chinese and a number of sister languages. I am doing what is called diachronic comparisons -- that is, between two time periods."
Mr. Hargrave has been squeezing in the work in free moments in the evening, during the day and on weekends, especially in winter, when the vineyard and winery require less time.
"At this point, it has become a much more consuming task," Mr. Hargrave said, "and I would like to put all my energies in it. A vineyard is not for retirement. In fact, it's an Olympic sport."
Hargrave Vineyard defined its intention and limits early on, and since 1980 has produced 6,000 to 10,000 cases, depending on the vintage.
"We could sell everything we make out of the front door," Mr. Hargrave once said. "But then we'd be a tourist winery. We want to be a serious presence in the restaurant and retail market. We aspire to be a petit chateau."
In knowledgeable American wine circles, the Hargrave name, estate and wines have long symbolized the premium quality and rising prominence of Long Island wines. Hargrave wines are found on the lists of prestigious Manhattan restaurants, like the Four Seasons and Lutece, and, on Long Island, of the American Hotel in Sag Harbor, Mirabelle in St. James and Tierra Mar in Westhampton.
The Hargraves, the East End's most Francophile winegrowers, were the first to demonstrate that European grape varieties could be successfully and profitably grown in the island's glaciated soil and maritime climate.
Wine specialists have long observed that Long Island, especially its North and South Forks, seems to share many of Bordeaux's terrain and weather characteristics. The Hargraves planted vines in potato fields and, through trial and error, capitalized on the parallels.
Their successful emphasis on red wines like cabernet sauvignon, cabernet franc and merlot, and on whites like chardonnay, pinot blanc and sauvignon blanc has coincided with New York State's so-called vinifera revolution, which began with the passage of the Farm Winery Act of 1976. That law made it easy and economical for grape growers to start wineries.
Since then vinifera grapes -- the classic European varieties -- have overtaken native American grapes (like Concord and Niagara) and French-American hybrids (Marechal Foch and Seyval blanc) as the wines that have defined the state's wine industry.
The nonviniferas have dominated the state's other wine regions: the Finger Lakes, Hudson Valley and Lake Erie. But largely because of the precedent set by the Hargraves, they have rarely been planted on Long Island.
The Hargraves' Francophile tastes have turned up in the names of many of their wines: Chardonette, their light, tank-fermented chardonnay; Le Noirien, the top-grade pinot noir; Pinot en Blanc, the pinot blanc; Blanc Fume, the sauvignon blanc, and Petit Chateau (the light, nonreserve cabernet sauvignon). They no longer use the name Fleurette, which designated a light-bodied pinot noir.
Their reserve wines, however, do not have French names and are designated by the Hargraves' so-called lattice label, an unusual laser-cut design depicting white garden latticework fronted by a grapevine.
The Hargraves, celebrities on Long Island, are a striking couple. He is 6 feet 6 inches tall; she is diminutive. Mr. Hargrave's conversation and wit have a dry, ironic, mandarin cast, while Mrs. Hargrave's manner is straightforward and vivacious.
The Hargraves come from prominent families. Mrs. Hargrave's paternal grandfather, Norman Thomas, was the Socialist Party's candidate for President six times. In Mr. Hargrave's family, in Rochester, there are lawyers and bankers.
It seems natural that in the east wall of their formal, oak-paneled tasting room, there is a Louis Comfort Tiffany stained-glass window that reproduces a figure from Millet's painting "The Sower."
Looking back to their early East End days, Mrs. Hargrave said: "We were romantics. We thought that there would be time for reading, writing and reflecting early on. That was never the case. Now, Alex wants more time under his vine and fig leaf -- but doesn't want to cultivate them."
