HEADLINE: Q&A: John H. Marburger 3d;
Taking the Reins at Brookhaven Lab

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER 

 BODY:
THERE was to have been a celebration last year of 50 years of advanced science at Brookhaven National Laboratory.
Instead, to borrow a phrase Queen Elizabeth II used to describe a particularly wretched year for England's royal family, 1997 was an annus horribilis for the laboratory, an Energy Department site that began operations in 1947 at 5,300-acre Camp Upton, a former Army base. 
 First came disclosures that radioactive tritium had been leaking undetected for at least 12 years from a fuel storage tank in the High Flux Beam Reactor building, a premier research tool shut down as a result. The Energy Department will decide later this year whether it reopens.
Then, in May, Energy Secretary Federico F. Pena summarily dismissed the lab managers, Associated Universities Inc., for putting science before safety, throwing the lab's 3,100 employees into turmoil. More disclosures about contamination and safety problems followed.
In March a new manager, Brookhaven Science Associates, won a $400 million contract to operate the lab, and John H. Marburger 3d became the new director.
Dr. Marburger, the president of the State University of New York at Stony Brook from 1980 to 1994 and more recently a professor and researcher in optical science there, comes to his new post determined to gain public confidence that the lab can operate safely.
Success or failure here, he said, may decide whether the lab's high science mission can survive. Thus, he has thrown open the doors to neighbors and critics, inviting them to take part in key cleanup decisions.
Yet to be seen, the critics say, is whether Dr. Marburger can maintain a sense that community counts at a Federal Government site where the Energy Department ultimately calls the shots.
Dr. Marburger, 57, a rare blend of scientist and soft-spoken public-relations natural, was born on Staten Island, grew up in Maryland near Washington and graduated with a bachelor's degree in physics from Princeton University in 1962.
He earned a Ph.D. in applied physics from Stanford University in 1967 and was a professor of physics and electrical engineering at the University of Southern California before going to Stony Brook.
He lives with his wife, Carol, in Port Jefferson. They have two grown sons.
Q. In your view, what is the laboratory's mission?
A. The mission of the laboratory is science. The mission is to do basic research on the structure of matter of all kinds and all scales, and to build and maintain and make available large machines that are used for basic scientific and technical studies in many areas of science.
Q. One of the machines is the High Flux Beam Reactor, which is currently closed because of a tritium leak. Should it be reopened?
A. Brookhaven Science Associates has stated its position as being that if the reactor is useful for science, if it is needed for the national science program and if it can be operated safely without negative impact on health or the environment, then it should be operated.
Q. Can it be operated safely?
A. Well, the studies that are currently commissioned by the Department of Energy are supposed to be directed to that end. The Secretary of Energy has asked for an environmental assessment. We are required in our contract to provide a safety assessment and the Nuclear Regulatory Commission is going to do another similar study. So when it comes time for the Secretary of Energy to make his or her decision, there should be a lot of information available about whether or not this reactor can be operated safely.
Q. Do you have a personal view on whether that reactor should reopen?
A. The key words in your question are "that reactor." I know that in general, reactors can be operated safely without negative impacts on health or environment. What I don't know is whether that reactor can be operated safely. It is an older reactor. It is located in a sensitive environment. And it needs to be studied. I need to the results of those studies before I can make up my mind.
Q. We have a Congressman, Michael P. Forbes, Republican of Quogue, and a Senator, Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of Island Trees, who say this reactor should never operate again. Do you have a reaction?
A. They are politicians, and politicians operate in a social dynamic that's different from science. I am a scientist, and I have responsibilities to one of the world's great science facilities here.
Q. You are a scientist, but does this job involve a public-relations aspect you are really not comfortable with?
A. I am perfectly comfortable with the public-relations aspect. I have no problems relating to the public on sensitive issues. That's one of the reasons I am here. I regard myself as part of the Long Island community. I am part of the public too. I care as much about Long Island as I do about Brookhaven National Laboratory.
Q. Some people criticize Brookhaven Science Associates and the Energy Department for giving lip service to the community. Is there any validity in that?
A. Yes and no. I think, unfortunately, the Department of Energy has very structured decision-making processes. The process of environmental impact studies, for example, is highly structured. And I believe that kind of structure makes it very difficult and can be criticized as being somewhat inflexible.
My own approach is to invite the community in to talk with our managers and go over the data we have with them. As the operator, the contractor as it were, to the Department of Energy, I actually have more flexibility than the department does and I can invite people and listen to them, change plans and so forth. So I am looking forward to that. I have invited some people in to work with our people in identifying issues.
Q. Do neighbors have grounds for fear about contamination from the laboratory?
A. Well there certainly has been contamination of the ground water, there is no question about that, and there are plumes of contaminated ground water seeping out underneath the Long Island Expressway and under homes down there that the D.O.E. has already hooked up to county water. That's absolutely an indication that there has been contamination here.
On the other hand, contamination appears to be chemical, not radioactive. There has never been any instances where ground water that has radioactivity in it has exceeded today's very low Federal standards for drinking water. The radioactive part of the concern seems to be quite small. The chemical part is not negligible. It is important to remediate the chemical plumes.
When I go back over the records to try to understand myself what the level of risk might be, I am surprised at how cautious and careful the scientists were about radiation and how careless they were about the chemicals.
Q. So when some people say the amount of radiation from the lab has really been far greater and hasn't been acknowledged, they are simply wrong?
A. Yes, but I like to be extremely careful when I talk to people who have concerns like that. I know that since I am an employee of the laboratory, everything I say could be regarded as self-serving. That's why I personally welcome external regulators or any organization that wants to come and sample the water. There is no data that I would withhold from anybody who was interested in seeing it.
We are not going to be able to do science here in the long run unless we bring the public along with us. We can't stonewall. We are not in a wartime situation where the public will accept almost any hazard. That's not the situation here. We are doing science, and that science mission could be jeopardized by decoupling with the community. That's why it is so important to take these community issues seriously and I really do personally take them very seriously.
Q. You are saying the community could close the lab down.
A. That's true. That's right. In the post-Cold War era, the public has a vastly increased impact on the conduct of science. We still have a national security mission here, but now the security is more related to economic competitiveness.
Q. Energy Secretary Pena is resigning. What would you like from the new Energy Secretary?
A. The thing I would like most right now is enough money to accelerate the cleanup of the laboratory by five years if possible. If I could get the laboratory cleanup done in two or three years rather than seven or eight years, then I think that would help us with the community and we would have a lot easier time convincing the community that we can operate this laboratory in a clean, environmentally sound way.
My first priority is clean up and the interface with the community, and I know that is necessary to continue the science mission. But I also want continued support for the excellent science that is done here. I don't want to lose this talent, which is a resource for Long Island and the nation. Long Island should be proud of the quality of the science that is done here. I'd like to build on that.

HEADLINE: A Rapture for Neglected History

BYLINE: By LORRAINE KREAHLING 

 BODY:
BARBARA GOLDSMITH has always been fascinated by controversial figures who wield exceptional power.
In 1980, her book "Little Gloria . . . Happy at Last," a tale of the custody battle over Gloria Vanderbilt, became a best seller. 
 "Johnson v. Johnson," published in 1987, presented a detailed account of the 1986 courtroom drama between the six children of J. Seward Johnson and his widow over a $500 million estate.
In "Other Powers: The Age of Suffrage, Spiritualism, and the Scandalous Victoria Woodhull," which has just been published by Alfred A. Knopf, Ms. Goldsmith examines the distinctly American odyssey of a 19th-century figure who was both a financial adviser to Commodore Vanderbilt and a carnival clairvoyant.
A woman who had at times accepted money for sex, Victoria Woodhull would go on to share the stage and argue for women's rights with America's premier suffragette, Susan B. Anthony. She would also found her own New York brokerage firm and newspaper and run for President of the United States.
In an interview at the Carlyle Hotel in Manhattan, Ms. Goldsmith said that more than simply paint a portrait of Victoria Clafin Woodhull, she wished to capture a time in our nation's history often passed over by historians.
"There have been 3,000 books written about the Civil War, but Reconstruction is a black hole in American history," Ms. Goldsmith said. "America was expanding and people began hacking out new territory, not only in the land but in their minds."
"Other Powers" depicts a nation being challenged to structure a new economy that could no longer rely on the free human labor provided by slavery. Government was trying to legislate the rights of its new black citizens just as women began to speak out about their own neglected rights.
The "other powers" of the title refers to Americans' turn away from the rigidity of Calvinism and Puritanism for "contact" with the divine. Across the country, revivalist preachers traveled from town to town, drawing huge crowds to tents where they inspired Dionsysian-like frenzies.
It was at such a gathering, Ms. Goldsmith tells her readers, that Roxy and Buck Clafin said they had conceived their daughter, Victoria.
"To women repressed in every way, the release provided by a revival was intense," Ms. Goldsmith writes. "The line between religious and sexual ecstasy was often crossed in the excitement."
Ms. Goldsmith said it made sense that women sought spiritual guidance outside the male-dominated religious establishments.
"Women were considered men's property," she said. "Sex was on demand from their husbands, who could beat them without fear of reprisal.
"If a woman worked, her wages went to her husband. If she divorced, she lost custody of her children. A woman could not testify in court or serve on a jury. And, of course, women could not vote."
"Other Powers" tells how Americans, particularly women, also had begun consulting Ouija boards and holding seances to communicate with the dead.
"One in two infants died, and women were the caretakers of the sick and dying," Ms. Goldsmith said. "Contact with their departed loved ones comforted women and made the harsh realities of daily life more bearable."
Through real-life stories, "Other Powers" shows how 19th-century Spiritualism undermined the antimaterialistic bias of Calvinism and the Puritan notion that the purpose of sex was exclusively procreative.
One of the main players in the drama is the minister of Plymouth Church in Brooklyn, Henry Ward Beecher, brother of Harriet Beecher Stowe, the abolitionist author.
The downfall of Victoria Woodhull, who had been accused in the press of being a "free lover," was set off largely by her miscalculated public challenge of this very popular minister, a pillar of the Establishment. She urged him to admit that he was living out the gospel of love he preached by having numerous adulterous affairs with his female parishioners.
"Calvinism changed," Ms. Goldsmith said. "So that Henry Beecher could preach God is love. Love is God. You yourselves are gods. Money is good.
"Of course, then as now, there was a disparity between the ideal image a public figure projected and their all-too-human reality," Ms. Goldsmith said.
Before she began writing social history in 1974, Ms. Goldsmith worked as a journalist. Following her graduation from Wellesley College, she wrote celebrity profiles for "The Woman's Home Companion."
"When I was 21 I was put on a plane to interview Clark Gable," she said, "and I had to write 4,000 words on Clark Gable."
Cary Grant, Audrey Hepburn, Alan Ladd and Danny Kaye were among her other early subjects.
Ms. Goldsmith also wrote for McCall's Magazine, The New York Herald Tribune and The New York Times. In 1968 she worked with Clay Felker to start New York Magazine, she said. She later became an adviser to the Hearst Corporation and senior editor at Harper's Bazaar.
Ms. Goldsmith conceded that there was an uncanny parallel between the use of sexual scandal as a political weapon in 19th-century politics and contemporary politics. She said that in both cases it seemed to divert the attention of elected officials away from important issues.
Ms. Goldsmith is a longtime trustee of the New York Public Library, and she said her love for books, history and scholarship had been a lifelong passion.
"My grandfather was a doctor, and we had a wonderful library, and I was a lonely kid, and I read my way through his library," Ms. Goldsmith said. "My father was a history buff and every dinner would be a history quiz. I later inherited all of his history books."
In 1988, through a foundation set up with money from the estate of her father, Joseph I. Lubin, who was the chairman of the board for the Pepsi-Cola Company, Ms. Goldsmith endowed the Goldsmith Preservation Libraries of the New York Public Library with $1 million.
The author said that the time she spent working with the library's rare books and manuscripts was unusually satisfying for her.
"To go into the preservation lab, I say it is like my 'Breakfast at Tiffany's,' " Ms. Goldsmith said. "I love the scent of the aging volumes and I love the silence."
A striking example of the benefits of the New York Public Library's vast antique collection was its ability to supply concrete evidence of the residences of Polish Jews before World War II.
"We had the only copies of the City of Warsaw telephone books," she said. "After the war it was the only way Jews could get reparation claims."
Recognizing the threat posed by the steady deterioration of most paper, Ms. Goldsmith's spearheaded a movement 15 years ago to limit the use of paper containing acid.
Today, thanks to pressure from publishing professionals and authors organized by Ms. Goldsmith, all trade hardcover books and important United States-Government documents are printed on acid-free paper. This will increase their life span from 50 years to 300 years, Ms. Goldsmith said.
The author has made another kind of pledge to protect written words that might otherwise be lost. In 1987 she founded the PEN Freedom to Write Award, which goes annually to an imprisoned writer or writers.
"The newspapers and other media have so cooperated that we have succeeded in getting most of these people who would have been disappeared or killed, out of jail," Ms. Goldsmith said.
Writers from 22 countries, including China, El Salvador, Indonesia, Kenya, Syria and Vietnam have been recipients.
In her own work, the author said she had tried to focus on careful research and objective reporting, and that she had been surprised by the popularity of her books.
"I work very hard to document everything," Ms. Goldsmith said. "I always wrote a book as honestly and as best I could. I never really expected that I would have a large audience."
A decade of research and writing went into "Other Powers." Ms. Goldsmith said she measured the success of any book by whether or not readers felt they had entered the world created by the author.
"I want readers to feel like they have stepped right into this age," Ms. Goldsmith said. "I want them to see the tobacco juice on the floor or the velvet on the walls of Victoria's house, things we actually know were there."
Reviewing the book in The New York Times, Richard Bernstein wrote, "Ms. Goldsmith keeps interpretation to a minimum. The most conspicuous elements of her book are the richness of its narrative, the complex and morally nuanced portraits of its characters and the author's tendency to present the little-known facts without judgment so readers can decide for themselves."
In the years of work on "Other Powers," Ms. Goldsmith said she sometimes felt overwhelmed by the prospect of organizing the research, books and documents that filled her offices, both at her Park Avenue apartment and in her East Hampton home.
"Writing 'Other Powers' was like being held under water for 10 years," Ms. Goldsmith said. "I really began to live in that age, so that I would go to dinner parties and have very little conversation. I would be on automatic pilot all the time."
The author said that when she was at her home in East Hampton and was frustrated by her work, she often retreated to the backyard hedge with pruning shears.
"When the writing isn't going well, I love to attack the privet," Ms. Goldsmith said. "I have this forest of privet in the backyard, and I go out and attack the privet."
She also spoke to her friend and former editor at Knopf, Robert Gottlieb, about the daunting task of pulling together the research for "Other Powers."
"I told him, 'Bob, I have enough material for 10 good books,' " Ms. Goldsmith recounted. "And he said, 'Well, if you only have enough material to write one book, you probably shouldn't be writing it. A good book is what's left because you have made the informed decision to throw everything else away.' "

GRAPHIC: Photo: Barbara Goldsmith, author and social historian, in her Manhattan home, before a Larry Rivers painting. (Jack Manning/The New York Times)

LENGTH: 1363 words

HEADLINE: Sue Kelly: An Upstart Settling In

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

DATELINE: KATONAH

 BODY:
HER detractors reside on both sides of the aisle, with many Democrats viewing her as a Newt Gingrich clone and some in the conservative wing of the Republican Party, her own party, rejecting her as a liberal. What no one disputes -- not even her supporters or Representative Sue W. Kelly herself -- is that the Congresswoman from the 19th District has been a controversial figure on Capitol Hill, especially when it comes to environmental matters.
But Mrs. Kelly, who is in her second term, insists that those who vilify her as a foe of the environment and a turncoat in office have misread her campaign promises. "I am exactly who I represent myself to be," said the 62-year-old Mrs. Kelly -- a fiscal conservative and social moderate -- recently from her district office here. 
 In her race to return to Congress for a second term, she was challenged in the Republican primary by Joseph J. DioGuardi, a former two-term representative who called her a "Democrat in disguise" with liberal views on abortion and gay rights.
But Mrs. Kelly, a former real estate broker, advocate for women's health issues and junior high school teacher, has provoked the most ire among environmentalists.
"In the 19th Congressional District, which has a long and illustrious history of giving green leadership to the nation, Sue Kelly is a disappointment," said Robert F. Kennedy Jr., one of Mrs. Kelly's most outspoken critics and the chief lawyer for the Riverkeeper, an environmental group in Garrison. "Unlike her predecessor, Mrs. Kelly is out of touch with her constituents."
The predominantly Republican 19th District covers part of White Plains and all of Westchester north of White Plains as well as Putnam County and parts of Orange and Dutchess Counties. For nearly three decades before Mrs. Kelly was elected, the district was represented by Hamilton Fish Jr., a moderate Republican with a strong environmental record.
Mrs. Kelly initially angered supporters in the environmental community during her first year in Washington when she voted for bills they believed would eviscerate existing laws -- especially those that benefited the Hudson Valley. The final straw, many environmentalists said, was Mrs. Kelly's support of revisions to the landmark 1972 Clean Water Act.
Referring to H.R. 961, the packet of changes that some environmentalists nicknamed the Dirty Water Act, she said, "I saw this as a way to bring money to New York, but it set the stage for people mistaking my position on the environment." Mrs. Kelly said she disagreed with language in the revisions that could sharply reduce protected wetlands but supported the package because it would bring $1 billion in Federal funds to the state for improvements like upgrading sewage-treatment plants.
Admittedly naive and politically unseasoned in the beginning, the Congresswoman said she learned the first of many difficult lessons that year.
"It took me a while to settle in," she said. "There was so much legislation coming so fast in those first 100 days, and I didn't have the historical perspective on it."
Despite her good intentions, a firestorm exploded at home. Her detractors picketed Mrs. Kelly's district office here, faxed letters to newspapers and spurned her invitation to them to serve on an ad hoc advisory committee, which she was forming. Even though she said she never strayed from pledges made as a candidate, groups like the Hudson Riverkeeper Fund and the Sierra Club railed against her as a traitor.
"I told people that what you see is what you get," Mrs. Kelly explained then.
"I signed the Contract With America, and I'm an environmentalist. As far as I can see, I haven't done anything off that message."
As she began to tap into the heart of her constituency, "the cacophony calmed down," Mrs. Kelly recalled recently.
Perhaps most meaningful to the voters at home was her vote for a law authorizing $17.5 million in Federal funds toward the acquisition of Sterling Forest in Tuxedo, N.Y.
The Congresswoman also gained the endorsement of the New York League of Conservation Voters by stating in a questionnaire that she supported so-called green -- and un-Republican -- causes like eliminating giveaways of Federal mining and grazing rights, improving gas mileage in cars and preserving wetlands.
This year, the Washington-based League of Conservation Voters, a political arm of a national environmental coalition, rated her among the most improved members of the House of Representatives. The group gave Ms. Kelly a score of 81 of a possible 100 points for her record last year, compared with a score of 58 in the 104th Congress the year before.
It may, however, have been but a brief respite from criticism. Early this month, representatives of local, regional and national environmental groups held a news conference on the banks of the Hudson River at Croton Point Park to protest House Bill 1704, which Representative Kelly introduced recently.
The bill, known as the Congressional Office of Regulatory Analysis Act, would establish an office with a yearly budget of $35 million to review new regulations to determine their impact on business and the economy. Environmental groups called the proposal a thinly veiled and costly initiative to elevate industry profits above health and safety concerns.
"Mrs. Kelly's record on the environment has been very, very inconsistent," said Jeffrey D. Fullmer, state program director for the Citizen's Campaign for the Environment, a statewide nonprofit advocacy organization. "Her actions often belie her words."
Paul J. Elston, chairman of the New York League of Conservation Voters, said that despite the Congresswoman's earlier turnaround on matters of open space, clean water and the Hudson River, "skepticism and concern continued in the environmental community." He added, "Good performance in the past is not an excuse for poor performance today."
Calling it a stealth attack on environmental laws, Mr. Kennedy said the bill had "nothing to do with good government and lots to do with the jingle jangle of industry money."
In response, Mrs. Kelly said the new office would have no authority to stop or amend any regulation, but it would advise Congress on regulatory matters.
As the lawmaker said during a recent interview, "I'm going to continue to do what I went down to Washington for, and that's to create a smaller, smarter government."
For her part, Mrs. Kelly said Mr. Kennedy, who lives in the 19th District, was "sparring on a partisan basis" because he wanted her job.
Mr. Kennedy denied having designs on a Congressional seat. "The easiest thing is for a politician to imply that there is a motive," he said. "But the fact is that it's a bad law, and there's no defense for it."
In contrast to those who oppose her, supporters of Mrs. Kelly say she is a pro-environment lawmaker, a hard worker and committed to representing her constituency.
"We're neighbors in Congress and have worked together on many issues, like Sterling Forest and the Hudson River," Representative Benjamin A. Gilman, a Republican from the 20th District, said. "I have a high regard for Sue."
Mr. Gilman called Mrs. Kelly's record on the environment good and suggested the flap would die down in time. "As all new members, she has been the subject of criticism," he said.
Charles I. Keane, the former director of the Museum of the Hudson Highlands near West Point, praised Mrs. Kelly's work on behalf of the Hudson River's shoreline and Manitou Marsh on the east bank of the river north of the Bear Mountain Bridge. "I'm not political," Mr. Keane said. "I'm a biologist mainly. But Sue Kelly helped us obtain funds for a Hudson River restoration project. She has been one of the moving forces."
Representative Kelly said that she often wearies of the criticism. "I've fought for these causes authorization by authorization and appropriation by appropriation," she said, adding that she is and always has been a steward of the Hudson River, clean water and open spaces. "It's like asking, 'When did you stop beating your wife?' " she said. "They're casting me in an unfair light, and it has made me very unhappy."

HEADLINE: More State Aid Helps Schools Prepare for Vote

BYLINE: By MERRI ROSENBERG 

 BODY:
PERHAPS it is El Nino, or maybe it is the spillover from Wall Street's largesse, but for the first time in many seasons most school districts are in the surprising situation of looking at increased state aid from Albany to bolster the 1998-99 school budgets, which will be presented to voters on May 19. Most residents will be asked to vote on local school spending that day, with a few exceptions, including Yonkers -- one of the cities that does not vote on school budgets -- and the special-act districts in the county.
Under current state law, school districts may present budgets to voters twice. Should the budget be defeated on its second vote, districts are obligated to adopt a contingengy, or austerity, budget. Austerity budgets can now include funds for things like interscholastic athletic programs and extracurricular activities. 
 For the most part, the proposed budgets -- devised by district superintendents and business managers, boards of education and citizen budget committees -- reflect a partnership, which is focused on curriculum, program and student needs. And in marked contrast to some recent budget seasons, where contentious and well-organized opposition to proposed budgets divided communities, a changing political and economic climate seems to have gained supporters. Even with relatively modest tax-rate increases -- with most falling within the 2 to 5 percent range -- districts are seeking to enhance their programs even as they plan for increased enrollment.
There are some exceptions -- notably Greenburgh Central 7, Blind Brook, and Katonah-Lewisboro -- where the spending increases and tax-rate increases either hover near or exceed 10 percent, but for the most part, this is shaping up as a very different sort of budget season.
"It has been an interesting year," Dr. Donald R. Kusel, Superintendent of the Tarrytowns public schools, said. "It's as if everybody wants to outdo everybody else in helping education. I like what we're hearing about support for education. It's important to have viable public education."
So in Edgemont, for example, where voters will decide on a $22.1 million budget that will increase taxes by 3.68 percent, program enhancements will include an enrichment teacher to extend classroom challenges at the elementary level and a science laboratory and a photography darkroom (financed in part by the Edgemont Education Foundation) for the high school.
"We have been able to provide in this budget for high-quality education at a fair cost and offer an enhancement of the program in a more comfortable budget," said Nancy L. Taddiken, Superintendent of Edgemont.
Similarly, in Rye Neck, the proposed $16.6 million budget represents a 5.08 spending increase over the previous year and reflects the district's efforts to continue and expand program improvements.
"We're looking at a 5 percent enrollment increase, in large part because of a new housing development known as the Preserve," Dr. Peter J. Mustich, Superintendent of Rye Neck, said. "It's a very thoughtful budget that raises standards for all students. Our program requires additional support. With the increased enrollment, we have to add staff. The community is seeing the results of our improvements and sees substantive changes in the schools. We're getting younger families who are concerned about the schools."
And in other communities facing the challenges of maintaining and improving the academic program while managing increased enrollment, similar tax-rate increases are proposed. In White Plains, the $98.5 million budget includes allocations for 13 new teachers, a spending increase of 3.4 percent and a 5.5 percent tax-rate increase. Ardsley's $27 million budget would raise taxes by 2.75 percent, while Scarsdale's $59.9 million budget reflects a 5.2 percent tax-rate increase.
"We're in pretty good shape," Dr. William French, interim Superintendent of the Scarsdale schools, said. "We've been out and touched all the bases in the community and gotten some minor suggestions, but we don't anticipate problems."
Still, districts are far from proposing sizable increases in spending or tax rates. The Southern Westchester Board of Cooperative Educational Services, for example, has proposed a budget that represents little cost increase to member districts.
Despite the almost serene atmosphere, educators remain cautious about the final disposition of their proposed budgets.
"Part of state aid is really reimbursements for expenditures school districts have made," Dr. Kusel said. "Here's the caution. If a school district is told it will get $1 million this year, we know it is a very good year for the state. Part of our dilemma is not only, What am I getting this year? but What am I getting next year? Districts tend to look past the now to not get clobbered in the future. There is concern among educators whether the Governor can keep funding at these levels if the economy changes."

HEADLINE: Why 'Titanic' Conquered the World

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING 

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
LONG before "Titanic" the movie, the enduring appeal of Titanic the story had already been proved by books, plays, exhibitions, documentaries and other films. Even so, who could have gauged the world's appetite for more? Until the last several months, fascination with accounts of the ship that went down in the North Atlantic in April 1912, killing more than 1,500 people, had been largely limited to the United States and Europe. Yet the movie was able to captivate audiences even in countries where the sinking of the unsinkable was never part of popular lore. And for them the movie became the story.
So what was it about James Cameron's blockbuster that turned it into what is surely the highest-grossing film of all time? Although it is finally showing signs of slowing down at the box office in the United States, it is still roaring along abroad, and has so far earned about $1.5 billion over all, apparently surpassing even "Gone With the Wind," adjustments for inflation notwithstanding. 
 Certainly, this could not have happened without Hollywood's money, screencraft, special effects, publicity machine and, most important, distribution network. But the movie struck virtually every market, big and small, with such force that it became impossible not to know of its existence, not to have heard Celine Dion sing the theme song and eventually, it seems, not to have seen the screen ship go under.
A quick tour d'horizon of why the film has drawn such a strong reaction around the world provides other -- more emotional, less commercial -- reasons: "Titanic" tells a story that is perceived to be true; it is a tragic love story of operatic dimension because the denouement is known; it demonstrates the terrifying and mystical power of nature, and it has in Leonardo DiCaprio a fated working-class hero with whom teen-age girls fall in love. In other words, it is a fine old tear-jerker and everyone likes a good sob.
Still, different countries have viewed the phenomenon of "Titanic" in their own ways. The sight of British aristocrats displaying stiff upper lips in face of adversity appealed to the Japanese sense of "gamen." But some British critics thought the movie anti-British. The French dwelled on the hidden political message of the movie (better food in first class, better dancing in third). And one German intellectual saw the ship's fate as punishment for the arrogance of modern technology. "Nature strikes back!" he said cheerfully. Whatever the explanation, "Titanic" has already grossed more than $100 million in each of these countries.
The Chinese have been rushing to see the film, but because it is being shown in just 127 theaters in China, a sidewalk market in pirated videos is flourishing. How could the Chinese not want to see the movie when their very own Communist Party chief, Jiang Zemin, praised it in a speech to the National Peoples Congress? Of course, he was not talking about the art of movie making. For him, "Titanic" was a great example of venture capitalism at work.
So the unsinkable movie floats on, showering both friend and foe with evidence not only of Hollywood's power to make money -- to date, about $543 million in the United States and about $933 million more in the rest of the world -- but also of its ability to shape the world's imagination, to the point that hundreds of millions of people will eventually have this experience in common. Indeed, the film has become a point of cultural reference. This month at the Paris Opera, for instance, the audience erupted in applause when a shipwreck in "L'Italiana in Algieri" by Rossini was represented by a sinking Titanic. A review of reactions in some of the 56 countries outside the United States in which the film is being shown confirms just that: as an image, as a story, as a metaphor, as a movie, there is still no escaping "Titanic."

HEADLINE: Why 'Titanic' Conquered the World;
Cairo

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL 

 BODY:
Most of the films showing in Egyptian cinemas these days tend to highlight the gritty side of life: poverty, street thuggery, even a vulgar competition for the affections of a man married to two women. Not so "Titanic," of course, and critics say that this is an important reason that the American movie has so quickly become beloved in a country whose own classics have always reached for the romantic heights.
Egyptians may grumble a lot these days about American arrogance, but they are also flocking to see "Titanic" in such numbers that theaters showing the film are still fully booked more than a week in advance. 
 "This is something that takes them away from what they see on the street, away from the depressing football matches on television and back to the romance of the old Arabic movies," said Khaled Farahat, one prominent critic. "Romance is something cinema direly lacks now."
Some recent American-made films -- most notably "Independence Day" -- have kindled a backlash among Egyptians who read their plots and popularity as proof that Americans are determined to dominate the world. But this spring, even on weekdays at 3:30 A.M., Cairenes have been streaming away from movie houses starry-eyed about a tale that appeals equally as love story, tragedy and window to grand possibility.
"It is not an American movie," said Rania al-Razaz, a graduate student at the American University in Cairo who had waited more than a week to get a ticket to "Titanic." "It is a human movie." DOUGLAS JEHL

HEADLINE: 'Troubling Legacy Of Conversions'

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"A Troubling Legacy of Conversions" March 22 assumes that resident shareholders suffer when sponsors retain ownership of their shares in co-op buildings. 
 In many cases, the resident shareholders allegedly harmed were "insiders" who knew that a significant percentage of the rent-regulated units would not be purchased. "Outsiders" clearly knew the percentage of unsold units when they bought.
Even if a purchaser assumed that all units would be sold eventually on turnover, that might not be in the best financial interest of the co-op now. Once the original regulated tenant moves out, the sponsor can re-rent the unit at a market rent. Thanks to the healthy rental market, this is certain to cover the maintenance expenses, with the excess often providing the sponsor with a better rate of return than selling the apartment and, say, buying Treasury bills.
A financially healthy shareholder is good news, and a sponsor commanding market rents will have an incentive to promote good building maintenance. Further, retaining ownership of market-rent apartments insures that the sponsor will have money available to pay the maintenance for the money-losing rent-regulated apartments.
The downside, as noted in the article, is the reluctance of banks to offer financing for co-ops in which there is a high percentage of rentals. Unfortunately, the banks are still reacting to mistakes they made in financing conversions in the 80's. The solution, however, is for banks to go back to basics by underwriting based on value, not to penalize sponsors for pursuing their economic self-interest.
It's ironic that resident shareholders seem more intent on suing their fellow-shareholding sponsors than in identifying their common problems.
 
BRUCE WITTENBERG
President
Rex Management Corporation
Great Neck, N.Y.

HEADLINE: YOUR HOME;
Losing A Co-op's Papers

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO 

 BODY:
CHRISTOPHER DALRYMPLE recently decided that interest rates had fallen enough to warrant refinancing his co-op share loan. A producer for CBS News, he had more than enough income to qualify for the loan, as well as 11 years of on-time loan payments behind him.
Within days, Mr. Dalrymple got a commitment at a locked-in interest rate of 7 1/8 percent. Then things came to a halt. "My original lender lost my stock certificate and proprietary lease," Mr. Dalrymple said. "It ended up costing me $400 to keep my rate after the lock-in expired and another $500 to have a replacement certificate and lease drawn up by the managing agent." 
 Last Wednesday, the bank reimbursed Mr. Dalrymple for the cost of the replacement certificates, so the situation involves a relatively small amount of money. But the lender's inability to find his original certificate has ominous implications.
"It seems to be happening a lot with all the bank mergers and acquisitions," said Paulette Bonnano, a vice president at National Cooperative Bank in Manhattan.
She said that as the banking industry consolidates it is becoming increasingly common for lenders to lose track of the mortgage papers, notes, stock certificates and proprietary leases that serve as evidence of their security for hundreds of millions of dollars worth of mortgages and share loans.
Unlike mortgages, which are promptly recorded in county clerks' offices, the stock certificates and proprietary leases that provide security for co-op share loans are often not recorded anywhere. As a result, those documents generally must be produced at the time of a sale or a refinancing.
Unlike Mr. Dalrymple, who was refinancing his own mortgage, co-op owners who are selling their apartments may not always be able to convince an eager buyer to wait a couple of weeks for the original lender to produce -- or discover it has lost -- the original documents needed for the closing.
"In the last several years we've had a growing number of stock certificates and leases supposedly lost by lenders who appear unwilling to put in much effort to find them," said Howard Schechter, a Manhattan lawyer who represents Mr. Dalrymple's co-op board. "It seems to be getting more and more difficult for lenders to retrieve paper documentation. Some of this paper has important legal significance."
Mr. Schechter explained that when shares to an apartment are transferred from one owner to another, the transfer agent needs the original certificates to provide new documents for the buyer.
If the current owner cannot produce the originals, he said, the transfer agent will not complete the sale because it is possible that a lender may be holding them as evidence of a lien against the apartment.
This is not just a remote possibility, Mr. Schechter said, because before 1988, when a state law was amended to allow for the filing of lien documents for share loans, lenders frequently made no official filing of their liens against property.
While lenders now file notice of their liens with the county clerk, in the case of loans originating before 1988, the only way that a transfer agent can be assured that all liens against the property have been satisfied is by requiring the return of the original documents.
Occasionally, of course, shareholders themselves misplace the documents. In such cases, Mr. Schechter said, a shareholder who needs replacement certificates is typically required to provide the co-op with an affidavit saying his documents are truly lost.
Last year, however, co-op boards received unsettling news: A New York State Supreme Court justice ruled that a co-op that had provided a replacement certificate to a shareholder selling his apartment was liable to a lender who later produced the original certificate as evidence of an unpaid lien on the property.
"The shareholder sold the apartment and lied to the co-op board about losing his stock certificate and proprietary lease," said Richard Nardi, a Manhattan co-op lawyer and former president of the Mortgage Bankers Association of New York, who represented the shareholder's original lender.
That, Mr. Nardi said, has made co-op lawyers and boards exceedingly skittish about issuing replacement certificates and leases.
As a result, he said, shareholders who have lost their documents are generally required to provide the co-op with an affidavit of loss and agree to accept responsibility for any liens outstanding at the time the replacement certificates were issued.
 However, said Mr. Nardi, since such an agreement is only as good as the shareholder's ability or inclination to abide by it, some co-op lawyers are recommending that boards require shareholders who need replacement documents to furnish a bond. Mr. Schechter, who endorsed that practice, said that such a bond can cost as much as 3 percent of the fair-market value of an apartment.
And since lenders who lose stock certificates or leases will not likely submit to a requirement to post a bond to obtain replacements, boards should at the very least require the lender to reimburse the co-op for future losses that may result from the issuance of replacement documents.
 Deborah O'Uhuru, president of Residential Capital Corporation in Manhattan, said that shareholders who are selling their apartment or refinancing their mortgage should notify their current lender as far in advance of closing as possible.
' Mr. Schechter said that the same thing would apply for shareholders selling their units.
"You certainly shouldn't wait until you've scheduled the closing," he said. "The more notice you give them, the better off you are."

HEADLINE: SPOKEN WORD;
Ups, Downs and Ups in Newark

 BODY:
THE people in Newark who in just seven months have presented more ballet, folk dance and symphonic music than the city has seen in decades are about to put their brand new culture palace in context.
Starting tomorrow, the New Jersey Performing Arts Center will offer "Bricks, Mortar and Spirit: The Endurance of Newark," four seminars illuminating significant aspects of the city's history, through good times and bad. It emphasizes the hope of redevelopment that has infused the city since the center opened in October. 
 "From the inception of NJPAC, there were many goals and the pulling together of many resources from around the state to support Newark," said Barbara Bell Campbell, a trustee of the arts center and the chairwoman of its cultural legacy committee. "The arts center is doing what the arts must do: serving as a humanizing force."
"It was the expressed desire of many people to connect further with the city of Newark," said Ms. Campbell, who recently retired as president of the Amelior Foundation, which awards grants to urban education projects. "Many who knew it before the 1967 riot can see possibilities. Many who are new have expressed curiosity about the past, present and future. This was a new opportunity to explore the fabric of the city through intellectual discourse."
The seminars will start tomorrow with an examination of Newark's rise as a 19th-century industrial center, proceeding through the more difficult times that gripped the city in the 1960's: social anxieties, the rise of suburbia and the decline of manufacturing. The May 11 session will look more closely at suburbanization and its effect on urban policy, with a look to the future.
In the third session, on May 18 at Trinity-St. Philip's Cathedral, a short walk from the arts center, panelists will discuss their research and perceptions of the city and discuss the role of ethnicity and race in 20th-century Newark.
The final session will be a tour of selected sites and neighborhoods. Dr. Clement Alexander Price, chairman of African-American studies at Rutgers University-Newark, who helped formulate the program, and Dr. Kenneth A. Jackson, a professor of history at Columbia University who is an expert on the development of suburbs, are among the scheduled speakers.
The lectures will begin at 5:30 P.M. The final session on May 31 includes the tour, at a time to be announced. Tickets: $85 for the series; $25 for individual events. Information: (800) 466-5722.

HEADLINE: ON POLITICS;
Another School Funding Suit Creates a 3-Ring Legal Circus

BYLINE: By Jennifer Preston; Jennifer Preston is Trenton bureau chief of The New York Times.

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
In the latest legal assault against the way New Jersey pays for public schools, a coalition of 25 middle-income school districts filed a lawsuit last week asking the courts to order the state to come up with a new way to finance public education.
This is now the third lawsuit pending against the state that contends the existing state aid formula is unconstitutional. The state Supreme Court ordered New Jersey last year to come up with $246 million to help end the spending disparity between the state's wealthiest and poorest school districts, and is now considering requiring the state to spend $312 million more. 
 Last fall, 17 rural school districts, mostly in southern New Jersey, moved ahead with a lawsuit of their own that also claims the existing system is inequitable.
With the middle-income districts, the debate is not about rich versus poor. It is about property, and the difficulties that school districts face asking already overburdened property taxpayers to pay even more.
The Association for Middle-Income Districts argues that the state's school aid formula promotes unequal tax rates. Too many school districts, the group says, must levy higher property taxes than others to keep their public schools afloat. Take, for example, the Matawan-Aberdeen Regional School District, one of the districts that has joined the suit. Its property tax rate last year was $2.08 for every $100 of assessed value, far above the state average of $1.31.
Those who filed suit want the state to cap the property tax rate at the state average of $1.31 for every $100 of assessed value, and make up the difference to school districts. The price tag, they estimate, is $1 billion.
Pete McDonough, chief spokesman for Governor Whitman, said that the complaints of the middle-income districts do not belong in the courtroom. "We believe that education funding should be handled as a matter of policy, not a matter of litigation," he said.
Attorney General Peter Vernerio made a similar point before the State Supreme Court last month while arguing that the state should not be forced to spend $312 million more in the most financially needy districts. He said the Governor and the Legislature, not the courts, should be deciding how to allocate state money for school programs.
The Governor and the Legislature were elected to tax and spend, not the state's Supreme Court justices. But until the Legislature and Governor Whitman address the state's overreliance on property taxes to finance public education, they run the risk of having the courts decide for them.
That is what happened just last year in New Hampshire, where the highest court ruled that the responsibility of paying for public schools belonged to the state.
New Jerseyans have been clamoring for property tax relief for some time. Two-thirds of what is collected in property taxes goes to schools in most communities. Yet despite the concerns about taxes, voters approved 74.6 percent of the school budgets in last Tuesday's election. School board officials said the state's strong economy helped produce the high approval rate, but warned that the state's overreliance on the property tax to pay for education will continue to plague schools and taxpayers.
Yet before any significant property tax relief can take place, New Jerseyans need to ask themselves a few difficult questions. Are they willing to trade lower property taxes for an increase in statewide taxes, like the income tax or sales tax? The money has to come from somewhere.
And are New Jerseyans willing to give up their cherished "home rule" style of government, which has led to the creation of more than 500 different school districts? Are they willing to give up some degree of local control over their schools and share costs and decisions with neighboring school districts?
To her credit, Governor Whitman put those hard questions on the table earlier this year in her annual address to the state Legislature. She emphasized that she opposed forced regionalization of school districts. But she did call for a referendum so that voters could send a direct message to their elected officials about what course they want to be taken.
At the time, some lawmakers criticized the Governor, saying that elected officials, not the voters, should be making those decisions. But a voter referendum would provoke a statewide debate on the issue. The public needs to know what it will be giving up and what it will be gaining.
So school districts do not need the courts to be making the decisions here. It is the people of New Jersey who need to decide what it is they really want. And they need to spell that out for their elected officials.
Maybe, then, property tax bills would fall. Or, at least, people would no longer have an excuse to complain about them.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 12; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1576 words

HEADLINE: VIEWPOINT;
What the Biggest Cities Can Learn From the Upstarts

BYLINE: By JOEL KOTKIN 

 BODY:
WHEN Richard J. Riordan, an entrepreneur who made a fortune as a venture capitalist in the booming 1980's, became Mayor of Los Angeles in 1993, he confronted a city still smoldering from the riots of the previous year, a virtually moribund economy and a city budget heading deeply into the red. Yet the Mayor saw the collapse of the local business leadership as perhaps his greatest long-range problem.
Many once-powerful locally based companies -- Carter Hawley Hale and Security Pacific Bank, among others -- had already disappeared and others were threatening to leave. 
 "As things were changing and getting worse, the C.E.O.'s in L.A. lost their power and their commitment," Mr. Riordan told me recently. "When the older guys gave up, there was no leadership, no strong group who considered commitment to the city and philanthropy important."
The Mayor's observation reflects the concern in cities nationwide about the role of business leaders in their communities. Because of mergers, shareholder pressure and economic globalization, many of the nation's biggest cities are facing new problems rallying strong civic leadership from executives. Although such business elites have often been attacked as fundamentally undemocratic and self-interested, there may be only one thing worse than having a class of civic-minded local leaders -- not having one at all.
"Globalization has changed people's loyalties," said Mike R. Bowlin, chairman and chief executive of Atlantic Richfield,long one of the linchpins of the Los Angeles business establishment. "Twenty years ago, ARCO had Los Angeles in its heart, and we were more of a regional company. Today, our operations are all over the country and the world. So the shareholders have to ask, 'Why is Los Angeles more important to you than Singapore?' "
As engaged business elites have weakened in cities like Los Angeles and New York, new ones are flourishing in upstart places like Seattle; Atlanta; Irvine, Calif., and the Research Triangle of North Carolina. John Kasarda, president of the Kenan Institute of Private Enterprise at the University of North Carolina in Chapel Hill, credits the growth of new regional power centers to advances in transportation and communications. Executives from cities like Portland, Ore., and Orlando, Fla., can now take direct flights to Europe, Latin America or Asia. More important, technology allows transmission of information from remote locations in ways that were impossible just a few years ago.
A look at today's corporate power structure suggests this new freedom. Microsoft runs its global operations from a suburb of Seattle. Wal-Mart operates from rural Bentonville, Ark. Nationsbank is swallowing BankAmerica, based in San Francisco, and taking its name but maintaining the headquarters of the merged banks in the former backwater of Charlotte, N.C.
The relatively strong cohesion of the new business elites makes their cities even more effective as competitors. A large part of Seattle's success stems from civic traditions of boosterism among its big players, particularly the so-called B.M.W. connection -- Boeing, Microsoft and Weyerhaeuser. "We have a great sense of common purpose that holds us together here," said Pat Davis, a Seattle port commissioner. "Loyalty to Seattle is the core of that tradition."
Such civic loyalties have shaped the patterns of urban growth throughout American history. New York's rise to national pre-eminence owed much to the vitality of its mercantile and financial top echelon --- Astors, Vanderbilts, Morgans and Rockefellers -- which proved to be more dynamic than its relatively complacent rivals in Philadelphia and Boston.
Los Angeles was virtually willed into creation through the ambition of business leaders like Henry Huntington, the railroad giant. They pushed development of the city's water, transportation and port systems.
Several newer factors make such elites increasingly crucial to the health of big cities today. In the 1960's and 70's, it seemed plausible to some urban politicians and activists to rely on Washington or state government rather than to appease the local business establishment. But this has changed drastically since the 80's. In New York City, for example, the percentage of the budget covered by state and Federal transfers dropped from 37 percent in 1982 to roughly 30 percent by 1990 and has moved little since.
At the same time, cities have also lost much political leverage. Since the 1950's, for example, Chicago's share of the Illinois electorate has dropped from 40 percent to well under 30 percent; Detroit's share of Michigan's voters has plunged from 30 percent to barely 10 percent.
Cities have also been losing the battle for the hearts, minds and wallets of middle-class citizens and businesses. Despite a turnaround in crime statistics and other social indicators, big-city job growth continues to lag. From 1993 to 1997, when the nation added 9 percent more jobs, job gains in Los Angeles were roughly half that figure, while New York's have barely been one-third.
IN the new business centers, companies have sunk their roots deeply into their home ground, calling on senior executives to perform a variety of philanthropic and entrepreneurial roles.
Paul Allen, the billionaire who was the co-founder of Microsoft, has financed not only a host of small technology firms but also the Seattle Seahawks of the National Football League along with a small film production company and a restoration of the downtown's old Union Station.
In the sprawling region stretching north from San Jose, Calif., and east to Fremont, relatively young technology businesses, organized around Joint Venture: Silicon Valley, an economic development group, have become the dominant voice in an area ruled a generation ago by land developers and farm interests.
And Atlanta's ability to marry its predominately black political class with the city's business leadership has been crucial to promoting its image as a progressive yet business-friendly center, helping it land the 1996 Summer Olympics.
Business elites in many larger urban areas often appear only peripherally connected to their cities' political structures. New York's growing reliance on Wall Street has placed the city's fate increasingly in the hands of an industry tied intimately to global markets and short-term profits originating elsewhere. "What do the people on Wall Street care about New York?" asks Edward N. Costikyan, a former Manhattan Democratic leader who is now a lawyer in midtown. "They don't use the schools or go to the outer boroughs."
However welcome the current Wall Street boom may be, people like Mr. Costikyan and Walter B. Wriston, the former chief executive of Citicorp, warn that the loss of corporate headquarters, along with the exodus of locally anchored manufacturing and service businesses, could leave New York rudderless in a future storm.
"When we had the fiscal crisis in the 1970's, I could schlep the city's paper to corporations who were still here and willing to do something for the city," Mr. Wriston recalled recently. "If it happens again, who would be there to do anything? J. C. Penney is now in Plano, Tex. Mobil is in Virginia."
Of course, New York, like other cities, is hardly without its boosters, notably in the real estate industry, whose commitment to the city is engraved in glass, cement and steel. Since the mid-70's, Manhattan real estate interests have been at the core of the varied attempts to resuscitate the city's economy and image.
But even the landlords' bond grows more tenuous as office towers are sold to publicly held real estate investment trusts with headquarters elsewhere. And over time, cities must be able to build a broader base of civic leadership, bringing in entrepreneurs from emerging industries like multimedia, entertainment, specialty manufacturing and international trade as well as increasingly important immigrant-owned enterprises.
In Los Angeles, such efforts to revive and to diversify civic elites face similar challenges. Like Wall Street in New York, the entertainment complex is the economic powerhouse of the city but has a tradition of noninvolvement and even disdain for the hometown.
"The movie and television business has always been a fairly tight-knit industry that's basically involved with itself and selling to the world," said Dennis C. Stanfill, former chief executive of 20th Century Fox. "You do your work locally, but you think nationally and internationally."
To date, Mayor Riordan has been only modestly successful in rallying the new entertainment moguls to the city's cause. The Mayor, along with Mr. Bowlin of ARCO and Eli Broad, chairman of SunAmerica, have recently organized Los Angeles Business Advisors, a group of about two dozen top corporate executives. But they have failed to recruit a single prominent figure from entertainment or from other growth sectors like toys and fashion.
Yet, the Mayor's efforts have not been entirely wasted. The stalled downtown concert center, Disney Hall, finally has the needed financial commitments. Other improvements include a downtown sports arena and a new Roman Catholic cathedral to replace one dating from the late 19th century that was damaged in the 1994 earthquake.
"If you rally the key people, anything is possible," Mr. Riordan explained bluntly. "If you can't, it's kind of a lost cause."

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Page 1; Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 2692 words

HEADLINE: Wanted: Alternate Route

BYLINE: By ANDREA KANNAPELL 

 BODY:
IT'S a Wednesday morning in April 2015, and you're late for work.
Because you're carpooling with a neighbor, you are allowed on the Turnpike, where single-occupant vehicles have been banned for years. But you and Kim Soo have agreed that only in emergencies will you pay the triple toll charged during peak hours. So when you punch your destination into the dashboard computer, you order a no-toll route. 
 A map flashes onto the screen. Ah, they finally finished that paving project, so you'll be able to save a couple of minutes taking the back streets of your suburban neighborhood, steering clear of the crowded school and shopping zones. Then you head onto what used to be a freeway and is now a broad boulevard with eight lanes in each direction, lined with trees, stores, sidewalks and bus stops.
Suddenly, an overhead sign flashes, warning of delays ahead, and the computer lists time estimates for five alternative routes, including a train link. The slowest route is on side streets, 49 minutes; the fastest is the Turnpike, 16.
"Let's splurge," Kim Soo says, and you zip up a ramp, not even slowing as the electronic reader scans your windshield card. You switch to autodrive and settle back over the paper while the car drives itself to the office at a comfortable, and perfectly legal, 80 miles per hour. Hey, if it weren't legal, you could get a $500 ticket!
At your exit, E-Z Pass charges your account $15, and you resume manual control for the last two blocks to the office.
This scenario is an amalgam of some of the ideas of urban planners and traffic engineers as they quietly consider the issues that lie beneath the vigorous debates roiling New Jersey over everything from new rail lines, road quality, speed limits, car insurance, and the gasoline tax to perpetuating the Federal transportation funding process known as ISTEA.
The bedrock of those myriad battles is a system of more than 34,000 miles of roads, on which, in transit parlance, a staggering 60 billion vehicle miles are traveled every year. It is a system of Indian paths and colonial roads that has evolved into an enormous complex of state and interstate highways, a system so strained that it is no longer capable of even pretending to be all things to all drivers.
More and wider roads are constantly being proposed to allow for more freight, more commuting, more getting around of all kinds. For instance, the New Jersey Turnpike Authority is hoping to build an east-west Route 92 across southern Middlesex County, saying it will ease traffic on Route 1. And along the Hudson shore, mayors are proposing a roadway through the abandoned railway tunnels known as the Bergen Arches to allow local traffic to bypass the jammed routes to the Lincoln and Holland tunnels.
But such proposals tend to draw bitter opposition from residents and environmentalists. Even some proponents of new highways believe they offer only a partial solution in a state that is already one of the most paved in the country, with 4.5 miles of roadway for every square mile of land.
"Generally speaking, there is a widespread recognition that we can't build ourselves out of congestion," said Joel Weiner, the executive director of the North Jersey Transportation Planning Authority. "You can't pave over everything."
Instead, urban planners and transit experts are looking at ways to alter as well as accommodate traffic, including technology like E-Z Pass, smart mass transit systems that give riders up-to-the-minute E.T.A.'s, and other innovations like the on-demand bus service planned for Bergen County.
And the experts are looking beyond traffic-control technology to the demographic and land-use patterns that create traffic in the first place. As one traffic engineer, Walter Kulash, puts it: "We've engineered the highways all we can. Now we have to engineer travel patterns."
 
Over the Centuries, A Reliance on Highways
To say that more roads can't solve New Jersey's traffic problems goes against a tradition with roots far deeper than the 1950's faith in progress that brought the Interstate system. Even in the colonial era, New Jersey's roads were serving as crucial connectors on the Eastern Seaboard. The colonial Post Road that ran across the state's waist, the 90-mile stretch between the Hudson River and Trenton, was one of the most heavily used highways in the Western Hemisphere. News of the shots fired at Lexington came overland through New Jersey to get to Philadelphia; people, trade and jobs collected along the route, which roughly followed the Indian Assanpink Trail and is now the infamous Route 1.
For much of the state's nearly 400 years of recorded history, road building and maintenance was the job of local towns or the private companies that built toll roads. Then in 1890, partly in response to pressure from fans of the newly invented bicycle, New Jersey became the first state in the nation to dedicate state funds to roads.
The automobile, which arrived shortly thereafter, rapidly increased public demand for a road system, and in 1909 the state created a highway commission. In 1917, the commission laid out a network of 15 state routes. (Many of those routes remain, but the numbering system was changed repeatedly, giving historians as many headaches as drivers.)
And the years since have seen superhighway after turnpike after expressway after freeway tear across the state. Many tried to bypass crowded cities and were too successful, attracting development that sapped vitality from urban centers.
The state's roadways are considered so historically rich that two (the Old Mine Road, in Sussex and Warren counties, and River Road, in Middlesex) are already on the National Register of Historic Places. The Pulaski Skyway, a 13-mile feat of 1930's engineering spanning the lowlands between Jersey City and Newark, has met all the criteria for designation, and preservationists are beginning to argue for the same protection for Routes 1 and 9.
Can the age of highway building really be over?
For sometimes contradictory reasons, transit experts say yes. For John J. Haley Jr., the Commissioner of the New Jersey Department of Transportation, it's simply no longer economically or politically feasible to add more than a few new roads. Maintaining and operating what already exists eats three-quarters of his $1.85 billion annual budget. Hundreds of jam-causing projects are underway at any given time. No fewer than 16 major projects are planned for this year.
Land and construction costs are prohibitive, it is difficult to get approval for any project that doesn't reduce pollution, and too much is known about the cost to communities when road projects rip through.
"The days of drawing a line on a map and simply pushing through like Robert Moses and then cleaning up after the elephants, those days are over," Mr. Haley said.
Others say the reason is that roadways operate like a vacuum, drawing as many cars as will fit. "The roadways become so much of an attraction, and then the traffic chokes the very thing that attracted it," said Alan Pisarski, a researcher in travel behavior and the author of "Commuting in America" (Urban Land Institute, 1996). "Transportation systems seem to have the seeds of their own destruction."
And in a state that is trying to rebuild its cities, more highways simply encourage the very sprawl Governor Whitman has pledged to curtail. Anton Nelessen, a Trenton-based transportation consultant who is helping Milwaukee replace a freeway with a boulevard, sees highway-building as simply outmoded Depression-era thinking.
"The idea was, if you build more highways, buy more cars, buy more gas, lighten up on regulations, it's good economically for the country," he said. "And it was. Then."
 
The Interactive Highway And the Dial-a-Bus
The first wave of ideas on solving traffic problems with highway management instead of new construction came in the late 80's, with the development of the intelligent transportation system, or I.T.S., a kind of interactive roadway. The concept was created to satisfy the Federal Clean Air Act, which mandated significant reductions in exhaust emissions when it was passed in 1970, at a time of enormous traffic increases caused by baby-boomers and increasing numbers of women entering the workforce.
In New Jersey, I.T.S. is manifest in the New Jersey Turnpike's radio broadcasts, the huge electronic signs that flash real-time traffic updates, the computer-controlled traffic lights along Route 18 that allow synchronization and the video cameras along accident-prone lengths of Route 1 that enable rapid accident clearing. It includes E-Z Pass, the electronic toll collectors installed at the Lincoln and Holland Tunnels and the George Washington Bridge. Commissioner Haley says the system will be installed on all of the state's toll roads within two years.
The key to 21st-century highway management is integrating all these tools, a unification already underway in places like San Antonio, Tex., and Southern California, according to Christine Johnson, the director of the I.T.S. program for the United States Department of Transportation.
"You have automatic vehicle location, using the Global Positioning System, that monitors where vehicles are," she said. "That can tell you that the bus is eight minutes away. You can link New Jersey Transit and computerized traffic-light controls and highway controls and emergency response."
Some of this information can be beamed directly into people's cars, allowing drivers to make better-informed choices. In Europe, she said, traffic conditions and route data are sent into individual cars in the language of the driver's choice.
But traffic management, which raises questions about exactly who will manage the managers, is not the only focus. There are also projects underway, or under consideration, to encourage people to get out of their cars.
New Jersey is the most densely populated state in the nation, with more than 1,000 people per square mile, but it is also the most densely vehicled state, with almost 790 per square mile. Of a residential total of about 7.7 million people, there are 5.7 million licensed drivers. There are even more registered cars: 5.9 million. Combined with the numbers is a rapidly growing commuting pattern, suburb to suburb, that is unservable by traditional mass transit.
"It used to be that our system focused on getting people into Newark, New York and Philadelphia," Mr. Haley said. "But now the people and the jobs are moving up and down within the state. And we're focusing on moving people better within the state."
The Hudson-Bergen light rail project, running from Bayonne to Ridgefield Park, links neighborhoods, railroads, highways and ferries; the stretch from Bayonne to Hoboken is expected to be operational by 2000, and the remainder by 2002. Mr. Haley said that another light rail plan for southern New Jersey was in design, and that he expected it go out for bid by the fall and be operational at about the same time as the Hudson-Bergen line. And, he said, five more light rail plans were under consideration.
These projects are in addition to rail improvements already approved, including the Secaucus transfer, which will allow commuters on the old Erie-Lackawanna lines from Bergen, Passaic and Rockland counties to link to Amtrak's Northeast Corridor rather than descending to Hoboken for connections. The Montclair connection, linking New Jersey Transit's Boonton line to its Montclair branch, will allow thousands of commuters to travel directly into midtown Manhattan without having to transfer at Hoboken.
Over the next few years, Mr. Haley said, the state's bus system, which already carries 143 million fares a year, will be rerouted through suburban points, and zippy little vans, not ponderous buses, will service those routes.
And a cutting-edge, on-demand bus service that planners believe may be able to pay for itself is being developed in Bergen County, with a pilot program set to go into effect when the light rail opens. Chester Mattson, the county's director of planning, described the pilot program as a system of vans that are tracked via Global Positioning System, which can pinpoint the location of any transmitter-equipped object on the planet. The vans, dispatched by a computer that calculates which is most available, will respond to specific calls of customers who want to be picked up and dropped off at any of hundreds of stops in more than a dozen municipalities in the county's dense, central core. The design limits a vanload to three passengers, so that riders, who will pay about $3 for a ride, will not face the delays caused by endless stops.
The program will kick off with no fewer than 40 vans. "The idea is to have a service large enough to respond to enough clients to succeed when it starts, rather than the usual governmental approach of putting one van out there and seeing if anybody uses it," Mr. Mattson said.
Commissioner Haley said that employers are being encouraged to offer a "cash-out parking plan" to their workers. In this plan, companies charge employees for parking, but also pay every worker the exact amount it costs to park every day. Those employees who find some other way to work can simply pocket the extra. The employer may be able to get tax incentives to make the plan worthwhile.
And after E-Z Pass is ubiquitous, Mr. Haley said, "congestion pricing" will go into effect, in which higher tolls at peak periods would be balanced by lower fares on mass transit.
Motorists groups have already promised to fight any such measure, and it is likely to be a sizzling political potato, but the Commissioner was adamant in his support for it.
"The single biggest complaint I get is about trucks on local roads," Mr. Haley said. "We want to encourage trucks to use the Turnpike and the interstates. We can do that with congestion pricing."
There are other possibilities. The H.O.V. lanes meant for high-occupancy vehicles on I-287 and I-80 are extremely unpopular among drivers, and experts question their utility. They could be transformed into H.O./ T. lanes, meaning high-occupancy or toll. The system, being tested in California, gives drivers of single-occupant vehicles the option of paying for the right to drive in the reserved lane.
 
Freight Clogs Roads In a Major Port State
Moving people off the roads is one thing; another key to unclogging traffic is diverting freight. Every year, about a tenth of the nation's cargo spends some time on New Jersey's roads. That's 850 million tons of cargo, and the state D.O.T. says that 59 percent of it is just passing through.
Later this year, the long-awaited division of the old Conrail lines between CSX and Norfolk Southern is expected to be accomplished. Both lines will operate in New Jersey, and both have promised to expand service. Price wars, experts say, are inevitable.
That could help New Jersey's highway problems considerably -- unless, as many economists promise, world trade doubles by 2010, and, as politicians promise, Port Newark and Port Elizabeth retain or increase their central role in the shipping industry. That much more cargo could simply clog the rail system as well as the highway system. Proposals for new rail tunnels under New York Harbor are already under consideration.
The clear message is, something's got to give. And there are scare stories out there. Angus Kress Gillespie, who wrote "Looking for America on the New Jersey Turnpike" (Rutgers University Press, 1989), notes that Tokyo requires drivers to prove they have off-road parking spaces before they are allowed to buy cars. Steve Carrellas, a New Jersey spokesman for the National Motorists Association, says that Singapore doesn't just ticket cars for minor infractions, it tows them away.
"No one thing is going to solve New Jersey's transportation problems," said Barbara Lawrence, the executive director of New Jersey Future, a non-profit organization that encourages compliance with the state's regional plan. "Can't you see the headline? 'Magic Bullet Found!' "
