HEADLINE: IN BRIEF;
Crackdown on Cheating

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
Fifty people are accused of collecting unemployment checks while employed, stealing anywhere from $1,316 to $8,475 each from the State Department of Labor, Commissioner James J. McGowan and District Attorney Jeanine Pirro of Westchester reported last week. All are charged with fourth-degree grand larceny, a felony punishable by up to four years in jail.
The charges cover reported thefts from September 1994 to December 1996 and are the result of an investigation by the District Attorney's Office and the Office of the Inspector General of the State Labor Department. Commissioner McGowan said that the policy of his department is to "aggressively pursue anyone who cheats the system." 
 The state and county agencies found the suspects by comparing computer lists of people collecting unemployment benefits with those paying income taxes.
Since the announcement, the Department of Labor reported that it had received many phone calls from people wanting to avoid prosecution. The focus of the crackdown, Mrs. Pirro said, was not only to find people defrauding the government but also to spur "others into voluntarily refunding" payments they were not entitled to.

HEADLINE: The World;
With Promises, Promises, NATO Moves the East

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: WARSAW

 BODY:
IN the United States, the question of whether to expand NATO eastward has been debated only in fits and starts, and then most passionately on the issues of how the Russians feel about it and whether it might cost too much.
But another question figures in the debate too: What effect has the lure of NATO membership had on the way the proposed new members -- Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic -- govern themselves and behave toward their neighbors after nearly half a century under Communism? 
 No one of these questions alone will decide the debate, which the Senate is scheduled to resume on Monday. Opponents of the Clinton Administration's proposal to expand NATO will doubtless emphasize the questions of money, Russia, and how many other new members this precedent will open the door to.
Still, it is on the question of how the prospective members are behaving that some of the hardest evidence is in, and it adds up to this:
 
Agreement on a Goal
While all three have a way to go on meeting Western standards of democratic rule and stable market economies, no issue has dominated the internal political behavior of the three Central European countries as much as the aspiration to belong to the Western security alliance.
In all three prospective new members, former Communists and anti-Communists alike have agreed on NATO membership as a national goal, and as a result all have tried with varying degrees of sincerity to meet the alliance's broad requirements of democratic rule and free enterprise.
In other words, the promise of inclusion in NATO has helped the cause of moderate government during a tough period of economic and political transition. And there is little doubt, analysts say, that trying to lay the political groundwork to satisfy NATO has left Hungary, Poland and the Czech Republic better positioned for sustained economic growth.
Such growth, in turn, could also help these countries join the European Union -- another goal they share, and one they are pursuing in negotiations that opened in Brussels last month and that promise to be tough.
One lesson clearly taken to heart by Poland, the Czech Republic and Hungary was the elimination of Slovakia from the list of potential NATO members after its Prime Minister, Vladimir Meciar, became increasingly authoritarian. Similarly, the European Union has cited Slovakia's lack of democratic progress as a reason for its exclusion from the first round of the economic union's eastward expansion.
The new American Ambassador to Poland, Daniel Fried, who helped formulate the arguments for expanding NATO when he worked at the National Security Council before coming to Warsaw last fall, likes to point to the way the three countries have behaved toward each other. "When Poland and Hungary became more confident of their NATO membership," he said, "they increased their outreach to their neighbors -- Hungary to Romania, and Poland to Lithuania."
A decade ago, when the Soviet hold on Eastern Europe was evaporating, one worry for NATO was that old national resentments would resurface in the form of border disputes and mistreatment of minorities, creating instability in the region. So when NATO decided it might enlarge, it made it clear that aspirants to membership had to avoid that kind of thing.
Now Hungary and Romania have signed a treaty guaranteeing each other's borders and respecting the right of the large Hungarian minority in Romania. And tense relations between Poland and Lithuania have improved to the point that they have created a joint peacekeeping battalion.
Another benchmark set down by NATO, and in particular by the Pentagon, was that the military in new members had to be subordinate to civilian control. This was a prickly subject in Poland, where former President Lech Walesa wanted to keep broad authority in the hands of his generals. Only since the defeat of Mr. Walesa in elections in 1995 and the adoption of a new Constitution calling for subordination of the general staff to the Minister of Defense has the strong political influence of the Polish military brass diminished.
 
Changes in the Brass
Last year, to the relief of the Pentagon, President Kwasniewski fired Gen. Tadeusz Wilecki, a Walesa appointee, who had shown open contempt for the civilians at the defense ministry.
Now Henry Szumski, a younger general who has United Nations field experience, is at the top, and Janusz Onyszkiewicz, an ardent proponent of civilian control of the military, is defense minister. NATO specialists say they are satisfied that the Polish military is on the right track, but another challenge remains: to clear out many of the Communist-era holdovers in the military intelligence service.
In another example of changing attitudes, the Hungarian Government passed over Soviet-trained generals for the post of chief of the general staff and reached down to the third level of the military hierarchy for Lieut. Gen. Ferenc Vegh, an English-speaking graduate of the United States Army War College. Now 7 of the top 10 generals in Hungary are Western trained.
Last month. the Czechs appointed a new chief of the general staff, Jiri Sedivy, 45, who stands out for his experience as a battalion commander in Bosnia and for his choice of military heroes: Eisenhower, Patton and Schwarzkopf.
Along with elevating military officers who think like those in the West, the three countries have been encouraged by NATO to get serious about parliamentary oversight committees. On this point, they still have a long way to go; the defense committee in the lower house of Poland's Parliament has no staff, and the enthusiastic members of Hungary's parliamentary defense committee have little background in military affairs.
No one would argue that Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic are mature democracies with classic capitalist economies. Progress toward the rule of law and the protection of minority rights is far from perfect. In all three countries, the judicial systems are fragile and financial corruption widespread. There are still huge disparities in terms of wealth between the European Union and its prospective new eastern members.
But Marek Matraszek, the Warsaw director of CEC Government Relations, a political consulting firm that has worked on NATO related issues, believes that without the prospect of membership in NATO, Poland might easily have fallen under the sway of nationalist and populist politicians. Now it seems reasonable to believe that Poland, a land with 40 million people and a bounding economy growing at six percent a year, may reach its goal of being a middle-size Western European power within the next decade.
"The promise of NATO has defused destabilizing forces from the left and right." Mr. Matraszek said. "If NATO had not been offered, Poland could have been in a disastrous situation, externally and internally."

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS;
Building Momentum With Foreign Stocks

BYLINE: By ARLENE WEINTRAUB 

 BODY:
IT would be difficult to find two more cosmopolitan stock pickers. Henrik Strabo, 38, a native of Copenhagen, moved to the United States as a teen-ager to attend the University of Washington and decided to stick around. Mark S. Kopinski, 41, meanwhile, took a different route, leaving his home outside of Chicago in 1973 to become a Rotary exchange student in Kariya, Japan. He liked it so much that he returned later, living in Tokyo for 10 years.
But ask these globe-trotters how their American Century-Twentieth Century International Discovery fund achieved its white-hot performance, and the impassioned response has nothing to with their worldliness. Instead, they cite their absolute belief in the power of momentum investing: the much-criticized practice of piling into stocks whose profits are on the upswing. 
 "Whether it's a software company or a steel company or a consumer company or an auto company, we're looking for earnings growth," the usually mild-mannered Mr. Strabo said as he pounded the table. "We firmly believe that there's nothing like a couple of good earnings announcements to get these stocks to move."
It is likely that Mr. Strabo and Mr. Kopinski are making believers out of their investors. For the three years ended April 17, the fund had an annualized return of 30.1 percent, compared with just 13.5 percent for its peer group of foreign stock funds, according to Morningstar Inc., the financial publisher in Chicago.
The momentum label, of course, is seldom meant as a compliment. First, critics complain that by paying scant heed to macroeconomic conditions, a momentum fund cannot pick a turnaround situation in the offing. But Mr. Kopinski says he believes that the fund does just that by looking at what he calls "micro-industry" statistics like department store sales and machinery orders.
Then there is the issue of wild volatility, which critics say is characteristic of the momentum style of investing. But Mr. Kopinski denies that his fund is more risky than rival offerings. According to Morningstar, the fund's three-year standard deviation, a common measure of volatility, is 14.5, just slightly greater than that of its peers.
By its nature, Discovery's momentum-based, bottoms-up approach means investing in businesses that have a strong record of earnings growth. If they were picking United States stocks, that would usually mean relying on huge amounts of computer-generated information -- sales, inventory and other data -- to help find companies with accelerating profits.
But finding such stocks abroad, where company numbers can be scarce and unreliable, is labor intensive. "We don't spend a lot of time building massive spreadsheets and all that," Mr. Strabo said. "What we're more concerned about is understanding the business."
The two managers also demand proof that companies have something special that guarantees continued profit momentum -- a dominant market share, perhaps, or a unique niche. To that end, Mr. Strabo, Mr. Kopinski and their team of six analysts each spend several weeks a year visiting foreign companies. In addition, executives from a company a day, on average, drop by the fund's headquarters in Greenwich, Conn. or meet with executives in New York.
"When we sit down with management we like to find out what really excites them about the business, what gets them up in the morning, and where the earnings growth is coming from," Mr. Strabo said.
In the fund's tiny, nondescript office, 13 languages are spoken, and the managers encourage their six analysts to take company-paid language courses in their spare time. "You don't need the language to pick stocks," Mr. Strabo said. "But when you learn a language, you get a little bit of understanding of how the person sitting on the other side of the table thinks."
Each day, the staff pours over dozens of foreign publications, from Nihon Keizai Shimbun of Tokyo to Le Monde of Paris to Dagens Industri of Denmark, searching for news that may not turn up elsewhere.
While other international funds often balance their portfolios based on which countries are strongest economically, Discovery's managers would rather spend their time sifting through earnings reports.
This intense focus on individual companies, they say, lets them spot trouble before many top-down strategists do. A recent example was the Asian market plunge last year.
"I think a lot of people were positive about Asia because they fell into what I call the G.D.P.-growth trap," Mr. Strabo said. "They were saying, 'these economies are growing 6 percent a year or more so it has to be a great place to invest,' which is simply not true. What we saw in Asia some time ago was margins coming under pressure and a very consistent deceleration in earnings."
The fund had 18.5 percent of its assets in Asia at the beginning of 1997. By September, as the Asian economies started their meltdown, Discovery had whittled that down to just 6.1 percent, having shifted much of its money to Europe, where it now invests 80 percent of assets.
Roughly 13 percent of the fund's holdings are in the Netherlands, 12 percent in Britain, 7 percent in Switzerland, 6 percent each in Germany and Sweden, and 5 percent each in France and Finland. Nine percent of the assets are in Canada.
PRIVATIZATION and the pending introduction of a common currency in Europe have bolstered growth in several industries, notably information technology.
"We're seeing the telcos, utilities, airports and so forth being privatized, and as that process goes through, those companies will need to become more efficient, which means they'll be using more technology," Mr. Strabo said. "Also the common currency requires a lot of preparation. That creates huge opportunities for technology companies."
One company that has benefited from the technology boom is Tieto of Finland, which builds and installs computer networks. "They have a dominant market position in Finland and the underlying market is growing rapidly, so they're basically in a sweet spot," Mr. Strabo said. Last year, earnings grew 55 percent, and consensus estimates predict further profit growth of 24 percent this year. The fund began building its position in 1996 at an average price of 269.67 Finnish markkaa; the stock now trades at 1,050 markkaa.
The only major factor limiting Tieto's growth prospects, Mr. Strabo says, is a challenge facing all information technology companies: finding enough qualified personnel.
Another Discovery holding, Parity P.L.C. of Britain, has stepped in to fill that demand. The company provides permanent and temporary technology professionals to businesses across Europe. In 1997, earnings jumped 32 percent, and analysts expect 30 percent profit growth this year. The fund acquired its shares at an average cost of 3.51 starting in mid-1996; they now trade at 7.79.
Parity is benefiting not only from the high demand for technology workers but also from an increasing acceptance of flexible labor throughout Europe. "In some countries until very recently, believe it or not, using a temporary work force was not allowed," Mr. Strabo said. "As places like Germany introduce flexible labor, we see tremendous growth opportunities for Parity."
Labor-related changes in Europe have also fueled earnings growth in the financial services sector. Governments have begun privatizing pension systems, which has increased demand for retirement plans based on mutual funds and sold by companies like Marschollek, Lautenschlaeger und Partner A.G. of Germany, known as M.L.P.
The company, Discovery's largest holding at 3.3 percent of the portfolio as of February, recently added funds to its menu of products. Selling them, Mr. Strabo predicted, should not be difficult. M.L.P., which started as an insurance company, has a highly effective sales technique: recruiting doctors, lawyers and other professionals out of graduate schools and then training them to sell financial products to their former classmates.
The company's profits are predicted to jump 30 percent this year. "M.L.P. will continue to expand into profitable products, and they'll be able to sell these products because they already have a very high-quality, low-risk, wealthy client base," Mr. Strabo said.
Mr. Strabo started acquiring M.L.P. shares shortly after the fund's inception in April 1994. The stock has risen fourfold over the fund's average purchase price, to 683 German marks.
Mr. Strabo and Mr. Kopinski have also met with momentum-driven success with another offering; they are co-managers of a large-cap fund, American Century-Twentieth Century International Growth. It returned 23.4 percent, annualized, for the three years ended April 17, compared with 13.5 percent for its peers, according to Morningstar.
International Discovery's neat sidestepping of the Asian crisis did not help Mr. Kopinski in his latest fund project, however. Last September, American Century started the American Century-Twentieth Century Emerging Markets fund, of which Mr. Kopinski and Michael Donnelly are co-managers. The new fund was hit hard -- losing 17 percent in its first two months.
"We had a lot invested in Hong Kong and Singapore, which we thought would be relatively safe havens, but they didn't escape the carnage," he said.
As for Discovery, Mr. Kopinski thinks the potential remains strong. "Look at how the depth of the U.S. market has changed over the last 15 years," he said. "Europe is in a similar growth stage now. The opportunities are just immense."

HEADLINE: SPENDING IT: FOCUS ON BANKING;
That Layered Look In Cash-Advance Fees

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
WITH credit-card competition so fierce -- when was the last week you weren't solicited? -- you might assume that it wouldn't much matter which card you pull from your wallet for a cash advance.
But down this path may lie a hard and costly lesson. An inattentive borrower on a business trip, for example, might wind up paying an effective interest rate of 40 percent or more when fees for processing and automatic teller machines are piled on top of interest charges. 
 "The cash-advance business is a tremendous service" to consumers, said Spencer Nilson, who publishes The Nilson Report, an credit-card industry newsletter in Oxnard, Calif. But, advising close scrutiny, he warned, "they can charge you anything they want."
The feature clearly fills a need for many consumers. According to the American Bankers Association, card holders who draw cash advances from accounts at the largest issuers average $287 for each use on standard cards and $520 on gold cards. But charges vary sharply. A Federal Reserve compilation of credit-card terms, filed by banks on a voluntary basis, points up some of the extremes.
Star Bank in Cincinnati, for example, charges a minimum of $20 for cash advances, which are often repaid in days or weeks, while the Metropolitan Savings Bank in Mayfield Heights, Ohio, has neither a percentage nor dollar-minimum fee on its Mastercard; it makes its money solely from the 13.9 percent interest it charges on cash advances.
Other special terms abound, such as at Dial Bank in South Dakota, where Visa fees vary according to the state in which the transaction occurs.
"Pricing does tend to vary a great deal," said Robert Stock, senior vice president for credit products at Visa U.S.A.. "Individual banks are entirely on their own."
Not surprisingly, banks with higher transaction fees tend to offer lower rates. But Wells Fargo charges an annual interest rate of 20.05 percent -- in addition to a cash-advance transaction fee that is 4 percent of the amount borrowed.
"If you look at 10 different cards, you'd probably see 10 different configurations of how they handle cash advances in terms of the transaction, fee, how the interest is accrued and what that interest rate actually is," said R. Douglas Rozman, a spokesman for Mastercard.
Smart use of cash advances involves several factors beyond tracking the varying interest rates. It's important to determine, for example, just how a bank allocates repayments on accounts in which purchases and cash advances are intermingled.
INTEREST rates are often higher for advances than for purchases, although the rates are identical at some banks. Still, interest on advances is almost always levied for each day of borrowing, with no grace period; thus, if you are not fully repaying the amount on your monthly statement, it matters how your partial payment is credited when your statement includes both advances and purchases.
Citibank assigns partial payments equally to advances and purchases. Household International sets them first against a card holder's lowest-rate obligations; AT&T Universal applies them to finance charges and phone calls first; Chase Manhattan allocates payments at its "discretion." The lesson is not to mix advances and purchases on a card that treats them differently.
One especially expensive type of advance can be for "quasi-cash," which includes money orders, travelers checks, lottery tickets, foreign currency, race-track tickets and casino chips. Bank of America, for example, charges a 4 percent transaction fee for quasi-cash, compared with 2.5 percent for an ordinary advance.
Cash-advance users can often do better at small and medium-sized institutions. There, the American Bankers Association says, the transaction fees average 2 percent, versus 2.5 percent for the giants.

HEADLINE: EARNING IT;
For Many Blue-Collar Fathers, Child Care Is Shift Work, Too

BYLINE: By JULIA LAWLOR 

 BODY:
CHRISTOPHER HEIB rises before dawn to get to his day job as a power line worker for the Los Angeles Department of Water and Power. But just as important to him is his second shift -- taking care of his sons Rudy, 6, and Thomas, a newborn.
Like many other men his age, Mr. Heib, 33, of Long Beach, Calif., regrets having spent so little time with his father growing up. But unlike fathers who hold professional or managerial jobs that occupy them 50 or more hours a week, Mr. Heib's job allows him the flexibility to be the father he wishes he'd had. 
 "I like coming home to take care of the kids," said Mr. Heib, who takes over at 4:30 P.M. when his wife, Sandra, 31, leaves for her job as a 911 dispatcher for the Los Angeles Police Department. Her shift runs from 6 P.M. to 2:30 A.M. "I feel I can talk to my son. He's closer to me than I was to my parents. I can come home every single night and be with him."
The number of children being cared for by their fathers is "the best-kept secret in American child care," said James Levine, author of "Working Fathers" (Addison-Wesley, 1997) and director of the Fatherhood Project at the Families and Work Institute in New York.
Moreover, it is not upper-middle-class professionals or corporate managers who are leading the trend toward more-involved fatherhood; it is lower-paid, blue-collar men. "Most people think of the stereotype of Mr. Mom, the guy who quits his job and stays home," said Mr. Levine, "when in fact most guys who are primary care givers are in families with two working parents on split shifts."
Fathers in municipal and service jobs -- firefighters, police officers and maintenance workers, for example, -- are twice as likely as those in professional, managerial or technical jobs to care for their children while their wives are working, according to Census Bureau data.
In 1993, among all married fathers of children younger than age 5, some 1.6 million -- about 25 percent -- cared for their children while the mothers worked. In service occupations, the numbers were far higher: 42 percent of fathers cared for preschoolers, the Census Bureau found, versus 20 percent of fathers with professional or managerial jobs.
Earlier this month, the Families and Work Institute released a study that said even working men who are not the primary providers of care for their children were spending significantly more time with their children than they did 20 years ago.
The National Study of the Changing Work Force, a survey of more than 3,500 working men and women in 1997, found that fathers spent an average of 2.3 hours each workday with their children, a half-hour more than the average reported by a Department of Labor survey in 1977.
Not surprisingly, economic factors are a primary reason that men are spending more time caring for their young children. Most families now need two incomes to pay the bills -- and child care is increasingly expensive.
According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, the largest projected job growth through 2006 will be in 10 occupations including cashiers, sales clerks, truck drivers and teacher's aides. Many of these jobs have relatively low wages and require night and weekend shifts.
That can mean a double whammy: younger workers with less seniority are more likely to have these shifts, and these same workers are also more likely than older colleagues to be raising young children.
"We think of dual-earner couples both going away in the morning, coming home in the evening and leaving the kids in day care," said Harriet Presser, a professor of sociology at the University of Maryland who studies the work schedules of American families. "But in a big proportion of these couples, especially those with young children, you get this split-shift arrangement. One works days; one works evenings. That's characteristic of one-fourth of all two-earner couples in the U.S., and one-third of all two-earner couples with children under 5."
Not all the forces driving the "daddy shift" are economic. Some two-income families do not believe in outside child care, and some men simply see their work at home as part of being a father.
"The expectation of young first-time marrying couples now is that fathers and mothers will co-parent," said Kyle Pruett, a professor of psychiatry at Yale University's Child Study Center who has studied the stay-at-home father's role in child development. "That was not the assumption their mothers and fathers made."
BEYOND savings on child care, such arrangements offer intangible benefits. There is ample research to indicate that having a father around to make dinner, play in the park and read stories is a plus for children.
But for couples, the arrangements can mean additional strains.
Alan Bamdas, 32, of West Orange, N.J., works a schedule of 24 hours on, 72 hours off, as a firefighter in Maplewood, N.J. His wife, Kimberley, 31, a police dispatcher for Maplewood, works a 7 A.M. to 3 P.M. shift. The two have complex arrangements for their 3-year-old son, Harrison, who attends preschool three days a week and sometimes goes to his grandparents when both parents are at work.
Scheduling, Mrs. Bamdas said, is a horror. "We can't do anything, including going to the movies, without opening our date books," she said. "We don't have good quality time together as husband and wife."
While they both accept this arrangement now, the difficulties have made them put off thoughts of having a second child. Switching to part-time work would not provide enough income, Mrs. Bamdas said.
Jonathan Hunter, 35, of Aliso Viejo, Calif., knows the problem well. He works as a bell captain for the Ritz-Carlton Laguna Niguel in Orange County, Calif., having quit a management job at another hotel company about a year ago after he realized that he could not tolerate spending 60 to 70 hours a week away from his wife, Racheal, and their two daughters, Chelsey, now 5, and Nicole, 2.
"Things were going by way too fast," said Mr. Hunter, who took a pay cut at his new job and now works from 3 to 11 P.M. so he can care for his daughters during the day. "I never saw them at all. It broke my heart, actually. The little one didn't seem to know who I was."
Mrs. Hunter also works at the Ritz-Carlton, as a market research analyst. Her shift runs from 7:30 A.M. to 4 P.M., and the couple use baby sitters to cover mid-afternoon hours.
The move has meant trade-offs, of course, and Mr. Hunter acknowledges some regrets. "It bothers me," he said. "People around me are constantly interviewing for other jobs, telling me about opportunities that come up. But when I think about my future, I look down and my future is running right around my feet."
And the demands of work and home take a toll, too. Lonnie Morgan, 31, a corrections officer in Madison, Wis., notes a lack of time for himself. He works a 3-to-11 P.M. shift and cares for his son Joshua, 4, and daughter, Moriah, 3, while his wife, Debora, 29, works as an office manager from 6:30 A.M. to 1:30 P.M.
"All I do is watch the kids and work," Mr. Morgan said. "There is no time to go out and play tennis or see friends." He has a new appreciation for all that child-rearing entails: "I understand how frustrating it can be. You're not just sitting around watching soap operas."
While child-care experts say more interaction with a father helps a young child, they caution against excluding other child care options.
"It's good for dads to get involved," said Stephanie Coontz, author of "The Way We Really Are: Coming to Terms with America's Changing Families" (Basic Books, 1997). "But to the extent a couple uses that as a substitute instead of a supplement to good child care, they may be putting a terrible strain on the marriage."
Studies have shown, Ms. Coontz said, that with "sensitive parents and adequate child care, there is no ill effect on the child."
"If you have good parenting and good child care, you have an extra advantage," she said. "Kids tend to have better social, emotional and cognitive skills.
"My advice to dads who want to do tag-team parenting is this: Stay involved, but don't kill yourself doing it."

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
An Iron Merchant Presses Fast-Forward

BYLINE: By RICHARD KORMAN 

 BODY:
ELIZABETH CHASE looked out over the excavation site. Tyrannosaurus-sized shovels bit into fields of blasted stone dotted with giant-tired dump trucks. To an iron-mining novice like Ms. Chase, who was visiting the Upper Peninsula of Michigan in late February to research a 151-year-old company called Cleveland-Cliffs, the scene seemed to be moving in slow motion.
"Can't they speed up?" Ms. Chase, a research analyst for Schafer Capital Management, recalled thinking. 
 Iron mining is not the kind of business that brings Wall Street analysts to their feet. It is part of a mature industry -- steelmaking -- that has seen its share of pain. Unlike gold or even copper, iron is plentiful and the deposits are well known. The stocks of integrated steel mills, the major buyers of the metal, are often out of favor, and so are iron merchants like Cleveland-Cliffs.
Indeed, the company's stock trades at a stingy 11.65 times 1997 earnings per share -- about half as much as the average for the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index.
But the company, which is based in Cleveland and had operating revenue of $439 million last year, says Wall Street has it all wrong. The company is "interested in new things, building where it can and expanding," said John S. Brinzo, the chief executive. In fact, a new plant is on the way and some major shareholders are convinced that earnings will rise sharply as a result. For several reasons, Cleveland-Cliffs may be shielded from the variations of price and demand that dog the steel industry. And, as its price-to-earnings ratio suggests, its stock has an advantage common to many that bore Wall Street: an attractive price.
As for the growth plans, Mr. Brinzo and his colleagues say they will use the strong balance sheet of Cleveland-Cliffs to finance growth. The company is moving to bolster overseas sales and is evaluating plans to build a plant to make pig iron, a high-grade metal. But as the centerpiece of its renewal program, the company is spending $74 million for its share of a technologically advanced processing plant in Trinidad and Tobago that will make bricks with a high iron content. The new plant could add as much as $1 a share to earnings in 1999.
High-iron products feed the appetite of steel mini-mills for competitively priced, high-quality feedstock. Currently, these mills make lower grades of steel, like structural steel for buildings; to break into higher-grade markets, like that for sheet steel used in large appliances, the mills need the kind of bricks that Cleveland-Cliffs will soon produce.
Many analysts and investors seem to like the company's plan. The stock, after bouncing around the high $30's and low $40's for three years, has risen from $42 in December to $53.6875 at Friday's close. "It's been a long time since Cliffs' stock made a move like that," said David MacGregor, senior analyst with Midwest Research in Cleveland.
Ms. Chase's employer, Schafer Capital Management, is a recent buyer. The firm, based in New York, began accumulating the stock in July and is now Cleveland-Cliffs' largest shareholder, with a 5.8 percent stake. "They definitely fit the profile" of stocks sought by Schafer, a value investor, Ms. Chase said.
Moreover, Cleveland-Cliffs seems somewhat insulated from the price fluctuations for iron pellets, which it produces from six mines of which it is the full or partial owner. And most of its pellets are sold on multiyear contracts with longtime customers; these pacts will be renegotiated next year and Cleveland-Cliffs should be able to win small price increases, according to analysts.
That setup should keep prices stable for a few years, say the analysts, who also note that Cleveland-Cliffs enjoys large reserves in its mines. And though demand for steel may fall slightly, it should be fairly steady for the next five years, according to the Commerce Department.
Another attraction is the royalties that Cleveland-Cliffs receives from its mineral rights in mines that it owns with others, usually steel companies. These royalties contributed $36 million, or 50 percent, of Cleveland-Cliff's pretax profits in 1997. And because the royalties are paid by co-owners who use the iron in their own manufacturing, the income is less vulnerable to the vagaries of demand than other sources of sales.
DESPITE the recent spurt in the stock, fans say it is still invitingly priced. One reason is that 1997 was an off year for the company; a mine closing, production delays and increased capital spending drove down earnings per share to $4.03, from $5.12 in 1996. And sales of inventory from the closed mine masked the usual seasonal lull in the first quarter of 1997, making the first quarter of 1998 look weak by comparison: The company reported earnings of 4 cents a share last week, down from 26 cents. But those problems are past, analysts say.
Obscurity also helps keeps the price low. "We are not well known and try as we might we are still fairly small and tend to get buried," Mr. Brinzo said.
Indeed, the royalties alone could justify a market capitalization of $500 million, said Michael Beall, an analyst with Davenport & Company, an investment firm with a 2.3 percent stake in Cleveland-Cliffs. On Friday, the company's market capitalization was just $610 million.
But the stock seems especially cheap to investors who see a sharp rise in earnings from the new plant and other initiatives. Assuming that Cleveland-Cliffs stock will eventually sell at about 13 times earnings to account for the company's future growth, a target price of more than $65 by next January is reasonable, Mr. Beal said. Others set their sights higher: Mr. MacGregor's company has a target of $75 a share by next March.
Of course, Cleveland-Cliffs faces plenty of risks. It still relies on the integrated steel mills for most of its sales; over many years, these mills are expected to die out. If the economy slows, so will demand for steel; a worsening of Asia's problems could lead to cheaper imported steel products, putting further downward pressure on iron prices.
Competition is also a worry. Other companies, like Nucor, have built or are building plants to make high-iron products. Weighing the competition and the demand for the bricks, Walter Carter, principal and steel analyst for Standard & Poor's/DRI, said the timing of the new plant was "not optimal, but not disastrous."
But even if the company looks dull, its immediate outlook is very strong.
"It's not the sexiest thing around," Mr. Beal said, "but it's a solid piece of equipment."
